Authors: T.M.T., Huynh, Thi Mien Trung; K., Tahara, Kazukuni; S., De-Feyter, Steven; T.H., Phan, Thanh Hai
Author full names: Huynh, Thi Mien Trung (49561334900); Tahara, Kazukuni (12797762600); De-Feyter, Steven (7004199804); Phan, Thanh Hai (57215052405)
Title: On the role of functional groups in the formation of diazonium based covalent attachments: dendritic vs. layer-by-layer growth
Affiliations: Quy Nhon University, Quy Nhon, Viet Nam; Meiji University, Tokyo, Japan; KU Leuven, Leuven, Belgium; Quy Nhon University, Quy Nhon, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Huynh, Thi Mien Trung, Department of Chemistry, Quy Nhon University, Quy Nhon, Viet Nam; Tahara, Kazukuni, Department of Applied Chemistry, Meiji University, Tokyo, Japan; De-Feyter, Steven, Department of Chemistry, KU Leuven, Leuven, Belgium; Phan, Thanh Hai, Department of Physics and Materials Science, Quy Nhon University, Quy Nhon, Viet Nam
Abstract: Multilayered growth is often observed upon electrografting aryl diazonium derivatives on graphitic substrates due to the reactive nature of aryl radicals. The mechanism of the multilayer formation has been investigated either by measuring the thickness of the grafted layer, the charge transfer, or via simulations. Spectroscopy and in particular microscopy approaches are underrepresented. Herein, we demonstrate a comparative characterization of the multilayer growth of two diazonium derivatives on highly oriented pyrolytic graphite using a combination of cyclic voltammetry, atomic force microscopy, and scanning tunneling microscopy. While dendritic growth is observed for 4-nitro phenyl diazonium (4-NBD), 4-carboxy phenyl diazonium (4-CBD) shows layer-by-layer growth upon increasing the molecular concentration, revealing the impact of the functional groups on the growth mechanism. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Abstract: The next years will see the completion of the radioactive ion beam facility SPES (Selective Production of Exotic Species) and the upgrade of the accelerators complex at Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare – Legnaro National Laboratories (LNL) opening up new possibilities in the fields of nuclear structure, nuclear dynamics, nuclear astrophysics, and applications. The nuclear physics community has organised a workshop to discuss the new physics opportunities that will be possible in the near future by employing state-of-the-art detection systems. A detailed discussion of the outcome from the workshop is presented in this report. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Funding Texts: Funding text 1: The NEPIR-0 is almost completely funded by the Italian Ministry for University Research (MUR), within the Italian SPARE (Space Radiation Shielding) project that deals with health risks due to cosmic radiation. In this phase the neutron source is a relatively simple, thick, low power (100 W) beryllium target located inside the conduit between the cyclotron hall and experimental hall of the SPES building []. The 3 m thick wall of the cyclotron cave provides shielding and the conduit acts as a collimator for the neutron beam directed to the neutron\u2019s experimental area. The expected neutron beam has a continuum spectrum with a different cut-off according to different proton energies. In this phase, a low proton current will be used ( 1 A) to reduce the radiation protection problems. The phase-0 facility will be open to academic and industrial users, to test microelectronic components and devices, for neutron detector characterization, and neutron shielding materials for space missions, in partnership with ASI.; Funding text 2: Open access funding provided by Universit\u00E0 degli Studi di Padova within the CRUI-CARE Agreement.

Authors: T.H., Nguyen, Thanh Hung; H.C., Nguyen, Huu Cuong; B., Ngoc-Tam, Bui; T.H., Bui, Trung Hieu; V.B., Vu, Van Ban; H.N., Duong, Hoai Nam; H., Hoang, Honghong
Author full names: Nguyen, Thanh Hung (57198024499); Nguyen, Huu Cuong (58595349100); Ngoc-Tam, Bui (57212681073); Bui, Trung Hieu (58535645900); Vu, Van Ban (58535558600); Duong, Hoai Nam (58535910200); Hoang, Honghong (56835258900)
Title: Vision-Based System for Black Rubber Roller Surface Inspection
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Thanh Hung, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Huu Cuong, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ngoc-Tam, Bui, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Bui, Trung Hieu, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vu, Van Ban, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Duong, Hoai Nam, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hoang, Honghong, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: This paper proposes a machine vision system for the surface inspection of black rubber rollers in manufacturing processes. The system aims to enhance the surface quality of the rollers by detecting and classifying defects. A lighting system is installed to highlight surface defects. Two algorithms are proposed for defect detection: a traditional-based method and a deep learning-based method. The former is fast but limited to surface defect detection, while the latter is slower but capable of detecting and classifying defects. The accuracy of the algorithms is verified through experiments, with the traditional-based method achieving near-perfect accuracy of approximately 98% for defect detection, and the deep learning-based method achieving an accuracy of approximately 95.2% for defect detection and 96% for defect classification. The proposed machine vision system can significantly improve the surface inspection of black rubber rollers, thereby ensuring high-quality production. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Classification; Deep Learning; Machine Vision; Rubber Roller; Surface Inspection

Title: Synthesis of rod–coil conjugated diblock copolymers, poly(3-hexylthiophene)-block-poly(2-(4,6-dichlorotriazin-2-yl]oxy)ethyl methacrylate) and click chemistry
Affiliations: Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Chemistry, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kanagawa University, Yokohama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Bui, Thao Thanh, National Key Laboratory of Polymer and Composite Materials, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Tam Huu, National Key Laboratory of Polymer and Composite Materials, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Department of Material and Life Chemistry, Kanagawa University, Yokohama, Japan; Tran, Hai Le, Faculty of Materials Technology, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tran, Chau Duc, Faculty of Materials Technology, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Le, Duongthanh, National Key Laboratory of Polymer and Composite Materials, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Dao, Dai N., National Key Laboratory of Polymer and Composite Materials, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Thao Phuong Le, National Key Laboratory of Polymer and Composite Materials, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Luan Thanh, National Key Laboratory of Polymer and Composite Materials, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Le Thu Thi, Faculty of Materials Technology, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Quoc Thiet, Institute of Applied Materials Science, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: A conjugated diblock copolymer of poly(3-hexylthiophene)-block-poly(2-(4,6-dichlorotriazin-2-yl]oxy)ethyl methacrylate) (P3HT-b-PDCTMA) has been obtained via the combination of Grignard metathesis method and organo-catalyzed atom transfer radical polymerization with a polymerization conversion of 73%. The synthesized diblock copolymer P3HT-b-PDCTMA exhibited an M<inf>n</inf> of 17,500 g/mol, which is approximately close to the theoretical value, and with polydispersity index (Đ) of 1.42. The conjugated diblock copolymer P3HT-b-PDCTMA bears functional reactive triazine chloride groups that act as a platform to react with mercaptan or amine groups via efficient nucleophilic aromatic substitution reactions. The chemical structures and macromolecular characteristic properties of the “rod–coil” conjugated diblock copolymers have been characterized by FT-IR, 1H NMR spectroscopy and gel permeation chromatography. In addition, their optical properties and conformation have been investigated via UV–Vis spectroscopy. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Conjugated Diblock Polymers; Cyanuric Chloride; Poly(3-hexylthiophene); Rod–coil Polymers; Substitution Reaction

Title: Cross-linked Polyimide Nanofibrous Aerogels with Hierarchical Cellular Structure for Thermal Insulation
Affiliations: Kyoto Institute of Technology, Kyoto, Japan; International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kyoto Institute of Technology, Kyoto, Japan; Kyoto Institute of Technology, Kyoto, Japan; Graduate School of Science, Kyoto, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Thi Khuat, Khanh Van, Doctor's Program of Materials Chemistry, Kyoto Institute of Technology, Kyoto, Japan; Doan, Hoan Ngoc, School of Biomedical Engineering, International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Phong Vo, Phu, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Faculty of Chemistry, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Negoro, Masaki, Master's Program of Innovative Materials, Kyoto Institute of Technology, Kyoto, Japan; Kinashi, Kenji, Faculty of Materials Science and Engineering, Kyoto Institute of Technology, Kyoto, Japan; Kanamori, Kazuyoshi, Department of Chemistry, Graduate School of Science, Kyoto, Japan; Sakai, Wataru, Faculty of Materials Science and Engineering, Kyoto Institute of Technology, Kyoto, Japan; Tsutsumi, Naoto, Faculty of Materials Science and Engineering, Kyoto Institute of Technology, Kyoto, Japan
Abstract: Due to their low bulk density, high porosity, and functional performance, aerogels are ideal candidates for a variety of applications. However, their potential application in a variety of fields is limited by their time-consuming and costly complex fabrication process. In this study, electrospun 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane-grafted polyimide (PI@APTES) nanofibers were used to construct nanofibrous aerogels (NFAs) via freeze-drying a dispersion of cross-linked-PI short fibers and a binder (PI@APTES), resulting in improved properties and functionalities. A highly siloxane cross-linked network structure was formed by hydrolysis and condensation reactions to generate stable nanofibrous aerogels. The obtained polyimide nanofibrous aerogels (PiNFAs) had a hierarchically three-dimensional (3D) microporous structure, high porosity (over 98%), tunable densities (10.6 ± 0.7-13.6 ± 0.2 mg cm-3), solvent resistance, superhydrophobicity (water contact angle over 163°), low thermal conductivity (as low as 33.2 mW m-1 K-1), and mechanical stability. These PiNFAs are promising candidates for potential applications in thermal insulation, lightweight construction, filtration, and sensors. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Assessment of Allelopathic Activity of Arachis pintoi Krapov. & W.C. Greg as a Potential Source of Natural Herbicide for Paddy Rice
Affiliations: Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Hung Vuong University, Viet Tri City, Viet Nam; Agricultural Genetics Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Gyeongsang National University, Jinju, South Korea; Tien Giang University, My Tho City, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Thai Nguyen University of Agriculture and Forestry, Thai Nguyen City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Thang, Phan Trung, Faculty of Agronomy, Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vien, Nguyen Van, Faculty of Agronomy, Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Anh, La Hoang, Department of Development Technology, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Xuan, T. D., Department of Development Technology, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Duong, Vu Xuan, Institute of Applied Research and Development, Hung Vuong University, Viet Tri City, Viet Nam; Nhung, Nguyen Thanh, Department of Genetic Engineering, Agricultural Genetics Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Trung, Khuat Huu, Department of Genetic Engineering, Agricultural Genetics Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Quan, Nguyenthanh, Department of Genetic Engineering, Agricultural Genetics Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Cam Chau, Research Institute of Life Science, Gyeongsang National University, Jinju, South Korea; Loan, Le Thi Kim, Department of Agriculture and Food Technology, Tien Giang University, My Tho City, Viet Nam
Abstract: Pinto peanut (Arachis pintoi Krapov. & W.C. Greg.) is an herbaceous perennial plant which belongs to the Leguminosae family. This plant is well known for its use as a cover crop, but little information is available on the allelopathic potential of this legume. Therefore, this study aimed to explore the allelopathic effects of A. pintoi under various screening conditions and to analyze its potential allelochemicals using gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (GC-MS). In laboratory bioassays, aqueous extracts of A. pintoi powder exerted the average inhibition of the growth of Echinochloa crus-galli (55.1%), Oryza sativa (77.1%), and Vigna radiata (60.1%), respectively, of which the root lengths of the tested plants were the most suppressed. In greenhouse experiments, E. crus-galli was inhibited by 63.4% at 200 g/m2 of A. pintoi dried powder application. In field trials, A. pintoi also significantly reduced the growth of E. crus-galli and natural weeds. By incorporating a dose of 200 g/m2, the average inhibition of E. crus-galli was 43.9%, the dry weight of natural paddy weeds was 43.1%, and rice yield was simultaneously increased by 35%. The growth inhibitions of weeds and tested plants were proportional to the doses of A. pintoi applied and varied with the tested plant species. Among three different solvent extracts (methanol, hexane, and ethyl acetate), the hexane extract exerted the highest suppression against the growth of E. crus-galli and L. sativa by IC<inf>50</inf> against root and shoot growth = 4.08 and 8.4 mg/mL and 1.7 and 1.54 mg/mL, respectively, followed by ethyl acetate extract, while the least effective was methanol extract. From those extracts, a total of 35 substances were detected by GC-MS analyses, including 14 newly identified constituents, such as phenolic acids, stearic acid, palmitic acid, fatty acids, pyranones, and benzofurans, which may be responsible for the herbicidal effects of A. pintoi. This study suggests that A. pintoi may be used as a source of bioherbicide to minimize the dependency on harmful synthetic herbicides and enhance rice yield. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.A., Bui, Tuan Anh; B., Ngoc-Tam, Bui
Author full names: Bui, Tuan Anh (45960912000); Ngoc-Tam, Bui (57212681073)
Title: Investigating the Impact of Fly-Ash Additive on Viscosity Reduction at Different Temperatures: A Comparative Analysis
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Bui, Tuan Anh, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ngoc-Tam, Bui, Innovative Global Program, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The viscosity of lubricating oils is influenced by fly-ash additives and temperature, as they play a crucial role in regulating the viscosity of oils. Fly-ash additives are added to lubricating oils to improve oxidation resistance and prevent deposit formation, which may reduce viscosity loss at high temperatures. This study aimed to investigate the impact of fly-ash additives and temperature on the viscosity of oils B, C, and A. The experimental methodology involved comparing the viscosity of these oils with and without the addition of a 0.5% fly-ash additive. Viscosity measurements were taken at different temperatures. The results showed significant changes in viscosity after incorporating the fly-ash additive. At 25 °C, oils B, C, and A exhibited viscosity increases of 6.2%, 8.1%, and 13.8%, respectively, compared to the samples without the additive. Similarly, at 75 °C, the viscosity increments were 10.2%, 11.5%, and 22.8% for oils B, C, and A, respectively. At 85 °C, the corresponding increments were 11.1%, 16.6%, and 32.8%. These findings highlight the effectiveness of fly-ash additives in reducing the impact of temperature on oil viscosity, with oil A demonstrating the highest efficacy. By adjusting the viscosity of the oil at different temperatures, the fly-ash additives contribute to maintaining stable lubricating performance. Understanding the influence of fly-ash additives and temperature on oil viscosity is crucial for optimizing the performance of lubricants across various temperature conditions. Additionally, this knowledge assists in selecting the appropriate additive ratios for specific applications, thereby ensuring optimal lubricant performance. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Fly-ash Additive; Shear Stress; Temperature; Viscosity

Authors: X., Fan, Xuezhou; H.A., Moria, Hazim Abdulaziz; S.A., Reda, Shaker A.; F., Aldawi, Fayez; N.L., Truong, Nguyen Le; S., Wu, Shuwen
Author full names: Fan, Xuezhou (58286189700); Moria, Hazim Abdulaziz (36617578600); Reda, Shaker A. (57644300900); Aldawi, Fayez (49060952100); Truong, Nguyen Le (36912044400); Wu, Shuwen (58286727000)
Title: Geothermal assisted Rankine cycle for performance enhancement of a biomass-driven power plant; Thermoeconomic and environmental impact assessment
Affiliations: Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou, China; Yanbu Industrial College, Yanbu, Saudi Arabia; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; The University of Kitakyushu, Kitakyushu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Fan, Xuezhou, School of Ecology and Environment, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou, China; Moria, Hazim Abdulaziz, Department of Mechanical Engineering Technology, Yanbu Industrial College, Yanbu, Saudi Arabia; Reda, Shaker A., Department of Mechanical Engineering Technology, Yanbu Industrial College, Yanbu, Saudi Arabia; Aldawi, Fayez, Department of Mechanical Engineering Technology, Yanbu Industrial College, Yanbu, Saudi Arabia; Truong, Nguyen Le, Institute of Engineering, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Wu, Shuwen, The University of Kitakyushu, Kitakyushu, Japan
Abstract: In view of the environmental concerns of increasing fossil fuel consumption, the renewable energy sources are promising alternatives, among which the biomass and geothermal energies are the two most common and mature ones. In the present research, a novel Electricity Generation System (EGS) driven by hybrid biomass fuel and geothermal source is developed and its performance is compared with Typical EGS (TEGS) driven by only the biomass fuel. The TEGS consists of a gas turbine cycle and a steam Rankine cycle equipped with an open-feed water heater (OFWH). In the proposed Hybrid Electricity Generation System (HEGS), the geothermal energy is deployed to heat the feedwater before entering the OFWH, as a result the bottoming Rankine cycle yields more electricity. However, a comprehensive investigation from technical and economic standpoints is required to compare its performance with the relevant TEGS. Therefore, through the application of thermodynamic, thermoeconomic, and environmental methodologies, the considered EGSs performance are modeled and comprehensively analyzed. Based on the modeling results, the maximum exergetic efficiency for the TEGS and HEGS is achieved, respectively as 40.8% and 43.05% under the gas turbine inlet temperature of 1550 K. Final optimal operating conditions are determined through a multi-criteria optimization respect to exergetic efficiency and cost criteria. Under these working conditions, the LCOE and exergetic efficiency for the TEGS are calculated to be respectively as 71.22 $/MWh and 43.22%. At this point, net electricity, total exergy destruction rate, and CO<inf>2</inf> emission rate are estimated to be as 7750 kW, 9446 kW, and 0.7401 kg/kWh, respectively. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Surface flow and aerodynamic drag of Ahmed body with deflectors
Affiliations: Le Quy Don Technical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Mazda Motor Corporation, Fuchu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hung Tran, The, Faculty of Aerospace Engineering, Le Quy Don Technical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Interdisciplinary Graduate School of Engineering Sciences, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Hijikuro, Masato, Interdisciplinary Graduate School of Engineering Sciences, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Anyoji, Masayuki, Interdisciplinary Graduate School of Engineering Sciences, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Uchida, Takanori, Interdisciplinary Graduate School of Engineering Sciences, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Nakashima, Takuji, Graduate School of Advanced Science and Engineering, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Shimizu, Keigo, Technical Research Center, Mazda Motor Corporation, Fuchu, Japan
Abstract: This study investigated the surface flow and the aerodynamic characteristics of a 7/10 scale Ahmed model equipped with deflectors at several angles. The experiments were conducted at Reynolds number of 2.45 × 105 based on the model height. A global luminescent oil film skin-friction measurement technique was applied for the flow fields on the slant and base surfaces. The aerodynamic forces of the model were measured to understand the effect of the deflection angle on the aerodynamic characteristics. The pressure was measured and pressure drags acting on the slant and base surfaces were also calculated. The results showed that the drag and lift of the model suddenly dropped at the deflection angle above −5°. The pressure distribution on the slant and base surfaces became flat with a maximum drag reduction of 8% for the model with a deflection angle of 0°. The skin-friction measurement indicated that the drag reduction was connected to the breakdown of the separation bubble and longitudinal vortices on the slant. At the fully separated flow state, the skin-friction results illustrated two small vortices and a counter-clockwise vortex on the slant. Additionally, the wake vortices shifted from horizontal to vertical structures. The relation among the flow fields on the slant surface, flow on the symmetric plan, pressure distribution, and drag was illustrated for the model with different deflection angles. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.H., Nguyen, Tan Hung; A.H., Limongan, Andrian H.; M.H., Huu Nguyen, May Huu; C., Hwang, Chaolung; T.P., Huynh, Trong Phuoc
Author full names: Nguyen, Tan Hung (57204362603); Limongan, Andrian H. (56811730700); Huu Nguyen, May Huu (57205271857); Hwang, Chaolung (8204295900); Huynh, Trong Phuoc (56688180600)
Title: Densified mixture design algorithm: A novel mix design concept and its application for green concretes incorporating industrial by-products
Affiliations: Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan; Đại học Công nghệ Giao thông vận tải, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan; Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Tan Hung, Department of Civil Engineering, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Limongan, Andrian H., Department of Civil and Construction Engineering, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan; Huu Nguyen, May Huu, Faculty of Civil Engineering, Đại học Công nghệ Giao thông vận tải, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Civil and Environmental Engineering Program, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Hwang, Chaolung, Taiwan Building Technology Center, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan; Huynh, Trong Phuoc, Department of Civil Engineering, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam
Abstract: Despite the fact that densified mixture design algorithm (DMDA) has been identified as a promising tool for green concrete mix design, its use in real practice has still been minimal worldwide. Due to the lack of precise information on DMDA computation in earlier studies, this work proposes DMDA including fly ash and ground granulated blast-furnace slag as a viable way to improve the long-term performance of green concrete. To encourage the use of DMDA, this study offers a detailed description of the DMDA mix design, as well as a step-by-step standard operating procedure and an empirical example of the computation. Assessments of the long-term performance of green mixtures (self-consolidating concrete and high-performance concrete) and ordinary Portland cement concrete (designed using the conventional method of American Concrete Institute, ACI) were made. Performances of the ACI (O6000 mixture) and DMDA concretes (S6000 and H6000 mixtures) were then compared in terms of compressive strength, elastic modulus, shrinkage, and creep strain. As a result, all of the concrete samples attained the target strength of above 41 MPa (6000 psi) after only 28 days. Moreover, compressive strength, elastic modulus, shrinkage, and creep strain increased significantly in all of the concretes over curing time. Importantly, the experimental results confirmed that both types of DMDA concrete exhibited higher compressive strength and better long-term performance than the ACI concrete under elastic modulus, creep, and shrinkage aspects. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Numerical study of electrohydrodynamic atomization considering liquid wetting and corona discharge effects
Affiliations: Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Griffith University, Brisbane, Australia; Explosion Research Institute Inc., Tokyo, Japan; University of Southern Queensland, Toowoomba, Australia; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Mai, Luan Ngoc, Department of Aerospace Engineering, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Vu, Trung Hieu, School of Engineering and Built Environment, Griffith University, Brisbane, Australia; Dinh, Thienxuan, Division of Research and Development, Explosion Research Institute Inc., Tokyo, Japan; Vu, Hoai Duc, School of Engineering and Built Environment, Griffith University, Brisbane, Australia; Tran, Canh Dung, School of Mechanical and Electrical Engineering, University of Southern Queensland, Toowoomba, Australia; Dau, Van Thanh, School of Engineering and Built Environment, Griffith University, Brisbane, Australia; Ngo, Hieu Khanh, Department of Aerospace Engineering, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: In this paper, the behavior of the cone-jet mode of fluid by electrohydrodynamic atomization (electrospray) is numerically simulated and investigated with the effect of liquid wetting and corona discharge effects. The simulation was performed with contact angle condition to fit the Taylor cone shape by experiments. Experimental data are provided to verify and validate the numerical method, followed by additional analyses on the effects of electrical conductivity, surface tension, flow rate, and fluid viscosity on the electrospray characteristics, including spray current and jet diameter. Numerical results by simulations are in reasonable agreement with experiments and consistent with the literature. Analyses on different contact angles suggest potentially major impacts of this factor on the cone-jet mode in high voltage and low flow rate circumstances. Furthermore, the influence of corona discharge on electrospray is also investigated by both electrospray-corona simulation and experiment using a high-speed camera, yielding a significant improvement in the numerical prediction for Taylor cone formation. Numerical results indicate that liquid wetting on capillary nozzles would be a vital factor for the Taylor cone formation in numerical electrospray-corona discharge studies. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Dynamic of microbial community in simultaneous nitrification and denitrification process: A review
Affiliations: Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, Japan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Dại học Nguyen Tat Thanh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ho Chi Minh City University of Industry and Trade, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Chung Yuan Christian University, Taoyuan, Taiwan; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam

Abstract: The simultaneous nitrification and denitrification (SND) process requires little to no external carbon or oxygen sources; thus, it is a revolutionary approach for treating municipal wastewater because of both economic and environmental benefits. This review provided an overview of the microbial communities, techniques to detect them in nitrogen removal systems, and SND mechanisms related to functional microorganisms and enzymes in flocs as well as biofilms. A thorough discussion of the dynamics of microbial communities under important conditions such as dissolved oxygen and C/N ratio was provided. The environmental effects in terms of greenhouse gas emission and energy consumption, as well as the difficulties and potential future applications of adopting SND in municipal wastewater treatment for environmental sustainability, were also covered. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N.I., Sulaiman, Nur I.; M.A., Abu Bakar, Mohamad Aizat; N.H.H., Abu-Bakar, Noor Hana Hanif; N., Saito, Nobuo; V.P., Thai, Van Phuoc
Author full names: Sulaiman, Nur I. (56688249900); Abu Bakar, Mohamad Aizat (57477668700); Abu-Bakar, Noor Hana Hanif (56208812600); Saito, Nobuo (55422710000); Thai, Van Phuoc (57202194953)
Title: Modified sol–gel method for synthesis and structure characterisation of ternary and quaternary ferrite-based oxides for thermogravimetrically carbon dioxide adsorption
Affiliations: Universiti Sains Malaysia, Gelugor, Malaysia; Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; HCMC University of Technology and Education, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Sulaiman, Nur I., Nanoscience Research Laboratory, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Gelugor, Malaysia; Abu Bakar, Mohamad Aizat, Nanoscience Research Laboratory, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Gelugor, Malaysia; Abu-Bakar, Noor Hana Hanif, Nanoscience Research Laboratory, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Gelugor, Malaysia; Saito, Nobuo, Department of Materials Science and Technology, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Thai, Van Phuoc, Department of Materials Science and Technology, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, HCMC University of Technology and Education, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: Soft-NiFe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>4</inf> (S-spinel), hard-BaFe<inf>12</inf>O<inf>19</inf> (M-type) and BaNi<inf>2</inf>Fe<inf>16</inf>O<inf>27</inf> (W-type) were successfully prepared via a novel modified sol–gel method. The mechanism of modified sol–gel method is to utilise the esterification reaction between citric acid chelate and 2-propanol to spontaneously generate more homogeneous esterified-gel. This modified sol–gel method produced pure and highly crystalline ferrite-based oxides with more uniform morphology and effective carbon dioxide (CO<inf>2</inf>) adsorption. It is a simpler and more efficient method than the traditional sol–gel method. XRD results proved the purity of the prepared ferrite-based oxides and exhibited smaller and comparable crystallite size when determined by the Debye–Scherrer equation. FTIR indicates the presence of metal–oxygen stretching bonds in the samples. Nitrogen sorption analysis confirmed the high surface area of ferrite-based oxides using this improvement method. EDX and XPS analyses verified the purity and chemical composition of the samples. The morphologies of the samples were investigated by SEM and HRTEM analysis. The CO<inf>2</inf> adsorption was evaluated by thermogravimetry method for all the samples, and BaNi<inf>2</inf>Fe<inf>16</inf>O<inf>27</inf> (W-type) shows the maximum CO<inf>2</inf> uptake with 20.43 mg/g<inf>ads</inf> compared to hard-BaFe<inf>12</inf>O<inf>19</inf> (M-type) and soft-NiFe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>4</inf> (S-spinel) with 17.33 and 11.31 mg/g<inf>ads</inf>, respectively. All the samples are best fitted with the pseudo-second order in kinetic analysis with high R2 values (> 0.98). Therefore, this improvement modified sol–gel method proved better and promising option and at the same time beneficial for CO<inf>2</inf> adsorption. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Carbon Dioxide Adsorption; Esterified-gel; Ferrite-based Adsorbent; Metal Oxide; Sol–gel Method

Authors: T.S., Nam, Tran Sy; N., van Cong, Nguyen; V.T., Huynh, Van Thao

Title: Enhancing renewable energy production from water hyacinth (Eichhornia crassipes) by a biogas-aerating recirculation system: A case study in the Vietnamese Mekong Delta
Source title: Case Studies in Chemical and Environmental Engineering
Affiliations: Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nam, Tran Sy, Department of Environmental Sciences, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; van Cong, Nguyen, Department of Environmental Sciences, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Huynh, Van Thao, Department of Environmental Sciences, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam, Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Japan
Abstract: The study aims to examine biogas-aerating recirculation on biomethanation in a farm-scale digester with water hyacinth substrate. The experiment was conducted with the difference in biogas-aerating times and frequencies. Methane yield considerably improved by 27.44–52.12%, 50.19–62.30% and 63.11−71.46% for aerating biogas from 15 to 60 minutes at once, twice and four-time d−1, respectively. Maximum biogas yields were estimated for biogas-aerating at once, twice, and four daily repetitions at 47.8, 78.0, and 145 minutes. Biogas-aerating 30 minutes at twice d−1 and 15–60 minutes at four-time d−1 displayed great potential for biogas production augmentation. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Anaerobic Digestion; Biogas Digester; Biogas Yield; Biogas-aerating Recirculation; Water Hyacinth

(55701829300); Tran, Nguyen Phuong Dung (57208862281); Angkawijaya, Artik Elisa (37027954600); Yuliana, Maria (37162390000); Nguyen, Minh Nhut (57746104100); Tuan, Thi Tran Anh (35270671400)
Title: Evaluation of the potential removal of phosphate using rice husk ash-derived zeolite NaP1
Source title: Journal of Chemical Technology and Biotechnology
Affiliations: Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Widya Mandala Surabaya Catholic University, Surabaya, Indonesia; National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan; RIKEN Center for Sustainable Resource Science, Yokohama, Japan; Tra Vinh University, Tra Vinh, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Tran-Nguyen, Phuong Lan, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Ly, Kim Phung, Department of Chemical Engineering, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Thanh Ty, Department of Chemical Engineering, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Santoso, S. P., Department of Chemical Engineering, Widya Mandala Surabaya Catholic University, Surabaya, Indonesia; Tran, Nguyen Phuong Dung, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan; Angkawijaya, Artik Elisa, RIKEN Center for Sustainable Resource Science, Yokohama, Japan; Yuliana, Maria, Department of Chemical Engineering, Widya Mandala Surabaya Catholic University, Surabaya, Indonesia; Nguyen, Minh Nhut, Department of Chemical Engineering, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Tuan, Thi Tran Anh, School of Basic Sciences, Tra Vinh University, Tra Vinh, Viet Nam
Abstract: BACKGROUND: Zeolite NaP1 with high crystalline intensity and good shape has been synthesized by utilizing rice husk ash. Several factors related to the formation of zeolite, such as mixing ratios, aging time, and reaction time, were investigated. Furthermore, the potential phosphate adsorption of the optimal synthesized zeolite was evaluated. RESULTS: Under the optimal conditions (SiO<inf>2</inf>/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> molar ratio = 4.0, NaOH concentration = 1.5 M, aging time = 12 h, and reaction time = 8 h), the surface area and pore diameter of the zeolite NaP1 obtained were 50 m2 g−1 and 40.77 Å, respectively. By varying the aging and reaction times, zeolite NaP1 with different surface areas could be created. Specifically, reducing the aging time and reaction time result in zeolite NaP1 with a lower surface area. The adsorption efficiency and adsorption capacity of the optimal synthesized zeolite NaP1 were 38.67% and 19.97 mg g−1, respectively, at pH 6.0, with an initial phosphate concentration of 100 mg L−1, an adsorbent dosage of 2 g L−1, and a contact time of 120 min. The data are well described under the Temkin and Redlich-Peterson models, with the correlation coefficients of 0.991 and 0.995, respectively. The maximum adsorption capacity of the Langmuir model reached 19.053 mg g−1. CONCLUSION: The main contribution of this work is the direct use of rice husk ash without pretreatment to generate high crystalline zeolite NaP1 in a shorter time. The phosphate ion removal efficiency by zeolite NaP1 may be further improved by functionalizing zeolite surfaces and expanding its other applications. © 2023 Society of Chemical Industry (SCI). © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Insight into the direct conversion of methane to methanol on modified ZIF-204 from the perspective of DFT-based calculations
Affiliations: Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; VNUHCM - University of Information Technology, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; SRM Institute of Science and Technology, Kattankulathur, India; Suranaree University of Technology, Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand; Culham Centre for Fusion Energy, Abingdon, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Le, Thong Nguyen Minh, Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Le, Thu Bao Nguyen, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Department of Mathematics and Physics, VNUHCM - University of Information Technology, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Phat Tan, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Department of Theoretical Physics, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Trang Thuy M., Key Laboratory for Multiscale Simulation of Complex Systems, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tran, Quang Ngoc, Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Toan The, Key Laboratory for Multiscale Simulation of Complex Systems, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan, Department of Physics and Nanotechnology, SRM Institute of Science and Technology, Kattankulathur, India, School of Physics, Suranaree University of Technology, Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand; Phan, Thang Bach, Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen-Manh, Duc, Culham Centre for Fusion Energy, Abingdon, United Kingdom
Abstract: Direct oxidation of methane over oxo-doped ZIF-204, a bio-mimetic metal-organic framework, is investigated under first-principles calculations based on density functional theory. In the pristine ZIF-204, the tetrahedral methane molecule anchors to an open monocopper site via the so-called η2 configuration with a physisorption energy of 0.24 eV. This weak binding arises from an electrostatic interaction between the negative charge of carbon in the methane molecule and the positive Cu2+ cation in the framework. In the modified ZIF-204, the doped oxo species is stabilized at the axial position of a CuN<inf>4</inf>-base square pyramid at a distance of 2.06 Å. The dative covalent bond between Cu and oxo is responsible for the formation energy of 1.06 eV. With the presence of the oxo group, the presenting of electrons in the O_p<inf>z</inf> orbital accounts for the adsorption of methane via hydrogen bonding with an adsorption energy of 0.30 eV. The methane oxidation can occur via either a concerted direct oxo insertion mechanism or a hydrogen-atom abstraction radical rebound mechanism. Calculations on transition-state barriers show that reactions via the concerted direct oxo insertion mechanism can happen without energy barriers. Concerning the hydrogen-atom abstraction radical rebound mechanism, the C-H bond dissociation of the CH<inf>4</inf> molecule is barrierless, but the C-O bond recombination to form the CH<inf>3</inf>OH molecule occurs through a low barrier of 0.16 eV. These predictions suggest the modified ZIF-204 is a promising catalyst for methane oxidization. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.H.P., Nguyen, Tinh Hong Phuong; V.M., Tran, Vu Minh; B., Ngoc-Tam, Bui
Author full names: Nguyen, Tinh Hong Phuong (57226685512); Tran, Vu Minh (58298880900); Ngoc-Tam, Bui (57212681073)
Title: Self-Adaptive Differential Evolution with Gauss Distribution for Optimal Mechanism Design
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Tinh Hong Phuong, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tran, Vu Minh, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ngoc-Tam, Bui, Department of Machinery and Control Systems, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Differential evolution (DE) is one of the best evolutionary algorithms (EAs). In recent decades, many techniques have been developed to enhance the performance of this algorithm, such as the Improve Self-Adaptive Differential Evolution (ISADE) algorithm. Based on the analysis of the aspects that may improve the performance of ISADE, we proposed a modified ISADE version with applying the Gauss distribution for mutation procedure. In ISADE, to determine the scaling factor (F), the population is ranked, then, based on the rank number, population size, and current generation, the formula of the Sigmoid function is used. In the proposed algorithm, F is amplified by a factor which is generated based on Gaussian distribution. It has the potential to enhance the variety of population. In comparison with several reference algorithms regarding converging speed and the consistency of optimal solutions, the simulation results reveal the performance of the suggested algorithm is exceptional. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Differential Evolution; Gauss Distribution; Mutation Procedure; Optimization Algorithm

Authors: L.T., Trang, Le Thi; H.V., Le, Hai Van; S., Hiromoto, Sachiko; M., Oh, Minho; E., Kobayashi, Equo; N.V., Nguyen, Nam Viet; Q.N., Cao, Quang Nguyen
Author full names: Trang, Le Thi (57763003100); Le, Hai Van (58144381900); Hiromoto, Sachiko (57218357751); Oh, Minho (57452485300); Kobayashi, Equo (7201949775); Nguyen, Nam Viet (57211678428); Cao, Quang Nguyen (59218424100)
Title: In vitro cellular biocompatibility and in vivo degradation behavior of calcium phosphate-coated ZK60 magnesium alloy
Affiliations: Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Vietnam Military Medical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan; 108 Military Central Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Université Laval, Quebec, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Trang, Le Thi, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Le, Hai Van, Military Hospital, Vietnam Military Medical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hiromoto, Sachiko, Research Center for Structural Materials, National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan; Oh, Minho, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Kobayashi, Equo, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Nguyen, Nam Viet, Institute of Traumatology and Orthopaedics, 108 Military Central Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Cao, Quang Nguyen, Laboratory for Biomaterials and Bioengineering, Université Laval, Quebec, Canada
Abstract: Calcium phosphate (Ca-P) surface coating is a simple but effective way to enhance both corrosion resistance and biocompatibility of ZK60 magnesium alloy. However, cell compatibility on different Ca-P layers coated on ZK60 alloy has seldom been investigated. In this study, the effects of type, morphology and corrosion protection of several Ca-P coatings formed at pH 6.5, 7.8 and 10.2 on cell behavior were examined by using an osteoblastic cell line MC3T3-E1. Furthermore, in vivo behavior in rabbits of the alloy coated with the optimum Ca-P layer was also studied. It was found that the surface factors governed the cell morphology and density. The coating morphology plays a dominant role in these surface factors. The sample coated at pH 7.8 showed the best cellular biocompatibility, suggesting that the hydroxyapatite (HAp) layer formed at pH 7.8 was the optimum coating. In rabbits, this optimum coating enhanced remarkably the corrosion resistance of the alloy. During implantation, the outermost crystals of the HAp coating were shortened and thinned due to the dissolution of HAp caused by the body fluid of the rabbits. It is indicated that ZK60 alloy coated at pH 7.8 can be applied as a biodegradable implant. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: C., Hsiao, Changyu; V.D., Dang, Van Dien; Y., Hsu, Yawen; Y.T., Lu, Yi Ting; P., Hsu, Peiju; P.–., Le, Phuoc –.Anh; K.H., Wei, Kung– Hwa
Title: Dual-cathode plasma-induced exfoliated WSe2/graphene nanosheet composite mediating an efficient hydrogen evolution reaction
Affiliations: National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Industry and Trade, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Shinshu University, Matsumoto, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Hsiao, Changyu, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Dang, Van Dien, Faculty of Biology and Environment, Ho Chi Minh City University of Industry and Trade, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Hsu, Yawen, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Lu, Yi Ting, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Hsu, Peiju, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Le, Phuoc –.Anh, Faculty of Textile Science and Technology, Shinshu University, Matsumoto, Japan, Institute of Sustainability Science, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Wei, Kung– Hwa, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan, Center for Emergent Functional Matter Science, National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Abstract: With the goal of obtaining a sustainable earth-abundant electrocatalyst that displays high performance in the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), herein we describe a new electrochemical process for the simultaneous dual-cathodic plasma-induced exfoliations of two different bulk materials—graphite and WSe<inf>2</inf>—into two-dimensional (2D) nanosheets for the fabrication of a homogeneous composite. Using this approach, we produced unique structures of graphene nanosheet-engulfed ultrathin WSe<inf>2</inf> nanosheets (WSe<inf>2</inf>@GN), stabilized through van der Waals and π–π interactions between the WSe<inf>2</inf> and GNs, possessing various morphologies and featuring large edge and defect densities on the basal plane of the GNs—potential active sites for HER catalysis. This synthesis of WSe<inf>2</inf>@GN structures not only increased the number of active sites in the semiconducting WSe<inf>2</inf> nanosheets but also enhanced their conductivity. Our dual-cathode plasma produced WSe<inf>2</inf>@GN nanosheet composites exhibited high HER performance, characterized by a low overpotential of 106 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm–2, a Tafel slope of 66 mV dec–1, and long-term stability in 0.5 M H<inf>2</inf>SO<inf>4</inf> (80% activity retention after >48 h); these performance metrics were much better than those of the corresponding WSe<inf>2</inf>/GN composite, prepared through two sequential single-cathode electrochemical plasma exfoliation and mixed together (233 mV, 111 mV dec–1), and are among the best ever reported for a composite involving WSe<inf>2</inf> and GNs, prepared through simultaneous exfoliation at a low temperature and over a short period of time, for the HER. This in situ dual-plasma-exfoliation synthetic approach allows the effective production of homogeneous 2D/2D heterostructures with great potential for various energy-related applications, while being an effective and simple strategy for tuning the morphologies of composites of graphene and transition metal dichalcogenide materials for a broad range of energy applications. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Antioxidant, Anti-Skin-Aging, Anti-Inflammatory, and Anti-Acetylcholinesterase Activities of Rourea oligophlebia Extracts
Affiliations: Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Ltd., Bangkok, Thailand; Ltd., Bangkok, Thailand; Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Tropical Biology, Dalat, Viet Nam; University of Toyama, Toyama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Buranasudja, Visarut Codey, Department of Physiology and Pharmacology, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand, Center of Excellence in Natural Products for Ageing and Chronic Diseases, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Vimolmangkang, Sornkanok, Department of Pharmacognosy and Pharmaceutical Botany, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand, Center of Excellence in Plant-Produced Pharmaceuticals, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Sanookpan, Kittipong, Department of Physiology and Pharmacology, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand, Ltd., Bangkok, Thailand; Binalee, Asma, HPTLC center, Ltd., Bangkok, Thailand; Bao Nguyen, Anh, Faculty of Pharmacy, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thach, Ut Dong, Faculty of Pharmacy, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Hang do, Bich, Faculty of Pharmacy, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Son Dang, Van, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Tropical Biology, Dalat, Viet Nam; Minh do, Kiep, Institute of Natural Medicine, University of Toyama, Toyama, Japan; Minh Nguyen, Hien, Faculty of Pharmacy, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: The objective of this study was to evaluate the antioxidant, anti-skin-aging, anti-inflammatory, and anti-acetylcholinesterase activities of the hexane (n-hex), AcOEt, BuOH, MeOH, and aqueous extracts from R. oligophlebia roots. The total phenolic and flavonoid contents (TPC and TFC) were determined using Folin-Ciocalteu and AlCl<inf>3</inf> colorimetric assays. The antioxidant capacity was examined by reducing power (RP), ferric reducing antioxidant power (FRAP), ABTS⋅+, and DPPH⋅+ radical cation assays. All extracts potentially exhibited antioxidant activity with IC<inf>50</inf> values ranging from 2.93 to 5.73 μg/mL for ABTS⋅+ and from 5.69 to 7.65 μg/mL for DPPH⋅+ except the n-hex extract. The BuOH, MeOH, and aqueous extract possess promising anti-skin-aging activities, as observed by an attenuation of UV-A toxicity on human keratinocytes. We proposed that these anti-skin-aging properties are possibly due to direct scavenging activity against reactive oxygen species and upregulate cellular antioxidant machinery. Moreover, we found that the antioxidant capacity was well correlated with anti-inflammatory capacity against nitric oxide (NO) production in terms of the n-hex, AcOEt, and BuOH extracts with IC<inf>50</inf> values from 23.21 to 47.1 μg/mL. In contrast, these activities were found to be poorly correlated with AchE activity. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of the antioxidant, anti-skin-aging, anti-inflammatory, and anti-acetylcholinesterase activities of the extracts of R. oligophlebia roots. These findings indicated that this species could be a potential source of natural antioxidant, anti-aging, and anti-inflammatory agents. Consequently, it may be suggested as a medicinal plant that prevents diseases related to oxidative stress and inflammatory responses. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Correlation between local structure variations and critical temperature of (Bi1.6Pb0.4Sr2Ca2Cu3O10+δ)1-x(TiO2)x superconductor
Affiliations: Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Synchrotron Light Research Institute, Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand; Hirosaki University, Hirosaki, Japan; International Training Institute for Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hanoi University of Civil Engineering, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Pham, An The, Faculty of Physics, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vu, Linh H., Faculty of Physics, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tran, Dzung T., Faculty of Physics, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Thien, Nguyen Duy, Faculty of Physics, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Klysubun, Wantana, Synchrotron Light Research Institute, Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand; Miyanaga, Takafumi, Department of Advanced Physics, Hirosaki University, Hirosaki, Japan; Man, Nguyen Khac, International Training Institute for Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Duong, Nhan T., Faculty of Physics, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Long, Nguyen Thanh, Urban & Architectural Institute, Hanoi University of Civil Engineering, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Pham, Phong V., Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: TiO<inf>2</inf> doping content affects the critical temperature (T<inf>c</inf>) and the variations of local structure on Bi<inf>1.6</inf>Pb<inf>0.4</inf>Sr<inf>2</inf>Ca<inf>2</inf>Cu<inf>3</inf>O<inf>10+δ</inf>. The (Bi<inf>1.6</inf>Pb<inf>0.4</inf>Sr<inf>2</inf>Ca<inf>2</inf>Cu<inf>3</inf>O<inf>10+δ</inf>)<inf>1-x</inf>(TiO<inf>2</inf>)<inf>x</inf> samples were fabricated with the solid-state reaction process, where x = 0, 0.002, 0.004, 0.006, 0.008, and 0.01. The T<inf>c</inf> values of the samples were obtained by measuring resistivity versus temperature, indicating that T<inf>c</inf> gradually decreased with increasing doping content (x). To explain the obtained degradation of T<inf>c</inf>, carrier properties, role of interlayer coupling, and local structure were systematically investigated using Azlamozov–Larkin theory and its Lawrence–Doniach modification for strong anisotropic superconductors. The calculation of excess conductivity at the mean field region showed that the c-axis coherence length (ξ<inf>c</inf>) and the effective inter-layering spacing (d) increased with increasing doping content. X-ray diffraction patterns also showed that the bond distances increased with increasing TiO<inf>2</inf> content. The copper valence (V) and carrier concentration (p) of the samples were determined by analyzing the Cu L<inf>2,3</inf>-edge X-ray absorption near edge structure spectra. The values of V and p showed the same trend of decreasing with increasing x. A close correlation between the changes in local structure parameters and degradation of T<inf>c</inf> of (Bi<inf>1.6</inf>Pb<inf>0.4</inf>Sr<inf>2</inf>Ca<inf>2</inf>Cu<inf>3</inf>O<inf>10+δ</inf>)<inf>1-x</inf>(TiO<inf>2</inf>)<inf>x</inf> was then probably concluded. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Le, Tan Khanh Trinh (58112458100); Kongparakul, Suwadee (24074703800); Zhang, Haibo (56903732500); Zhao, Jinggang (57204655452); Guan, Guoqing (36026624000); Chanlek, Narong (24775167600); Tran, Thi Tuong Vi (59269885600); Samart, Chanatip (26436343700)
Title: Highly efficient liquid-phase oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural over Co-Cu/activated carbon catalysts
Affiliations: Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, China; Hirosaki University, Hirosaki, Japan; Hirosaki University, Hirosaki, Japan; 111 University Avenue, Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand; Dại học Nguyen Tat Thanh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Industrial University of Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Le, Tan Khanh Trinh, Department of Chemistry, Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Kongparakul, Suwadee, Department of Chemistry, Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand, Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Zhang, Haibo, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, China; Zhao, Jinggang, Graduate School of Science and Technology, Hirosaki University, Hirosaki, Japan; Guan, Guoqing, Institute of Regional Innovation, Hirosaki University, Hirosaki, Japan; Chanlek, Narong, Synchrotron Light Research Institute, 111 University Avenue, Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand; Tran, Thi Tuong Vi, Faculty of Environmental and Food Engineering, Dại học Nguyen Tat Thanh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Samart, Chanatip, Department of Chemistry, Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand, Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand, Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Industrial University of Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: Selective oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) is a key reaction in biopolymer production. A non-noble metal catalyst and mild reaction conditions are highlighted in this work. Co-Cu nanoparticles supported on activated carbon (Co-Cu/AC) were introduced in the liquid-phase oxidation of HMF. The catalysts were prepared via a co-impregnation method, followed by reduction with hydrazine. The presence of the Cu promoter resulted in dispersion of the metal particles. The good distribution and small crystal size of Co<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf> significantly increased the active surface area and enhanced the catalytic activity. In addition, the presence of CuO synergized with the oxidation ability of the Co catalyst to increase the FDCA yield. The catalytic activity at different reaction temperatures, reaction times, catalyst loadings, and Co:Cu ratios revealed that the highest selectivity for FDCA (92%) was achieved using the 4Co-Cu/AC catalyst. According to the proposed reaction mechanism, the redox reaction between Cu2+/Cu+ and Co3+/Co4+, together with H<inf>2</inf>O<inf>2</inf> as the oxidant, promotes the complete oxidation of HMF to FDCA. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: SPS-Prepared High-Entropy (Bi0.2Na0.2Sr0.2Ba0.2Ca0.2)TiO3 Lead-Free Relaxor-Ferroelectric Ceramics with High Energy Storage Density
Affiliations: Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, China; Guangdong HUST Industrial Technology Research Institute, Dongguan, China; Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, China; Industrial University of Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, China; Guilin University of Electronic Technology, Guilin, China; Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Fukuoka University, Fukuoka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Lu, Ya, State Key Laboratory of Digital Manufacturing Equipment and Technology, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, China, Guangdong HUST Industrial Technology Research Institute, Dongguan, China; Zhang, Haibo, Guangdong HUST Industrial Technology Research Institute, Dongguan, China, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, China, Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Industrial University of Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, China; Yang, Huabing Bin, Guangxi Key Laboratory of Information Materials, Guilin University of Electronic Technology, Guilin, China; Fan, Pengyuan, Guangdong HUST Industrial Technology Research Institute, Dongguan, China, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, China; Samart, Chanatip, Department of Chemistry, Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Takesue, Naoshia, Faculty of Science, Fukuoka University, Fukuoka, Japan; Tan, Hua, State Key Laboratory of Digital Manufacturing Equipment and Technology, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, China, Guangdong HUST Industrial Technology Research Institute, Dongguan, China, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, China
Abstract: Compared to batteries and electrochemical capacitors, dielectric capacitors are widely studied because of their huge advantages in terms of charging/discharging speed and power density. In this work, high-entropy (Bi<inf>0.2</inf>Na<inf>0.2</inf>Sr<inf>0.2</inf>Ba<inf>0.2</inf>Ca<inf>0.2</inf>)TiO<inf>3</inf> lead-free relaxor-ferroelectric ceramics were prepared by both conventional sintering (CS) and spark plasma sintering (SPS). The results showed that the ceramic prepared by SPS obtained a high energy storage density of 6.66 J/cm3 and a satisfied energy storage efficiency of 77.2% under an electric field of 430 kV/cm. This is directly related to the high density, fine grains, number of oxygen vacancies, and composition uniformity of the SPS samples. This study provides a new path for the preparation of high-entropy dielectric energy storage ceramics with high energy storage properties. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Dielectric Ceramics; Energy Storage; Relaxor-ferroelectrics; Spark Plasma Sintering

Authors: V., van Thanh, Vuong; D., van Truong, Do; N., Tuan Hung, Nguyen

Title: Janus γ-GeSSe Monolayer as a High-Performance Material for Photocatalysis and Thermoelectricity
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Authors with affiliations: van Thanh, Vuong, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; van Truong, Do, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tuan Hung, Nguyen, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Abstract: Two-dimensional Janus materials have attracted increasing attention in recent years because of their potential as materials for energy applications, such as photocatalysis and thermoelectricity (TE). Here, for the first time, we propose a monolayer Janus structure with the Mexican-hat band, γ-GeSSe, by replacing the S atoms on one side of the synthesized γ-GeS with Se atoms. Using first-principles calculations based on density functional theory (DFT), we show that γ-GeSSe is mechanically, dynamically, and thermally stable. The mechanical, electronic, optical, and transport properties of monolayer Janus γ-GeSSe are also investigated in the DFT calculations. We find that the ideal strengths of the Janus γ-GeSSe are 6.08, 8.6, and 10.08 GPa for the armchair, zigzag, and biaxial directions, respectively. The Janus γ-GeSSe is an indirect-gap semiconductor with a band gap of 1.131 eV. Our results show the Janus γ-GeSSe as a photocatalysis material for water splitting with a high solar-to-hydrogen efficiency of up to 28.78%. This is because the combination of features includes an intrinsic electric field, high optical absorption coefficient, and carrier mobility. In addition, with the γ-structure, the Janus γ-GeSSe shows an intrinsic low lattice thermal conductivity of 3.33 W/mK at room temperature, which will contribute to obtaining high TE efficiency. By using the Boltzmann transport theory, we find that the maximum TE power factor and figure of merit of the Janus γ-GeSSe reach 55-85 mW/mK2 and 0.7-0.9 in the temperature range from 300 to 900 K, respectively. Thus, our findings not only contribute to proposing a Janus material but also suggest that it can be used as an energy material with high-performance photocatalysis and TE. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M.T., Le, Minh Tien; H.H., Pham, Ha H.; N.T., Nghia, Nguyen The; N., Nam, Nguyenhoang; T., Miyanaga, Takafumi; D.H., Tran, Duc Hai; W., Kang, Wonnam
Author full names: Le, Minh Tien (57202738937); Pham, Ha H. (57222316031); Nghia, Nguyen The (57215048196); Nam, Nguyenhoang (57208561720); Miyanaga, Takafumi (15054613100); Tran, Duc Hai (56226812800); Kang, Wonnam (7202401576)
Title: Effects of Sn-ion irradiation on local structure and flux pinning properties of MgB2 thin films
Affiliations: Sungkyunkwan University, Seoul, South Korea; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hirosaki University, Hirosaki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Le, Minh Tien, Department of Physics, Sungkyunkwan University, Seoul, South Korea; Pham, Ha H., Faculty of Physics, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nghia, Nguyen The, Faculty of Physics, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nam, Nguyenhoang, Faculty of Physics, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Miyanaga, Takafumi, Department of Mathematics and Physics, Hirosaki University, Hirosaki, Japan; Tran, Duc Hai, Faculty of Physics, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kang, Wonnam, Department of Physics, Sungkyunkwan University, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: We studied the effects of tin (Sn) ion irradiation on the local structure and flux pinning properties of 412-nm-thick MgB<inf>2</inf> thin films. Ions with 2 MeV incident energy were irradiated onto MgB<inf>2</inf> thin films at room temperature and various dose levels from 2 × 1012 to 7 × 1013 atoms/cm2. X-ray diffraction and extended X-ray absorption fine-structure results confirmed extended average bond lengths and increased mean-square relative displacement that correlated with crystalline disorder serving as artificial pinning centers induced by ion irradiation. While the superconducting transition temperature (T<inf>c</inf>) exhibited a decreasing trend, the magnetization J<inf>c</inf> (H) of the irradiated films measured at both 5 K and 20 K were remarkably enhanced compared to that of pristine films at high applied magnetic fields. The decreases in exponent β from 1.1 and 1.13 to 0.69 and 0.62 after irradiation at 5 K and 20 K, respectively, as the dose increased to 5 × 1013 atoms/cm2 indicates a shift in the pinning mechanism from weak collective pinning to strong plastic pinning according to collective pinning theory. In addition, the scaling behavior of the flux pinning force density (F<inf>p</inf>) in the irradiated MgB<inf>2</inf> films showed a crossover from surface pinning to normal point pinning. These results suggest that intermediate-energy irradiation by heavy ions such as Sn generates effective pinning sources for improving J<inf>c</inf>(H) in MgB<inf>2</inf> superconductors. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Abstract: In this paper, we develop a method for Friedel−Crafts acylation using metal triflate in deep eutectic solvents.Various metal triflates were tested and provided good to excellent yields of corresponding ketone products.The density functional theory calculation revealed the metal effects on the formation of active intermediate acylium triflate as well as the acidic condition.The metal triflate in the deep eutectic solvent can be recovered and reused with a little loss in the catalytic activity. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N.X.D., Mai, Ngoc Xuan Dat; T.H.T., Nguyen, Thu Ha Thi; D.H., Nguyen, Du Huy; L.H.T., Nguyen, Linh Ho Thuy; T.H., Nguyen, Thi Hiep; T.B., Phan, Thang Bach; F., Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; B.L., Vong, Binh Long; T.L.H., Doan, Tan Le Hoang
Author full names: Mai, Ngoc Xuan Dat (57193926093); Nguyen, Thu Ha Thi (57216184503); Nguyen, Du Huy (58593832400); Nguyen, Linh Ho Thuy (57195363019); Nguyen, Thi Hiep (55313200400); Phan, Thang Bach (56182322400); Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko (7007075493); Vong, Binh Long (55366287800); Doan, Tan Le Hoang (57939112200)
Title: Engineering biodegradable periodic mesoporous functionalized-organosilica nanocarriers for efficient paclitaxel delivery
Source title: Colloids and Surfaces A: Physicochemical and Engineering Aspects
Affiliations: Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Institute for Integrated Cell-Material Sciences, Kyoto, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Mai, Ngoc Xuan Dat, Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Thu Ha Thi, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, School of Biomedical Engineering, International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Du Huy, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Linh Ho Thuy, Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Thi Hiep, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, School of Biomedical Engineering, International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Phan, Thang Bach, Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko, Institute for Integrated Cell-Material Sciences, Kyoto, Japan; Vong, Binh Long, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, School of Biomedical Engineering, International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Doan, Tan Le Hoang, Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: Periodic mesoporous organosilica (PMO) materials have attracted considerable attention as promising nanocarriers to improve the therapeutic efficacy of anticancer drugs. Herein, a new type of biodegradable disulfide-based PMO was synthesized by incorporating disulfide linkers into the silica framework of nanoparticles (NPs). The homogeneous spherical morphology with an average size of 50 nm is observed by scanning electron microscope, transmission electron microscopy. Furthermore, the physicochemical characterizations were also performed by using Fourier transform infrared spectra and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy confirmed the presence of disulfide in the structure of NPs. It is notable that the disulfide moieties incorporated into the structure of NPs lead to fast degradation, within 5 days to complete degradation. Paclitaxel (PTX), a hydrophobic anticancer drug, was loaded into the porous particles with a high loading capacity up to 602 mg.g−1. A large amount of PTX was released at the early stage of the release process in the phosphate buffer saline solution containing reduced glutathione and then released slowly at a steady rate. The effective cellular uptake of NPs into malignant cells and normal cells also demonstrated. PTX-loaded NPs exhibited higher anticancer activity against cancer cells as compared to free PTX, indicating the potential nanocarrier for cancer therapy. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D.B., Nguyen, Duy Bao; T., Fujiwara, Takeshi; C., Le Dinh, Cuong; S.T.P., Phu, Song Toan Pham
Author full names: Nguyen, Duy Bao (57406388400); Fujiwara, Takeshi (55502389900); Le Dinh, Cuong (57222016137); Phu, Song Toan Pham (57406473300)
Title: Composting Activities in Vietnam – The Situation, Problems, and Challenges
Affiliations: Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Duy Bao, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Fujiwara, Takeshi, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Le Dinh, Cuong, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Phu, Song Toan Pham, University of Science and Technology, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Abstract: In Vietnam, biodegradable waste is a primary component of urban municipal solid waste, accounting for 54 - 65 % of the total waste. Aerobic composting is one of the most effective methods for reducing this waste as well as decarbonization, but with poor management, it is the greatest source of greenhouse gas emissions. According to the Ministry of Environment and Natural Resource, there are 37 composting facilities in Vietnam, treating 16 % of the total municipal solid waste. However, the number of well-maintained facilities is decreasing over time, due to difficulties and challenges in operating and maintaining highly efficient composting. This study aimed at evaluating the current situation of composting facilities in Vietnam, evaluating the efficiency and problems in the composting facility in Hoi An City (HAC). Social and technical surveys were conducted to identify the social consensus on waste separation and to measure the performance of the Cam Ha composting facility. The results indicated that 91.95 % of HAC’s households were aware of the separation of waste since the waste segregation policy was implemented in 2012. In the composting facilities, raw materials for composting contained 40.44 % inorganic matter, showing the low efficiency in waste separation at source. 1.27 % glass and plastic debris in the composting product lowering the compost quality, raising the concern on human health and safety. This study gives an overview of Vietnam's composting situation and contributes to local decision-making related to the municipal solid waste management system toward sustainability and lowering global warming. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Biodegradable Waste; Composting; Global Warming; Solid Waste Management; Sustainable Development
