Title: Facile synthesis of Co3O4@SiO2/Carbon Nanocomposite Catalysts from Rice Husk for Low-Temperature CO Oxidation
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tokyo Metropolitan University, Hachioji, Japan; Universidad de Córdoba, Cordoba, Spain; College of Sciences, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia; RUDN University, Moscow, Russian Federation; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Dien, Luong Xuan, School of Chemical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Tokyo Metropolitan University, Hachioji, Japan; Huynh, Chinh Dang, School of Chemical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nga, Nguyen Kim, School of Chemical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Luque, Rafael L., Campus de Rabanales, Universidad de Córdoba, Cordoba, Spain; Osman, Sameh M., Department of Chemistry, College of Sciences, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia; Voskressensky, Leonid G., RUDN University, Moscow, Russian Federation; Tran, Dai Lam, Institute for Tropical Technology, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ishida, Tamao, Tokyo Metropolitan University, Hachioji, Japan; Murayama, Toru, Tokyo Metropolitan University, Hachioji, Japan
Abstract: Co<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf> was synthesized in the presence of 3D porous nanostructured SiO<inf>2</inf>/carbon composite derived from rice husk via a hydrothermal method to produce Co<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf>@SiO<inf>2</inf>/C nanostructures with good microstructural, morphological and excelling catalytic properties. The morphology and textural properties of the products were tuned by using different amounts of hydrocarbonized rice husk. TEM images exhibited nanoclusters 1–9 nm in diameter and reducing the nanoparticle size of Co<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf> by adding hydrocarbonized rice husk. The specific surface area value of Co<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf>@SiO<inf>2</inf>/C is 115 m2 /g which is significantly improved as compared to Co<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf> prepared in the absence of hydrocarbonized rice husk (70 m2 /g). Materials were tested in the oxidation of CO oxidation as model reaction. Compared to conventional Co<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf> nanoparticles, as-prepared Co<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf>@SiO<inf>2</inf>/C exhibited a superior catalytic activity for CO oxidation, i.e., T<inf>50</inf> (50% conversion) is at <25 °C (at 100°C for Co<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf>). © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D., van Pham, Duong; D., van Nguyen, Diep; T.X., Nguyen, Tu Xuan; K.A.T., Doan, Kieu Anh Thi; Q.M., Le, Quan Minh; M., Pham, Minhhong; M.M., Raduban, Marilou M.
Author full names: van Pham, Duong (57202984323); van Nguyen, Diep (58224085800); Nguyen, Tu Xuan (57202994045); Doan, Kieu Anh Thi (57393472900); Le, Quan Minh (57393473000); Pham, Minhhong (23973373800); Raduban, Marilou M. (26654667100)
Title: Studying the Nonlinear Optical Properties of Fluoride Laser Host Materials in the Ultraviolet Wavelength Region
Affiliations: Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Physics and Electronics, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ha Tinh College of Technology, Ha Tinh, Viet Nam; Massey University Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand; The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Authors with affiliations: van Pham, Duong, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Physics and Electronics, Hanoi, Viet Nam; van Nguyen, Diep, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Physics and Electronics, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Tu Xuan, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Physics and Electronics, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Doan, Kieu Anh Thi, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Physics and Electronics, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le, Quan Minh, Faculty of Teacher Education, Ha Tinh College of Technology, Ha Tinh, Viet Nam; Pham, Minhhong, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Physics and Electronics, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Raduban, Marilou M., Centre for Theoretical Chemistry and Physics, Massey University Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Abstract: Fluoride host materials doped with trivalent cerium ions have previously been demonstrated as successful laser materials in the ultraviolet wavelength region. However, the nonlinear optical properties of the fluoride hosts in this wavelength region have not been investigated yet, although nonlinearity could result in undesirable effects such as self-focusing and pulse distortion when these fluoride materials are used as gain media in high-power, ultrashort pulse laser oscillator and amplifier systems. In this work, the nonlinear refractive index of lithium calcium aluminum fluoride (LiCaAlF<inf>6</inf>), lithium strontium aluminum fluoride (LiSrAlF<inf>6</inf>), lanthanum fluoride (LaF<inf>3</inf>), and yttrium lithium fluoride (YLiF<inf>4</inf>) fluoride host materials are determined using the Kramers–Krönig relation model in the ultraviolet wavelength region. Self-focusing conditions, particularly at the peak laser emission wavelength of these materials, are further analyzed. Results show that LiCaAlF<inf>6</inf> has the smallest nonlinear refractive index and self-focusing, making it an ideal host material under the conditions of ultrashort pulse and ultrahigh-power laser generation. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Fluoride Materials; Laser; Nonlinear Refractive Index; Self-focusing; Ultraviolet

Authors: T.K.D., Huynh, Thi Kim Duyen; L.A.D., Nguyen, Le Anh Dao; T.N.H., Nguyen, Thị Nhu Ha; Q.T., Nguyen, Quoc Thinh; H., Tomoaki, Hagiwara; M.P., Tran, M. P.
Author full names: Huynh, Thi Kim Duyen (57367890900); Nguyen, Le Anh Dao (57367473500); Nguyen, Thị Nhu Ha (57368510800); Nguyen, Quoc Thinh (57204557631); Tomoaki, Hagiwara (57222678445); Tran, M. P. (57195943294)
Title: Effects of green tea (Camellia sinensis) and guava (Psidium guajava) extracts on the quality of snakehead (Channa striata) fillets during ice storage
Source title: Journal of Food Processing and Preservation
Affiliations: Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Tokyo University of Marine Science and Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Huynh, Thi Kim Duyen, Department of Food Science and Technology, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Le Anh Dao, Department of Food Science and Technology, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Thị Nhu Ha, Department of Food Science and Technology, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Quoc Thinh, Department of Food Science and Technology, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Tomoaki, Hagiwara, Tokyo University of Marine Science and Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Tran, M. P., Department of Food Science and Technology, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam
Abstract: The antioxidant and antimicrobial properties of Camellia sinensis and Psidium guajava leaf extracts were determined and applied as soaking solutions for snakehead (Channa striata) fillets prior to 12-day ice storage. The scavenge 50% of the DPPH (2,2ʹ-diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl) free radicals (IC<inf>50</inf>) of C. sinensis was 7.63 µg/mL and 5.04 µg/mL for P. guajava extract. The minimum inhibition concentrations (MIC) of C. sinensis and P. guajava against Aeromonas hydrophila were 625 and 313 µg/mL, respectively. The IC<inf>50</inf> and MIC concentrations were then applied as extract solutions for soaking snakehead fillets before ice storage. During ice storage, snakehead fillets treated with plants extracts showed reduced lipid oxidation, inhibited bacteria growth, and enhanced sensory properties compared to untreated samples. Based on the total viable count, shelf life of snakehead fillets treated with C. sinensis and P. guajava extracts can be prolonged up to 8 days while less than 8 days for the control treatment. Novelty impact statement: In order to maintain the quality of fish products during storage, many preservation methods and techniques are commonly used, where the use of chemicals can directly affect human health. The use of natural preservatives is a promising method that could be an alternative to synthetic additives. In this study, C. sinensis and P. guajava extracts showed significant in vitro antibacterial and antioxidant properties, and therefore have high potential as an agent for ice storage of snakehead fish fillets. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Elucidate Fluid Vortex in Plasma Arc Welding

Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Thanh Hai, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; van Anh, Nguyen, Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan, Murata Welding Laboratory, Osaka, Japan, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tashiro, Shinichi, Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan; Le Quy, Thu, National Research Institute of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tanaka, Manabu, Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan
Abstract: This paper is adopted to discuss the relationship between fluid vortex in the melted domain and copper orifice diameter. In order to explode this behavior, four-dimensional material flow was discussed based on an innovative X-ray imaging technology approach. As a result of the advanced experimental measurement, two fluid vortexes (a vortex pair) are found in the melted domain. The relative contour of each vortex is enormously altered when the keyhole boundary changes due to the orifice diameter variation. These relative profiles of each vortex are dependent to decisively govern the mass transfer and convection flow in the melted domain. Steeper keyhole parapet was formed by a strong plasma jet, accelerated through the narrow orifice diameter (2.0 mm), resulting in a large downward shear force component inside the keyhole to produce a larger vortex at the lower part of the weld pool. On the other hand, due to a wider diameter of orifice (2.4 mm), the plasma arc column is expanded. Rear kerf of the keyhole is more inclined toward the ending part of the weld pool. This caused a stronger shear force component along the keyhole surface at the top side of the weld pool in the outward direction. As a result, the vortex at the top side of the weld pool is much bigger and longer in comparison with diameter 2.0 mm. This resulted in a larger keyhole size with diameter 2.4 mm copper orifice, especially on the top side. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.H., Nguyen, Thanh Hai; T.L., Vu, Tran Long; V., van Duy Phong, Vo; T.N.T., Dat, Tra Ngoc Tien; V.A., Nguyen, Van Anh; S.M., Pham, Son Minh; N.H., Loc, Nguyen Huu
Author full names: Nguyen, Thanh Hai (57209167098); Vu, Tran Long (58711265800); van Duy Phong, Vo (57336955500); Dat, Tra Ngoc Tien (57336538300); Nguyen, Van Anh (57748361800); Pham, Son Minh (35199949500); Loc, Nguyen Huu (57207982088)
Title: Investigation the Ultrasonic Injection Molding of Polyamide 6
Affiliations: Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Murata Welding Laboratory, Osaka, Japan; HCMC University of Technology and Education, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam

Abstract: In this work, the miniature tensile sample of polyamide 6 (PA6) is produced by using the ultrasonic injection molding process. The ultrasonic horns vibrating at 20 kHz in both cases of half wave length and full wave length are designed by finite element method. Aluminum 7075 alloy is used for fabricating the ultrasonic horn. The injection mold of miniature parts was designed and manufactured for producing the tensile samples with PA6. Heater is also inserted in the injection mold for controlling the temperature of the injection mold. As a result, the miniature products are successfully obtained by ultrasonic injection molding. The major parameters of pressure, ultrasonic applying time, holding time and mold temperature are utilized at 0.2 MPa, 2 s, 5 s, 60 °C, respectively. Some ultrasonic molding process parameters and its interactive parameters such as pressure, ultrasonic applying time, holding time and molding temperature were also investigated. The Pareto chart expresses that the pressure and mold temperature are the two factors that have the most influence on the tensile strength. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Non-submerged attached growth process for domestic wastewater treatment: Influence of media types and internal recirculation ratios
Affiliations: Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Gwangju Institute of Science and Technology, Gwangju, South Korea; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; University of Technology Sydney, Sydney, Australia; National Chung Hsing University, Taichung, Taiwan; Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, Japan; Graduate School of Biomedical Sciences, Nagasaki, Japan; Asian Institute of Technology Thailand, Khlong Luang, Thailand; Gujarat Pollution Control Board, Gandhinagar, India; IHE Delft Institute for Water Education, Delft, Netherlands

Abstract: This study is aimed to comprehend the treatment of non-submerged attached growth systems using bio-sponge, bio-cord, and bio-cloth media. Three reactors were set up with internal recirculation ratio of 1 (IR = 1) and similar media surface area. Bio-sponge and bio-cloth reactors showed removal of COD (79 vs. 76%) and NH<inf>4</inf>+–N (78 vs. 73%). While bio-cord treatment was deteriorated due to time-dependent process. Multiple linear regression revealed that alkalinity governed the formation degree of the anaerobic zone in bio-sponges, partially affecting nitrification. Increasing IR from 1 to 3 caused sloughing of the attached biomass and was positively correlated with effluent nitrite nitrogen concentration, indicating the sensitivity of nitrification to spatial distribution effects. In addition, bio-sponge system obtained superior performance at IR of 2 while bio-cloth one might be also an effective media for wastewater treatment if having good durability. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N.T., Nguyen, Ngoc Tinh; N.L., Ngoc, Nguyen Linh
Author full names: Nguyen, Ngoc Tinh (57220023805); Ngoc, Nguyen Linh (57265240600)
Title: The Equation Connecting Boyle’s and Bernoulli’s Laws
Affiliations: Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Tokyo University of Science, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Ngoc Tinh, Institute of Research and Development, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Ngoc, Nguyen Linh, Tokyo University of Science, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: An isothermal process is a basic process which can occur in any kind of system that has some means of regulating the temperature, including highly structured machines, and even living cells. In this paper, the authors propose the equation which demonstrates the relationship between the internal pressure of an isothermal system (with orifices ventilating out) and the velocity of a gas flow field (abides by Bernoulli’s law) that this system is immersed in. Whereby the internal pressure in the system with N compartments is represented by a system of N differential equations with N unknowns. Also, the equation that describes the internal pressure of compartment e (e = 1.N) of the isothermal system included N + M compartments in which the pressure of M compartments take to change initiative (known parameter), also has been established. The equation connecting Boyle’s and Bernoulli’s laws will pave the way for more complex analyses in relevant fields. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Vu, Thai Van (57265417800); Nguyen, Nha Thanh (57208791372); Nguyen, Minh Ngoc Binh (56643831700); Truong, Thien Tich (56156116500); Bui, Tinh Quoc (26032534300)
Title: A Meshfree Method Based on Integrated Radial Basis Functions for 2D Hyperelastic Bodies
Affiliations: Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Vu, Thai Van, Department of Engineering Mechanics, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Nha Thanh, Department of Engineering Mechanics, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Minh Ngoc Binh, Department of Engineering Mechanics, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Truong, Thien Tich, Department of Engineering Mechanics, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Bui, Tinh Quoc, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents a meshfree method based on integrated radial basis functions (iRBF) for hyperelastic bodies with compressible and nearly-incompressible behavior. The neo-Hookean model is used for hyperelastic material and the nonlinear elastic behavior of 2D bodies are simulated under finite deformation state with total Lagrange formulation. In the approximation of field nodes, the present iRBF shape functions are constructed through integration. With the property of damping out or at least containing an inherent inaccuracy, the iRBF produces a greatly improved approximation of its derivatives. Moreover, the meshfree numerical approach shows its advantage to analyze large deformation problems by the feature of “free of mesh”, especially it does not suffer from the volumetric locking. A number of numerical examples are given to compare the results of the proposed method with the reference solutions given by other methods. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: L.X., Bach, Le Xuan; V., van Thanh, Vuong; H., van Bao, Hoang; D., van Truong, Do; N., Tuan Hung, Nguyen
Author full names: Bach, Le Xuan (57264857900); van Thanh, Vuong (36949866300); van Bao, Hoang (57220164014); van Truong, Do (15756283400); Tuan Hung, Nguyen (56912954900)
Title: Electromechanical Properties of Monolayer Sn-Dichalcogenides
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Bach, Le Xuan, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; van Thanh, Vuong, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; van Bao, Hoang, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; van Truong, Do, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tuan Hung, Nguyen, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Abstract: We demonstrate electromechanical properties of monolayer SnX<inf>2</inf> (X = Se, Te) with 1T structure as a function of charge doping using first-principles methods. We indicate that the monolayer SnSe<inf>2</inf> shows a semiconductor-metal transition for the case of heavy electron doping, while SnTe<inf>2</inf> retains the metallic properties under both electron and hole dopings. The actuation strain of SnX<inf>2</inf> in the case of electron doping is significantly higher than those of hole doping. In addition, we also compute the ideal strength and ideal strain of the monolayer SnX<inf>2</inf> under charge doping. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: V., van Thanh, Vuong; N.T., Dung, Nguyen Thuy; L.X., Bach, Le Xuan; D., van Truong, Do; N., Tuan Hung, Nguyen
Author full names: van Thanh, Vuong (36949866300); Dung, Nguyen Thuy (57265257000); Bach, Le Xuan (57264857900); van Truong, Do (15756283400); Tuan Hung, Nguyen (56912954900)
Title: Turning Electronic and Optical Properties of Monolayer Janus Sn-Dichalcogenides By Biaxial Strain
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Authors with affiliations: van Thanh, Vuong, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Dung, Nguyen Thuy, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Bach, Le Xuan, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; van Truong, Do, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tuan Hung, Nguyen, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Abstract: We investigate mechanical, electronic, and optical properties of monolayer Janus SnSTe and SnSeTe with 1T structure under biaxial strain based on first-principles calculations. We find that both SnSTe and SnSeTe are metallics for the unstrain case. SnSTe and SnSeTe become semiconductors at the biaxial strains of 6% and 4%, respectively. The biaxial strain effectively modulates the optical absorption of the monolayer Sn-dichalcogenides. Besides, the theoretical strengths of SnSTe and SnSeTe are also investigated. Our obtained results are helpful for applications in nano-electromechanical, optoelectronic, and photocatalytic devices based on the monolayer SnSTe and SnSeTe. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.H.Y., Tran, Thi Hai Yen; A., Fukuda, Aya; K., Hisatake, Koji
Author full names: Tran, Thi Hai Yen (57225675690); Fukuda, Aya (7201772872); Hisatake, Koji (7004871354)
Title: Noninvasive System for Tracking Naïve Induced Pluripotent Stem Cells During Reprogramming
Affiliations: International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Faculty of Medicine, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tran, Thi Hai Yen, School of Biotechnology, International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Fukuda, Aya, Faculty of Medicine, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Hisatake, Koji, Faculty of Medicine, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: Naïve induced pluripotent stem (iPS) cells are useful for drug development, disease model and regenerative medicine. In female cells, X chromosome reactivation (XCR) is closely linked to the acquisition of naïve iPSCs. To visualize the status of X chromosome in living cells and further analyze XCR mechanism, we established a novel noninvasive detection system of XCR. Here we established female mouse embryonic stem cell (mESC) lines whose allele of both X chromosomes carry each of different fluorescent protein genes [Kusabira Orange (KO) and Enhanced green fluorescent protein (EGFP)]. These mESC clones, initially displaying yellow fluorescence owing to two active X chromosomes, generate chimeric cluster of cells showing either orange or green fluorescence (KO+ or EGFP+), indicating that X chromosome inactivation (XCI) occurs in these mESC clones during differentiation. When the single colored cells were reprogrammed, the iPS colonies displayed yellow (KO+/EGFP+) fluorescence, indicating XCR upon reprogramming. Our work reveals generated female KO+/EGFP+ mESC lines can be used for monitoring X chromosome status during differentiation and/or reprogramming. This novel system is also potential for tracking acquisition of pluripotency of iPSCs during reprogramming and screening for factors or culture conditions which promote this event. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.T., Nhan, Tran Thi; Y., Matuo, Youichirou; M., Abdillah, Maradi; L.W., Wicaksono, Lukas Wisnu; Y., Izumi, Yoshinobu
Author full names: Nhan, Tran Thi (57261667100); Matuo, Youichirou (15053421300); Abdillah, Maradi (57261813800); Wicaksono, Lukas Wisnu (57261667200); Izumi, Yoshinobu (59109220100)
Title: Ascorbic Acid as a Radiation-Protective Agent Against Ionizing Radiation
Affiliations: Electric Power University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; University of Fukui, Fukui, Japan; Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nuclear Energy Regulatory Agency, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Nhan, Tran Thi, Electric Power University, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Research Institute of Nuclear Engineering, University of Fukui, Fukui, Japan, Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Matuo, Youichirou, Research Institute of Nuclear Engineering, University of Fukui, Fukui, Japan; Abdillah, Maradi, Research Institute of Nuclear Engineering, University of Fukui, Fukui, Japan, Nuclear Energy Regulatory Agency, Jakarta, Indonesia; Wicaksono, Lukas Wisnu, Research Institute of Nuclear Engineering, University of Fukui, Fukui, Japan, Nuclear Energy Regulatory Agency, Jakarta, Indonesia; Izumi, Yoshinobu, Research Institute of Nuclear Engineering, University of Fukui, Fukui, Japan
Abstract: Ascorbic acid (AA) is well known as a good radical scavenger and antioxidant. Here, the protection effects of AA against free radicals (mainly hydroxyl radicals) caused by low and high linear energy transfer radiation were examined. In this study, cobalt-60 gamma rays and helium ion beams were used as the sources of ionizing radiation. DNA strand breaks of PUC118 plasmid in the presence and absence of AA were monitored using agarose gel electrophoresis. Moreover, the survival rates of Saccharomyces cerevisiae yeast cells irradiated with different AA concentrations in growing medium were analysed using the linear quadratic survival model. Based on the results of DNA strand break experiments, the yield of strand breaks increased with an increase in absorbed dose. In the presence of AA, the yield of strand breaks decreased with an increase in AA concentration. In other words, the greater the additive concentration, the more effective the radiation-protective agent. On the other hand, in the survival rate experiments, the dependence on additive concentration was not similar to that of the DNA experiments. We consider that the main reason for our observations is the difference in additive concentration between the outside and inside of the cell membrane of yeast cells. These results suggest that AA plays an effective role as a radiation-protective agent for DNA and living cells against free radicals formed by radiation. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N., Hung, Nguyentrong; N.T., Thuy, Nguyen Thanh; L.B., Thuan, Le Ba; D.T.T., Tra, Doan Thi Thu; D., Van Khoai, Do; J.H., Jeon, Jong Hyuk; J., Lee, Jinyoung; R.K., Jyothi, Rajesh Kumar
Author full names: Hung, Nguyentrong (57188694788); Thuy, Nguyen Thanh (57195905591); Thuan, Le Ba (57188706314); Tra, Doan Thi Thu (57189610624); Van Khoai, Do (55630952500); Jeon, Jong Hyuk (57225105077); Lee, Jinyoung (35233901600); Jyothi, Rajesh Kumar (57216781429)
Title: Anhydrous oxygen-free rare earth material preparation and characterization
Affiliations: Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kashiwa, Japan; Korea Institute of Geoscience and Mineral Resources, Daejeon, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Hung, Nguyentrong, Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Thuy, Nguyen Thanh, Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Thuan, Le Ba, Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tra, Doan Thi Thu, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Van Khoai, Do, Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kashiwa, Japan; Jeon, Jong Hyuk, Korea Institute of Geoscience and Mineral Resources, Daejeon, South Korea; Lee, Jinyoung, Korea Institute of Geoscience and Mineral Resources, Daejeon, South Korea; Jyothi, Rajesh Kumar, Korea Institute of Geoscience and Mineral Resources, Daejeon, South Korea
Abstract: The present paper addresses the preparation and characterization of anhydrous oxygen-free rare earth materials, such as terbium fluoride (TbF<inf>3</inf>). The fluorination of terbium oxide (Tb<inf>4</inf>O<inf>7</inf>) by ammonium bifluoride (NH<inf>4</inf>HF<inf>2</inf>) to prepare anhydrous TbF<inf>3</inf> was reported in this work. The parameters affecting fluorination were studied, including the fluorination temperature, excess stoichiometric amount of NH<inf>4</inf>HF<inf>2</inf>, and time for fluorination. The temperatures of Tb<inf>4</inf>O<inf>7</inf> fluorination by NH<inf>4</inf>HF<inf>2</inf> determined by thermogravimetric analysis and differential thermal analysis ranged from 350°C to 500°C. The phase structure of the as-prepared products identified by the X-ray diffraction method was indexed to the orthorhombic phase of TbF<inf>3</inf> [space group: Pnma (no. 62)] that exhibited good accordance with the values in the standard cards JCPDS No. 37-1487 for TbF<inf>3</inf>. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) methods were used to analyze the elemental compositions in the as-prepared products; the fluorine (F) and terbium (Tb) elemental compositions calculated from the [TbF<inf>3</inf>] formula are in good agreement with those calculated from the EDS pattern. The optimum parameters for fluorination were determined from the results, and anhydrous oxygen-free TbF<inf>3</inf> can be used to study the preparation of metallic terbium by the calcinothermic reduction method. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H.T., Vu, Hoa Thi; P.N., Thao, Pham Ngoc; T., Yokawa, Takashi; M., Nishijo, Muneko; T.P., The, Tai Pham; Q.B., Do, Quyet Ba; Y., Nishino, Yoshikazu; H., Nishijo, Hisao
Author full names: Vu, Hoa Thi (57218550488); Thao, Pham Ngoc (56622896900); Yokawa, Takashi (6603547692); Nishijo, Muneko (7004475342); The, Tai Pham (57385977200); Do, Quyet Ba (59662828800); Nishino, Yoshikazu (7102096060); Nishijo, Hisao (7005780854)
Title: Alterations in regional brain regional volume associated with dioxin exposure in men living in the most dioxin-contaminated area in vietnam: Magnetic resonance imaging (mri) analysis using voxel-based morphometry (vbm)
Affiliations: Kanazawa Medical University, Kahoku, Japan; Vietnam Military Medical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Bio-Research Inc., Kobe, Japan; University of Toyama, Faculty of Medicine, Toyama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Vu, Hoa Thi, Department of Public Health, Kanazawa Medical University, Kahoku, Japan; Thao, Pham Ngoc, Biomedical and Pharmaceutical Research Center, Vietnam Military Medical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yokawa, Takashi, Bio-Research Inc., Kobe, Japan; Nishijo, Muneko, Department of Public Health, Kanazawa Medical University, Kahoku, Japan; The, Tai Pham, Biomedical and Pharmaceutical Research Center, Vietnam Military Medical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Do, Quyet Ba, Biomedical and Pharmaceutical Research Center, Vietnam Military Medical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nishino, Yoshikazu, Department of Public Health, Kanazawa Medical University, Kahoku, Japan; Nishijo, Hisao, University of Toyama, Faculty of Medicine, Toyama, Japan
Abstract: To clarify the influence of dioxin exposure on brain morphometry, the present study investigated associations between dioxin exposure at high levels and brain structural irregularities in 32 Vietnamese men. Two exposure markers were used: blood dioxin levels, as a marker of exposure in adulthood, and perinatal dioxin exposure, estimated by maternal residency in a dioxin-contaminated area during pregnancy. All subjects underwent brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans. We analyzed correlations between regional gray matter volumes and blood dioxin levels, and compared regional volumes between men with and without perinatal dioxin exposure using the voxel-based morphometry (VBM) tool from Statistical Parametric Mapping 12 (SPM12). Blood 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin (TCDD) was associated with low volume of the medial temporal pole and fusiform gyrus. Toxic equivalency (TEQ)-PCDDs were correlated with low medial temporal pole volume. However, 1,2,3,4,7,8-HxCDD was associated with high middle frontal gyrus and cerebellum volume. In men with perinatal dioxin exposure, the left inferior frontal gyrus pars orbitalis volume was significantly lower than in those without perinatal exposure. These results suggest that dioxin exposure during the perinatal period and in adulthood may alter regional brain volume, which might lead to cognitive deficits and unusual social emotional behavior in Vietnamese men living in dioxin-contaminated areas. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A., Babu Ganganboina, Akhilesh; M., Dung Nguyen, Manh; T., Hien Luong Nguyen, Thi; E., Prasetyo Kuncoro, Eko; R.A., Doong, Rueyan An
Author full names: Babu Ganganboina, Akhilesh (57897731700); Dung Nguyen, Manh (57896776500); Hien Luong Nguyen, Thi (57896776600); Prasetyo Kuncoro, Eko (57897491800); Doong, Rueyan An (7006956479)
Title: Boron and phosphorus co-doped one-dimensional graphitic carbon nitride for enhanced visible-light-driven photodegradation of diclofenac
Affiliations: Shizuoka University, Shizuoka, Japan; National Tsing Hua University, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Thai Nguyen University of Agriculture and Forestry, Thai Nguyen City, Viet Nam; National Tsing Hua University, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Universitas Airlangga, Surabaya, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Babu Ganganboina, Akhilesh, Shizuoka University, Shizuoka, Japan; Dung Nguyen, Manh, Department of Biomedical Engineering and Environmental Sciences, National Tsing Hua University, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Hien Luong Nguyen, Thi, Advanced Education Office, Thai Nguyen University of Agriculture and Forestry, Thai Nguyen City, Viet Nam; Prasetyo Kuncoro, Eko, Environmental Engineering Program, Universitas Airlangga, Surabaya, Indonesia; Doong, Rueyan An, Institute of Analytical and Environmental Sciences, National Tsing Hua University, Hsinchu, Taiwan, Environmental Engineering Program, Universitas Airlangga, Surabaya, Indonesia
Abstract: In this study, the boron (B) and phosphorous (P) co-doped one-dimensional graphitic carbon nitride (CN) (1D BPCN) photocatalysts with various P loadings have been synthesized by hydrothermal-assisted thermal polymerization method for rapid and efficient photodegradation of diclofenac (DCF) under visible light irradiation. The hydrolysis of melamine produces cyanuric acid during the hydrothermal treatment, and then the layered melamine-cyanuric acid complex serves as the supramolecular unit to form the 1D hexagonal-shaped BPCN after thermal polymerization at 500 °C for 4 h. The B and P heteroatoms can be doped inside the CN framework to form P-N and B-C bonds, resulting in the decrease in electric resistance to accelerate the electron transfer as well as the reduction of hole-electron recombination rate to enhance the photocatalytic activity of BPCN. Addition of 3 mL of phosphoric acid significantly enhances the visible-light-responsive photocatalytic activity of 1D BPCN toward DCF degradation. The photodegradation efficiency and rate of DCF over BPCN is a function of initial DCF concentration, pH and anions. Moreover, the BPCN exhibits an excellent reusability which can be effectively photodegrade DCF for at least 5 consecutive cycles. The reactive species of h+ and O<inf>2</inf>−• play an crucial role in the enhanced photodegradation of DCF, and, therefore, the plausible reaction mechanism and pathway for DCF photodegradation over 1D BPCN are proposed. These results clearly demonstrate that the BPCN is a superior visible-light-driven photocatalyst, and can pave a gateway to develop metal-free 1D nanocatalysts for the photodecomposition of emerging pollutants in water and wastewater. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Polyacrylonitrile nanofibers containing viroblock as promising material for protective clothing
Affiliations: National Textile University Faisalabad, Faisalabad, Pakistan; Shinshu University, Matsumoto, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Alkaram Textile Mills Pvt. Ltd., Karachi, Pakistan; National Textile University Faisalabad, Faisalabad, Pakistan
Authors with affiliations: Hussain, Mujtaba, Department of Textile & Clothing, National Textile University Faisalabad, Faisalabad, Pakistan; Salam, Abdul, Department of Textile & Clothing, National Textile University Faisalabad, Faisalabad, Pakistan; Arain, Muhammad Fahad, Department of Textile & Clothing, National Textile University Faisalabad, Faisalabad, Pakistan; Ullah, Azeem, Shinshu University, Matsumoto, Japan; Dao, Anh Tuan, School of Textile-Leather and Fashion, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vu-Manh, Hai, School of Textile-Leather and Fashion, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Phan, Duynam, School of Textile-Leather and Fashion, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ansari, Aamir Shabbir, Alkaram Textile Mills Pvt. Ltd., Karachi, Pakistan; Khan, Muhammad Qamar, Department of Textile & Clothing, National Textile University Faisalabad, Faisalabad, Pakistan; Javed, Zafar, Department of Design, National Textile University Faisalabad, Faisalabad, Pakistan
Abstract: Antimicrobial viroblock/polyacrylonitrile nanofiber webs fabricated using the electro-spinning method were assessed in terms of the antimicrobial activity against infectious agents as a potential material used in mask production. Viroblock (VB) is an amalgam of lipid vesicle and silver. Lipid vesicle depletes the virus outer membrane, which contains cholesterol, while silver ions penetrate the virus, interact with sulfur-bearing moieties, and possess the virus bactericidal property. VB, having anti-coronavirus and anti-influenza properties, was prepared in four different concentrations, 0.5 wt%, 1 wt%, 1.5 wt%, and 2 wt%, in regard to nanofiber weight. The resultant nanofibers were characterized by scanning electron microscope (SEM), Fourier transform infrared (FTIR), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), water contact angle, water content, and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). Moreover, all nanofibrous samples were evaluated for cell proliferation assay and ATCC antibacterial tests. Based on characterization results and cytotoxicity, the developed composite nanofibers-based webs showed good promise for utilization in anti-viral masks. Particularly, 2 wt% VB/PAN nanofibers have the highest antibacterial properties against negative and positive bacteria along with excellent cell viability. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Antimicrobial; Antiviral; Cell Viability; Nanofibers; Viroblock

Title: One-pot upgrading of coconut coir lignin over high-efficiency Ni2P catalysts
Affiliations: Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Wuhan University, Wuhan, China; Hirosaki University, Hirosaki, Japan; Hirosaki University, Hirosaki, Japan; Synchrotron Light Research Institute (SLRI), Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand; Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Dại học Nguyen Tat Thanh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Panpian, Pattreeya, Department of Chemistry, Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Pham, Le Kim Hoang, Department of Chemistry, Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand, Dại học Nguyen Tat Thanh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kongparakul, Suwadee, Department of Chemistry, Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand, Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Ding, Mingyue, Wuhan University, Wuhan, China; Wang, Peifen, Graduate School of Science and Technology, Hirosaki University, Hirosaki, Japan; Guan, Guoqing, Institute of Regional Innovation, Hirosaki University, Hirosaki, Japan; Chanlek, Narong, Synchrotron Light Research Institute (SLRI), Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand; Poo-Arporn, Yingyot, Synchrotron Light Research Institute (SLRI), Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand; Reubroycharoen, Prasert, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Samart, Chanatip, Department of Chemistry, Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand, Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand
Abstract: The utilization of lignin as a source of phenolic compounds requires highly efficient and selective depolymerization catalysts. Herein, lignin depolymerization was investigated over Ni<inf>2</inf>P catalysts supported on nitrogen-doped activated carbon (Ni<inf>2</inf>P/AC_N). The catalysts were prepared by an incipient wetness co-impregnation method followed by reduction with H<inf>2</inf> gas. The presence of nitrogen-containing functional groups on the activated carbon surface resulted in the dispersion of Ni<inf>2</inf>P particles. The good distribution and small crystal size of Ni<inf>2</inf>P significantly increased the active surface area, which enhanced both the catalytic activity and phenol selectivity. Investigations of the catalytic activity at different reaction temperatures and lignin-to-catalyst ratios using pyrolysis–gas chromatography/mass spectrometry revealed that the highest phenol selectivity of 80% was achieved using the Ni<inf>2</inf>P/AC_N25% catalyst. The proposed reaction mechanism involves lignin depolymerization via C–O and C–C cleavage with subsequent phenol formation by demethoxylation. Owing to its high phenol selectivity, the Ni<inf>2</inf>P/AC_N catalyst has good potential for the transformation of lignin to phenol. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Pyrite biomining proficiency of sulfur dioxygenase (SDO) enzyme extracted from Acidithiobacillus thiooxidans
Affiliations: Adhiyamaan Educational Research Institute, Hosur, India; Periyar University, Salem, India; Periyar University, Salem, India; College of Sciences, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia; National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan; Saveetha Dental College And Hospitals, Chennai, India; Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Mathiyazhagan, Narayanan, MGR College, Adhiyamaan Educational Research Institute, Hosur, India; Natarajan, D., Department of Biotechnology, Periyar University, Salem, India; Kandasamy, Sabariswaran, Department of Environmental Sciences, Periyar University, Salem, India; Arunachalam, C., Department of Botany and Microbiology, College of Sciences, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia; Ali Alharbi, Sulaiman, Department of Botany and Microbiology, College of Sciences, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia; Karuppusamy, Indira, Corrosion Resistant Steel Group, National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan; Kathirvel, Brindhadevi, Department of Pharmacology, Saveetha Dental College And Hospitals, Chennai, India, Institute of Research and Development, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Abstract: Minerals are the most important content for many organisms, including humans. Secondary pollution is produced as a result of chemical-based element extraction. Thus, an eco-friendly approach to extracting elements from various ores is an urgent requirement. Hence, the purpose of this study is to evaluate the biomining potential of Acidithiobacillus thiooxidans (pre isolated) and their enzyme involved in the elements solubilization process using the biomining concept. According to the findings, the previously identified A. thiooxidans from bauxite mine tailings have reasonable biomining competence and produced sulfur as a core element and iron as a byproduct from powder for pyrite ore. Under optimal biomining reaction conditions (culture density 5 × 105, pH 4, 30 °C, and 80 h) the A. thiooxidans produced the 8.7 and 4.2 mg mL−1 of sulfur and iron from pyrite ore, respectively. Furthermore, the enzyme responsible for this biomining potential in A. thiooxidans was extracted and identified as sulfur dioxygenase (SDO) with a molecular weight of about 26 kDa using SDS PAGE analysis. Through the oxidation process, the extracted SDO leached the sulfur and produced 4. 9 mg of sulfite after 30 min of biomining. These findings suggested that A. thiooxidans and their intracellular enzyme SDO enzyme could be useful for using in the biomining process on pyrite ore as an environmentally friendly approach. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Q.D., Nguyen, Quoc Dinh; T., Shikina, Tomoaki; D., Teruya, Daichi; S., Hotta, Seiji; H.D., Han, Huy Dung; H., Nakajo, Hironori
Author full names: Nguyen, Quoc Dinh (57650604800); Shikina, Tomoaki (57353471400); Teruya, Daichi (57216847023); Hotta, Seiji (55566812500); Han, Huy Dung (35194086300); Nakajo, Hironori (7003534476)
Title: Leveraging expert knowledge for label noise mitigation in machine learning
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Quoc Dinh, School of Electronics and Telecommunications, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Shikina, Tomoaki, Department of Computer and Information Science, Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Japan; Teruya, Daichi, Department of Computer and Information Science, Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Japan; Hotta, Seiji, Department of Computer and Information Science, Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Japan; Han, Huy Dung, School of Electronics and Telecommunications, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nakajo, Hironori, Department of Computer and Information Science, Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Japan
Abstract: In training-based Machine Learning applications, the training data are frequently labeled by non-experts and expose substantial label noise which greatly alters the training models. In this work, a novel method for reducing the effect of label noise is introduced. The rules are created from expert knowledge to identify the incorrect non-expert training data. Using the gradient descent algorithm, the violating data samples are weighted less to mitigate their effects during model training. The proposed method is applied to the image classification problem using Manga109 and CIFAR-10 dataset. The experiments show that when the noise level is up to 50% our proposed method significantly increases the accuracy of the model compared to conventional learning methods. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Label Noise; Noise Datasets; Prior Knowledge; Weighting Training Data

Title: Rice Husk Valorization into NiO@SiO2/Carbon Nanocomposites for Low-Temperature CO Oxidation: Effect of Surface Area and Ni3+Cations
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tokyo Metropolitan University, Hachioji, Japan; Universidad de Córdoba, Cordoba, Spain; RUDN University, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Dien, Luong Xuan, School of Chemical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Research Center for Gold Chemistry, Tokyo Metropolitan University, Hachioji, Japan; Luque, Rafael L., Campus de Rabanales, Universidad de Córdoba, Cordoba, Spain, RUDN University, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: NiO was synthesized in the presence of a 3D porous nanostructured SiO2/carbon composite derived from rice husk via a hydrothermal method to produce NiO@SiO2/C nanostructures with good microstructural and morphological properties and high catalytic activity. Textural properties and physicochemical characteristics of the materials could be modified by the addition of varying amounts of hydrocarbonized rice husk. The as-prepared NiO@SiO2/C catalysts obtained in the presence of hydrocarbonized rice husk exhibited optimum CO oxidation; i.e., T50 (50% conversion) is at 80 °C (for NiO at 205 °C). © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Lab-scale experiments for soil cementing through bio-chemical process
Affiliations: Tokyo University of Science, Tokyo, Japan; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ho Chi Minh City University of Industry and Trade, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Huynh, Nguyen Ngoc Tri, Department of Architecture, Tokyo University of Science, Tokyo, Japan, Faculty of Materials Technology, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tu, Trananh, Faculty of Materials Technology, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Huyen, Nguyen Pham Huong, Department of Biotechnology, Ho Chi Minh City University of Industry and Trade, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Khanh Son,
Abstract: Ureolytic bacteria strains of Bacillus show its ability of calcium carbonate precipitation through metabolic activity. Different studies related to self-healing concrete material were reported associated with the generated calcium carbonate of Bacillus subtilis HU58 metabolism in recent communications. In this paper, recent findings of soil cementing with a combination of such precipitated products were presented. The experiments relied on the lab-scale studies with the use of sand-clay mixture as the controlled soil specimens. Bacillus bacteria and nutrients were mixed to introduce in the sand matrix and then curing in high moisture condition. The composition and morphology of soil specimens were characterized after solidifying by FTIR, XRD, and SEM. Water percolation and mechanical stability for the physicomechanical properties were also tested with the unconventional method. Discussing the relevant results can help to figure out the next experiments in the field of geotechnical engineering. From the perspective of this study, the sustainability factor should be considered to apply this promising technique for soil stabilization and improvement and/or for the formulation of bio-brick as an alternative to sintered clay-based brick. From the perspective of this study, this technique for soil stabilization and improvement and/or for the formulation of bio-brick can be considered a promising sustainable alternative to sintered clay-based brick. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Bacillus Subtilis Metabolism; Bio-cementation; Microbially Induced Caco3 Precipitation; Soil Improvement

Authors: T., Le, Thaihung; V.S., Le, Van Son; Q., Dang, Quockhanh; M.T., Nguyen, Minh Thuyet; T.K., Le, Trung Kien; B., Ngoc-Tam, Bui
Author full names: Le, Thaihung (57851399500); Le, Van Son (57274094700); Dang, Quockhanh (57223874383); Nguyen, Minh Thuyet (57189032560); Le, Trung Kien (57222326926); Ngoc-Tam, Bui (57212681073)
Title: Microstructure evaluation and thermal–mechanical properties of abs matrix composite filament reinforced with multi-walled carbon nanotubes by a single screw extruder for fdm 3d printing
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Le, Thaihung, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le, Van Son, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Dang, Quockhanh, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Minh Thuyet, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le, Trung Kien, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ngoc-Tam, Bui, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, College of Systems Engineering and Science, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: This paper reports the synthesis of a new printable ABS–MWCNT composite filament, for use in fused deposition modeling (FDM), using an extrusion technique. Acrylonitrile butadiene styrene (ABS) and multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) were the initial materials used for fabricating the filaments. The MWCNTs were dispersed in ABS resin, then extruded through a single-shaft extruder in filament form, with MWCNT contents of 0.5%, 1%, 1.5%, 2%, 3% or 4% by weight. After extrusion, the diameter of the filaments was about 1.75 mm, making them appropriate for FDM. The as-synthesized filaments were then used in FDM to print out samples, on which tensile tests and other analyses were carried out. The results demonstrate that the sample with 2% MWCNTs had the highest strength value, 44.57 MPa, comprising a 42% increase over that of the pure ABS sample. The morphology and dispersion of MWCNTs in the composite were observed by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), demonstrating the uniform distribution of MWCNTs in the ABS matrix. The thermal behavior results indicated no significant change in the ABS structure; however, the melt flow index of the filaments decreased with an increase in the MWCNT content. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: 3d Printing; Abs; Composite Filament; Fdm; Multi-walled Carbon Nanotubes (mwcnts)

Title: Development of a photo-baffled reactor for microalgae-nitrifying bacteria consortia: Achieving long-term, stable partial nitrification
Affiliations: Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; National Institute of Technology, Anan College, Anan, Japan; Showa Kogyo Co. Authors with affiliations: Watari, T., Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan, Department of Chemical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Fukushima, Yoshiki, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Miwa, Toru, Department of Science of Technology Innovation, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Hirakata, Yuga, Department of Science of Technology Innovation, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan, Bioproduction Research Institute, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Kawakami, Shuji, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, National Institute of Technology, Anan College, Anan, Japan; Nakamura, Yoshinobu, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan, Showa Kogyo Co. LTD, Yurihonjyo, Japan; Hatamoto, M., Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Yamaguchi, Takashi, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan, Department of Science of Technology Innovation, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan
Abstract: In this study, a photo-baffled reactor was operated to assess the performance of microalgal-nitrifying bacteria consortia in treating ammonia with its input concentration up to 180 mg-N·L−1. The six-compartment reactor, with a total effective volume of 3.2 L, was run continuously for 350 days at 30 °C. Overall, 66 ± 11% of ammonia was removed at a nitrogen loading rate of 0.083 ± 0.011 kg-N·m−3·day−1. In addition, long-term, stable partial nitrification was confirmed with nitrite concentration of 60 ± 26 mg-N·L−1 in effluent. On days 200 and 350, due to inhibition from the nitrite-oxidizing bacteria (NOB) activity, the dissolved oxygen and the free ammonia concentration was recorded as low as 0.3–0.7 mg·L−1 and 14–24 mg-N·L−1 in each column, respectively. The special configuration of the photo-baffled reactor created a competitive environment between Chlorella vulgaris and nitrifying bacteria. The microbial community structure of the retained sludge indicated that although detected at only 2–3% upstream, ammonia-oxidizing bacteria Nitrosomonas europaea increased downstream of the reactor. Meanwhile, the detection rate of NOB was less than 0.05% in each column and based on quantitative polymerase chain reaction analysis, NOB growth was inhibited. Therefore, these microalgae-nitrifying bacteria consortia have the potential to be a novel partial nitrification process for post-treatment using the anammox process. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Enabling the fast lithium storage of large-scalable γ-Fe2O3/Carbon nanoarchitecture anode material with an ultralong cycle life
Source title: Journal of Industrial and Engineering Chemistry
Affiliations: Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing, China; Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, China; Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Jerome J. Lohr College of Engineering, Brookings, United States; Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Imam Abdulrahman Bin Faisal University, Dammam, Saudi Arabia
Authors with affiliations: Ullah, Sadeeq, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing, China; Campéon, Benoît Denis Louis, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan, Research Core for Interdisciplinary Sciences, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Ibraheem, Shumaila, Institute for Advanced Study, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, China; Yasin, Ghulam, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing, China, Institute for Advanced Study, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, China; Pathak, Rajesh, Center for Advanced Photovoltaics and Sustainable Energy, Jerome J. Lohr College of Engineering, Brookings, United States; Nishina, Yuta, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan, Research Core for Interdisciplinary Sciences, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Nguyen, Tuan Anh, Institute for Tropical Technology, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Slimani, Yassine Abdelhamid, Department of Biophysics, Imam Abdulrahman Bin Faisal University, Dammam, Saudi Arabia; Yuan, Qipeng, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing, China
Abstract: Two-dimensional (2D) materials are generally expected to have superior lithium-ion (LIBs) performances compare with their bulk counterpart as they display superior specific surface area. In this context, the development of 2D maghemite would be of great interest owing to its high theoretical specific capacity, natural abundance, and relatively low cost and toxicity; however, maghemite do not have a layered crystalline structure. Herein, to overcome this hindrance, γ-Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> has been enclosed within a 2D carbon matrix via a simple and facile synthesis strategy based on the complexation of ethylene glycol with aqueous iron species by hydrolysis and condensation reactions followed by its carbonization. As obtained 2D carbon γ-Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> nanosheet composite (C<inf>EG</inf>-Fe) is composed of 41.3 wt.% carbon and 10.2 wt.% Fe. When used as anode materials in LIBs, C<inf>EG</inf>-Fe demonstrated the enhanced initial discharge capacity of 1589 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1, and outstanding ultralong cycling performance with the significant stable capacity of 700 mAh g−1 and 230 mAh g−1 at the higher current rate of 0.5 A g−1 and 10 A g−1 for more than 300 and 6000 cycles, respectively. These results enable a promising avenue to design the large-scale production of 2D C<inf>EG</inf>-Fe sheets-based nanostructured anode materials for next-generation LIBs for large‐scale energy storage applications. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Nguyen, Thi Kieu Trang (57351720400); Dao, Quang Khai (59429797100); Tanaka, Daisuke (55208073700); Nghiem, Lien Thi Ha (56998460600); Nguyen, Minh Viet (55235210400); Nguyen, Zoom Hoang (36814100600); Pham, Tien Thanh (57208742629)
Title: Flexible, affordable and environmentally sustainable solar vapor generation based on ferric tannate/bacterial cellulose composite for efficient desalination solutions
Affiliations: Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; National Institute of Technology, Oita College, Oita, Japan; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Physics and Electronics, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Thi Kieu Trang, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Dao, Quang Khai, Soft Matter and Biological Physics Center, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tanaka, Daisuke, Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, National Institute of Technology, Oita College, Oita, Japan; Nghiem, Lien Thi Ha, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Physics and Electronics, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Minh Viet, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Zoom Hoang, Soft Matter and Biological Physics Center, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Pham, Tien Thanh, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Desalination by solar steam generation (SSG) system is a green technology to produce pure water, which can address the issue of water scarcity. A novel photothermal material for the SSG system was fabricated by immersing bacterial cellulose (BC) sequentially into tannic acid (TA) and iron(iii) (Fe3+) solutions. Surface analysis of the resulting BC-TA-Fe3+ (BTF) material showed that coordination nanocomplexes between Fe3+ and hydroxyl groups of TA were formed on the surface of cellulose nanofibers. BTF material exhibited high sunlight absorption (∼95%), hydrophilic, self-cleaning properties, and excellent structural stability. SSG systems based on BTF had an evaporation efficiency of 91% and an evaporation rate of 1.56 kg m-2 h-1 under 1 sun illumination. Then, an efficient desalination device based on the larger-scale BTF material was fabricated to produce freshwater, the amount of freshwater per day was 5.6 kg m-2 on a sunny day. BTF material, thus, showed great potential in seawater desalination applications along with simple, versatile, scalable, and affordable fabrication methods. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M.T., Nguyen, Minh Truong; T., Vu, Tienthuy; Q.N., Nguyen, Quang Ngoc
Author full names: Nguyen, Minh Truong (57218913217); Vu, Tienthuy (57218910633); Nguyen, Quang Ngoc (56725044800)
Title: Advanced digital 3d technology in the combined surgery-first orthognathic and clear aligner orthodontic therapy for dentofacial deformity treatment
Affiliations: Hanoi Medical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hanoi Medical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Ha Noi National Hospital of Odonto-stomatology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Minh Truong, School of Odonto Stomatology, Hanoi Medical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Hanoi Medical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vu, Tienthuy, Dental Biomaterials Science Program, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand, Department of Endodontics, Ha Noi National Hospital of Odonto-stomatology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Quang Ngoc, Department of Computer Science and Communications Engineering, Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Orthognathic surgery and orthodontic treatment are required for patients with dentofacial deformities to obtain an ideal facial esthetic with good functioning. Recently, characterized by the surgery-first approach, an integrated orthodontic–surgical treatment has been introduced as an emerging solution to dentofacial deformity treatment. The surgery-first approach is regarded to have less treatment time and quicker enhancement of a facial profile than the conventional orthodontic– surgical treatment. Moreover, the recent advances in computing and imaging have allowed the adoption of 3-dimensional (3D) virtual planning protocols in orthognathic surgery as well as digital orthodontic treatment, which enables a paradigm shift when realizing virtual planning properly. These techniques then allow the surgeon and orthodontist to collaborate, plan, and simulate the dentofacial deformity treatment before performing the whole procedure. Along this line, in this research article, we present an integrated treatment method for the realization of an effective deformity treatment. Specifically, we implemented the integrated 3D technique by combining it with the surgery-first orthognathic approach (SFOA) as a novel treatment method for the patients. The outcomes from the combined treatments of the patients with dentofacial deformity, in practice, have demonstrated that our proposed 3D technique in orthognathics and orthodontics using clear aligner therapy (e.g., Invisalign) can enhance the satisfactory level of the patient since the start of treatment then improve their quality of life. As a result, the combined techniques realize the novel integrated treatment method using 3D technology with the use of 3D imaging and modeling as a promising development trend of dentistry, which fits into the context of Dentistry 4.0 as a key enabler to the concept of sustainable dentistry development. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: 3d Deformity Treatment; Clear Aligner; Dentofacial Deformity; Digital Orthodontic; Surgery-first Orthognathic Approach (sfoa)

Authors: S., Fujikura, Shuichi; M.H., Nguyen, Minh Hai; S., Baba, Shotaro; H., Fujiwara, Hiromi; H., Tategami, Hisao; H., Murai, Hiroyasu
Author full names: Fujikura, Shuichi (57213377199); Nguyen, Minh Hai (56303576700); Baba, Shotaro (57250309100); Fujiwara, Hiromi (55054124200); Tategami, Hisao (6507172051); Murai, Hiroyasu (57250420200)
Title: Development of narrow loop joint for precast concrete slabs with fiber-reinforced mortar: Experimental investigation of material properties and flexural behavior of joint
Affiliations: Utsunomiya University, Utsunomiya, Japan; University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Ltd., Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Fujikura, Shuichi, Department of Civil Engineering and Regional Design, Utsunomiya University, Utsunomiya, Japan; Nguyen, Minh Hai, Faculty of Road and Bridge Engineering, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Baba, Shotaro, Department of Civil Engineering and Regional Design, Utsunomiya University, Utsunomiya, Japan; Fujiwara, Hiromi, Department of Civil Engineering and Regional Design, Utsunomiya University, Utsunomiya, Japan; Tategami, Hisao, Ltd., Tokyo, Japan; Murai, Hiroyasu, Ltd., Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: In the replacement of the reinforced concrete slab in existing steel girder bridges, a loop joint is commonly used to join precast concrete slabs on site. However, a relatively wide joint is needed, and considerable time and effort are consumed to construct the joint due to the addition of transverse reinforcements to the joint on site. These disadvantages affect the progress of on-site construction and should be addressed, especially when this method is applied to highway bridges, where early traffic opening is necessary in many cases. This study proposes a narrow loop joint that has fiber-reinforced mortar without transverse reinforcements. Several material tests were conducted to determine a suitable material for the joint. A series of flexural loading tests of slabs was conducted to investigate the flexural behavior of the proposed loop joint with the selected material (polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) fibers). The results showed that the flexural capacity and deformation performance of the proposed joint with PVA fibers are equivalent to those of the conventional loop joint. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Fiber-reinforced Mortar; Flexural Loading Test; Loop Joint; Polyvinyl Alcohol Fiber; Precast Concrete Slab

Authors: T.T.T., Truong, Thi Thuy Trang; T.N., Vu, Thi Ngan; T.D., Dinh, Thi Diu; T.T., Pham, Thu Thao; T.A.H., Nguyen, Thi Anh Huong; M.H., Nguyen, Manh Ha; D.T., Nguyen, Dung The; S., Yusa, Shinichi; T.D., Pham, Tien Duc
Author full names: Truong, Thi Thuy Trang (57343828700); Vu, Thi Ngan (57193665338); Dinh, Thi Diu (57683252500); Pham, Thu Thao (57660271700); Nguyen, Thi Anh Huong (56305502400); Nguyen, Manh Ha (57193668885); Nguyen, Dung The (57203611919); Yusa, Shinichi (7003732650); Pham, Tien Duc (55797010800)
Title: Adsorptive removal of cefixime using a novel adsorbent based on synthesized polycation coated nanosilica rice husk
Affiliations: Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; University of Hyogo, Kobe, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Truong, Thi Thuy Trang, Department of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vu, Thi Ngan, Department of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Dinh, Thi Diu, Department of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Pham, Thu Thao, Department of Applied Chemistry, University of Hyogo, Kobe, Japan; Nguyen, Thi Anh Huong, Department of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Manh Ha, Department of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Dung The, Department of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yusa, Shinichi, Department of Applied Chemistry, University of Hyogo, Kobe, Japan; Pham, Tien Duc, Department of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: We report the first study of adsorption of a strong polycation, poly(3-methacryloylamino propyl-trimethylammonium chloride) (PMAPTAC) on nanosilica (nano-SiO<inf>2</inf>) extracted from rice husk. PMAPTAC was successfully synthesized and characterized by 1H-nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) and gel-permeation chromatography (GPC) methods. PMAPTAC characteristics were found to be M<inf>n</inf> = 1.61 × 105, M<inf>w</inf> = 2.16 × 106, M<inf>w</inf>/M<inf>n</inf> = 13.4. Beta-lactam cefixime (CEF) removal was dramatically enhanced after polymer coating by pre-adsorption of PMAPTAC on nano-SiO<inf>2</inf>. The new adsorbent was dubbed PMAPTAC coated nano-SiO<inf>2</inf> (PCNS). Required time for adsorption, PCNS dosage, pH, and KCl concentration were thoroughly optimized for CEF removal and achieved at 120 min, 10 mg/mL, 4, and 1 mM, respectively. A two-step model can be used to fit the PMAPTAC on nano-SiO<inf>2</inf> and CEF on PCNS isotherms at different ionic strengths. Adsorption kinetics of CEF on PCNS appears to be pseudo-second-order. CEF removal using PCNS reached 89%, saturating at 10.9 mg/g. The driving force for CEF adsorption on PCNS was primarily Coulombic interaction of negative CEF species and positive surface charge of PCNS. After three reuses, CEF elimination was still greater than 85%. The influence of some organics on CEF treatment using PCNS was insignificant while CEF removal from a real hospital wastewater sample was greater than 70%. Our study indicates that a hybrid and new adsorbent based on nano-SiO<inf>2</inf> rice husk with pre-adsorption with PMAPTAC is useful for antibiotic removal from wastewater. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Adsorption; Cefixime; Coating, Nanosilica; Pmaptac; Chlorine Compounds; Gel Permeation Chromatography; Ionic Strength; Nuclear Magnetic Resonance; Plastic Coatings; Potassium Compounds; Silica; Wastewater Treatment; Adsorptive Removal; Cefixime; Coating, Nanosilicum; Nano Silica; Nano-sio$-2$; Poly(3-methacryloylamino Propyl-trimethylammonium Chloride); Polycations; Pre-adsorption; Rice Husk; Synthesised; Adsorption

Authors: B., van Nguyen, Bach; X., Yang, Xiaojing; S., Hirayama, Shota; J., Wang, Jixiang; Z., Zhao, Ziwen; Z., Lei, Zhongfang; K., Shimizu, Kazuya; Z., Zhang, Zhenya; S.X., Le, Sinh Xuan
Author full names: van Nguyen, Bach (57227448900); Yang, Xiaojing (57203163181); Hirayama, Shota (57222228499); Wang, Jixiang (57191205000); Zhao, Ziwen (57034523100); Lei, Zhongfang (22941688400); Shimizu, Kazuya (55330289100); Zhang, Zhenya (8227998500); Le, Sinh Xuan (57228359000)
Title: Effect of salinity on cr(Vi) bioremediation by algal-bacterial aerobic granular sludge treating synthetic wastewater
Affiliations: University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: van Nguyen, Bach, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan, Institute of Marine Environment and Resources, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yang, Xiaojing, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Hirayama, Shota, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Wang, Jixiang, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Zhao, Ziwen, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Lei, Zhongfang, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Shimizu, Kazuya, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Zhang, Zhenya, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Le, Sinh Xuan, Institute of Marine Environment and Resources, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Heavy metal-containing wastewater with high salinity challenges wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) where the conventional activated sludge process is widely applied. Bioremediation has been proven to be an effective, economical, and eco-friendly technique to remove heavy metals from various wastewaters. The newly developed algal-bacterial aerobic granular sludge (AGS) has emerged as a promising biosorbent for treating wastewater containing heavy metals, especially Cr(VI). In this study, two identical cylindrical sequencing batch reactors (SBRs), i.e., R1 (Control) and R2 (with 1% additional salinity), were used to cultivate algal-bacterial AGS and then to evaluate the effect of salinity on the performance of the two SBRs. The results reflected that less filamentation and a rougher surface could be observed on algal-bacterial AGS when exposed to 1% salinity, which showed little influence on organics removal. However, the removals of total inorganic nitrogen (TIN) and total phosphorus (TP) were noticeably impacted at the 1% salinity condition, and were further decreased with the co-existence of 2 mg/L Cr(VI). The Cr(VI) removal efficiency, on the other hand, was 31–51% by R1 and 28–48% by R2, respectively, indicating that salinity exposure may slightly influence Cr(VI) bioremediation. In addition, salinity exposure stimulated more polysaccharides excretion from algal-bacterial AGS while Cr(VI) exposure promoted proteins excretion. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Algal-bacterial Aerobic Granular Sludge; Bioremediation; Hexavalent Chromium; Salinity; Wastewater Treatment

Title: Preparation and desalination performance of PA/UiO-66/PES composite membranes
Affiliations: Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Universität Witten/Herdecke, Witten, Germany; Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Trinh, Daixuan, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Pham, Ngo Nghia Q., Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Institute of Environmental Engineering and Management, Universität Witten/Herdecke, Witten, Germany; Chammingkwan, Patchanee, Graduate School of Advanced Science and Technology, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Taniike, Toshiaki, Graduate School of Advanced Science and Technology, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan
Abstract: UiO-66 nanoparticles are considered highly potential fillers for the application in desalination membranes. In this study, UiO-66 nanoparticles were anchored to PES membrane substrates, which were subsequently subjected to the interfacial polymerization reaction to coat a layer of polyamide (PA) on their surface. For comparison, a blank membrane incorporating no UiO-66 and a reference membrane incorporating ZrO<inf>2</inf> (instead of UiO-66) were prepared. All prepared membranes were tested for their desalination performance. The membranes containing UiO-66 were found to outperform the blank and the reference counterparts. The reason for this outperformance is possibly attributed to the hydrophilicity of UiO-66 nanoparticles and the presence of nanochannels in their structure. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Takano, Hirotaka; N., Yoshida, Naohiro; H., Asano, Hiroshi; A., Hagishima, Aya; D.T., Nguyen, Duc Tuyen
Author full names: Takano, Hirotaka (54394480500); Yoshida, Naohiro (57226469259); Asano, Hiroshi (55662621100); Hagishima, Aya (6505814162); Nguyen, Duc Tuyen (58279068400)
Title: Calculation method for electricity price and rebate level in demand response programs
Affiliations: Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Central Research Institute of Electric Power Industry, Chiyoda-ku, Japan; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Takano, Hirotaka, Department of Electrical, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Yoshida, Naohiro, Department of Electrical, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Asano, Hiroshi, Department of Electrical, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan, Energy Innovation Center, Central Research Institute of Electric Power Industry, Chiyoda-ku, Japan; Hagishima, Aya, Department of Internationalization and Future Conception, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Nguyen, Duc Tuyen, Department of Electric Power Systems, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Demand response programs (DRs) can be implemented with less investment costs than those in power plants or facilities and enable us to control power demand. Therefore, they are highly expected as an efficient option for power supply–demand-balancing operations. On the other hand, DRs bring new difficulties on how to evaluate the cooperation of consumers and to decide electricity prices or rebate levels with reflecting its results. This paper presents a theoretical approach that calculates electricity prices and rebate levels in DRs based on the framework of social welfare maximization. In the authors’ proposal, the DR-originated changes in the utility functions of power suppliers and consumers are used to set a guide for DR requests. Moreover, optimal electricity prices and rebate levels are defined from the standpoint of minimal burden in DRs. Through numerical simulations and discussion on their results, the validity of the authors’ proposal is verified. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Demand Response Programs; Electricity Price; Power Supply– Demand Balance; Rebate Level; Social Welfare Maximization; Utility Function
