Title: Application of a similarity measure using fuzzy sets to select the optimal plan for an air-assisted rice seeder
Affiliations: Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hai, Nguyen Thanh, Faculty of Engineering, Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Chosa, Tadashi, Department of Environmental and Agricultural Engineering, Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Japan; Tojo, Seishu, Department of Environmental and Agricultural Engineering, Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Japan; Thi-Hien, Ngo, Faculty of Engineering, Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Air-assisted rice seeders were designed to perform sowing while ensuring the alignment and depth of seeds within the allowable standard range of 5–10 mm. Their performance varies on the basis of different specifications; thus, it is necessary to evaluate them to select the best one. Fuzzy set theory allows us to flexibly handle practical problems, especially applied problems in engineering. In this paper, a new similarity measure using fuzzy sets is proposed, and its advantages were tested using the technique for order preference by similarity to ideal solution (TOPSIS) method to select technical parameters for the sowing machines. The experiments allowed identifying the best results. The correlations between input attributes and decision variables were determined on the basis of their correlation coefficients with technical factors. The influence of technical factors on output results was also examined to determine the technical factors providing superior product quality. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Air-assisted Rice Seeder; Optimal Plan; Rice Direct Seeding; Similarity Measure Of Fuzzy Sets; Sowing Machines

Authors: V.T., Thang, Vu Toan; T.T., Vu, Tung Thanh; V.H., Tran, Van Huong; T., Nguyen, Thanhdong; B., Ngoc-Tam, Bui
Author full names: Thang, Vu Toan (57201677375); Vu, Tung Thanh (57164371400); Tran, Van Huong (56810532500); Nguyen, Thanhdong (57204544922); Ngoc-Tam, Bui (57212681073)
Title: A new method to verify the measurement speed and accuracy of frequency modulated interferometers
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Thang, Vu Toan, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vu, Tung Thanh, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tran, Van Huong, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Thanhdong, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ngoc-Tam, Bui, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, College of Systems Engineering and Science, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The measurement speed and measurement accuracy of a displacement measuring interferometer are key parameters. To verify these parameters, a fast and high-accuracy motion is required. However, the displacement induced by a mechanical actuator generates disadvantageous features, such as slow motion, hysteresis, distortion, and vibration. This paper proposes a new method for a nonmechanical high-speed motion using an electro-optic modulator (EOM). The method is based on the principle that all displacement measuring interferometers measure the phase change to calculate the displacement. This means that the EOM can be used to accurately generate phase change rather than a mechanical actuator. The proposed method is then validated by placing the EOM into an arm of a frequency modulation interferometer. By using two lock-in amplifiers, the phase change in an EOM and, hence, the corresponding virtual displacement could be measured by the interferometer. The measurement showed that the system could achieve a displacement at 20 kHz, a speed of 6.08 mm/s, and a displacement noise level < 100 pm//√ Hz above 2 kHz. The proposed virtual displacement can be applied to determine both the measurement speed and accuracy of displacement measuring interferometers, such as homodyne interferometers, heterodyne interferometers, and frequency modulated interferometers. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Displacement Measuring Interferometer; Electro-optic Modulator; Frequency Modulation

Authors: T.K., Le, Trung Kien; T.T., Nguyen, Thu Thi; B., Ngoc-Tam, Bui
Author full names: Le, Trung Kien (57222326926); Nguyen, Thu Thi (57219407107); Ngoc-Tam, Bui (57212681073)
Title: Experimental modeling of pressure in the hydrostatic formation of a cylindrical cup with different materials
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Le, Trung Kien, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Thu Thi, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ngoc-Tam, Bui, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, College of Systems Engineering and Science, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Forming complex sheet products using hydrostatic forming technology is currently a focus of the majority of forming processes. However, in order to increase stability during the forming process, it is necessary to identify and analyze the dependency of the forming pressure and the quality of a product on input parameters. For the purpose of modeling the forming pressure, this paper presents empirical research on the product of a cylindrical cup made of various materials, including carbon steel (DC04), copper (CDA260), and stainless steel (SUS 304) with different thicknesses (0.8 mm, 1.0 mm, and 1.2 mm), under a defined range of binder pressures. The regression method is selected to formulate an equation that shows the relationship between the input parameters, including the materials (ultimate strength and yield stress), workpiece thickness, binder pressure and the output parameter, and the formation of fluid pressure. The mathematical equation allows us to determine the extent of the effect of each input on the forming pressure. The experimental results can be used for the easier planning and forecasting of the process and product quality in hydrostatic forming. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Experimental Modeling; Forming Pressure; Hydroforming; Regression; Sheet Metal Forming

Authors: P.H., Tuyen, Pham Huu; P., Tuan, Phamminh; K., Yamamoto, Kazuhiro; P., Karin, Preechar
Author full names: Tuyen, Pham Huu (57192914147); Tuan, Phamminh (57216561824); Yamamoto, Kazuhiro (55489382000); Karin, Preechar (35084986500)
Title: Updating emission factors for in-use motorcycles fueled by gasoline, e5 and e10 in Vietnam
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan; King Mongkut's Institute of Technology Ladkrabang, Bangkok, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Tuyen, Pham Huu, Department of Internal Combustion Engine, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tuan, Phamminh, Department of Internal Combustion Engine, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yamamoto, Kazuhiro, Department of Engineering Science and Mechanics, Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan; Karin, Preechar, International College, King Mongkut's Institute of Technology Ladkrabang, Bangkok, Thailand
Abstract: Motorcycle is the most popular transportation means in Vietnam due to its low cost and flexibility. However, motorcycles emit substantial quantities of hydrocarbons, carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides and some amount of particulate matter. Emission factors for in-use motorcycles in Vietnam were studied and established quite a long time ago. The objective of this study is to update the emission factors, not only gaseous emissions but also particle number, for in-use motorcycles in Vietnam. Ten carbureted and electronic fuel injected motorcycles representative for in-use motorcycles were selected for investigation. Each motorcycle was fueled by conventional gasoline, E5 and E10 in turn, and was tested on a chassis dynamometer according to ECE R40 driving cycle. The gaseous emissions were sampled and determined by standard methods, while the particle number in exhaust gas was sampled by using the sampling system developed by Laboratory of Internal Combustion Engine, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Vietnam. The updated emission factors were then provided for carbureted motorcycles, EFI motorcycles and average motorcycle fleet in case of gasoline, E5 and E10 fueling. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: E10; E5; Emission Factors; Exhaust Gas Emissions; Motorcycles; Vietnam

Authors: M.T.T., Ngo, My Thi Tra; T., Ueyama, Tetsuro; R., Makabe, Ryo; X.T., Bui, Xuan Thanh; L.D., Nghiem, Long D.; T.T.V., Nga, Tran Thi Viet; T., Fujioka, Takahiro
Author full names: Ngo, My Thi Tra (57216808798); Ueyama, Tetsuro (57204105782); Makabe, Ryo (57073098100); Bui, Xuan Thanh (58143042800); Nghiem, Long D. (36778460100); Nga, Tran Thi Viet (20635314900); Fujioka, Takahiro (55173146300)
Title: Fouling behavior and performance of a submerged flat-sheet nanofiltration membrane system for direct treatment of secondary wastewater effluent
Affiliations: Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, Japan; Kyowakiden Industry Co., Ltd., Nagasaki, Japan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; University of Technology Sydney, Sydney, Australia; Hanoi University of Civil Engineering, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Ngo, My Thi Tra, Graduate School of Engineering, Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, Japan; Ueyama, Tetsuro, Graduate School of Engineering, Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, Japan, Division of Research and Development, Kyowakiden Industry Co., Ltd., Nagasaki, Japan; Makabe, Ryo, Division of Research and Development, Kyowakiden Industry Co., Ltd., Nagasaki, Japan; Bui, Xuan Thanh, Faculty of Environment and Natural Resources, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Key Laboratory of Advanced Waste Treatment Technology, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nghiem, Long D., University of Technology Sydney, Sydney, Australia; Nga, Tran Thi Viet, Faculty of Environmental Engineering, Hanoi University of Civil Engineering, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Fujioka, Takahiro, Graduate School of Engineering, Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, Japan
Abstract: Direct nanofiltration (NF) of secondary treated effluent can significantly simplify water recycling, especially for small scale operations. This study evaluated the performance of a novel flat-sheet submerged NF membrane module at low water flux to minimize membrane fouling. The separation performance of the NF system was assessed by periodically measuring the color, turbidity, pH, UV light absorbance at the wavelength of 254 nm, and total organic carbon concentrations of the NF feed water and permeate. During the 48-d test, negligible membrane fouling was found when direct NF treatment of secondary wastewater effluent was conducted at a water flux of 3 L/m2h. The trans-membrane pressure increased by less than 0.072 kPa/d. The foulant layer on the membrane surface was readily removed by simple physical cleaning, which suggests that the reversible fouling was the major fouling mechanism. Direct NF treatment achieved high and stable removal of organics (total organic carbon removal of >80 %) during the operation period. This study demonstrated the efficacy of the direct NF treatment using a submerged NF module for achieving stable operations and producing high-quality recycled water. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Advanced Wastewater Treatment; Direct Nanofiltration; Membrane Fouling Mitigation; Non-potable Water Reuse; Water Reclamation

Author full names: Ta, Luong Thi (57224095104); Hamada, Ikutaro (7005614511); Morikawa, Yoshitada (56042230400); Dinh, Van An (6603847411)
Title: Adsorption of toxic gases on borophene: Surface deformation links to chemisorptions
Affiliations: The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam Maritime University, Haiphong, Viet Nam; Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ta, Luong Thi, Department of Precision Engineering, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, Nanotechnology Program, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Chemistry, Vietnam Maritime University, Haiphong, Viet Nam; Hamada, Ikutaro, Department of Precision Engineering, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, Elements Strategy Initiative for Catalysts and Batteries (ESICB), Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Morikawa, Yoshitada, Department of Precision Engineering, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, Elements Strategy Initiative for Catalysts and Batteries (ESICB), Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan, Research Center for Precision Engineering, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Dinh, Van An, Nanotechnology Program, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Center for Atomic and Molecular Technologies, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Abstract: β12 borophene has received great attention because of its intriguing mechanical and electronic properties. One of the possible applications of borophene is gas sensing. However, the interaction between common gases and β12 borophene remains to be clarified. In this work, we study the interactions of β12 borophene towards five hazardous gases, namely, CO, NO, NH3, NO2, and CO2 using various non-empirical van der Waals density functionals and provide an insight into the adsorption behavior of borophene. The adsorption mechanism and molecular vibrations are discussed in great detail. Among the gases considered, CO2 is physisorbed while other gases are chemically bonded to β12 borophene. We also demonstrate that the deformation at the ridge of borophene enables its active pz orbital to strongly hybridize with frontier orbitals of the studied polar gases. Consequently, borophene is predicted to interact strongly with CO, NO, NH3, and especially NO2, making it a sensitive sensing material for toxic gases. Author full names: Lai, Quoc Dat (57216178014); Tagashira, Nobuhiro (25228065400); Hagiwara, Shoji (7102207333); Nakajima, Mitsutoshi (7402943385); Kimura, Toshinori (55664325800); Nabetani, Hiroshi (57207899269)
Title: Influences of technological parameters on cross-flow nanofiltration of cranberry juice
Affiliations: Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; AOHATA Corporation, Hiroshima, Japan; National Agriculture and Food Research Organization, NARO, Tsukuba, Japan; University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Japan; Tokyo Kasei University, Sayama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Lai, Quoc Dat, Department of Food Technology, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tagashira, Nobuhiro, AOHATA Corporation, Hiroshima, Japan; Hagiwara, Shoji, National Agriculture and Food Research Organization, NARO, Tsukuba, Japan; Nakajima, Mitsutoshi, Faculty of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Kimura, Toshinori, Research Faculty of Agriculture, Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Japan; Nabetani, Hiroshi, Tokyo Kasei University, Sayama, Japan
Abstract: The paper focused on the influence of operative conditions on the separation of benzoic acid from 10 °Brix cranberry juice by cross-flow nanofiltration with a plate and frame pilot scale (DDS Lab Module Type 20 system). Six kinds of commercial nanofiltration membrane were investigated. The results showed that the rejection of benzoic acid was significantly lower than that of other components in cranberry juice, including sugars and other organic acids. In a range of 2-7.5 L/min, feed flow rate slightly affected the performance of nanofiltration. Higher temperatures resulted in higher permeate flux and lower rejection of benzoic acid, whereas rejection of sugar and organic acid was stable at a high value. In a range of 2.5-5.5, pH also significantly affected the separation of benzoic acid and negative rejection against benzoic acid was observed at pH 4.5 with some of the membranes. This implies that pH 4.5 is considered as an optimum pH for benzoic acid separation from cranberry juice. The lower permeate flux caused a lower rejection of benzoic acid and negative rejection of benzoic acid was observed at the low permeate flux. Pretreatment by ultrafiltration with CR61PP membranes could improve the permeate flux but insignificantly influenced the efficiency of separation. The results also indicated that NF99 and DK membranes can be effectively used to separate benzoic acid from cranberry juice. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

(57219668903); Xue, Wenchao (36337939600); Avtar, Ram (35885220000); Othman, Mohd Hafiz Dzarfan (57217148784); Shirazian, Saeed (25959724400)
Title: Characterization and applications of Thermomonas hydrothermalis isolated from Jordan's hot springs for biotechnological and medical purposes
Affiliations: Al-Balqa Applied University, Salt, Jordan; German Jordanian University, Amman, Jordan; Xiamen University, Xiamen, China; National Institutes for the Humanities, Research Institute for Humanity and Nature, Kyoto, Japan; The University of Jordan, Amman, Jordan; Asian Institute of Technology Thailand, Khlong Luang, Thailand; Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Japan; Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, Johor Bahru, Malaysia; Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; South Ural State University, Chelyabinsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Al-Daghistani, H. I., Department of Medical Laboratory Sciences, Al-Balqa Applied University, Salt, Jordan; Mohammad, Balsam Talal, Pharmaceutical and Chemical Engineering Department, German Jordanian University, Amman, Jordan; KURNIAWAN, Tonni Agustiono, College of the Environment and Ecology, Xiamen University, Xiamen, China; Singh, Deepak, National Institutes for the Humanities, Research Institute for Humanity and Nature, Kyoto, Japan; Rabadi, Alexander D., School of Medicine, The University of Jordan, Amman, Jordan; Xue, Wenchao, Department of Energetics, Asian Institute of Technology Thailand, Khlong Luang, Thailand; Avtar, Ram, Faculty of Environmental Earth Science, Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Japan; Othman, Mohd Hafiz Dzarfan, Advanced Membrane Technology Research Centre (AMTEC), Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, Johor Bahru, Malaysia; Shirazian, Saeed, Institute of Research and Development, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam, Faculty of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam, Laboratory of Computational Modeling of Drugs, South Ural State University, Chelyabinsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: We identified and investigated the biological activities of Thermomonas hydrothermalis, isolated bacteria strains present in Jordan's hot springs, based on their morphological, biochemical, and physiological characteristics. The colonies exhibited light brown with a diameter ranging from 0.5 to 2.0 mm. For screening their metabolic activities, API 50CHB strips and esculin were used. We phylogenetically typified the isolated bacteria by applying 16S ribosomal DNA gene amplification and sequencing followed by the Basic Local Alignment Search Tool (BLAST) tests. About 100 μL of the enriched sample was streaked on nutrient agar using a calibrated wire loop, while 20 μg crude powder was mixed with dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) to test their activities against standard pathogenic bacterial strains (ATCC). The water samples collected from the hot springs had temperatures ranging between 44–56 °C, pH between 7.11–8.51, and electrical conductivity between 1.06–1.41 ms/cm. To utilize their isolate for characterization and applications, pH, temperature, and generation time were optimized. It was found that the Gram-negative isolated bacteria strain exhibited an optimum growth at 55 °C, pH 8.5, and 30 min of generation time (GT). The BLAST results showed a 99 % of similar identity of the sample to Thermomonas hydrothermalis. Due to their antibacterial effects against Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria, bioactive compounds identified using gas chromatography–mass spectroscopy (GC–MS) had novel features such as 4(3 H)-pyrimidinone, dihydroxy-1,5- naphthyridine, actinomycine-D, and pyrrolo [1,2-a]pyrazine-1,4-dione hygrazides. Screening of cytotoxic activity tests using MTT (3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide) assay was conducted toward their water extract, which exerted cytostimulatory effects on human lung fibroblasts (MRC-5) with an IC<inf>50</inf> of 5.109 μg/mL and accelerated wound closure. Overall, the implications of this study provided new insights into the bioproducts of Thermomonas hydrothermalis and offered opportunities to utilize their isolate for biotechnological and medicinal applications. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: K.L.A., Cao, Kiet Le Anh; A.M., Rahmatika, Annie Mufyda; Y., Kitamoto, Yasuhiko; M.T.T., Nguyen, Mai Thanh Thi; T., Ogi, Takashi
Author full names: Cao, Kiet Le Anh (57215853965); Rahmatika, Annie Mufyda (57190933932); Kitamoto, Yasuhiko (57221534653); Nguyen, Mai Thanh Thi (9634268400); Ogi, Takashi (8927036100)
Title: Controllable synthesis of spherical carbon particles transition from dense to hollow structure derived from Kraft lignin
Source title: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
Affiliations: Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Universitas Gadjah Mada, Yogyakarta, Indonesia; University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Cao, Kiet Le Anh, Graduate School of Advanced Science and Engineering, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Rahmatika, Annie Mufyda, Graduate School of Advanced Science and Engineering, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan, Department of Biotechnology, Universitas Gadjah Mada, Yogyakarta, Indonesia; Kitamoto, Yasuhiko, Graduate School of Advanced Science and Engineering, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Nguyen, Mai Thanh Thi, Faculty of Chemistry, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ogi, Takashi, Graduate School of Advanced Science and Engineering, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan
Abstract: The tailored synthesis of carbon particles with controllable shapes and structures from biomass as a raw material would be highly beneficial to meet the demands of various applications of carbon materials from the viewpoint of sustainable development goals. In this work, the spherical carbon particles were successfully synthesized through a spray drying method followed by the carbonization process, using Kraft lignin as the carbon source and potassium hydroxide (KOH) as the activation agent. As the results, the proposed method successfully controlled the shape and structure of the carbon particles from dense to hollow by adjusting the KOH concentration. Especially, this study represents the first demonstration that KOH plays a crucial role in the formation of particles with good sphericity and dense structures. In addition, to obtain an in-depth understanding of the particle formation of carbon particles, a possible mechanism is also investigated in this article. The resulting spherical carbon particles exhibited dense structures with a specific surface area (1233 m2 g−1) and tap density (1.46 g cm−3) superior to those of irregular shape carbon particles. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Kinetic and structural changes during gasification of cashew nut shell char particles
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Chemistry, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kyushu Institute of Technology, Kitakyushu, Japan; Trường Đại học Giao thông vận tải, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Université de Montpellier, Montpellier, France
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Hong Nam, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Khuong, Duy Anh, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vu, Thi Thu Ha, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Chemistry, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Mai, Thi Nga, Faculty of Environmental Sciences, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tsubota, Toshiki, Department of Applied Chemistry, Kyushu Institute of Technology, Kitakyushu, Japan; Tran, Van Bay, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Trường Đại học Giao thông vận tải, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Blin, Joël, Université de Montpellier, Montpellier, France; Van de steene, L., Université de Montpellier, Montpellier, France
Abstract: Cashew Nut Shell (CNS), an abundant waste from the cashew nut production, could become a promising material for gasification. Nevertheless, engineering data regarding this technology is still small and fragmented. In this study, the evolution of the char textural properties during gasification, as well as the effect of operating conditions on char gasification kinetics were extensively investigated and quantified. The textural properties of cashew nut shell char changed significantly following different pathways between CO<inf>2</inf> and H<inf>2</inf>O gasification. Micropores and mesopores were well developed along with the conversion in the case of H<inf>2</inf>O gasification instead of only micropores in the case of CO<inf>2</inf> gasification. Regarding char gasification kinetics, an increase of the temperature from 800 to 1000°C enhanced five times the conversion rate under an H<inf>2</inf>O atmosphere and 15 times under a CO<inf>2</inf> atmosphere. The conversion rate increased two times when the concentration of reacting gases changed from 20 to 60 vol % for both atmospheres. Similarities in terms of gasification kinetics between CNS chars and wood chip chars were found in this range of operating conditions. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.T.D., Nguyen, Thuy T.D.; D., Dao, Dungvan; D., Kim, Dong-seog; H., Lee, Hujun; S., Oh, Sang-yeob; I., Lee, Inhwan; Y., Yu, Yeontae
Title: Effect of core and surface area toward hydrogen gas sensing performance using Pd@ZnO core-shell nanoparticles
Source title: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
Affiliations: Jeonbuk National University, Jeonju, South Korea; Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Korea University, Seoul, South Korea; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Korea Institute of Carbon Convergence Technology, Jeonju, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Thuy T.D., Division of Advanced Materials Engineering, Jeonbuk National University, Jeonju, South Korea; Dao, Dungvan, Institute of Research and Development, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea University, Seoul, South Korea; Kim, Dong-seog, Division of Advanced Materials Engineering, Jeonbuk National University, Jeonju, South Korea; Lee, Hujun, Department of Materials Physics and Chemistry, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Oh, Sang-yeob, Korea Institute of Carbon Convergence Technology, Jeonju, South Korea; Lee, Inhwan, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea University, Seoul, South Korea; Yu, Yeontae, Division of Advanced Materials Engineering, Jeonbuk National University, Jeonju, South Korea
Abstract: A versatile hydrogen gas sensor is fabricated using Pd@ZnO core-shell nanoparticles (CSNPs), which were synthesized through a hydrothermal route. Effect of oxidation behavior of Pd core to hydrogen sensing is also investigated for Pd@ZnO CSNPs. Accordingly, Pd@ZnO-2 sensor (core-shell sample was calcined in argon) demonstrates the best performance with respect to Pd@ZnO-1 (core-shell sample was calcined in air) and pure ZnO. It shows a much higher response (R = R<inf>a</inf>/R<inf>g</inf> = 22) than those of Pd@ZnO-1 (12) and pure ZnO (7) sensors with faster response and recovery times (1.4 and 7.8 min) to 100 ppm hydrogen at 350 °C. In addition, Pd@ZnO-2 sensor owns high selectivity to hydrogen among interfering target gases. Improvement can be attributed to the high content of metallic Pd0 species in CSNPs as calcined in argon. Thereby, a higher Pd metallic content (77%) still remains in Pd@ZnO-2 compared to Pd@ZnO-1 (56%), which in turn modulates the resistance of sensors as exposed to air and target gas, thus enhancing gas sensing activity. High BET surface area of core-shell materials provides plenty of active sites for accelerating the sensing reactions as well. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M., Wouters, Marly; S., Rahman, Shamaun; H., Myamoto, Hideaki; N.N., Tran, Nam Nghiep; V., Hessel, Volker
Author full names: Wouters, Marly (57208592509); Rahman, Shamaun (57221292659); Myamoto, Hideaki (57221283378); Tran, Nam Nghiep (57220895180); Hessel, Volker (7003726937)
Title: Continuous microfluidic solvent extraction of cobalt from mimicked and real asteroid leaching solutions
Affiliations: The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, Australia; Technische Universiteit Eindhoven, Eindhoven, Netherlands; The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; University of Warwick, Coventry, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Wouters, Marly, School of Chemical Engineering and Advanced Materials, The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, Australia, Department of Chemical Engineering and Chemistry, Technische Universiteit Eindhoven, Eindhoven, Netherlands; Rahman, Shamaun, School of Chemical Engineering and Advanced Materials, The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, Australia; Myamoto, Hideaki, Department of Systems Innovation, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Tran, Nam Nghiep, School of Chemical Engineering and Advanced Materials, The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, Australia, Department of Chemical Engineering, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Hessel, Volker, School of Chemical Engineering and Advanced Materials, The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, Australia, School of Engineering, University of Warwick, Coventry, United Kingdom
Abstract: This research proposes a pathway for the last step of the asteroid mining process: the purification of the adjacent metals, cobalt and nickel, in the frame of in-situ resource utilization (ISRU) in space. Major technological and economic challenges will need to be overcome, and one main issue to be tackled is the reduction of water usage in this process. Therefore, the leached metal solutions are expected to contain ultra-high metal concentrations, up to 10 mol/l. These solutions will have challenging thermodynamic properties (increased density, viscosity and interfacial tension). As a result, an analysis of dimensionless numbers for fluidics and mass transport was made, showing that some of these are favourable under the constraints of accessible microfluidic operations. Experiments were performed with advanced microfluidic reactors (a coiled-flow inverter (CFI) and an industrial re-entrance flow reactor from Corning®) at high metal concentrations and high nickel to cobalt ratios (3:0.3 mol/l Ni:Co). Using Cyanex 272 as a selective extractant for cobalt, extraction efficiencies of 60% with high separation factors (>1000) were reached in just one extraction stage. The CFI showed high extraction efficiency for low fluid velocities and a residence time of 60 s. For the Corning® reactor, high fluid velocities or the use of many modules (>3) are needed to obtain an emulsion, resulting in high extraction efficiencies at a very short residence time of 13 s. The comparison between the CFI and the Corning® reactor shows that they share the best operation point (at 120 ml/h), but the Corning® reactor performs better at higher flow rates and thus can leverage higher productivity. However, the CFI is easier to operate and has a much lower pressure drop, resulting in low energy input. Finally, an iron meteorite sample was leached and efficiently extracted in both microfluidic reactors. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Data-driven prediction of biomass pyrolysis pathways toward phenolic and aromatic products
Affiliations: Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Wuhan University, Wuhan, China; Hirosaki University, Hirosaki, Japan; Dại học Nguyen Tat Thanh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam

Abstract: This study clarifies the reaction pathway for biomass pyrolysis to phenolic compounds and aromatic hydrocarbons by analyzing 20 biomass samples using a central composite design and response surface plot. The pyrolysis reaction was performed using two integrated fixed-bed reactors. The product yield was significantly affected by pyrolysis temperature when utilizing the thermal cracking, repolymerization, and Boudouard reaction pathways. The bio-oil used in the study was obtained from the volatile matter fraction, where the fixed carbon content strongly affected biochar yield. Regarding bio-oil composition, both pyrolysis temperature and biomass constituents, including hemicellulose and lignin, significantly affected the yield of phenolics and aromatic hydrocarbons. In addition, biomass pyrolysis reaction pathways toward phenolic compounds and aromatic hydrocarbons were proposed. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D.T.X., Dang, Diem Thi Xuan; H.T., Hoang, Hieu Trung; T.L.H., Doan, Tan Le Hoang; N., Thoai, Nam; Y., Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki; D., Nguyen-Manh, Duc
Author full names: Dang, Diem Thi Xuan (57205225800); Hoang, Hieu Trung (57204146816); Doan, Tan Le Hoang (57939112200); Thoai, Nam (6603793994); Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki (57208764411); Nguyen-Manh, Duc (7003528210)
Title: Effect of axial molecules and linker length on CO2adsorption and selectivity of CAU-8: a combined DFT and GCMC simulation study
Affiliations: Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures (INOMAR), Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; University of Technology, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Suranaree University of Technology, Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand; SRM Institute of Science and Technology, Kattankulathur, India; United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority, Oxford, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Dang, Diem Thi Xuan, Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures (INOMAR), Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Hoang, Hieu Trung, Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures (INOMAR), Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Doan, Tan Le Hoang, Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures (INOMAR), Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thoai, Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, High Performance Computing Lab, University of Technology, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan, Department of Physics, Suranaree University of Technology, Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand, Department of Physics and Nanotechnology, SRM Institute of Science and Technology, Kattankulathur, India; Nguyen-Manh, Duc, Culham Science Centre, United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority, Oxford, United Kingdom
Abstract: Density Functional Theory (DFT) and Grand Canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) calculations are performed to study the structures and carbon dioxide (CO<inf>2</inf>) adsorption properties of the newly designed metal-organic framework based on the CAU-8 (CAU stands for Christian-Albrechts Universität) prototype. In the new MOFs, the 4,4′-benzophenonedicarboxylic acid (H<inf>2</inf>BPDC) linker of CAU-8 is substituted by 4,4′-oxalylbis(azanediyl)dibenzoic acid (H<inf>2</inf>ODA) and 4,4′-teraphthaloylbis(azanediyl)dibenzoic acid (H<inf>2</inf>TDA) containing amide groups (-CO-NH- motif). Furthermore, MgO<inf>6</inf>octahedral chains where dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) decorating the axial position bridged two Mg2+ions are considered. The formation energies indicate that modified CAU-8 is thermodynamically stable. The reaction mechanisms between the metal clusters and the linkers to form the materials are also proposed. GCMC calculations show that CO<inf>2</inf>adsorptions and selectivities of Al-based MOFs are better than those of Mg-based MOFs, which is due to DMSO. Amide groups made CO<inf>2</inf>molecules more intensively distributed besides organic linkers. CO<inf>2</inf>uptakes and selectivities of MOFs containing H<inf>2</inf>TDA linkers are better in comparison with those of MOFs containing H<inf>2</inf>BPDC linkers or H<inf>2</inf>ODA linkers. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Construction of boronophenylalanine-loaded biodegradable periodic mesoporous organosilica nanoparticles for bnct cancer therapy
Affiliations: Institute for Integrated Cell-Material Sciences, Kyoto, Japan; Institute for Integrated Radiation and Nuclear Science, Kyoto University, Sennan, Japan; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; TAE Life Sciences, Santa Monica, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko, Institute for Integrated Cell-Material Sciences, Kyoto, Japan; Chinnathambi, Shanmugavel, Institute for Integrated Cell-Material Sciences, Kyoto, Japan; Laird, Mathilde, Institute for Integrated Cell-Material Sciences, Kyoto, Japan; Komatsu, Aoi, Institute for Integrated Cell-Material Sciences, Kyoto, Japan; Birault, Albane, Institute for Integrated Cell-Material Sciences, Kyoto, Japan; Takata, Takushi, Institute for Integrated Radiation and Nuclear Science, Kyoto University, Sennan, Japan; Doan, Tan Le Hoang, Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures (INOMAR), Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Mai, Ngoc Xuan Dat, Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures (INOMAR), Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Raitano, Arthur B., Drug Development Division, TAE Life Sciences, Santa Monica, United States; Morrison, Kendall, Drug Development Division, TAE Life Sciences, Santa Monica, United States
Abstract: Biodegradable periodic mesoporous organosilica (BPMO) has recently emerged as a promising type of mesoporous silica-based nanoparticle for biomedical applications. Like mesopo-rous silica nanoparticles (MSN), BPMO possesses a large surface area where various compounds can be attached. In this work, we attached boronophenylalanine (10BPA) to the surface and explored the potential of this nanomaterial for delivering boron-10 for use in boron neutron capture therapy (BNCT). This cancer therapy is based on the principle that the exposure of boron-10 to thermal neutron results in the release of α-particles that kill cancer cells. To attach10BPA, the surface of BPMO was modified with diol groups which facilitated the efficient binding of10BPA, yielding10BPA-loaded BPMO (10 BPA-BPMO). Surface modification with phosphonate was also carried out to increase the dispersibility of the nanoparticles. To investigate this nanomaterial’s potential for BNCT, we first used human cancer cells and found that10 BPA-BPMO nanoparticles were efficiently taken up into the cancer cells and were localized in perinuclear regions. We then used a chicken egg tumor model, a versatile and convenient tumor model used to characterize nanomaterials. After observing significant tumor accumulation,10 BPA-BPMO injected chicken eggs were evaluated by irradiating with neutron beams. Dramatic inhibition of the tumor growth was observed. These results suggest the potential of10BPA-BPMO as a novel boron agent for BNCT. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H.M., Nguyen, Hoang Minh; C.M., Phan, Chi M.; G.H., Pham, Gia Hung; Y., Asakuma, Yusuke; R., Vagnoni, Robert; S., Liu, Shaomin
Author full names: Nguyen, Hoang Minh (56710826600); Phan, Chi M. (7004175765); Pham, Gia Hung (36920793700); Asakuma, Yusuke (6602310476); Vagnoni, Robert (57204361382); Liu, Shaomin (35242760200)
Title: Size-tailored microwave absorption and reaction activity of Co3O4 nanocatalysts
Source title: Journal of Industrial and Engineering Chemistry
Affiliations: WA School of Mines: Minerals, Energy and Chemical Engineering, Kalgoorlie, Australia; University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; The University of Western Australia, Perth, Australia; University of Hyogo, Kobe, Japan; Pty Ltd, Perth, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Hoang Minh, Energy and Chemical Engineering, WA School of Mines: Minerals, Energy and Chemical Engineering, Kalgoorlie, Australia, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Phan, Chi M., Energy and Chemical Engineering, WA School of Mines: Minerals, Energy and Chemical Engineering, Kalgoorlie, Australia; Pham, Gia Hung, Centre for Energy, The University of Western Australia, Perth, Australia; Asakuma, Yusuke, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Hyogo, Kobe, Japan; Vagnoni, Robert, Eco Technol Co., Pty Ltd, Perth, Australia; Liu, Shaomin, Energy and Chemical Engineering, WA School of Mines: Minerals, Energy and Chemical Engineering, Kalgoorlie, Australia
Abstract: Microwave (MW)-assisted heterogeneous catalytic chemical reactions have opened advanced routines over the conventional methodology. MW absorption ability of catalyst governed by its particle size is the foremost important factor to be considered before designing catalysts for such MW-based chemistry. Despite considerable interest in applying metallic-based catalysts for MW-assisted reactions, the influences of particle size on catalyst's MW absorption ability and its resultant activity remain elusive. Here, we report an effective approach to tailor the MW absorption ability of Co<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf> catalyst via controlling its particle size during the crystal growth. A developed theoretical model verified that a capping agent could regulate Co<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf> particle size effectively. For the unsupported Co<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf> catalysts, smaller particle size possessed higher MW absorption capacity and thereby delivered higher activity for MW-assisted bi-reforming of methane. High conversion of 63% CH<inf>4</inf> and a syngas ratio (H<inf>2</inf>/CO) of 2.2 was achieved with the smallest Co<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf> particles, at 20 nm. In contrast, the supported Co<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf> samples required larger particles to ensure adequate exposure to the incident MW, which is partially covered by MW-inert support. The results disclose that by tailoring particles size appropriately, metallic-based catalysts can be optimised for MW-based chemical reactions. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D.A., Khuong, Duy Anh; H.N., Nguyen, Hong Nam; T., Tsubota, Toshiki

Title: CO2activation of bamboo residue after hydrothermal treatment and performance as an EDLC electrode
Affiliations: Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kyushu Institute of Technology, Kitakyushu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Khuong, Duy Anh, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Materials Science, Kyushu Institute of Technology, Kitakyushu, Japan; Nguyen, Hong Nam, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tsubota, Toshiki, Department of Materials Science, Kyushu Institute of Technology, Kitakyushu, Japan
Abstract: CO<inf>2</inf>activation of the solid residue of bamboo after hydrothermal treatment, which is used for the production of xylo-oligosaccharide, was investigated in detail. The reference temperature for carbonization and CO<inf>2</inf>activation was 800 °C. The activated carbon from a solid residue was demonstrated to have a higher potential for making EDLC electrodes than bamboo activated carbon thanks to its very low ash content (almost 0) and high porosity structure with a BET surface area up toca.2150 m2g−1. The electrochemical performance of ELDC electrodes prepared from solid residue-derived activated carbon in 1 M H<inf>2</inf>SO<inf>4</inf>aqueous solution was measured and well compared with carbon from bamboo. Through investigation, it is clear that the capacitance of the electrode made from the solid residue has a better capacity than that of raw bamboo. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Structural, elastic, and electronic properties of chemically functionalized boron phosphide monolayer
Affiliations: Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Macnica, Inc., Kohoku-ku, Yokohama-shi, Kanagawa, Japan; Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Belarusian State University, Minsk, Belarus; Dong Thap University, Cao Lanh, Viet Nam; Le Quy Don Technical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Vu, Tuan V., Division of Computational Physics, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Faculty of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kartamyshev, A. I., Division of Computational Physics, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Faculty of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Hieu, N. V., Faculty of Physics, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Dang, Tran D.H., Macnica, Inc., Kohoku-ku, Yokohama-shi, Kanagawa, Japan; Nguyen, Sy Ngoc, Division of Construction Computation, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Poklonski, Nikolai A., Faculty of Physics, Belarusian State University, Minsk, Belarus; Nguyen, Chuong V., Division of Theoretical Physics, Dong Thap University, Cao Lanh, Viet Nam; Phuc, Huynh V., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Le Quy Don Technical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Ngoc Hieu, Institute of Research and Development, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam, Faculty of Natural Sciences, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Abstract: Surface functionalization is one of the useful techniques for modulating the mechanical and electronic properties of two-dimensional systems. In the present study, we investigate the structural, elastic, and electronic properties of hexagonal boron phosphide monolayer functionalized by Br and Cl atoms using first-principles predictions. Once surface-functionalized with Br/Cl atoms, the planar structure of BP monolayer is transformed to the low-buckled lattice with the bucking constant of about 0.6 Å for all four configurations of functionalized boron phosphide,i.e., Cl-BP-Cl, Cl-BP-Br, Br-BP-Cl, and Br-BP-Br. The stability of functionalized BP monolayers is confirmedviatheir phonon spectra analysis andab initiomolecular dynamics simulations. Our calculations indicate that the functionalized BP monolayers possess a fully isotropic elastic characteristic with the perfect circular shape of the angle-dependent Young's modulus and Poisson's ratio due to the hexagonal symmetry. The Cl-BP-Cl is the most stiff with the Young's modulusC<inf>2D</inf>= 43.234 N m−1. All four configurations of the functionalized boron phosphide are direct semiconductors with a larger band gap than that of a pure BP monolayer. The outstanding stability, isotropic elastic properties, and moderate band gap make functionalized boron phosphide a very intriguing candidate for next-generation nanoelectromechanical devices. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: I., Karuppusamy, Indira; M.S., Samuel, Melvin S.; S., Ethiraj, Selvarajan; S., Shanmugam, Sabarathinam; S.M.K., Paskalis, Sahaya Murphin Kumar; B., Kathirvel, Brindhadevi; P., Arivalagan, Pugazhendhi
Author full names: Karuppusamy, Indira (57192009903); Samuel, Melvin S. (55921151200); Ethiraj, Selvarajan (57219592305); Shanmugam, Sabarathinam (57192212395); Paskalis, Sahaya Murphin Kumar (57195282483); Kathirvel, Brindhadevi (57200567025); Arivalagan, Pugazhendhi (57191625854)
Title: Ultrasound-assisted synthesis of mixed calcium magnesium oxide (CaMgO2) nanoflakes for photocatalytic degradation of methylene blue
Source title: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
Affiliations: Indira Gandhi Centre for Atomic Research, Kalpakkam, India; Indian Institute of Technology Kharagpur, Kharagpur, India; SRM Institute of Science and Technology, Kattankulathur, India; Chongqing University, Chongqing, China; Chongqing University, Chongqing, China; National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan; Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Karuppusamy, Indira, Corrosion Science and Technology Division, Indira Gandhi Centre for Atomic Research, Kalpakkam, India; Samuel, Melvin S., School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Kharagpur, Kharagpur, India; Ethiraj, Selvarajan, Department of Genetic Engineering, SRM Institute of Science and Technology, Kattankulathur, India; Shanmugam, Sabarathinam, Key Laboratory of Low-grade Energy Utilization Technologies and Systems, Chongqing University, Chongqing, China, Chongqing University, Chongqing, China; Paskalis, Sahaya Murphin Kumar, National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan; Kathirvel, Brindhadevi, Institute of Research and Development, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Arivalagan, Pugazhendhi, Faculty of Environment and Labour Safety, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: In the present study, mixed calcium magnesium oxide (CaMgO<inf>2</inf>) nanoflakes were synthesized using an ultrasound-assisted co-precipitation method. The physicochemical, structural and functional properties and elemental composition of the nanoflakes had been characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM), Fourier Transform Infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), UV–VIS spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and Raman spectroscopy. Moreover, the photocatalytic actions of the nanoflakes were evaluated by the removal rates of methylene blue (MB) and p-nitrophenol (4-NP) under UV irradiation at room temperature. SEM-EDS studies revealed that the nanoflakes consisted of mixed oxide such as magnesium oxide (MgO) and calcium oxide (CaO) particles. The size of the nanoflakes was found to be in the range of 10–30 nm and the average size was 25 nm as confirmed by HR-TEM analysis. XRD revealed that the standard crystal size was calculated to be 25 nm. The synthesized nanoflakes had a strong photocatalytic activity for methylene blue (MB) and p-nitrophenol (4-NP) degradation in the presence of H<inf>2</inf>O<inf>2</inf> under UV light irradiation within 60 min and 30 min, respectively. Hence, the present study proposes that the CaMgO<inf>2</inf> nanoflakes can be employed for the removal of dyes from wastewater. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: The effects of meteorological conditions and long-range transport on PM2.5 levels in Hanoi revealed from multi-site measurement using compact sensors and machine learning approach
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan; University of Birmingham, Birmingham, United Kingdom; Saitama University, Saitama, Japan; Thai Nguyen University of Technology, Thai Nguyen, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Graduate School of Fisheries and Environmental Sciences, Nagasaki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ly, Thuy Bich, School of Environmental Science and Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Matsumi, Yutaka, Institute for Space-Earth Environmental Research, Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan; Vu, Tuan V., Division of Environmental Health and Risk Management, University of Birmingham, Birmingham, United Kingdom; Sekiguchi, Kazuhiko, Graduate School of Science and Engineering, Saitama University, Saitama, Japan; Nguyen, Thi Thu Thuy, Faculty of International Training, Thai Nguyen University of Technology, Thai Nguyen, Viet Nam, Institute for Environment and Resources, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Pham, Chau Thuy, Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nghiem, Trung Dung, School of Environmental Science and Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ngo, Ich Hung, School of Environmental Science and Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kurotsuchi, Yuta, Graduate School of Science and Engineering, Saitama University, Saitama, Japan; Nguyen, Thu Hien T., School of Environmental Science and Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Hanoi, the capital of Vietnam, frequently experiences heavy air pollution episodes in the winter, causing health concerns for the 7.5 million people living there. Spatial-temporal variations in PM<inf>2.5</inf> levels can provide useful information about the sources and transportation of PM<inf>2.5</inf>. However, the published spatial-temporal data in the area are limited. In this research, PM<inf>2.5</inf> concentrations at two sites in Hanoi and a site in Thai Nguyen (60 km north of Hanoi) were observed from October 2017 to April 2018, using newly available low-cost sensors. Hourly concentrations of PM<inf>2.5</inf> at the three sites were similar on average (57.5, 54.9, and 53.6 μg m−3) and clearly co-varied, suggesting remarkable large-scale effects. The contribution of long-range transport and meteorological factors on PM<inf>2.5</inf> levels were investigated with a machine learning technique based on a random forest (RF) algorithm and concentration weight trajectory (CWT). The results showed that the contribution of long-range transport from the north and northeast to local PM<inf>2.5</inf> levels was significant. Moreover, weather normalized PM<inf>2.5</inf> concentrations and partial plots of meteorological factors on the levels of PM<inf>2.5</inf> showed that meteorological conditions play a significant role in the formation of winter haze events. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Performance evaluation of down-flow hanging sponge reactor for direct treatment of actual textile wastewater; Effect of effluent recirculation to performance and microbial community
Affiliations: Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Nihon Suido Consultants Co, Ltd, Tokyo, Japan; Institut Teknologi Bandung, Bandung, Indonesia; Institut Teknologi Bandung, Bandung, Indonesia; University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Watari, T., Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan, Department of Chemical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hata, Yuya, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan, Nihon Suido Consultants Co, Ltd, Tokyo, Japan; Hirakata, Yuga, Department of Science of Technology Innovation, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan, Bioproduction Research Institute, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Nguyet, Phan Nhu, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan, Faculty of Environment, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Thu Huong, Department of Science of Technology Innovation, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Maki, Shinya, Department of Science of Technology Innovation, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Hatamoto, M., Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Sutani, Daisuke, Nihon Suido Consultants Co, Ltd, Tokyo, Japan; Setiadi, Tjandra, Department of Chemical Engineering, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Bandung, Indonesia, Centre for Environmental Studies (PSLH), Institut Teknologi Bandung, Bandung, Indonesia; Yamaguch, Takashi, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan, Department of Science of Technology Innovation, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan
Abstract: The textile industry discharges large amounts of polluted wastewater containing synthetic dyes. A down-flow hanging sponge (DHS) reactor is a novel aerobic wastewater treatment process that utilizes a sponge as a biomass-retaining carrier. This sponge carrier has both aerobic and anaerobic zones owing to different dissolved oxygen concentrations. In this study, the process performance of a DHS reactor treating actual textile wastewater obtained from a factory in Japan was evaluated. The effects of hydraulic retention time (HRT) and effluent recirculation (recirculation ratio = 1) on the DHS process performance were investigated. The DHS reactor showed good organic (up to 93 ± 13% of BOD) and nitrogen removal (56 ± 14% of TN) abilities during the entire experimental period. The color removal efficiencies of the DHS reactor were 55 ± 15%, 53 ± 26%, 72 ± 34%, and 35 ± 22% with HRTs of 4 h, 4 h + effluent recirculation (R = 1), 8 h + effluent recirculation (R = 1), and 8 h, respectively. Microbial community structure analysis of the DHS retained sludge showed that genus Acinetobacter was detected predominantly and reported as an azo dye-degrading bacterium. Effluent recirculation was also observed to increase the presence of aromatic-degrading bacteria and protists in the DHS reactor. These results suggest that the DHS reactor is suitable for textile wastewater treatment. Furthermore, the effluent recirculation is effective for enhancing decolorization performance. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Biological Wastewater Treatment; Textile Wastewater; Trickling Filter Reactor

Authors: T., Sadeghi Rad, Tannaz; Z., Ansarian, Zahra; A., Khataee, A.; B., Vahid, Behrouz; E., Doustkhah, Esmail

Title: N-doped graphitic carbon as a nanoporous MOF-derived nanoarchitecture for the efficient sonocatalytic degradation process
Affiliations: University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran; Gebze Teknik Üniversitesi, Gebze, Turkey; Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Islamic Azad University, Tabriz Branch, Tabriz, Iran; National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sadeghi Rad, Tannaz, Department of Applied Chemistry, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran; Ansarian, Zahra, Department of Applied Chemistry, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran; Khataee, A., Department of Applied Chemistry, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran, Department of Environmental Engineering, Gebze Teknik Üniversitesi, Gebze, Turkey, Institute of Research and Development, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Vahid, Behrouz, Department of Chemical Engineering, Islamic Azad University, Tabriz Branch, Tabriz, Iran; Doustkhah, Esmail, International Center for Materials Nanoarchitechtonics (WPI-MANA), National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: Here, a nanoporous N-doped graphitic carbon (NC) obtained via the pyrolysis of the zeolitic imidazolate framework-67 (ZIF-67) in the N<inf>2</inf> atmosphere and then etched with hydrofluoric acid (HF) to remove the cobalt particles. The carbonized imidazoles in the framework of the ZIF-67 converted to the formation of N-doped graphitic sheets. The N<inf>2</inf> adsorption-desorption isotherms verified an arise in the surface area after etching the carbonized ZIF-67 and removing the Co nanoparticles (384 m2/g). Then, the prepared nanoporous carbon (NC<inf>ZIF-67</inf>) was employed as a catalyst under the ultrasonic (US) irradiation for the degradation of the methylene blue (MB) as a model thiazine-based dye. The effects of main operational parameters including the initial pH, MB concentration, catalyst dosage, and ultrasonic power on the coupled US/NC<inf>ZIF-67</inf> process were investigated. The addition of radical scavengers and enhancers revealed the main role of reactive oxygen species in the treatment process particularly hydroxyl radicals ([rad]OH), in which their presence is confirmed by the photoluminescence (PL) spectra. The GC–MS method was performed for recognition of the seven detectable intermediates during the MB degradation. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Analysis of Thermal Behavior of Crystalline Minerals in Bituminous Coal Samples under Air and Argon Atmospheres
Affiliations: Mie University, Tsu, Japan; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hashimoto, Tadanori, Department of Chemistry for Materials, Mie University, Tsu, Japan; Takai, Kentarou, Department of Chemistry for Materials, Mie University, Tsu, Japan; Nguyen, Hung Viet Quang, Department of Chemistry for Materials, Mie University, Tsu, Japan, Center of Severe Materials and Environment, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nomura, Masakatsu, Department of Applied Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Ishihara, Atsushi, Department of Chemistry for Materials, Mie University, Tsu, Japan
Abstract: The thermal behavior of ash components in two bituminous coal samples [Upper Freeport (the "UF") and Illinois #6 (the "IL")] was investigated under air and argon atmospheres in the temperature range of 800-1200 °C using thermal gravimetric-differential thermal analysis, X-ray diffraction transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and TEM-energy dispersive X-ray spectrometry measurements. The UF treated under air formed the needle-like crystals which were assumed to be mullite-related substances formed by transformation of andalusite, because the crystals are mainly composed of SiO2 and Al2O3. In contrast to the UF, the IL did not generate such crystals; however, when the IL was treated under air after carbonization under Ar, crystals appeared. The composition of the UF with an Al/Si ratio higher than that of the IL favored the formation of mullite-related substances, while the presence of lime in the IL inhibited the formation of mullite-related substances. Oldhamite was formed by the reaction of lime with sulfur at the carbonization of the IL under Ar and remained even at the successive air treatment. As lime was consumed, the formation of mullite-related substances was ceased to be inhibited under air after Ar treatment. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Funding Texts: A part of this work (TEM–EDS) was supported by Nagoya University microstructural characterization platform as a program of “Nanotechnology Platform” of the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (MEXT), Japan. Authors thank Shunsuke Koyabu, Karin Uemura and Dr. Hiroyuki Nasu for their helpful work.

Authors: D., Van Duong, Doan; M., Hasegawa, Masumi
Author full names: Van Duong, Doan (57195416108); Hasegawa, Masumi (35464809700)
Title: Predicting Mechanical Properties of Clear Wood from Acacia mangium Provenances Using Ultrasound
Affiliations: Thai Nguyen University, Thai Nguyen, Viet Nam; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Van Duong, Doan, Faculty of Forestry, Thai Nguyen University, Thai Nguyen, Viet Nam; Hasegawa, Masumi, Laboratory of Wood Science, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Abstract: Ultrasound was considered as a means for determining mechanical properties of clear wood in six different Acacia mangium provenances from a trial forest planted in Vietnam. A total of 30 trees (5 trees from each provenance) with no major defects were selected, and a 50-cm-long log was obtained at 1.3 m above the ground from each tree for the assessment of mechanical properties. The measured average ultrasound velocities for provenances tested in the longitudinal direction ranged from 4094 m/s to 4271 m/s. The predicted average dynamic modulus of elasticity (Ed) values varied from 7.42 GPa to 8.70 GPa among provenances. The Ed indicated significant positive correlation coefficients with modulus of elasticity (0.64 to 0.96), modulus of rupture (0.44 to 0.87), and compression strength (0.54 to 0.92) for provenances examined in this study. The results indicated that the use of ultrasound was feasible to determine the mechanical properties of A. mangium provenances planted in Vietnam. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: C., Le Dinh, Cuong; T., Fujiwara, Takeshi; S.T., Pham Phu, Song Toan
Author full names: Le Dinh, Cuong (57222016137); Fujiwara, Takeshi (55502389900); Pham Phu, Song Toan (57201079513)
Title: Waste Segregation at Source and Separately Collection - The Inadequacy in Implementation in Vietnam
Affiliations: Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Le Dinh, Cuong, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Fujiwara, Takeshi, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Pham Phu, Song Toan, University of Science and Technology, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Abstract: Hoi An city is a dynamic tourism city in Vietnam which had received the certificate of World Heritage Site by UNESCO. The boom in tourism activities led to problems for the solid waste management system. Solid waste collection activities account for the largest proportion of expenses on solid waste management. Optimization of the present solid waste collection system of Hoi An city is an urgent mission. This research is an effort to describe the current solid waste collection system of Hoi An city with the support of GIS and GPS. The results denoted Thursday, Friday, and Saturday accounted for the most enormous workload with 36, 34, and 40 trips. The total working time for these days were 103.86, 96.12, and 109.6 h while the total traveled distances were 733.76, 719.21, and 848.12 km. The complexity of solid waste collection routes, frequencies of solid waste collection, and coverage of solid waste collection activities decreased from urban areas to rural areas. Collection of waste accounted for the largest amount of time in solid waste collection activities. The low rate of waste separation at source, illegal solid waste collection, extreme weather, misbehaviours of drivers and workers, as well as the limitation in waste treatment facilities were the problems and challenges of the solid waste collection system in Hoi An city. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Funding Texts: The authors are thankful to Hoi An Public Work Company for supporting the survey as well as Graduate School of Environmental and Life Science, Okayama University for financial support.

Author full names: Shah, Ku Nur Afrina Ku Azman (57329900900); Mohd Yusop, Mohd Zamri (24472319200); Rohani, J. M. (43661897900); Fadil, Nor Akmal Binti (55024227300); Abdul Manaf, Norhuda Binti (57552326800); Hartono, Budi (56246437300); Nguyen, Duc Tuyen (58279068400); Tanemura, Masaki (7007035010); Ahmad, Abdul Samad (57683920800); Ramli, Ashaari (57329319400)
Title: Feasibility Study on Biomass Bamboo Renewable Energy in Malaysia, Indonesia, Vietnam and Japan
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, Johor Bahru, Malaysia; Universiti Teknologi Malaysia Kuala Lumpur, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia; Universitas Gadjah Mada, Yogyakarta, Indonesia; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nagoya Institute of Technology, Nagoya, Japan; MyBamboo Sdn. Bhd., Subang Jaya, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Shah, Ku Nur Afrina Ku Azman, School of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Johor Bahru, Malaysia; Mohd Yusop, Mohd Zamri, School of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Johor Bahru, Malaysia; Rohani, J. M., School of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Johor Bahru, Malaysia; Fadil, Nor Akmal Binti, School of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Johor Bahru, Malaysia; Abdul Manaf, Norhuda Binti, Department of Chemical Process Engineering, Universiti Teknologi Malaysia Kuala Lumpur, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia; Hartono, Budi, Universitas Gadjah Mada, Yogyakarta, Indonesia; Nguyen, Duc Tuyen, School of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tanemura, Masaki, Department of Physical Science and Engineering, Nagoya Institute of Technology, Nagoya, Japan; Ahmad, Abdul Samad, MyBamboo Sdn. Bhd., Subang Jaya, Malaysia; Ramli, Ashaari, MyBamboo Sdn. Bhd., Subang Jaya, Malaysia
Abstract: Bamboo has become a new trend or focus point as a source of biomass energy in which its proper application is believed to generate the electricity with near-zero waste. ASEAN countries especially have an abundant amount of bamboo that has been use for decades in various applications through their civilization. This study aims to determine the feasibility of bamboo as a renewable energy resource in Malaysia, Indonesia, Vietnam and Japan. This paper reviews general biomass bamboo, availability, and methods of technology in the respective countries based on the review of publication papers and country reports. This fast-growing crop is identical for biomass production as it rapidly self-propagates. Bamboo requires minimum maintenance to grow and is always accessible to be harvested. The woody nature of the tropical bamboo stem contributes to its high calorific value in the form of energy. It was found that Indonesia had become a leading country in generating renewable energy via biomass bamboo through a power plant with a capacity of 700 kW off-grid in Mentawai, Japan with a power generation capacity of 995 kW and Malaysia with 4 MW, will be commercialised by 2023 and 2022. In conclusion, biomass bamboo has great potential for renewable energy generation within these countries. This has consequently contributed to increase in the value of bamboos while positively impacting the socioeconomic stance of the community. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D.B., Nguyen, Duy Bao; S.T., Pham Phu, Song Toan; C., Le Dinh, Cuong; M., Usami, Makoto
Author full names: Nguyen, Duy Bao (57406388400); Pham Phu, Song Toan (57201079513); Le Dinh, Cuong (57222016137); Usami, Makoto (57406996800)
Title: Practical Solid Waste Management System in a Campus in Danang city, Vietnam
Affiliations: Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Graduate School of Global Environmental Studies, Kyoto, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Duy Bao, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Pham Phu, Song Toan, University of Science and Technology, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Le Dinh, Cuong, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Usami, Makoto, Graduate School of Global Environmental Studies, Kyoto, Japan
Abstract: Da Nang is a city with rapid growth and expansion, along with it is pressure for municipal solid waste treatment. Within a decade, waste generation from commercial and service activities increased significantly at a rate of 9 %/y and reached 1.073 t/d in 2018. This study aims at developing municipal solid waste management toward sustainability in the campus of Danang University. A waste audit was performed to evaluate the total emission and characteristics of the solid waste generated by the campus. Simultaneously, the 3R program was applied for assessing the current status of the waste management practice (WMP) system. This study analyzes the total amount and characteristics of campus waste, in which, recycling (25 %) and organic waste (28 %) took up a great proportion. It also reveals that even though a big part has shown disinterest in waste management, the awareness of students toward environmental protection was raised during the process of this research. Therefore, the improvement of WMP at source and formal environmental education at a younger age can reduce a significant amount of waste-to-landfill, as well as enhancing environmental awareness. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Funding Texts: The authors would like to thank for the financial support of GSGES Seeds Funding Program 2016, Kyoto University.

Authors: S.T., Pham Phu, Song Toan; T., Fujiwara, Takeshi; D.B., Nguyen, Duy Bao; C., Le Dinh, Cuong
Author full names: Pham Phu, Song Toan (57201079513); Fujiwara, Takeshi (55502389900); Nguyen, Duy Bao (57406388400); Le Dinh, Cuong (57222016137)
Title: Home-Composting - A Study on the Simplicity of the System in the Application toward the Effectiveness and Feasibility in Spreading in Vietnam
Affiliations: University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Okayama University, Okayama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Pham Phu, Song Toan, University of Science and Technology, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Fujiwara, Takeshi, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Nguyen, Duy Bao, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Le Dinh, Cuong, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan
Abstract: In 2018, the landfill in Danang city (DNC) received a significant amount of 1,073 t/d of waste, of which 54 % are bio-degradable waste, this lead to the overloaded of DNC landfill. It also shows the huge potential of composting using organic waste is being overlooked. This study aims at introducing a biowaste treatment with a conventional aerobic composting method, the T-COM V2.0 system. The model is a horizontal rotary drum with the same operating principle as the in-vessel composting system, with a capacity of 200 L, equivalent to 10 kg/d. Four models are alternately operated at DNC primary school for kitchen waste treatment, with the combination of effective microorganisms to improve decomposition efficiency and reduce odor. The Compost showed positive results with organic matter 2.5 times higher than the Vietnamese standard on organic fertilizer, odorless, non-contaminated by heavy metal, and can be applied for cultivation or improving soil condition. Within three months of operation, the system had shown efficiency impact with more than 1 t of organic waste treated and is possible to replicate at households, restaurants, hotels with outstanding features like technical assurance, economic optimization, operational simplification, and ease of application. Thus, this system can benefit the DNC waste management system by reducing the quantity of organic waste generation at source. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Phi, Hungtrong; G., van Hoang, Got; B., Ngoc-Tam, Bui; T.K., Nguyen, Trung Kien; S.H., Truong, Son Hoanh
Author full names: Phi, Hungtrong (57220066482); van Hoang, Got (57220070598); Ngoc-Tam, Bui (57212681073); Nguyen, Trung Kien (57209166056); Truong, Son Hoanh (59158005200)
Title: The effect of microstructure on the cutting forces and microhardness in the surface grinding of titanium alloys
Affiliations: Electric Power University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; National Research Institute of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Phi, Hungtrong, Mechanical and Power Engineering Faculty, Electric Power University, Hanoi, Viet Nam, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; van Hoang, Got, National Research Institute of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ngoc-Tam, Bui, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, College of Systems Engineering and Science, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Nguyen, Trung Kien, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Truong, Son Hoanh, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Ti-6Al-4V (Ti64) is the most popular alpha-beta titanium alloy employed in the aerospace industry. Ti64 is developed in many modifications of the basic formulation to gain favorable properties according to different applications. The heating temperature and cooling conditions are the basis of the titanium alloy’s heat treatment resulting in various microstructures which influences the machinability of the Ti alloys and other alloys. This research investigates the effect of Ti64 microstructure on the grinding forces and surface roughness in the surface grinding process using a resin-bonded cBN wheel. The grinding process of Ti64 with a fully elongated alpha microstructure (Ti64-Elo) produces smaller grinding forces than those with Ti64 samples with a fully lamellar microstructure (Ti64-La). For the same cutting conditions, the Ti64-La surface shows a gain in hardness compared to the Ti64-Elo one. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
