Authors: F., Noguchi, Fumitoshi; Y., Zhou, Yuanbing; K., Kosugi, Kenichiro; Y., Yamamoto, Yoshimasa; P.T., Nghia, Phan Trung; M., Fukuda, Masao; S., Kawahara, Seiichi
Author full names: Noguchi, Fumitoshi (34267714500); Zhou, Yuanbing (57190348419); Kosugi, Kenichiro (48461664100); Yamamoto, Yoshimasa (55255881100); Nghia, Phan Trung (15763233700); Fukuda, Masao (7404038135); Kawahara, Seiichi (7101824012)
Title: Effect of strain-induced crystallization on the tear strength of natural rubber/styrene butadiene rubber blend
Affiliations: Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; National Institute of Technology, Tokyo College, Hachioji, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Noguchi, Fumitoshi, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Zhou, Yuanbing, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Kosugi, Kenichiro, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Yamamoto, Yoshimasa, Tokyo College, National Institute of Technology, Tokyo College, Hachioji, Japan; Nghia, Phan Trung, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Fukuda, Masao, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Kawahara, Seiichi, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan
Abstract: Strain-induced crystallization of natural rubber (NR) can greatly influence the mechanical properties of NR blends. In this study, we investigated the effect of strain-induced crystallization on the tear energy (G) of NR/styrene butadiene rubber (SBR) blends with different compositions and cross-link densities. Using a shift factor, we could superimpose G of an SBR blend and an NR/SBR (1/9) blend onto a single master curve. In contrast, G of NR was split into two master curves. Although the master curve of G for the NR/SBR (3:7) blend was split, increasing the cross-link density threefold made it possible to superimpose it onto a single master curve. Strain-induced crystallization of NR in the NR/SBR blend did not occur as a result of decreasing the NR content, increasing the cross-link density, or removing fatty acids. Together, these findings indicate that strain-induced crystallization of NR plays an important role in the mechanical properties of the blend. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: C.M., Phan, Chi M.; S., Yusa, Shinichi; T., Honda, Tomoko; K.K., Sharker, Komol Kanta; A.E., Hyde, Anita Evelyn; C.V., Nguyen, Cuong Van
Author full names: Phan, Chi M. (7004175765); Yusa, Shinichi (7003732650); Honda, Tomoko (57200555009); Sharker, Komol Kanta (56403421900); Hyde, Anita Evelyn (56303240800); Nguyen, Cuong Van (56843313800)
Title: Micelle and Surface Tension of Double-Chain Cationic Surfactants
Affiliations: Curtin University, Perth, Australia; University of Hyogo, Kobe, Japan; Military Technical Academy, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Phan, Chi M., Curtin Institute for Functional Molecules and Interfaces, Curtin University, Perth, Australia; Yusa, Shinichi, Graduate School of Engineering, University of Hyogo, Kobe, Japan; Honda, Tomoko, Graduate School of Engineering, University of Hyogo, Kobe, Japan; Sharker, Komol Kanta, Graduate School of Engineering, University of Hyogo, Kobe, Japan; Hyde, Anita Evelyn, Curtin Institute for Functional Molecules and Interfaces, Curtin University, Perth, Australia; Nguyen, Cuong Van, Curtin Institute for Functional Molecules and Interfaces, Curtin University, Perth, Australia, Military Technical Academy, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Since the early 20th century, the slightly disparate measurements of a surfactant's critical micelle concentration, via either surface tension or electrical conductivity, have been assumed one and the same. As a consequence, the possibility that micelles can adsorb at the air/water surface has been disregarded and has led to some abnormalities in the literature that remain as yet unresolved. In this paper, we closely examined the two critical concentrations for a double-chain cationic surfactant. We confirmed that the two concentrations represent two different physical phenomena. Furthermore, the results verified the existence of surface micelles, which are different from the bulk micelles. The formation of the surface micelles can be explained by the structural changes of the adsorption layer, which was also corroborated by molecular simulations. The findings open new challenges to examine the surface adsorption, which offers new insights into the molecular levels. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: V.H., Tu, Vo Hong; N., Can, Nguyenduy; Y., Takahashi, Yoshifumi; M., Yabe, Mitsuyasu

Title: Water Use Efficiency in Rice Production: Implications for Climate Change Adaptation in the Vietnamese Mekong Delta
Source title: Process Integration and Optimization for Sustainability
Affiliations: Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tu, Vo Hong, Department of Rural Socio-Economics, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Can, Nguyenduy, Department of Rural Socio-Economics, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Takahashi, Yoshifumi, Department of Agricultural and Resource Economics, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Yabe, Mitsuyasu, Department of Agricultural and Resource Economics, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Abstract: Water scarcity and competition in the Vietnamese Mekong Delta becomes a great matter of concern under the contexts of climate change and tributary dam construction in upstream countries. Moreover, water productivity or water use efficiency in rice production was quite low in the region due to free-rider problem. Therefore, the study was aimed at measuring water use efficiency at farm level and investigating the factors affecting water use efficiency. The study applied stochastic frontier analysis to estimate water use efficiency for 159 rice farmers in the upstream of the Vietnamese Mekong Delta. The study shows that the average water use efficiency was 18.81%, indicating that rice farmers did consume water very inefficiently. On the average, the rice farmers could reduce their water consumption about 81.19%, keeping their output level and other inputs constant. To improve water use efficiency, the study found that land accumulation or large-scaled production is essential. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Sudrajat, Hanggara; S., Hartuti, Sri
Author full names: Sudrajat, Hanggara (56884577200); Hartuti, Sri (59685272600)
Title: Structural properties and catalytic activity of a novel ternary CuO/gC3N4/Bi2O3 photocatalyst
Source title: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
Affiliations: Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Gifu University, Gifu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sudrajat, Hanggara, Division of Computational Physics, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Faculty of Applied Sciences, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Hartuti, Sri, Environmental and Renewable Energy Systems Division, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan
Abstract: In the present study, CuO/gC<inf>3</inf>N<inf>4</inf>/Bi<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> composite is constructed as a ternary visible light active photocatalyst. Since CuO plays a critical role in enhancing the photocatalytic activity of the formed composite, its structural properties are particularly studied using synchrotron X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), including X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS). XANES confirms the presence of Cu species with +2 oxidation state in the form of CuO. EXAFS furthermore confirms that each Cu cation is coordinated to four O anions in an approximately square planar configuration. The length of the Cu-O coordination is estimated to be 1.92 Å, slightly shorter than that of bulk CuO (1.95 Å). The CuO/gC<inf>3</inf>N<inf>4</inf>/Bi<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> composite exhibits highly enhanced photocatalytic activity in the 2,4-dichlorophenol decomposition under visible light. The enhanced photocatalytic activity is due to the increased population of electrons and the successful consumption of the photoproduced electrons by the dissolved oxygen through the one-electron transfer reaction. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M., Sakamoto, Mineshi; N., Tatsuta, Nozomi; K., Izumo, Kimiko; P., Phan, Phuongthanh; L.D., Vu, Loi Duc; M., Yamamoto, Megumi; M., Nakamura, Masaaki; K.A., Nakai, Kunihiko A.; K., Murata, Katsuyuki
Author full names: Sakamoto, Mineshi (7402113709); Tatsuta, Nozomi (36638439600); Izumo, Kimiko (23094051200); Phan, Phuongthanh (57204615482); Vu, Loi Duc (15835053800); Yamamoto, Megumi (7405312965); Nakamura, Masaaki (59121888400); Nakai, Kunihiko A. (7201487585); Murata, Katsuyuki (55787156300)
Title: Health impacts and biomarkers of prenatal exposure to methylmercury: Lessons from Minamata, Japan
Affiliations: National Institute for Minamata Disease, Minamata, Japan; Graduate School of Medicine, Sendai, Japan; Thai Nguyen University of Sciences, Thai Nguyen, Viet Nam; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Chemistry, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Faculty of Medicine, Akita, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sakamoto, Mineshi, National Institute for Minamata Disease, Minamata, Japan, Department of Development and Environmental Medicine, Graduate School of Medicine, Sendai, Japan; Tatsuta, Nozomi, Department of Development and Environmental Medicine, Graduate School of Medicine, Sendai, Japan; Izumo, Kimiko, National Institute for Minamata Disease, Minamata, Japan; Phan, Phuongthanh, Faculty of Chemistry, Thai Nguyen University of Sciences, Thai Nguyen, Viet Nam; Vu, Loi Duc, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Chemistry, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yamamoto, Megumi, National Institute for Minamata Disease, Minamata, Japan; Nakamura, Masaaki, National Institute for Minamata Disease, Minamata, Japan; Nakai, Kunihiko A., Department of Development and Environmental Medicine, Graduate School of Medicine, Sendai, Japan; Murata, Katsuyuki, Department of Environmental Health Sciences, Faculty of Medicine, Akita, Japan
Abstract: The main chemical forms of mercury are elemental mercury, inorganic divalent mercury, and methylmercury, which are metabolized in different ways and have differing toxic effects in humans. Among the various chemical forms of mercury, methylmercury is known to be particularly neurotoxic, and was identified as the cause of Minamata disease. It bioaccumulates in fish and shellfish via aquatic food webs, and fish and sea mammals at high trophic levels exhibit high mercury concentrations. Most human methylmercury exposure occurs through seafood consumption. Methylmercury easily penetrates the blood-brain barrier and so can affect the nervous system. Fetuses are known to be at particularly high risk of methylmercury exposure. In this review, we summarize the health effects and exposure assessment of methylmercury as follows: (1) methylmercury toxicity, (2) history and background of Minamata disease, (3) methylmercury pollution in the Minamata area according to analyses of preserved umbilical cords, (4) changes in the sex ratio in Minamata area, (5) neuropathology in fetuses, (6) kinetics of methylmercury in fetuses, (7) exposure assessment in fetuses. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Fetus; Exposure Assessment; Kinetics; Methylmercury; Toxicity

Title: Hierarchical nanorod-based TiO2 microspheres for superior electrochemical energy storage
Affiliations: Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; National Tsing Hua University, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Universiti Malaysia Pahang Al-Sultan Abdullah, Pekan, Malaysia; Universiti Malaysia Pahang Al-Sultan Abdullah, Pekan, Malaysia; Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Le, Thihang, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Chemistry, National Tsing Hua University, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Son, Le Thanh, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Dien, Luong Xuan, School of Chemical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vo, Dai Viet N., Faculty of Chemical and Natural Resources Engineering, Universiti Malaysia Pahang Al-Sultan Abdullah, Pekan, Malaysia, Centre of Excellence for Advanced Research in Fluid Flow, Universiti Malaysia Pahang Al-Sultan Abdullah, Pekan, Malaysia; Truong, Quang Duc, Ceramics and Biomaterials Research Group, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Faculty of Applied Sciences, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Institute of Multidisciplinary Research for Advanced Materials, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Abstract: Nanorod-based rutile TiO<inf>2</inf> microspheres composed of numerous single-crystalline nanorods are successfully fabricated by hydrothermal treatment of peroxo titanic acid in acidic solution. The formation of highly oriented nanorod-based microspheres can be explained in view of crystal growth under the coordination chemistry rule, followed by particle attachment and coalescence. As anodes for Li-ion batteries, the TiO<inf>2</inf> microsphere electrodes show enhanced rate performance, deliver a high reversible specific capacity of 180 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C (33.6 mA g−1) and 85.6 mAh g−1 at an extremely high rate of 50 C with an outstanding retention of 47.5%. These remarkable electrode properties are attributed to the efficient electron-transport by the hierarchical conductive pathway which promoted electronic conductivity and the shortened Li+ diffusion length resulting from the ultrafine nanorod structure. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.T.M., Nguyen, Trinh Thi My; Y., Ishida, Yoko; S., Kato, Sae; A., Iwaki, Aya; S., Izawa, Shingo
Author full names: Nguyen, Trinh Thi My (55961866200); Ishida, Yoko (57190764882); Kato, Sae (57192114424); Iwaki, Aya (55340475500); Izawa, Shingo (7007013145)
Title: The VFH1 (YLL056C) promoter is vanillin-inducible and enables mRNA translation despite pronounced translation repression caused by severe vanillin stress in Saccharomyces cerevisiae
Affiliations: Kyoto Institute of Technology, Kyoto, Japan; University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Trinh Thi My, Department of Applied Biology, Kyoto Institute of Technology, Kyoto, Japan, Department of Molecular and Environmental Biotechnology, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ishida, Yoko, Department of Applied Biology, Kyoto Institute of Technology, Kyoto, Japan; Kato, Sae, Department of Applied Biology, Kyoto Institute of Technology, Kyoto, Japan; Iwaki, Aya, Department of Applied Biology, Kyoto Institute of Technology, Kyoto, Japan; Izawa, Shingo, Department of Applied Biology, Kyoto Institute of Technology, Kyoto, Japan
Abstract: Vanillin, furfural and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) are representative fermentation inhibitors generated during the pretreatment process of lignocellulosic biomass in bioethanol production. These biomass conversion inhibitors, particularly vanillin, are known to repress translation activity in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. We have reported that the mRNAs of ADH7 and BDH2 were efficiently translated under severe vanillin stress despite marked repression of overall protein synthesis. In this study, we found that expression of VFH1 (YLL056C) was also significantly induced at the protein level by severe vanillin stress. Additionally, we demonstrated that the VFH1 promoter enabled the protein synthesis of other genes including GFP and ALD6 under severe vanillin stress. It is known that transcriptional activation of VFH1 is induced by furfural and HMF, and we verified that Vfh1 protein synthesis was also induced by furfural and HMF. The null mutant of VFH1 delayed growth in the presence of vanillin, furfural and HMF, indicating the importance of Vfh1 for sufficient tolerance against these inhibitors. The protein levels of Vfh1 induced by the inhibitors tested were markedly higher than those of Adh7 and Bdh2, suggesting the superior utility of the VFH1 promoter over the ADH7 or BDH2 promoter for breeding optimized yeast strains for bioethanol production from lignocellulosic biomass. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: G., Kumar, Gopalakrishnan; D.D., Nguyen, Dinh D.; P., Sivagurunathan, Periyasamy; T., Kobayashi, Takurou; K., Xu, Kaiqin; S., Chang, Soonwoong
Author full names: Kumar, Gopalakrishnan (7202418804); Nguyen, Dinh D. (55749243300); Sivagurunathan, Periyasamy (57050451800); Kobayashi, Takurou (55724307100); Xu, Kaiqin (55570728500); Chang, Soonwoong (8931821100)
Title: Cultivation of microalgal biomass using swine manure for biohydrogen production: Impact of dilution ratio and pretreatment
Affiliations: Yonsei University, Seoul, South Korea; Kyonggi University, Suwon, South Korea; Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kumar, Gopalakrishnan, School of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Yonsei University, Seoul, South Korea; Nguyen, Dinh D., Department of Environmental Energy Engineering, Kyonggi University, Suwon, South Korea; Sivagurunathan, Periyasamy, Green Energy Technology Research Group, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Faculty of Environment and Labour Safety, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kobayashi, Takurou, Center for Material Cycles and Waste Management Research, National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan; Xu, Kaiqin, Center for Material Cycles and Waste Management Research, National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan; Chang, Soonwoong, Department of Environmental Energy Engineering, Kyonggi University, Suwon, South Korea
Abstract: This study assessed the impact of swine manure (SM) dilution ratio on the microalgal biomass cultivation and further tested for biohydrogen production efficiency from the mixed microalgal biomass. At first, various solid/liquid (S/L) ratio of the SM ranged from 2.5 to 10 g/L was prepared as a nutrient medium for the algal biomass cultivation without addition of the external nutrient sources over a period of 18 d. The peak biomass concentration of 2.57 ± 0.03 g/L was obtained under the initial S/L loading rates of 5 g/L. Further, the cultivated biomass was subjected to two-step (ultrasonication + enzymatic) pretreatment and evaluated for biohydrogen production potential. Results showed that the variable amount of hydrogen production was observed with different S/L ratio of the SM. The peak hydrogen yield of 116 ± 6 mL/g TS<inf>added</inf> was observed at the 5 g/L grown SM mixed algal biomass. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.T.V., Tran, Thi Tuong Vi; S., Kongparakul, Suwadee; P., Reubroycharoen, Prasert; G., Guan, Guoqing; M.H., Nguyen, Manh Huan; N., Chanlek, Narong; C., Samart, Chanatip
Author full names: Tran, Thi Tuong Vi (59269885600); Kongparakul, Suwadee (24074703800); Reubroycharoen, Prasert (6507272038); Guan, Guoqing (36026624000); Nguyen, Manh Huan (57188633416); Chanlek, Narong (24775167600); Samart, Chanatip (26436343700)
Title: Production of furan based biofuel with an environmental benign carbon catalyst
Affiliations: Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Hirosaki University, Hirosaki, Japan; Vietnam Petroleum Institute, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Synchrotron Light Research Institute (SLRI), Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Tran, Thi Tuong Vi, Department of Chemistry, Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Kongparakul, Suwadee, Department of Chemistry, Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Reubroycharoen, Prasert, Department of Chemical Technology, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Guan, Guoqing, North Japan Research Institute for Sustainable Energy (NJRISE), Hirosaki University, Hirosaki, Japan; Nguyen, Manh Huan, Petrovietnam Research and Development Center for Petroleum Processing, Vietnam Petroleum Institute, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Chanlek, Narong, Synchrotron Light Research Institute (SLRI), Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand; Samart, Chanatip, Department of Chemistry, Thammasat University, Pathum Thani, Thailand
Abstract: A sulfonated carbon material was developed and investigated as an environmentally benign catalyst for furfural production. The sulfonic acid functionality was introduced by sequential hydrothermal carbonization and sulfonation of xylose. The morphology and textural properties were examined by scanning electron microscopy and N<inf>2</inf> sorption measurements, respectively. The presence of sulfonic acid on the surface was proven by both Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis. Meanwhile, the acid properties were studied using an NH<inf>3</inf>-TPD profile. Two different sulfonated carbons that was activated with KOH before sulfonation and one that was compared. The KOH-activated sulfonated carbon contained both a porous structure and a high sulfonic acid content that improved the furfural yield and selectivity by more than 50% compared to the nonactivated sulfonated carbon. The reusability of the catalyst was investigated by monitoring the furfural selectivity over several reaction cycles, and after the 3rd cycle, a reduction in the selectivity from 72 to 30% was observed. However, the acid-functionalized carbon could still be useful for furfural production due to its low environmental impact in both the preparation and disposal steps. © 2017 American Institute of Chemical Engineers Environ Prog, 37: 1455–1461, 2018. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Truong, Xuan Luan (57200274019); Mitamura, Muneki (6603558821); Kono, Yasuyuki (36024711800); Raghavan, Venkatesh (7103398103); Yonezawa, Go (15752369900); Truong, Xuan Quang (57200274020); Do, Thihang (57208708285); Tien Bui, D. (54400192000); Saro, Lee M. (7601413342)
Title: Enhancing prediction performance of landslide susceptibility model using hybrid machine learning approach of bagging ensemble and logistic model tree
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Mining and Geology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Hanoi University of Natural Resources and Environment, Hanoi, Viet Nam; University of South-Eastern Norway, Kongsberg, Norway; Korea Institute of Geoscience and Mineral Resources, Daejeon, South Korea; University of Science and Technology (UST), Daejeon, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Truong, Xuan Luan, Faculty of Information Technology, Hanoi University of Mining and Geology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Mitamura, Muneki, Graduate School for Creative Cities, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Kono, Yasuyuki, Center for Southeast Asian Studies, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Raghavan, Venkatesh, Graduate School for Creative Cities, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Yonezawa, Go, Graduate School for Creative Cities, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Truong, Xuan Quang, Faculty of Information Technology, Hanoi University of Natural Resources and Environment, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Do, Thihang, Faculty of Information Technology, Hanoi University of Mining and Geology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Graduate School for Creative Cities, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Tien Bui, D., Department of Business and IT, University of South-Eastern Norway, Kongsberg, Norway; Saro, Lee M., Geological Research Division, Korea Institute of Geoscience and Mineral Resources, Daejeon, South Korea, Department of Geophysical Exploration, University of Science and Technology (UST), Daejeon, South Korea
Abstract: The objective of this research is introduce a new machine learning ensemble approach that is a hybridization of Bagging ensemble (BE) and Logistic Model Trees (LMTree), named as BE-LMtree, for improving the performance of the landslide susceptibility model. The LMTree is a relatively new machine learning algorithm that was rarely explored for landslide study, whereas BE is an ensemble framework that has proven highly efficient for landslide modeling. Upper Reaches Area of Red River Basin (URRB) in Northwest region of Viet Nam was employed as a case study. For this work, a GIS database for the URRB area has been established, which contains a total of 255 landslide polygons and eight predisposing factors i.e., slope, aspect, elevation, land cover, soil type, lithology, distance to fault, and distance to river. The database was then used to construct and validate the proposed BE-LMTree model. Quality of the final BE-LMTree model was checked using confusion matrix and a set of statistical measures. The result showed that the performance of the proposed BE-LMTree model is high with the classification accuracy is 93.81% on the training dataset and the prediction capability is 83.4% on the on the validation dataset. When compared to the support vector machine model and the LMTree model, the proposed BE-LMTree model performs better; therefore, we concluded that the BE-LMTree could prove to be a new efficient tool that should be used for landslide modeling. This research could provide useful results for landslide modeling in landslide prone areas. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Bagging Ensemble; Gis; Landslide; Logistic Model Trees; Vietnam

Author full names: Do, Loc Quang (56681076500); Thuy, Ha Tran Thi (57195632555); Bui, Tung Thanh Quyen (57211373464); Dau, Van Thanh (8899357100); Nguyen, Ngoc Viet (57194186619); Chu Duc, Trinh Chu (15022471300); Chun-Ping, JEN (7101860105)
Title: Dielectrophoresis Microfluidic Enrichment Platform with Built-In Capacitive Sensor for Rare Tumor Cell Detection
Affiliations: Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Sumitomo Chemical. Ltd, Hyogo Prefecture, Japan; National Chung Cheng University, Min-Hsiung, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Do, Loc Quang, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Thuy, Ha Tran Thi, Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Bui, Tung Thanh Quyen, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Dau, Van Thanh, Research Group (Environmental Health), Sumitomo Chemical. Ltd, Hyogo Prefecture, Japan; Nguyen, Ngoc Viet, Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Chung Cheng University, Min-Hsiung, Taiwan; Chu Duc, Trinh Chu, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Chun-Ping, JEN, Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Chung Cheng University, Min-Hsiung, Taiwan
Abstract: The manipulation and detection of rare cells are important for many applications in early disease diagnosis and medicine. This study presents a dielectrophoresis (DEP) microfluidic enrichment platform combined with a built-in capacitive sensor for circulating tumor cell detection. The microchip is composed of a lollipop-shaped gold microelectrode structure under a polydimethylsiloxane chamber. A prototype of the device was fabricated using standard micromachining technology. With the proposed device, target cells (in this study, A549 non-small human lung carcinoma and S-180 sarcoma cell lines) are firstly guided toward the center of the working chamber via DEP forces. Then, the target cells are captured by an electrode immobilized by anti-EGFR, which has high affinity toward the target cells. After the cell concentration process, the differential capacitance is read to detect the presence of the target cells. Numerical simulations and measurement experiments were performed to demonstrate the high sensitivity of differential capacitive sensing. The obtained results show high sensitivity for S-180 cell detection (3 mV/cell). The proposed platform is suitable for rapid cancer diagnoses and other metabolic disease applications. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: B.L., Vong, Binh Long; T.Q., Bui, Thang Quoc; T., Tomita, Tsutomu; H., Sakamoto, Hiroaki; Y., Hiramatsu, Yuji; Y., Nagasaki, Yukio
Author full names: Vong, Binh Long (55366287800); Bui, Thang Quoc (57201744213); Tomita, Tsutomu (59081401000); Sakamoto, Hiroaki (55426522300); Hiramatsu, Yuji (55621341500); Nagasaki, Yukio (7006029895)
Title: Novel angiogenesis therapeutics by redox injectable hydrogel - Regulation of local nitric oxide generation for effective cardiovascular therapy
Affiliations: University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Timelapse Vision Inc., Shiki, Japan; University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Vong, Binh Long, Department of Materials Science, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan, Department of Biochemistry, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Bui, Thang Quoc, Department of Cardiovascular Surgery, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Tomita, Tsutomu, Timelapse Vision Inc., Shiki, Japan; Sakamoto, Hiroaki, Department of Cardiovascular Surgery, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Hiramatsu, Yuji, Department of Cardiovascular Surgery, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Nagasaki, Yukio, Department of Materials Science, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan, Master's School of Medical Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan, Center for Research in Isotopes and Environmental Dynamics, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: Nitric oxide (NO) possesses various functions in cardiovascular diseases; however, due to an extremely short half-life and low bioavailability, its therapeutic application is limited. In inflamed tissues, overproduced reactive oxygen species (ROS) rapidly react with the endogenous NO, reducing its bioavailability. Here, we developed a controllable NO-releasing redox injectable hydrogel (NO-RIG) formed by the electrostatic crosslinking between the polyion complex flower-type micelles composing of functional polymers to scavenge overproduced ROS and regulate the local NO expression level simultaneously. After the intracardiac injection to mice, NO-RIG converted to gel via physiological temperature-responsive character, distributed homogeneously, and retained in the myocardial tissue for more than 10 d. Treatment with NO-RIG remarkably decreased the infarction size and improved the heart function after myocardial infarction when compared to control injectable hydrogels, such as a simple NO-releasing or ROS-scavenging injectable gels. We found that NO-RIG treatment significantly enhanced the angiogenesis and new blood vessels formation in mice through the regulation of the NO sustained release and redox equilibrium. NO-RIG presents high potential in preventing and treating cardiovascular diseases. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Synthesis of poly(3-hexylthiophene) based rod-coil conjugated block copolymers: Via photoinduced metal-free atom transfer radical polymerization
Affiliations: Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kanagawa University, Yokohama, Japan; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Tam Huu, Faculty of Materials Technology, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Le Thu Thi, Faculty of Materials Technology, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Viet Quoc, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ngoc Tan Phan, Lan, Faculty of Materials Technology, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Zhang, Geng, Department of Material and Life Chemistry, Kanagawa University, Yokohama, Japan; Yokozawa, Tsutomu, Department of Material and Life Chemistry, Kanagawa University, Yokohama, Japan; Thuy Thi Phung, Dung, Faculty of Materials Technology, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Ha Tran T., Faculty of Materials Technology, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: The photo-mediated "metal-free" atom transfer radical polymerization approach has been investigated for the first time to polymerize methyl methacrylate, N,N-dimethylamino-2-ethyl methacrylate, 2-([4,6-dichlorotriazin-2-yl]oxy)ethyl methacrylate and a mixture of methyl methacrylate and 1-pyrenemethyl methacrylate from a regioregular poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT) macroinitiator to produce well-defined rod-coil conjugated diblock copolymers, highly relevant for use as organic electronic materials without metal catalyst contamination. This was achieved using pyrene and a pyrenyl N-substituted phenothiazine (PPTh) as UV light photoredox catalysts. Spectral and chromatographic results revealed that the applied synthetic approach generated P3HT-based diblock copolymers in a controlled manner and with narrow molecular weight distributions (≤ 1.3). From a comparison of the efficiency of the photocatalysts, PPTh has shown advantages over pyrene, including much lower catalyst content and higher polymerization conversions. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Nanoporous Copper-Silver Alloys by Additive-Controlled Electrodeposition for the Selective Electroreduction of CO2 to Ethylene and Ethanol
Source title: Journal of the American Chemical Society

Abstract: Electrodeposition of CuAg alloy films from plating baths containing 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole (DAT) as an inhibitor yields high surface area catalysts for the active and selective electroreduction of CO<inf>2</inf> to multicarbon hydrocarbons and oxygenates. EXAFS shows the co-deposited alloy film to be homogeneously mixed. The alloy film containing 6% Ag exhibits the best CO<inf>2</inf> electroreduction performance, with the Faradaic efficiency for C<inf>2</inf>H<inf>4</inf> and C<inf>2</inf>H<inf>5</inf>OH production reaching nearly 60 and 25%, respectively, at a cathode potential of just -0.7 V vs RHE and a total current density of ∼- 300 mA/cm2. Such high levels of selectivity at high activity and low applied potential are the highest reported to date. In situ Raman and electroanalysis studies suggest the origin of the high selectivity toward C<inf>2</inf> products to be a combined effect of the enhanced stabilization of the Cu<inf>2</inf>O overlayer and the optimal availability of the CO intermediate due to the Ag incorporated in the alloy. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Le, Thihang; L.T., Son, Le Thanh; Q.D., Truong, Quang Duc

Title: Synthesis of Europium-doped Yttrium Picolinate Microspheres and Photoluminescence Properties
Affiliations: Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Le, Thihang, Department of Applied Chemistry, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Son, Le Thanh, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Truong, Quang Duc, Ceramics and Biomaterials Research Group, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Faculty of Applied Sciences, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Institute of Multidisciplinary Research for Advanced Materials, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Abstract: Europium-doped yttrium picolinate microspheres have been synthesized by a facile aqueous solution method using picolinic acid as complexing as well as structure-directing agents. The synthesized particles are composed of microspheres with europium-doped yttrium picolinate nanohybrids as building blocks which are stacked together driven by mutual interactions of organic components. The formula of undoped hybrid was determined as Y(OH)<inf>2</inf>(C<inf>6</inf>H<inf>4</inf>NCOO)•1.5H<inf>2</inf>O based on thermogravimetry (TG), elemental analysis and Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy. The formation of the hybrid microspheres can be explained on the basis of metal-ligand complexation and self-assembly through π-π interactions. Picolinic acid was found to play dual roles as chelating and structure-directing agents for manipulating the particle morphology. The europium-doped yttrium picolinate shows strong red luminescence due to an efficient energy transfer from pyridyl rings to luminescent Eu centers. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H.N.T., Le, Hanh Ngoc Thi; K., Imamura, Kiyoshi; N., Watanabe, Norie; M., Furuta, Masakazu; N., Takenaka, Norimichi; L., van Boi, Luu; Y., Maeda, Yasuaki
Author full names: Le, Hanh Ngoc Thi (57201462555); Imamura, Kiyoshi (57202410922); Watanabe, Norie (15126303800); Furuta, Masakazu (7103086416); Takenaka, Norimichi (7007012272); van Boi, Luu (6507028401); Maeda, Yasuaki (55797766600)
Title: Biodiesel Production from Rubber Seed Oil by Transesterification Using a Co-solvent of Fatty Acid Methyl Esters
Affiliations: Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Bridgestone Corporation, Chuo-Ku, Japan; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; An Giang University, Long Xuyen, An Giang Province, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Le, Hanh Ngoc Thi, Department of Quantum and Radiation Engineering, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan, Faculty of Education, An Giang University, Long Xuyen, An Giang Province, Viet Nam; Imamura, Kiyoshi, Research Organization for University-Community Collaborations, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Watanabe, Norie, Central Research, Bridgestone Corporation, Chuo-Ku, Japan; Furuta, Masakazu, Department of Quantum and Radiation Engineering, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Takenaka, Norimichi, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; van Boi, Luu, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Maeda, Yasuaki, Research Organization for University-Community Collaborations, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: Rubber seed oil (RSO) is a high-potential feedstock for the production of biodiesel fuel (BDF) in Asia. Transesterification using fatty acid methyl esters (FAMEs) as co-solvents was developed for BDF production from RSO with high content of free fatty acids (FFAs). The homogeneous system (FAMEs/triglyceride/methanol) was attained when the FAME content was more than 30 wt %. After esterification of RSO, the crude RSO obtained was transesterified with FAMEs as a co-solvent. The quality of BDF with high FAME content satisfied the criteria of the EN 14214/JIS K2390 standards. These results suggest that FAMEs converted from FFAs can be applied as a co-solvent and, thus, reused for BDF production. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: K., Yasuda, Keiji; T.T., Nguyen, Tam Thanh; Y., Asakura, Yoshiyuki
Author full names: Yasuda, Keiji (7403377802); Nguyen, Tam Thanh (57209166140); Asakura, Yoshiyuki (7103285701)
Title: Measurement of distribution of broadband noise and sound pressures in sonochemical reactor
Affiliations: Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan; University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Honda Electronics Co., Ltd., Toyohashi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yasuda, Keiji, Department of Chemical System Engineering, Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan; Nguyen, Tam Thanh, Department of Chemical System Engineering, Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan, Faculty of Environment, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Asakura, Yoshiyuki, Honda Electronics Co., Ltd., Toyohashi, Japan
Abstract: Cross-sectional area distribution of broadband noise in a sonochemical reactor was measured to estimate reaction fields. A needle-type hydrophone scanned the sonochemical reactor in horizontal and vertical directions at one-millimeter interval. To show an absolute value of broadband noise, average of broadband sound pressure was defined. The distribution of sound pressures at the fundamental and second harmonic frequencies were also measured. In the case of driving frequency at 130 kHz, sonochemical reaction fields were observed in several ellipse shapes. The reaction fields in upper part of the reactor was high because cavitation bubbles moved upper part due to radiation force. The sound pressure distribution at the fundamental frequency showed existence of standing wave and reaction fields were weak at pressure antinode because cavitation bubbles were repelled by primary Bjerknes force. The sound pressure distribution at the second harmonic frequency indicated that the pattern of bubbles distribution resembled to that of reaction fields closely. In the case at 43 kHz, distributions of reaction fields and sound pressures were complex due to coupled vibration. The reaction fields were relatively weak in areas which had very high sound pressures at the fundamental frequency. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H.N.T., Le, Hanh Ngoc Thi; K., Imamura, Kiyoshi; M., Furuta, Masakazu; L., van Boi, Luu; Y., Maeda, Yasuaki
Author full names: Le, Hanh Ngoc Thi (57201462555); Imamura, Kiyoshi (57202410922); Furuta, Masakazu (7103086416); van Boi, Luu (6507028401); Maeda, Yasuaki (55797766600)
Title: Production of biodiesel from Vernicia Montana Lour. Oil using a co-solvent method and the subsequent evaluation of its stability during storage
Affiliations: Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; An Giang University, Long Xuyen City, An Giang, Viet Nam; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Le, Hanh Ngoc Thi, Department of Quantum and Radiation Engineering, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan, Faculty of Education, An Giang University, Long Xuyen City, An Giang, Viet Nam; Imamura, Kiyoshi, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Furuta, Masakazu, Department of Quantum and Radiation Engineering, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; van Boi, Luu, Faculty of Chemistry, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Maeda, Yasuaki, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: The costs associated with the production of biodiesel fuel (BDF) are directly affected by the nature of the feedstock material and the methods used during the production process. In Southeast Asia, many non-edible oils are used to produce BDFs, as exemplified by the recent use of the non-edible oil derived from Vernicia montana Lour. in Laos and Vietnam for the production of BDF. In this work, we developed an improved procedure for the production of BDF from Vernicia montana oil consisting of 80.3%±0.5% α-eleostearic acid moiety (C18:3) using a co-solvent method. Furthermore, the stability of the BDF was evaluated based on its iodine value and unsaturated ester content. The optimized production conditions were determined to be as follows: methanol/oil molar ratio of 6:1, 1% (wt/wt) KOH, 20% (wt/wt) acetone as a co-solvent, and a reaction temperature of 40°C. Under these conditions, we achieved a BDF conversion efficiency of 99%±0.3% within 30 min of initiating the transesterification process. Notably, the BDF produced from Vernicia montana oil showed good stability to air at temperatures ≤30°C for 1 month, showing similar stability properties to the BDF produced from rapeseed oil. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Binh, Tran Thanh (55415987700); Tuan, Vo Phuoc (57195367045); Dung, Ho Dang Quy (56681908900); Tung, Phamhuu (57193226531); Tri, Tran Dinh (57193226752); Thuan, Ngo Phuong Minh (57193231097); Tam, Lequang (57193220206); Nam, Buichi (57193229159); Giang, Doanh (57200991756); Hoan, Phan Quoc (56596695900)
Title: Molecular epidemiology of helicobacter pylori infection in a minor ethnic group of Vietnam: A multiethnic, population-based study
Affiliations: Oita University Faculty of Medicine, Yufu, Japan; Cho Ray Hospital, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Daklak Hospital, Viet Nam; Lao Cai Hospital, Viet Nam; Bach Mai Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; 108 Military Central Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Oita University Faculty of Medicine, Yufu, Japan; 108 Military Central Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, United States
Authors with affiliations: Binh, Tran Thanh, Department of Environmental and Preventive Medicine, Oita University Faculty of Medicine, Yufu, Japan, Department of Endoscopy, Cho Ray Hospital, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tuan, Vo Phuoc, Department of Environmental and Preventive Medicine, Oita University Faculty of Medicine, Yufu, Japan, Department of Endoscopy, Cho Ray Hospital, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Dung, Ho Dang Quy, Department of Endoscopy, Cho Ray Hospital, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tung, Phamhuu, Department of Endoscopy, Cho Ray Hospital, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tri, Tran Dinh, Department of Endoscopy, Cho Ray Hospital, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thuan, Ngo Phuong Minh, Department of Endoscopy, Cho Ray Hospital, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tam, Lequang, Department of Endoscopy, Daklak Hospital, Viet Nam; Nam, Buichi, Department of Endoscopy, Lao Cai Hospital, Viet Nam; Giang, Doanh, Department of Endoscopy, Bach Mai Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hoan, Phan Quoc, Department of Molecular Biology, 108 Military Central Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: The Helicobacter pylori-induced burden of gastric cancer varies based on geographical regions and ethnic grouping. Vietnam is a multiethnic country with the highest incidence of gastric cancer in Southeast Asia, but previous studies focused only on the Kinh ethnic group. A population-based cross-sectional study was conducted using 494 volunteers (18–78 years old), from 13 ethnic groups in Daklak and Lao Cai provinces, Vietnam. H. pylori status was determined by multiple tests (rapid urease test, culture, histology, and serology). cagA and vacA genotypes were determined by PCR-based sequencing. The overall H. pylori infection rate was 38.1%. Multivariate analysis showed that variations in geographical region, age, and ethnicity were independent factors associated with the risk of H. pylori acquisition. Therefore, multicenter, multiethnic, population based study is essential to assess the H. pylori prevalence and its burden in the general population. Only the E De ethnicity carried strains with Western-type CagA (82%) and exhibited significantly lower gastric mucosal inflammation compared to other ethnic groups. However, the histological scores ofWestern-type CagA and East-Asian-type CagA within the E De group showed no significant differences. Thus, in addition to bacterial virulence factors, host factors are likely to be important determinants for gastric mucosal inflammation and contribute to the Asian enigma. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: V., Van Pham, Viet; T.B., Phan, Thang Bach; D.M., Mott, Derrick M.; S., Maenosono, Shinya; T.T., Sang, Truong Tan; C.M., Thi, Cao Minh; L.V., Hieu, Le Van
Author full names: Van Pham, Viet (57224559491); Phan, Thang Bach (56182322400); Mott, Derrick M. (8256268300); Maenosono, Shinya (6701605610); Sang, Truong Tan (57196372698); Thi, Cao Minh (55315987000); Hieu, Le Van (59158005100)
Title: Silver nanoparticle loaded TiO2 nanotubes with high photocatalytic and antibacterial activity synthesized by photoreduction method
Source title: Journal of Photochemistry and Photobiology A: Chemistry
Affiliations: University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Van Pham, Viet, Nanomaterials for Environmental Applications Laboratory, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Phan, Thang Bach, Nanomaterials for Environmental Applications Laboratory, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Mott, Derrick M., School of Materials Science, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Maenosono, Shinya, School of Materials Science, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Sang, Truong Tan, CM Thi Laboratory, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thi, Cao Minh, CM Thi Laboratory, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Hieu, Le Van, Nanomaterials for Environmental Applications Laboratory, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: Silver nanoparticles (Ag NPs) were loaded on TiO<inf>2</inf> nanotubes (TNTs) via photoreduction method at room temperature without any additional reducing agent. The morphology and crystal structure were examined by transmission electron microscopy, X–ray diffraction pattern, and Raman spectroscopy. Chemical states of silver, titanium, and oxygen were analyzed by X–ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The results showed that Ag NPs with an average diameter of 5 nm were uniformly distributed on TNTs surface. Ag NPs improved both photocatalytic and the antibacterial activity of TNTs under sunlight irradiation. Ag/TNTs decomposed 81.2% of methylene blue and 75.8% of methylene orange after 150 min under sunlight irradiation. In addition, Ag/TNTs at 20 ppm concentration eliminated 99.99% of Staphylococcus aureus after 60 min under sunlight irradiation. This research demonstrated that Ag/TNTs can be synthesized at industrial scale by the photoreduction method and are effective antibacterial materials. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M., Kurjogi, Mahantesh; P., Satapute, Praveen; S., Jogaiah, Sudisha; M., Abdelrahman, Mostafa; J.R., Daddam, Jayasimha Rayalu; V., Ramu, Venkatesh; L.S.P., Tran, Lam Son Phan
Author full names: Kurjogi, Mahantesh (55203679900); Satapute, Praveen (57189713878); Jogaiah, Sudisha (16744010100); Abdelrahman, Mostafa (56542956600); Daddam, Jayasimha Rayalu (58494651000); Ramu, Venkatesh (57200549394); Tran, Lam Son Phan (7102277565)
Title: Computational modeling of the staphylococcal enterotoxins and its interaction with natural antitoxin compounds
Affiliations: Karnatak University Dharwad, Dharwad, India; Faculty of Science, Aswan, Egypt; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University Anantapur, Anantapur, India; Indian Institute of Science, Bengaluru, India; Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; RIKEN Center for Sustainable Resource Science, Yokohama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kurjogi, Mahantesh, PG Department of Studies in Biotechnology and Microbiology, Karnatak University Dharwad, Dharwad, India; Satapute, Praveen, PG Department of Studies in Biotechnology and Microbiology, Karnatak University Dharwad, Dharwad, India; Jogaiah, Sudisha, PG Department of Studies in Biotechnology and Microbiology, Karnatak University Dharwad, Dharwad, India; Abdelrahman, Mostafa, Department of Botany, Faculty of Science, Aswan, Egypt, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Daddam, Jayasimha Rayalu, Department of Biotechnology, Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University Anantapur, Anantapur, India; Ramu, Venkatesh, Department of Biochemistry, Indian Institute of Science, Bengaluru, India; Tran, Lam Son Phan, Institute of Research and Development, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam, Signaling Pathway Research Unit, RIKEN Center for Sustainable Resource Science, Yokohama, Japan
Abstract: Staphylococcus aureus is an opportunistic bacterium that produces various types of toxins, resulting in serious food poisoning. Staphylococcal enterotoxins (SEs) are heat-stable and resistant to hydrolysis by digestive enzymes, representing a potential hazard for consumers worldwide. In the present study, we used amino-acid sequences encoding SEA and SEB-like to identify their respective template structure and build the three-dimensional (3-D) models using homology modeling method. Two natural compounds, Betulin and 28-Norolean-12-en-3-one, were selected for docking study on the basis of the criteria that they satisfied the Lipinski’s Rule-of-Five. A total of 14 and 13 amino-acid residues were present in the best binding site predicted in the SEA and SEB-like, respectively, using the Computer Atlas of Surface Topology of Proteins (CASTp). Among these residues, the docking study with natural compounds Betulin and 28-Norolean-12-en-3-one revealed that GLN43 and GLY227 in the binding site of the SEA, each formed a hydrogen-bond interaction with 28-Norolean-12-en-3-one; while GLY227 residue established a hydrogen bond with Betulin. In the case of SEB-like, the docking study demonstrated that ASN87 and TYR88 residues in its binding site formed hydrogen bonds with Betulin; whereas HIS59 in the binding site formed a hydrogen-bond interaction with 28-Norolean-12-en-3-one. Our results demonstrate that the toxic effects of these two SEs can be effectively treated with antitoxins like Betulin and 28-Norolean-12-en-3-one, which could provide an effective drug therapy for this pathogen. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.T.Q., Bui, Tung Thanh Quyen; T., Dinh, Thienxuan; C.D., Tran, Canh Dung; T.C., Chu Duc, Trinh Chu; V.T., Dau, Van Thanh
Author full names: Bui, Tung Thanh Quyen (57211373464); Dinh, Thienxuan (7103165009); Tran, Canh Dung (27667914300); Chu Duc, Trinh Chu (15022471300); Dau, Van Thanh (8899357100)
Title: A study of ion wind generator using parallel arranged electrode configuration for centrifugal flow mixer
Affiliations: Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ritsumeikan University Biwako-Kusatsu Campus, Kusatsu, Japan; University of Southern Queensland, Toowoomba, Australia; Griffith University, Brisbane, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Bui, Tung Thanh Quyen, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Dinh, Thienxuan, Ritsumeikan University Biwako-Kusatsu Campus, Kusatsu, Japan; Tran, Canh Dung, School of Mechanical and Electrical Engineering, University of Southern Queensland, Toowoomba, Australia; Chu Duc, Trinh Chu, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Dau, Van Thanh, School of Engineering and Built Environment, Griffith University, Brisbane, Australia
Abstract: Ion wind is recently applied in various research areas such as the biomedical engineering, microfluidic mixing and particle manipulation. In this work, a bipolar ion wind generator configured by parallel arranged electrodes is used for centrifugal mixing applications. With the proposed configuration, negative and positive ion winds are simultaneously generated, mixed and then neutralized by each other while travelling toward liquid surface. The efficiency of the device was investigated both computationally and experimentally. The mixing of liquid occurred in different ways when the system is activated by either direct or alternating currents. Furthermore, the mixing is dependent on the dimension of electrode tip. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N.T., Tung, Nguyen Thanh; T.D., Farha, Trisha Diba; H., Tsutsui, Hidekazu; L.T.N., Truong, Lien Thi Ngoc; Y., Ohno, Yasuhide; K., Maehashi, Kenzo; K., Matsumoto, Kazuhiko; M., Biyani, Manish; P., Tue, Phantrong; Y., Takamura, Yuzuru
Author full names: Tung, Nguyen Thanh (57200034403); Farha, Trisha Diba (57210121239); Tsutsui, Hidekazu (15736399500); Truong, Lien Thi Ngoc (48663052300); Ohno, Yasuhide (7401514922); Maehashi, Kenzo (7003464377); Matsumoto, Kazuhiko (8435356100); Biyani, Manish (6603433406); Tue, Phantrong (36474285700); Takamura, Yuzuru (8552872900)
Title: Development of glutamate biosensor based on the integration of network SWCNT-FET and glutamate-binding protein
Affiliations: Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tokushima University, Tokushima, Japan; Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Japan; The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan

Abstract: We report a new platform for glutamate (Glu) detection based on the integration of glutamate-binding protein (GBP) probe molecule into the network single-walled carbon nanotube field-effect transistor (SWCNT-FET) transducer. The GBP that specifically recognizes Glu was used as the probe molecule to overcome the biofouling occurrence from other electroactive species in the conventional enzymatic-based Glu sensors. The network SWCNT-FET, which is highly stable and sensitive, was utilized as the transducer. The GBP was immobilized on the network SWCNT via 1-pyrenebutanoic acid succinimidyl ester. As the result, the fabricated sensor could monitor Glu in real-time at micromolar range with high selectivity. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M., Vu, Minhchien; T., Satomi, Tomoaki; H., Takahashi, Hiroshi; A.T., Le, Anh Tuan
Author full names: Vu, Minhchien (57211373956); Satomi, Tomoaki (54922505400); Takahashi, Hiroshi (55711673600); Le, Anh Tuan (57218500775)
Title: Study on weak soil improvement by using geopolymer and paper fragments
Source title: International Journal of the Society of Materials Engineering for Resources
Affiliations: Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Bach Khoa University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Vu, Minhchien, Graduate School of Environmental Studies, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Satomi, Tomoaki, Graduate School of Environmental Studies, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Takahashi, Hiroshi, Graduate School of Environmental Studies, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Le, Anh Tuan, Faculty of Civil Engineering, Bach Khoa University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: Landslide or landslip is one of the natural disasters which is unfortunately unavoidable. We have already established the Fiber-Cement-Stabilized Soil Method that can improve the weak soil of actual landslide areas engendered from an earthquake or heavy rainfall by using paper fragments and cement. However, nowadays, the cost of fiber (paper debris) is tending to increase and Portland cement is not environmentally friendly cementitious material for sustainable development. In this research, Geopolymer which expects to modify soft soil (sludge) at low degree Celsius condition and reduces amount additive of fiber is executed. The process of Geopolymerization involving the silicates and aluminates exacted from by-products is contemplated as a mature and cost-effective solution to many problems where hazardous residue has to be treated and stored under critical environmental conditions. This paper presents the details of the study carried out on the characteristic of sludge improved Fiber-Geopolymer-Stabilized Soil Method. The composition of imitation sludge was 60% silt, 40% clay and 70% water content. Sodium hydroxide (NaOH) 12 Molar and sodium silicate solution (Na<inf>2</inf>SiO<inf>3</inf>) were prepared. The test specimens were made of 50 x 100 mm cylindrical mold and 20℃ temperature curing condition. The result of modified sludge shows the improvement in strength, strain and high durability with drying and wetting tests regardless of the increase in experimenting rounds. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N.X., Loc, Nguyen Xuan; P.T.M., Do, Phuong Thi My; C.H., Nguyen, Chiem Huu; R., Kose, Ryota; T., Okayama, Takayuki; T.N., Pham, Thoa N.; N.T., Phuong, Nguyen Thanh; T., Miyanishi, Takayuki
Author full names: Loc, Nguyen Xuan (57208727326); Do, Phuong Thi My (57203431960); Nguyen, Chiem Huu (57211539447); Kose, Ryota (14919490200); Okayama, Takayuki (7006378610); Pham, Thoa N. (57211537434); Phuong, Nguyen Thanh (8379210700); Miyanishi, Takayuki (7003475769)
Title: Properties of biochars prepared from local biomass in the Mekong Delta, Vietnam
Affiliations: Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Graduate School of Fisheries and Environmental Sciences, Nagasaki, Japan; Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Loc, Nguyen Xuan, College of Environment and Natural Resources, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Do, Phuong Thi My, College of Environment and Natural Resources, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam, Institute of Agriculture, Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Japan; Nguyen, Chiem Huu, College of Environment and Natural Resources, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Kose, Ryota, Institute of Agriculture, Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Japan; Okayama, Takayuki, Institute of Agriculture, Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Japan; Pham, Thoa N., College of Environment and Natural Resources, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Phuong, Nguyen Thanh, College of Environment and Natural Resources, Can Tho University, Can Tho, Viet Nam; Miyanishi, Takayuki, Graduate School of Fisheries and Environmental Sciences, Nagasaki, Japan
Abstract: Wood- (bamboo and melaleuca) and herbaceous-based (rice husk and water hyacinth) biochars, produced from local biomass by slow pyrolysis at 500 °C, 700 °C, and 900 °C, were examined for their physical and chemical properties. The wood-based biomass produced biochars with lower ash contents (<14 wt.%db ash) and higher fixed carbon contents (> 54 wt.%db), greater higher heating value (>23 MJ/kg), higher degree of aromaticity (with O/C, H/C, and volatile matter/fixed carbon ratios were less than 0.08, 0.51, and 0.61, respectively), and smaller amount of salt nutrients (<76 g/kgdb) compared with those of the herbaceous-based biochars. Their unique properties have generated more interest in using them as a solid fuel, for carbon sequestration, and for soil amendment. The rice husk biochars contained more than 300 g/kgdb silica, which is potential for silicophilic plants. The water hyacinth biochars with the greatest volatile matter/fixed carbon (ranging from 0.72 to 2.35), and highest O/C ratios (0.11 to 0.18), indicating the lowest aromaticity among studied biochars and thus maybe least suitability for carbon sequestration. They also possessed a highest soluble salts content (>240 g/kgdb), highest electrical conductivity (>6489 μS/cm), and greatest liming potential (>6.56 %CaCO<inf>3</inf>-eq), which may not be suitable for salt-sensitive plants or low-buffer capacity soils. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Multi-physics analysis of the thermal behavior of inductor by using open-source software
Affiliations: Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Zheng, Mengyi, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Doan, Hongduc, Advanced Materials and Structures Laboratory, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Fushinobu, Kazuyoshi, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Inductors are one of the most important components during the early-stage thermal design of electronic equipment. The objective of this research is to develop a multi-physics simulation method for inductors' thermal analysis by using open source software with finite element method (FEM). Both two-dimensional model and three-dimensional model of low-frequency inductor have been built for comparison using the partial differential equation solver FreeFem++. Maxwell's equations and heat conduction equation based model are introduced. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Abstract: Iron oxide (Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>) is considered as an excellent catalyst for reduction of hydrogen sulphide (H<inf>2</inf>S) due to not only good sulphur adsorption capacity but also low cost. However, the catalytic effect of Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> is deactivated rapidly after running. Doping heteroatoms is assumed to improve its catalytic activity and extend its life time. Among doped heteroatoms, cerium doping on Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> has exhibited an extremely high catalytic activity. In this paper, the iron cerium oxide (FeCeO<inf>x</inf>) nanoparticles were synthesised by temperature- and time-controlled hydrothermal method. The FeCeO<inf>x</inf> nanoparticles were characterised by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy and field emission scanning electron microscopy and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (FESEM-EDX). The results showed that the average particle size of the obtained FeCeO<inf>x</inf> was less than 40 nm and size distribution was narrow. Remarkably, the synthesised nanoscale-sized FeCeO<inf>x</inf> compound was not only highly pure but also uniform without traces of Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> or FeOOH at 80°C for 16 h. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A., Kimura, Akihiro; M., Kato, Mahiro; H., Doan, Hongduc; K., Fushinobu, Kazuyoshi
Author full names: Kimura, Akihiro (59802035900); Kato, Mahiro (57200816696); Doan, Hongduc (36182302500); Fushinobu, Kazuyoshi (7004131266)
Title: Oxygen transport prediction in the electrolyte membrane of PEMFC by using molecular dynamics simulation
Source title: International Conference on Computational Methods for Thermal Problems
Affiliations: Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Kimura, Akihiro, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Kato, Mahiro, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Doan, Hongduc, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Fushinobu, Kazuyoshi, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Effect of force field selection and the parameters are investigated on the prediction of molecular transport of oxygen in the electrolyte membrane of PEMFC (proton exchange membrane fuel cell.) Simulation has been conducted by using GROMACS. Various force fields are examined to compare the calculated density to choose the AMBERGS with parameter adjustment. The results predict the density within 5% or relative error to the experimental value, and the value of D (relative diffusion coefficient of oxygen to the humidified electrolyte membrane) within about 20% of relative error to the experiment in the range of λ (water content) between 2.5 to 7.5. The results also predict the decreasing trend of D with increasing T (temperature of the membrane) within the range of 80 ˚C to 30 ˚C. Comparison between calculated and experimentally obtained values of Ea (activation energy obtained from the Arrhenius plot of D) with various λ are also disccussed to show that the calculated values are relatively smaller than the values in membrane and closer to the value in bulk water. The results can be due to the domain size. Further study is needed to simulate much larger computational domain to see the effect on the data prediction. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Force Field; Molecular Dynamics Simulation; Pemfc

Authors: T.N., Phong, Thanh Nguyen; V., Likhitruangsilp, Veerasak; M., Onishi, Masamitsu

Title: Prioritizing factors affecting traffic volume of public-private partnership infrastructure projects
Source title: International Journal of Engineering and Technology (UAE)
Affiliations: Đại học Mở Thành phố Hồ Chí Minh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Phong, Thanh Nguyen, Department of Project Management, Đại học Mở Thành phố Hồ Chí Minh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Department of Civil Engineering, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Likhitruangsilp, Veerasak, Department of Civil Engineering, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Onishi, Masamitsu, Research Center for Disaster Reduction Systems, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan
Abstract: Public-private partnership (PPP) is an effective alternative for raising capital for infrastructure projects and has been a popular trend in developing countries recently. A key factor that affects the success of PPP transportation projects is traffic demand because it directly influences project revenue. Inaccurate traffic demand estimates may lead to financial difficulties for private partners. This paper applies fuzzy extended analytic method (FEAM) to prioritize critical factors that affect traffic volume of PPP infrastructure projects. The results benefit both public and private sectors for realizing key factors for the success of PPP infrastructure project implementation. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Fuzzy Extent Analysis Method; Fuzzy Logic; Infrastructure; Public-private Partnership (ppp); Traffic Volume

Authors: V., van Thanh, Vuong; N., Tuan Hung, Nguyen; D., van Truong, Do
Author full names: van Thanh, Vuong (36949866300); Tuan Hung, Nguyen (56912954900); van Truong, Do (15756283400)
Title: Charge-induced electromechanical actuation of Mo- and W-dichalcogenide monolayers
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: van Thanh, Vuong, Department of Design of Machinery and Robot, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tuan Hung, Nguyen, Department of Physics, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; van Truong, Do, Department of Mechatronics, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, International Institute for Computational Science and Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Using first-principle density functional calculations, we investigate electromechanical properties of two-dimensional MX<inf>2</inf> (M = Mo, W; X = S, Se, Te) monolayers with the 1H and 1T structures as a function of charge doping for both electron and hole doping. We find that by increasing the atomic number, Z<inf>X</inf>, of X atoms (Z<inf>S</inf> < Z<inf>Se</inf> < Z<inf>Te</inf>), the work density per cycle of the MX<inf>2</inf> monolayers are increased and decreased for the 1H and 1T structures, respectively. On the other hand, the work density per cycle of the WX<inf>2</inf> monolayers are higher than that of the MoX<inf>2</inf> monolayers for both the 1H and 1T structures. Therefore, WTe<inf>2</inf> and WS<inf>2</inf> monolayers for the 1H and 1T structures, respectively, have the best electromechanical performances in the MX<inf>2</inf> compounds. In addition, the MX<inf>2</inf> monolayers show a reversible strain up to 3%, which is higher than that of graphene (∼1%). Our results provide an important insight into the electromechanical properties of the MX<inf>2</inf> monolayers, which are useful for artificial muscles applications. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Rogier Van (56941604800); Le van, Tan (57189414830); Chan, Yokefun Fun Chan (8091117300); Farrar, Jeremy James (7103292979); Oishi, Kazunori (7202376038)
Title: Epidemic dynamics, interactions and predictability of enteroviruses associated with hand, foot and mouth disease in Japan
Source title: Journal of the Royal Society Interface
Affiliations: Princeton School of Public and International Affairs, Princeton, United States; Infectious Disease Surveillance Center, United States; National Institute of Infectious Diseases, Tokyo, Japan; Oxford University Clinical Research Unit, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nuffield Department of Medicine, Oxford, United Kingdom; Universiti Malaya, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia; National Institutes of Health (NIH), Bethesda, United States
Authors with affiliations: Takahashi, Saki, ; Jessica E Metcalf, null, , Princeton School of Public and International Affairs, Princeton, United States; Arima, Yuzo, Infectious Disease Surveillance Center, United States; Fujimoto, Tsuguto, Infectious Disease Surveillance Center, United States; Shimizu, Hiroyuki, Department of Virology II, National Institute of Infectious Diseases, Tokyo, Japan; Doorn, H. Rogier Van, National Hospital for Tropical Diseases, Oxford University Clinical Research Unit, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Nuffield Department of Medicine, Oxford, United Kingdom; Le van, Tan, National Hospital for Tropical Diseases, Oxford University Clinical Research Unit, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Chan, Yokefun Fun Chan, Department of Medical Microbiology, Universiti Malaya, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia; Farrar, Jeremy James, National Hospital for Tropical Diseases, Oxford University Clinical Research Unit, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Nuffield Department of Medicine, Oxford, United Kingdom; Oishi, Kazunori, Infectious Disease Surveillance Center, United States
Abstract: Outbreaks of hand, foot and mouth disease have been documented in Japan since 1963. This disease is primarily caused by the two closely related serotypes of Enterovirus A71 (EV-A71) and Coxsackievirus A16 (CV-A16). Here, we analyse Japanese virologic and syndromic surveillance time-series data from 1982 to 2015. As in some other countries in the Asia Pacific region, EV-A71 in Japan has a 3 year cyclical component, whereas CV-A16 is predominantly annual. We observe empirical signatures of an inhibitory interaction between the serotypes; virologic lines of evidence suggest they may indeed interact immunologically. We fit the time series to mechanistic epidemiological models: as a first-order effect, we find the data consistent with single-serotype susceptible-infected-recovered dynamics. We then extend the modelling to incorporate an inhibitory interaction between serotypes. Our results suggest the existence of a transient cross-protection and possible asymmetry in its strength such that CV-A16 serves as a stronger forcing on EV-A71. Allowing for asymmetry yields accurate out-of-sample predictions and the directionality of this effect is consistent with the virologic literature. Confirmation of these hypothesized interactions would have important implications for understanding enterovirus epidemiology and informing vaccine development. Our results highlight the general implication that even subtle interactions could have qualitative impacts on epidemic dynamics and predictability. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Phuc, Le Thi Minh (57194598620); Sasaki, Tetsuji (56746852500); Shimizu, Hisayo (58447085800); Huyen, Nguyen Thi Minh (58717888100); Thuy, Nguyen Thi Thu (58308290200); Huan, Lequang (57202705682); Taniguchi, Akiyohshi (7102264165)
Title: Enhancement of recombinant antibody expression level by growth controlled medium
Affiliations: National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan; Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Biotechnology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kyokuto Pharmaceutical Industrial Co., Ltd., Chuo-Ku, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Phuc, Le Thi Minh, Cellular Functional Nanobiomaterials Group, National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan, Graduate School of Advanced Science and Engineering, Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Biotechnology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Sasaki, Tetsuji, Kyokuto Pharmaceutical Industrial Co., Ltd., Chuo-Ku, Japan; Shimizu, Hisayo, Kyokuto Pharmaceutical Industrial Co., Ltd., Chuo-Ku, Japan; Huyen, Nguyen Thi Minh, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Biotechnology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Thuy, Nguyen Thi Thu, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Biotechnology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Huan, Lequang, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Biotechnology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Taniguchi, Akiyohshi, Cellular Functional Nanobiomaterials Group, National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan, Graduate School of Advanced Science and Engineering, Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Background: Transient expression system is very widely used for protein expression including recombinant protein expression. Normally, in the commercially available expression system, cells were grown rapidly in protein expression. However, over cell growth was not only unnecessary for high level protein expression, but also induced cell death and led to protein degradation. Aims and Objectives: To overcome these limitations a new adapted culture method needs to be developed. Methods: In this work, we developed growth control medium for transient high protein expression system using NPLAd (Non-Protein and Lipid Medium Adopted) cells. With this system, cell numbers were not increased until 10 days. Results: Our results indicated that expression level in NPLAd system was 1.8 times higher than that in Free style system, which was one of the commercially available high expression systems. Conclusion: The antibody performance expressed by NPLAd system was almost the same to that of expressed by Free style system. The results suggested that NPLAd system could be useful for protein expression, such as recombinant antibody. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
