Authors: K.T., Nguyen, Kuong Trong; E., Uchino, Eiji; N., Suetake, Noriaki
Author full names: Nguyen, Kuong Trong (57202351243); Uchino, Eiji (55209443500); Suetake, Noriaki (6603040494)
Title: Recognition of coronary atherosclerotic plaque tissue on intravascular ultrasound images by using misclassification sensitive training of discriminative restricted boltzmann machine
Source title: Journal of Biomimetics, Biomaterials and Biomedical Engineering
Affiliations: Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi, Japan; Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Fuzzy Logic Systems Institute, Iizuka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Kuong Trong, Graduate School of Sciences and Technology for Innovation, Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi, Japan, Faculty of Information Technology, Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Uchino, Eiji, Graduate School of Sciences and Technology for Innovation, Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi, Japan, Fuzzy Logic Systems Institute, Iizuka, Japan; Suetake, Noriaki, Graduate School of Sciences and Technology for Innovation, Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi, Japan
Abstract: Coronary atherosclerotic plaque has been extensively studied in pathological research. Improving the evaluation of vulnerable rupture is important to prevent acute heart failure. Intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) method is one of techniques to acquire information about atherosclerotic plaque, which is backscattered ultrasound signal sensed by IVUS transducer. The vessel structure and tissue components are then characterized in relation to the acquired signals. In this study, eight human coronary vessel sections are involved, and we use discriminative restricted Boltzmann machine (RBM) to classify coronary tissues as a target classifier. The quantization domain of IVUS signals are used to extract binary features for adapting Gaussian model of RBM. In addition, we propose a misclassification sensitive training of disRBM to deal with the class imbalances. The results are compared to the conventional integrated backscattered IVUS method (IB-IVUS) and the cost sensitive neural network for the same tasks. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: P.N., Lan, Pham Ngoc; L., van Boi, Luu; H.D., Phuoc, Hung Duong; H.N.T., Le, Hanh Ngoc Thi; H.T., Truong, Hoa Thi; P., Duc Luu, Phuong; M., Furuta, Masakazu; K., Imamura, Kiyoshi; Y., Maeda, Yasuaki
Author full names: Lan, Pham Ngoc (56385210900); van Boi, Luu (6507028401); Phuoc, Hung Duong (57195284803); Le, Hanh Ngoc Thi (57201462555); Truong, Hoa Thi (56385221700); Duc Luu, Phuong (57201909713); Furuta, Masakazu (7103086416); Imamura, Kiyoshi (57202410922); Maeda, Yasuaki (55797766600)
Title: Production of biodiesel from candlenut oil using a two-step co-solvent method and evaluation of its gaseous emissions
Affiliations: Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment, Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Lan, Pham Ngoc, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; van Boi, Luu, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Phuoc, Hung Duong, Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment, Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le, Hanh Ngoc Thi, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Truong, Hoa Thi, Danang Environmental Technology Center, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Duc Luu, Phuong, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Furuta, Masakazu, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Imamura, Kiyoshi, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Maeda, Yasuaki, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: Candlenut oil (CNO) is a potentially new feedstock for biodiesel (BDF) production. In this paper, a two-step co-solvent method for BDF production from CNO was examined. Firstly, esterification of free fatty acids (FFAs) (7 wt%) present in CNO was carried out using a co-solvent of acetonitrile (30 wt%) and H<inf>2</inf>SO<inf>4</inf> as a catalyst. The content of FFAs was reduced to 0.8 wt% in 1 h at 65℃. Subsequent transesterification of the crude oil produced was carried out using a co-solvent of acetone (20 wt%) and 1 wt% potassium hydroxide (KOH). Ester content of 99.3% was obtained at 40℃ in 45 min. The water content in BDF was 0.023% upon purification using vacuum distillation at 5 kPa. The components of CNO BDF were characterized using a Fourier-transform infrared spectrometry and gas chromatography-flame ionization detector. The physicochemical properties of BDF satisfied the ASTM D6751-02 standard. The gaseous exhaust emissions from the diesel engine upon combustion of the BDF blends (B0–B100) with petrodiesel were examined. The emissions of carbon monoxide and hydrocarbons were clearly lower, but that of nitrogen oxides was higher in comparison to those from petro-diesel. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.D., Tran, Tien D.; M.T.T., Nguyen, Mai Thi Tuyet; H.V., Le, Hoang V.; D.N., Nguyen, Duc N.; Q.D., Truong, Quang Duc; P.D., Tran, Phong Dinh

Title: Gold nanoparticles as an outstanding catalyst for the hydrogen evolution reaction
Affiliations: Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Hanyang University, Seoul, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Tran, Tien D., Department of Advanced Materials Science and Nanotechnology, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Mai Thi Tuyet, School of Chemical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le, Hoang V., Department of Advanced Materials Science and Nanotechnology, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Duc N., Department of Advanced Materials Science and Nanotechnology, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Truong, Quang Duc, Institute of Multidisciplinary Research for Advanced Materials, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Tran, Phong Dinh, Department of Advanced Materials Science and Nanotechnology, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Chemistry, Hanyang University, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: An electrode made of Au nanoparticles, ca. 13 nm in diameter, displays outstanding catalytic activity for the hydrogen evolution reaction in water. At an overpotential of 200 mV it operates with a catalytic rate TOF of 0.3 s-1, which is among the best performances ever achieved for a Pt-free H<inf>2</inf>-evolving catalyst. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.T., Nguyen, Tat Thang; H.N., Duong, H. N.; Q.T., Nguyen, Quang Thai; H., Kikura, Hiroshige
Author full names: Nguyen, Tat Thang (59794533500); Duong, H. N. (57201013763); Nguyen, Quang Thai (58779687500); Kikura, Hiroshige (35597037700)
Title: CFD simulations of the natural cavitating flow around high-speed submerged bodies
Affiliations: Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Mechanics, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Tat Thang, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Mechanics, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Duong, H. N., Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Quang Thai, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Mechanics, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kikura, Hiroshige, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Cavitating flow is of considerable importance in underwater high-speed applications because of the desirable drag-reduction effect that concerns the presence of a cavity around moving objects. In many operating regimes, a proper design of high-speed underwater bodies, e.g., the slender ones, should produce not only a stable motion with a straight trajectory but also maximize the travel distance of the bodies. To this end, both physical experiment and CFD simulation can be exploited to investigate the behaviors of a body. Regarding this issue, a number of previous studies have been carried out. However, little specific data of the body design have been documented in the published literature so far. This study investigates numerically a number of varied designs of high-speed underwater slender bodies. The designs are different in some of the bodies’ typical parameters which include the cavitator shape and body length. Steady state simulations of the single/two-phase partial- and super-cavitating flows around the bodies have been carried out by using the CFD approach. A two-phase mixture formulation, turbulence k-ɛ model (for the solution of the flow field) and Zwart-Geber-Belamri (ZGB) cavitation modeling (for mass transfer modeling) are exploited. For the model validation, comparisons with the published experimental and numerical data have been performed. The behaviors of the natural cavitating flow around the different bodies investigated are obtained. The modified drag coefficient for these specific bodies and operating conditions are proposed. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: B.S., Gan, Buntara S.; D.K., Nguyen, Dinh Kien; A.L., Han, Ay Lie; S.W., Alisjahbana, Sofia W.
Author full names: Gan, Buntara S. (53864786800); Nguyen, Dinh Kien (55801713700); Han, Ay Lie (57199323133); Alisjahbana, Sofia W. (25637196800)
Title: DOF condensation of thick curved beam element formulated by isogeometric approach
Affiliations: Nihon University, Tokyo, Japan; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Mechanics, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Universitas Diponegoro, Semarang, Indonesia; Universitas Bakrie, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Gan, Buntara S., Department of Architecture, Nihon University, Tokyo, Japan; Nguyen, Dinh Kien, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Mechanics, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Han, Ay Lie, Department of Civil Engineering, Universitas Diponegoro, Semarang, Indonesia; Alisjahbana, Sofia W., Faculty of Engineering and Informatics, Universitas Bakrie, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The study of a thick in-plane curved beam is more complex than that of the straight beam because the structural deformations of the curved beam depend not only on the rotation and transverse displacement but also on the coupled tangential displacement caused by the curvature of the structure. The Isogeometric approach is a computational geometry based on a piecewise ratio function (Non-Uniform Rational B-Spline (NURBS)) used to represent the exact geometry. In the Isogeometric approach, the free curvature geometry of the beam element can be represented exactly. A thick two-node curved beam element can be developed by using the Isogeometric approach based on Timoshenko beam theory, which allows the transverse shear deformation and rotatory inertia effects. The natural shape of the beam curvature and the shape functions formulation of the element can be formulated by using the Isogeometric approach. However, in the Isogeometric approach, the number of equations will increase according to the number of degree of the polynomial and its control points. A novel technique is been proposed to condense the number of equations of the DOFs at control points so that it is equal to the standard two-node six DOFs beam element. This paper highlights the application of the NURBS for a curved Timoshenko beam element in the context of finite element analysis and proposes a new condensation method to eliminate the drawbacks raised from the Isogeometric approach. Examples are given to verify the effectiveness of the condensation method in static and free vibration problems. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.T., Nguyen, Tat Thang; H.N., Duong, H. N.; V.T., Tran, V. T.; H., Kikura, Hiroshige
Author full names: Nguyen, Tat Thang (59794533500); Duong, H. N. (57201013763); Tran, V. T. (57225703400); Kikura, Hiroshige (35597037700)
Title: A CFD modeling of subcooled pool boiling
Affiliations: Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Mechanics, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Tat Thang, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Mechanics, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Duong, H. N., Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tran, V. T., Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Kikura, Hiroshige, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Subcooled pool boiling is of immense importance in many industrial and engineering systems because of its great heat transfer coefficient in comparison with other heat transfer mechanisms. However it is one of the most complicated two-phase phenomena due to, for example, the simultaneous liquid/vapor motion at the same time with heat and mass transfer across the phase interfaces, distorted and deformable phase interface geometry with complicated bubble breakup/coalescence mechanisms etc. As the accuracy of the CFD simulation of two-phase flows has much improved, numerical study of subcooled pool boiling two-phase flow by using the CFD approach is desirable. To incorporate experimental and numerical studies of subcooled boiling, the objective of this study is to setup a numerical modeling of the subcooled pool boiling in a vertical pipe by using the CFD approach. The numerical setup is based on the physical experimental model developed in our previous study. For the numerical simulation of subcooled pool boiling and wall boiling, the extended RPI boiling model is exploited in the framework of the two-fluid CFD approach. Test simulations by using the numerical setup have been carried out for three cases: a single air bubble rising in still water, a vapor Taylor bubble rising in saturated still water, and a vapor bubble rising and condensing in subcooled still water. Evaluation of the model setup has been clarified. An initial simulation of subcooled pool boiling has also been demonstrated. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Nguyen-Xuan, Toan; Y., Kuriyama, Yukihisa; D.T., Nguyen, Duy Thao
Author full names: Nguyen-Xuan, Toan (57201011619); Kuriyama, Yukihisa (7103067904); Nguyen, Duy Thao (57204428899)
Title: Analysis of dynamic impact factors of bridge due to moving vehicles using finite element method
Affiliations: University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen-Xuan, Toan, Faculty of Road and Bridge Engineering, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Kuriyama, Yukihisa, Center for Engineering, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Nguyen, Duy Thao, Faculty of Road and Bridge Engineering, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Abstract: This article presents analysis of dynamic impact factors for displacement, bending moment, and shear force of bridge under moving vehicles by finite element method. Vehicle is a dumper truck with three axles. Each axle of vehicle is idealized as two mass dynamic systems, in which a mass is supported by a spring and a dashpot. The structural bridges are simulated as bending girder elements. The finite element method is applied to establish the overall model of vehicle–bridge interaction. Galerkin method and Green theory are used to discrete the motion equation of vehicle–bridge system in space domain. Solutions of the motion equations are solved by Runge–Kutta–Mersion method (RKM) in time domain. The numerical results are in good agreement with full-scale dynamic testing under controlled traffic condition of the super T concrete girder at NguyenTriPhuong Bridge in Danang city, Vietnam. Numerical results figure out that there are significant differences between dynamic factors for displacement, bending moment, and shear force. Therefore, the common use of only one dynamic impact factor for displacements, bending moment, and shear forces of bridge structure in each limited state should add more consideration. Furthermore, current results are references for bridge engineers to have more information for safety design requirements and suitability in bridge operation. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H.T., Pham, Hang Thi; T., Iwamoto, Takeshi
Author full names: Pham, Hang Thi (57210940811); Iwamoto, Takeshi (7202555320)
Title: Finite element simulation on small punch test for an evaluation of J-integral for TRIP steel
Affiliations: Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Pham, Hang Thi, Faculty of Engineering, Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Iwamoto, Takeshi, Academy of Science and Technology, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan
Abstract: The small punch test (SPT) has been recently successfully developed for the purpose of evaluating the fracture toughness in not only brittle but also ductile materials. It is considered that fracture toughness of materials can be estimated by means of the SPT based on the measurement of equivalent fracture strain in the SPT and its correlation with fracture toughness. Moreover, fracture toughness of TRIP (transformation-induced plasticity) steel was evaluated by J-integral by using pre-cracked specimen under three-point bending test in the past study. However, the value of J-integral is determined at a limited range of deformation rate in three-point bending test. Thus, fracture toughness of TRIP steel needs to be evaluated by means of the SPT, especially at a relatively high deformation rate. Additionally, since the effect of strain-induced martensitic transformation during plastic deformation of TRIP steel coupled with a high increase of temperature is quite complicated, a computational work is indispensable. In this study, finite element simulations are performed for the SPT at various deflection rates and different sizes of specimen and puncher by an application of damage model for type-304 austenitic stainless steel, a kind of TRIP steel. The rate-sensitivity of fracture-mechanical characteristics is examined for different sizes of specimen and puncher. Furthermore, a relationship between equivalent fracture strain in the SPT and J-integral obtained from three-point bending test is challenged to be correlated. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Nguyen-Xuan, Toan; Y., Kuriyama, Yukihisa; D.T., Nguyen, Duy Thao
Author full names: Nguyen-Xuan, Toan (57201011619); Kuriyama, Yukihisa (7103067904); Nguyen, Duy Thao (57204428899)
Title: Stationary random vibration analysis of dynamic vehicle-bridge interaction due to road unevenness
Affiliations: University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen-Xuan, Toan, Faculty of Road and Bridge Engineering, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Kuriyama, Yukihisa, Center for Engineering, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Nguyen, Duy Thao, Faculty of Road and Bridge Engineering, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Abstract: This article presents stationary random vibration analysis of dynamic vehicle-bridge interaction due to road unevenness based on the Finite element method and Monte-Carlo simulation method. The road unevenness are described by a zero-mean stationary Gaussian random process. The vehicle is a dumper truck with three axles. Each axle of vehicle is idealised as two mass dynamic system, in which a mass is supported by a spring and a dashpot. The structural bridges are simulated as bending beam elements. The finite element method is applied to established the overall model of vehicle-bridge interaction. Galerkin method and Green theory are used to discrete the motion equation of vehicle-bridge system in space domain. Solutions of the motion equations are solved by Runge-Kutta-Mersion method (RKM) in time domain. The numerical results are in good agreement field test results of the prestressed beam-slab at Nguyen-Tri-Phuong bridge, Danang city, Vietnam. Also, the effects of road surface condition on dynamic impact factor of bridge are investigated detail. The numerical results show that dynamic impact factor of bridge has increased significantly when road unevenness have changed from Grade A-road to Grade E-road according to ISO 8608:1995 [1] “Mechanical vibration—Road surface profiles—Reporting of measured data”. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: L.Q., Do, Loc Quang; T.T.Q., Bui, Tung Thanh Quyen; H.T.T., Tran, Ha Thuy Thi; K., Kikuchi, Katsuya; M., Aoyagi, Masashiro; T.C., Chu Duc, Trinh Chu
Author full names: Do, Loc Quang (56681076500); Bui, Tung Thanh Quyen (57211373464); Tran, Ha Thuy Thi (57200735598); Kikuchi, Katsuya (7404088870); Aoyagi, Masashiro (7201467657); Chu Duc, Trinh Chu (15022471300)
Title: Fluidic platform with embedded differential capacitively coupled contactless conductivity detector for micro-object sensing
Affiliations: Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Do, Loc Quang, Radio Physics Department, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Bui, Tung Thanh Quyen, D Integration System Group, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan, MEMs and Microsystem Department, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tran, Ha Thuy Thi, Faculty of Electronics Engineering, Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kikuchi, Katsuya, Faculty of Electronics Engineering, Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Aoyagi, Masashiro, D Integration System Group, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Chu Duc, Trinh Chu, MEMs and Microsystem Department, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: In this paper, we present a microfluidic platform with differential capacitively coupled contactless conductivity detection (DC4D) technique for microparticle detection. The microfluidic platform is formed by bonding PDMS channel to glass substrate. The proposed microfluidic sensor embedded in the microchannel consists of three adjacent electrodes. These electrodes are arranged to form differential coplanar capacitor structures to provide high sensitivity. The differential capacitance is changed when a microsized object crosses the sensing area in the microfluidic channel. This microfluidic system with the novel sensing design based on DC4D technique provides a platform for detection the presence of an object as well as its electrical property. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Y., Huang, Yi; A., Yamaguchi, Atsushi; T.D., Pham, Tien Duc; M., Kobayashi, Motoyoshi
Author full names: Huang, Yi (57197757266); Yamaguchi, Atsushi (55190434900); Pham, Tien Duc (55797010800); Kobayashi, Motoyoshi (8531601700)
Title: Charging and aggregation behavior of silica particles in the presence of lysozymes
Affiliations: University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Huang, Yi, Graduate School of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Yamaguchi, Atsushi, Graduate School of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Pham, Tien Duc, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kobayashi, Motoyoshi, Faculty of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: To gain insight into the colloidal stability in the presence of proteins, we measured the electrophoretic mobility and aggregation rate constant of silica particles coated with lysozymes, and the adsorbed amount of lysozymes on the silica. We also examined model analyses, which are based on the Derjaguin, Landau, Verwey, and Overbeek theory with the effect of charge heterogeneity, to discuss the aggregation of lysozyme-coated silica. Our results show that lysozymes enhance the aggregation of silica when the lysozyme-coated silica is near the isoelectric point. When the adsorbed amount of lysozyme is low, the effect of charge-patch attractive force promotes the aggregation of silica. The effect of charge heterogeneity weakens with the increase of adsorbed amount of lysozyme. Our model which takes account of the effect of charge heterogeneity can capture the trend of the aggregation of silica in the presence of lysozyme qualitatively, but there are also large quantitative discrepancies between the theoretical prediction and experimental results. Further improvement is required to describe realistic charge heterogeneity and the effect of the surface coverage of lysozyme on the silica. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N.X.T., Tram, Nguyen Xuan Thanh; K., Ishikawa, Kunio
Author full names: Tram, Nguyen Xuan Thanh (37003202500); Ishikawa, Kunio (7404554763)
Title: Fabrication of calcite block with interconnecting porous structure for bone substitutes
Affiliations: Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tram, Nguyen Xuan Thanh, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Department of Biomaterials, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Ishikawa, Kunio, Department of Biomaterials, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Abstract: In this study porous calcite block was fabricated using calcium hydroxide (Ca(OH)<inf>2</inf>) as precursor and wax spheres as pore-creating volatile particles. X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Scanning electron microscope (SEM) were used to characterize phase composition and structure. The results indicated that pure calcite block consisting of interconnecting pores with pore size about 200–400-µm diameter could be obtained. It is indicated that wax spheres are advantageous on producing interconnecting porous structure since they could be easily removed by sintering. Porous calcite block with interconnecting porous structure is expected to apply as bone substitutes since it could support effectively bone cell activities to promote bone healing. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Paskalis, Sahaya Murphin Kumar (57195282483); Sivakumar, Thiripuranthagan (7005070239); Imai, Tsubasa (57192170842); Kumar, Gopalakrishnan (7202418804); Arivalagan, Pugazhendhi (57191625854); Ramkumar, Vijayan Sri (56581577400); Esparza, Rodrigo A. (56002650800); Abe, Hideki (7404482056); Kumar-Krishnan, Siva (56108455800)
Title: Pt Nanoparticles Supported on Mesoporous CeO2 Nanostructures Obtained through Green Approach for Efficient Catalytic Performance toward Ethanol Electro-oxidation
Affiliations: National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan; Anna University, Chennai, India; Daegu University, Gyeongsan, South Korea; Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Bharathidasan University, Tiruchirappalli, India; UNAM campus Juriquilla, Juriquilla, Mexico; Benemérita Universidad Autónoma de Puebla, Puebla, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Paskalis, Sahaya Murphin Kumar, National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan, Department of Applied Science and Technology, Anna University, Chennai, India; Sivakumar, Thiripuranthagan, Department of Applied Science and Technology, Anna University, Chennai, India; Imai, Tsubasa, National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan; Kumar, Gopalakrishnan, Department of Environmental Engineering, Daegu University, Gyeongsan, South Korea; Arivalagan, Pugazhendhi, Faculty of Environment and Labour Safety, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ramkumar, Vijayan Sri, Department of Environmental Biotechnology, Bharathidasan University, Tiruchirappalli, India; Esparza, Rodrigo A., Centro de Física Aplicada y Tecnología Avanzada, UNAM campus Juriquilla, Juriquilla, Mexico; Abe, Hideki, National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan; Kumar-Krishnan, Siva, Centro de Física Aplicada y Tecnología Avanzada, UNAM campus Juriquilla, Juriquilla, Mexico, Institute of Physics, Benemérita Universidad Autónoma de Puebla, Puebla, Mexico
Abstract: In this report, an easy and green approach to the synthesis of mesoporous cerium oxide (CeO<inf>2</inf>) nanostructures and followed by supporting platinum nanoparticles (NPs) on CeO<inf>2</inf> nanostructures (Pt/CeO<inf>2</inf>) and their application as versatile electrocatalysts for ethanol electrooxidation has been established. The synthesis of mesoporous Pt/CeO<inf>2</inf> nanostructures involves two steps. First, mesoporous CeO<inf>2</inf> nanostructures were synthesized via macroalgae polymer mediated approach and followed by supporting of PtNPs of ca. 5-10 nm over the mesoporous CeO<inf>2</inf> nanostructures using seed-mediated chemical reduction process. The structural and spectroscopic characterization techniques such as transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) studies confirm the strong coupling between PtNPs and the mesoporous CeO<inf>2</inf> support resulting in the generation of more oxygen vacancies, which can facilitate the enhanced charge transport at their functional interface. Significantly, the synthesized mesoporous Pt/CeO<inf>2</inf> nanostructures were found to show enhanced electrocatalytic activity for ethanol electrooxidation reaction. The enhanced performance is attributed to the synergistic effect of both mesoporous structure and the formation of more oxygen vacancies in the resultant Pt/CeO<inf>2</inf> nanostructures. Our facile and eco-friendly approach to the synthesis of mesoporous CeO<inf>2</inf> nanostructures that supports PtNPs with an excellent catalytic activity is validated as a promising strategy for potential applications in fuel cells. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Lam, Hoangtrong; H., Katsuchi, Hiroshi; H., Yamada, Hitoshi
Author full names: Lam, Hoangtrong (57195771964); Katsuchi, Hiroshi (55907698400); Yamada, Hitoshi (7407537833)
Title: Investigation of Turbulence Effects on the Aeroelastic Properties of a Truss Bridge Deck Section
Affiliations: University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Lam, Hoangtrong, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Katsuchi, Hiroshi, Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan; Yamada, Hitoshi, Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents the flutter derivatives (FDs) extracted from a stochastic system identification (SSI) method under different turbulent flows. The objective of the study is to investigate the effects of oncoming turbulence on the flutter of suspended long-span bridges using a section model wind-tunnel test. Several wind-tunnel tests were performed on a truss bridge deck section with different oncoming turbulent properties involving reduced turbulence intensities and turbulent scales. This study includes an investigation of the effect of oncoming flows on modal dynamic responses. The transient and buffeting response data from the wind-tunnel test are analyzed using the system identification technique in extracting FDs, and the difficulties involved in this method are discussed. The time-domain SSI is applied to extract all FDs simultaneously from one and two degree-of-freedom (1DOF and 2DOF) systems. Finally, the results under different conditions are discussed and conclusions are formed. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S., Kongmany, Santi; H.T., Truong, Hoa Thi; L.T.N., Hanh, Le Thi Ngoc; H., Matsuura, Hiroto; M., Furuta, Masakazu; S., Okuda, Shuichi; K., Imamura, Kiyoshi; Y., Maeda, Yasuaki
Author full names: Kongmany, Santi (47962239400); Truong, Hoa Thi (56385221700); Hanh, Le Thi Ngoc (57191834231); Matsuura, Hiroto (57223597706); Furuta, Masakazu (7103086416); Okuda, Shuichi (23392972800); Imamura, Kiyoshi (57202410922); Maeda, Yasuaki (55797766600)
Title: Photodegradation of 12-deoxy-13,16-dioxy phorbol esters in aqueous solution under UV light and natural sunlight
Affiliations: National University of Laos, Vientiane, Laos; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kongmany, Santi, Department of Chemistry, National University of Laos, Vientiane, Laos; Truong, Hoa Thi, Danang Environmental Technology Center, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hanh, Le Thi Ngoc, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Matsuura, Hiroto, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Furuta, Masakazu, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Okuda, Shuichi, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Imamura, Kiyoshi, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Maeda, Yasuaki, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: 12-Deoxy-13,16-dioxy phorbol esters (PEs) are bio-active and highly toxic compounds that can be found in the seed oil of the Jatropha curcas Linnaeus (JCL) plant. In this report, the photodegradation behaviors of PEs and an isolated J2 component were examined under UV/Vis <inf>254–575nm</inf> irradiation (power 0.4–120 W/m2) and natural sunlight (maximum power of 800–1100 W/m2) in aqueous solution. The J2 was selectively degraded when it was irradiated with UV<inf>254–280nm</inf>. The photodegradation of the PEs occurred with first order kinetics, and the rate constants of J2 and PEs under UV<inf>254nm</inf> irradiation were 1.78 × 10−2 and 2.41 × 10−3 s−1, respectively. The rate constant of the PEs under natural sunlight was 1.37 × 10−3 s−1. Characterization by high performance liquid chromatography/tandem mass spectrometry revealed that the degradation process was preceded by the isomerization of the conjugated unsaturated diester group of the PEs, followed by disruption of the phorbol skeleton. These results indicate that PEs can be selectively degraded in aqueous solution by UV<inf>254–280nm</inf> and/or Vis<inf>545–575nm</inf> irradiation. The aqueous waste streams contaminated with PEs that are generated during biodiesel production could therefore be detoxified by degradation under UV<inf>254nm</inf> light and natural sunlight. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Thanh Nguyen, Tam; Y., Asakura, Yoshiyuki; S., Koda, Shinobu; K., Yasuda, Keiji
Author full names: Thanh Nguyen, Tam (57194160263); Asakura, Yoshiyuki (7103285701); Koda, Shinobu (7103404774); Yasuda, Keiji (7403377802)
Title: Dependence of cavitation, chemical effect, and mechanical effect thresholds on ultrasonic frequency
Affiliations: Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan; University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Honda Electronics Co., Ltd., Toyohashi, Japan; Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Thanh Nguyen, Tam, Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan, Faculty of Environment, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Asakura, Yoshiyuki, Honda Electronics Co., Ltd., Toyohashi, Japan; Koda, Shinobu, Department of Molecular Design and Engineering, Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan; Yasuda, Keiji, Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan
Abstract: Cavitation, chemical effect, and mechanical effect thresholds were investigated in wide frequency ranges from 22 to 4880 kHz. Each threshold was measured in terms of sound pressure at fundamental frequency. Broadband noise emitted from acoustic cavitation bubbles was detected by a hydrophone to determine the cavitation threshold. Potassium iodide oxidation caused by acoustic cavitation was used to quantify the chemical effect threshold. The ultrasonic erosion of aluminum foil was conducted to estimate the mechanical effect threshold. The cavitation, chemical effect, and mechanical effect thresholds increased with increasing frequency. The chemical effect threshold was close to the cavitation threshold for all frequencies. At low frequency below 98 kHz, the mechanical effect threshold was nearly equal to the cavitation threshold. However, the mechanical effect threshold was greatly higher than the cavitation threshold at high frequency. In addition, the thresholds of the second harmonic and the first ultraharmonic signals were measured to detect bubble occurrence. The threshold of the second harmonic approximated to the cavitation threshold below 1000 kHz. On the other hand, the threshold of the first ultraharmonic was higher than the cavitation threshold below 98 kHz and near to the cavitation threshold at high frequency. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A., Ishizaki, Azumi; X., Bi, Xiuqiong; L., van Nguyen, Lam; K., Matsuda, Kazunori; H.V., Pham, Hung Viet; C.T.T., Phan, Chung Thi Thu; D.T.K., Khu, Dung Thi Khanh; H., Ichimura, Hiroshi
Author full names: Ishizaki, Azumi (36839788600); Bi, Xiuqiong (16938499400); van Nguyen, Lam (54396225800); Matsuda, Kazunori (56525962900); Pham, Hung Viet (57197674160); Phan, Chung Thi Thu (56769258100); Khu, Dung Thi Khanh (56769937500); Ichimura, Hiroshi (15826547800)
Title: Effects of short-term probiotic ingestion on immune profiles and microbial translocation among HIV-1-infected Vietnamese children
Affiliations: Kanazawa University, Kanazawa, Japan; Vietnam National Children's Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yakult Honsha Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ishizaki, Azumi, Graduate School of Medical Science, Kanazawa University, Kanazawa, Japan; Bi, Xiuqiong, Graduate School of Medical Science, Kanazawa University, Kanazawa, Japan; van Nguyen, Lam, Vietnam National Children's Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Matsuda, Kazunori, Yakult Honsha Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan; Pham, Hung Viet, Vietnam National Children's Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Phan, Chung Thi Thu, Vietnam National Children's Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Khu, Dung Thi Khanh, Vietnam National Children's Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ichimura, Hiroshi, Graduate School of Medical Science, Kanazawa University, Kanazawa, Japan
Abstract: Here, we investigated the effects of the probiotic strain Lactobacillus casei Shirota (LcS) on immune profiles and intestinal microbial translocation among children infected with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). This prospective study included 60 HIV-infected children—including 31 without antiretroviral therapy (ART) (HIV(+)) and 29 who received ART for a median of 3.5 years (ART(+)) and 20 children without HIV infection (HIV(−)). Participants were recruited in Vietnam. All children were given fermented milk containing LcS (6.5 × 109 cfu) daily for 8 weeks. Before and after LcS ingestion, blood samples were collected for virological, immunological, and bacteriological analyses. After LcS ingestion, peripheral CD4+ T-cell and Th2 (CXCR3−CCR6−CD4+) counts significantly increased in both HIV-infected groups; Th17 (CXCR3−CCR6+CD4+) counts increased in all three groups; regulatory T-cell (CD25highCD4+) counts decreased in the ART(+) and HIV(−) groups; activated CD8+ cells (CD38+HLA-DR+CD8+) decreased from 27.5% to 13.2% (p < 0.001) in HIV(+) children; and plasma HIV load decreased slightly but significantly among HIV(+) children. No group showed a significantly altered frequency of bacterial 16S/23S rRNA gene detection in the plasma. No serious adverse events occurred. These findings suggest that short-term LcS ingestion is a safe supportive approach with immunological and virological benefits in HIV-infected children. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Q.D., Truong, Quang Duc; H.T., Hoa, Huu Thu; L.T., Son, Le Thanh
Author full names: Truong, Quang Duc (41361850100); Hoa, Huu Thu (55250552300); Son, Le Thanh (59157758300)
Title: Rutile TiO2 nanocrystals with exposed {3 3 1} facets for enhanced photocatalytic CO2 reduction activity
Source title: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
Affiliations: Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Truong, Quang Duc, Institute of Multidisciplinary Research for Advanced Materials, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Hoa, Huu Thu, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Son, Le Thanh, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Rutile TiO<inf>2</inf> nanocrystals with exposed high-index facets have been investigated in detail by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) and selected-area electron diffraction (SAED). It was found that the each branched nanocrystal is bound by 4 facets of high-index {3 3 1}. Additionally, rutile {1 0 1} twinned structures are formed in the boundary of branches during the growth of multi branches in a hierarchical flower-like nanostructures. Notably, the synthesized nanostructures showed significantly higher photocatalytic activities than that of rod particles with exposed {1 1 0} facets in photocatalytic CO<inf>2</inf> reduction. Correlating the presence of high-energy surface on rutile nanocrystals with the photocatalytic activity clearly shows the significant role of surface steps in enhancing intrinsic activity for CO<inf>2</inf> reduction to methanol. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Q.D., Truong, Quang Duc; M., Kempaiah Devaraju, Murukanahally; P.D., Tran, Phong Dinh; Y., Gambe, Yoshiyuki; K., Nayuki, Keiichiro; Y., Sasaki, Yoshikazu; I., Honma, Itaru
Author full names: Truong, Quang Duc (41361850100); Kempaiah Devaraju, Murukanahally (55346060300); Tran, Phong Dinh (18435066600); Gambe, Yoshiyuki (55584005900); Nayuki, Keiichiro (35084117700); Sasaki, Yoshikazu (56204042000); Honma, Itaru (7004878048)
Title: Unravelling the Surface Structure of MgMn2O4 Cathode Materials for Rechargeable Magnesium-Ion Battery
Affiliations: Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Hanoi University of Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; JEOL Ltd., Japan, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Truong, Quang Duc, Institute of Multidisciplinary Research for Advanced Materials, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Kempaiah Devaraju, Murukanahally, Institute of Multidisciplinary Research for Advanced Materials, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Tran, Phong Dinh, Department of Advanced Materials Science and Nanotechnology, Hanoi University of Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Gambe, Yoshiyuki, Institute of Multidisciplinary Research for Advanced Materials, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Nayuki, Keiichiro, Field Solution Division, JEOL Ltd., Japan, Tokyo, Japan; Sasaki, Yoshikazu, Field Solution Division, JEOL Ltd., Japan, Tokyo, Japan; Honma, Itaru, Institute of Multidisciplinary Research for Advanced Materials, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Abstract: The spinel MgMn<inf>2</inf>O<inf>4</inf>, a cathode material with theoretical capacity of 272 mA h g-1, holds promise for future application in high volumetric magnesium-ion batteries. Atomic-resolution imaging of the structure of the spinel and its surface composition would advance our understanding on its electrochemical properties, mass, and charge transport behavior in electrodes. We observe directly, by aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM), the atomic structure of cubic spinel MgMn<inf>2</inf>O<inf>4</inf> for the first time. More importantly, we find that a thin stable surface layer of rocksalt MgMnO<inf>2</inf> was grown on a bulk cubic spinel phase. The formation of a rocksalt phase was induced by reconstruction of the spinel phase, i.e., the insertion of Mg into the spinel lattice together with Mg/Mn cation exchange and Frenkel-defect-mediated relocation of Mg cations. This new structural analysis provides a critical step toward understanding and tuning the electrochemical performance of spinel oxide in rechargeable Mg-ion batteries. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Truong, Hoa Thi (56385221700); do van, Manh (59158748100); Huynh, Long Duc (57195286347); Thi Nguyen, Linh (57202320325); do Tuan, Anh (57195073560); Thanh, Thao Le Xuan (57195279694); Phuoc, Hung Duong (57195284803); Takenaka, Norimichi (7007012272); Imamura, Kiyoshi (57202410922); Maeda, Yasuaki (55797766600)
Title: A method for ferulic acid production from rice bran oil soapstock using a homogenous system
Affiliations: Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment, Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Truong, Hoa Thi, Danang Environmental Technology Center, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; do van, Manh, Danang Environmental Technology Center, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Huynh, Long Duc, Danang Environmental Technology Center, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Thi Nguyen, Linh, Danang Environmental Technology Center, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; do Tuan, Anh, Danang Environmental Technology Center, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Thanh, Thao Le Xuan, Danang Environmental Technology Center, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Phuoc, Hung Duong, International Cooperation Department, Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment, Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Takenaka, Norimichi, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Imamura, Kiyoshi, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Maeda, Yasuaki, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: Ferulic acid (FA) is widely used as an antioxidant, e.g., as a Ultraviolet (UV) protectant in cosmetics and in various medical applications. It has been produced by the hydrolysis of γ-oryzanol found in rice bran oil soapstock. In this study, the base-catalyzed, homogenous hydrolysis of γ-oryzanol was conducted using various ratios of potassium hydroxide (KOH) to γ-oryzanol, initial concentrations of γ-oryzanol in the reaction mixture, and ratios of ethanol (EtOH) (as cosolvent)/ethyl acetate (EtOAc) (γ-oryzanol solution). Acceleration of the reaction using a planar type of ultrasound sonicator (78 and 130 kHz) at different reaction temperatures was explored. By using a heating method, the 80% yield of FA was attained at 75 C in 4 h under homogeneous conditions (initial concentration of γ-oryzanol 12 mg/mL, the KOH/γ-oryzanol ratio (wt/wt) 10/1, and EtOH/EtOAc ratio (v/v) 5/1). With the assistance of 78 and 130 kHz irradiation, the yields reached 90%. The heating method was applied for the γ-oryzanol-containing extract prepared from rice bran oil soapstock. From soapstock, the 74.3% yield of FA was obtained, but 20% of the trans-FA in the reaction mixture was transformed into cis-form within one month. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: A symmetrically arranged electrodes for corona discharge anemometry
Affiliations: Academy of Military Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ritsumeikan University Biwako-Kusatsu Campus, Kusatsu, Japan; Clearview Traffic Group Limited, Bicester, United Kingdom; Sumitomo Chemical Company, Limited, Tokyo, Japan

Abstract: This paper presents a novel anemometry based on bipolar corona discharge probe with symmetrically arranged parallel electrodes, which is potentially applicable for in-situ measurement. With the proposed configuration, under the existence of the airflow, the decomposed gas is redistributed towards the downstream electrode, and changes the current-voltage characteristics of the system. Experimental study on the anemometry characteristics demonstrates the possibility of measuring a wide range of air flow rate/ flow velocity, i.e., up to 80 l/m. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Dielectrophoresis enrichment with built-in capacitive sensor microfluidic platform for tumor rare cell detection
Affiliations: Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Sumitomo Chemical Company, Limited, Tokyo, Japan; National Chung Cheng University, Min-Hsiung, Taiwan

Abstract: This paper presents a dielectrophoresis (DEP) enrichment microfluidic platform with built-in antibody-based capacitive sensor for tumor rare cells detection. We take the advantages of the effective DEP actuation, the high selectivity property of antibody for rare cell immobilization, and the high sensitivity of differential capacitive sensing for quantitatively reading out, to produce advanced platform, toward single tumor cell detection for the rapid laboratory tests of cancers diagnoses and other metabolic diseases applications. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Computational and experimental study on ion wind scheme based aerosol sampling for biomedical applications
Affiliations: Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ritsumeikan University Biwako-Kusatsu Campus, Kusatsu, Japan; University of Southern Queensland, Toowoomba, Australia; Sumitomo Chemical Company, Limited, Tokyo, Japan

Abstract: In this paper, an efficient electrostatic particle sampling system is developed based on the neutralized ion wind. Compare with the conventional schemes where unipolar ion is used to charge the airborne sample and the sampling stage is fixed as a part of high voltage circuit, the new approach allows sampling stage to be electrically floated and adds insignificant charge to the bioaerosol, thus reduces damages to the microorganisms while provides design flexibility and good collecting efficiency. The approach is suitable for the combination with a microfluidic interface to develop complex aerosol-to-hydrosol bio-samplers. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Abstract: In this paper, we present a coplanar differential capacitively coupled contactless conductivity detection (CD-C4D) structure for the detection of tiny objects with dimension in micro scale. The differential capacitance changed due to the occurrence of an object in micro scale in is detected and used to recognize the presence as well as properties (i.e., electrical property and moving speed) of the object in fluidic flow. The experimental results and discussion in this paper can be generalized to any living cell or particle detection applications. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Ionic JET flow in a circulatory miniaturized system
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ritsumeikan University Biwako-Kusatsu Campus, Kusatsu, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hanoi University of Industry, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Sumitomo Chemical Company, Limited, Tokyo, Japan

Abstract: This paper reports a novel device for generating circulatory jet flow using bipolar discharge configuration. This arrangement, in which two electrodes serve as mutual emitters and reference defining the electric field, allows to generate simultaneously ionic wind with opposite charge, thus the ion flow is self-neutralized while keeping the momentum in desired direction. In order to prevent system from sparking over, between the two parallel electrodes is installed one millimetre thick polypropylene wall. Experiment and simulation has shown that the air flow is successfully circulated in the confined device with peak velocity of 2 m/s while consuming only 33 mW. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N., Minh Hien, Nguyen; M., Izumi, Masayuki; H., Sato, Hajime; R., Okamoto, Ryo; Y., Kajihara, Yasuhiro
Author full names: Minh Hien, Nguyen (36989858400); Izumi, Masayuki (36198209500); Sato, Hajime (55731940400); Okamoto, Ryo (36194293500); Kajihara, Yasuhiro (7006984179)
Title: Chemical Synthesis of Glycoproteins with the Specific Installation of Gradient-Enriched 15N-Labeled Amino Acids for Getting Insights into Glycoprotein Behavior
Affiliations: The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Bruker Corporation, Billerica, United States; University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Minh Hien, Nguyen, Department of Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, Current address: Department of Chemistry, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Izumi, Masayuki, Department of Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Sato, Hajime, Bruker Corporation, Billerica, United States; Okamoto, Ryo, Department of Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Kajihara, Yasuhiro, Department of Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Abstract: Elucidating the effects of oligosaccharides on glycoprotein properties, such as local conformational changes, stability, and dynamics, has still been challenging. In this paper, a novel partial 15N-labeling method for the amide backbone of a synthetic glycoprotein is proposed. Using solid-phase peptide synthesis (SPPS) and native chemical ligation (NCL), thirteen 15N-labeled amino acids were inserted at specific positions of the protein backbone, while intentionally varying the enrichment of 15N atoms. This idea discriminated even the same type of amino acid based on the intensities of 1H-15N HSQC signals, combined with classic homonuclear TOCSY and NOESY methods, thus allowing for understanding the dynamics of the local conformation of a synthetic homogeneous glycoprotein. Results suggested that the attachment of an oligosaccharide of either a bi-antennary complex-type or a high-mannose-type did not disturb protein conformation. However, T<inf>1</inf> values suggested that the oligosaccharide influenced dynamics at the local conformation. Temperature-varied circular dichroism (CD) spectra and T<inf>1</inf> values clearly indicated that oligosaccharides appeared to inhibit protein fluctuation or, in other words, stabilize protein structure. This insight into oligosaccharide behavior suggests some further effects on binding affinity between a glycoprotein and its receptor. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Nguyen Van, Thinh; A., Ozaki, Akinori; Y., Xie, Yiping; A., Duc, Anhnguyen; K., Kurosawa, Kiyoshi
Author full names: Nguyen Van, Thinh (57191889642); Ozaki, Akinori (7103207693); Xie, Yiping (57191576800); Duc, Anhnguyen (57197856733); Kurosawa, Kiyoshi (7203077675)
Title: Contamination of agricultural soils by Toxic trace metals in an industrial district in Vietnam
Affiliations: Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen Van, Thinh, Graduate School of Integrated Sciences for Global Society, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Ozaki, Akinori, Institute of Tropical Agriculture, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Xie, Yiping, Graduate School of Social and Cultural Studies, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Duc, Anhnguyen, Soil Science Laboratory, Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kurosawa, Kiyoshi, Institute of Tropical Agriculture, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Abstract: Contamination of agricultural soils by toxic trace metals of arsenic (As), lead (Pb), cadmium (Cd), chromium (Cr), copper (Cu) and zinc (Zn) was investigated in an industrial district in Vietnam. In the district, irrigation agriculture is performed through channels, in addition, there are two industrial parks are nearby agricultural land. The purpose of the study is to clarify the magnitude and spatial distribution of the trace metal concentrations, the source of the trace metals, the difference in the concentrations between the two industrial park areas, and usability of soils for agriculture. As a result, the trace metal concentrations were in the order of Cr>Zn>Pb>Cu>As>Cd for the district. No significant differences were observed between the two park areas in concentrations. Cr and Zn concentrations were high near factories in the park areas, and the other concentrations were comparatively high in the areas, showing that the trace metals were supplied from the factories with wastewaters. The correlations observed between Cd, Pb and Zn, between Cr and Zn, and between Cu and as in the concentrations suggested that there were several groups of wastewaters supplying the trace metals. Concentrations of all kinds trace metals exceeded the permissible level for agricultural soils, and the remediation measures to reduce contamination are necessary. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Dao, Viet Linh (57215903336); Huong, Nguyen Lan (57195637515); Tabata, Michiro (36471211600); Imai, Shunsuke (54794181900); Iijima, Sou (57125540000); Kasai, Daisuke (56823700300); To, Kim Anh (57206415596); Fukuda, Masao (7404038135)
Title: Characterization and functional expression of a rubber degradation gene of a Nocardia degrader from a rubber-processing factory
Affiliations: Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Sumitomo Riko Co. Ltd., Komaki, Japan; Niigata University, Niigata, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Dao, Viet Linh, Department of Bioengineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan, School of Biotechnology and Food Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Huong, Nguyen Lan, School of Biotechnology and Food Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tabata, Michiro, Department of Bioengineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Imai, Shunsuke, Department of Bioengineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan, Sumitomo Riko Co. Ltd., Komaki, Japan; Iijima, Sou, Department of Bioengineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan, Health Administration Office, Niigata University, Niigata, Japan; Kasai, Daisuke, Department of Bioengineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; To, Kim Anh, School of Biotechnology and Food Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Fukuda, Masao, Department of Bioengineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan
Abstract: A rubber-degrading bacterial consortium named H2DA was obtained from an enrichment culture with natural rubber latex and rubber-processing factory waste in Vietnam. Gel permeation chromatography analysis revealed that only the strain NVL3 degraded synthetic poly(cis-1,4-isoprene) into low-molecular-weight intermediates among the three strains found in the H2DA. The 16S-rRNA gene sequence of NVL3 showed the highest identity with that of Nocardia farcinica DSM 43665T. NVL3 accumulated aldehyde intermediates from synthetic poly(cis-1,4-isoprene) on a rubber-overlay plate as indicated by Schiff's staining. NVL3 also degraded deproteinized natural rubber into low-molecular-weight aldehyde intermediates. A latex-clearing protein (lcp) gene ortholog was identified within the genome sequence of NVL3, and it showed a moderate amino-acid identity (54–75%) with the lcp genes from previously reported rubber degraders. The heterologous expression of the NVL3 lcp in Escherichia coli BL21(DE3) allowed us to purify the 46.8-kDa His-tagged lcp gene product (His-Lcp). His-Lcp degraded synthetic poly(cis-1,4-isoprene) and accumulated aldehyde intermediates from deproteinized natural rubber suggesting the functional expression of the lcp gene from a Nocardia degrader in E. coli. Quantitative reverse transcription PCR analysis indicated the strong transcriptional induction of the lcp gene in NVL3 in the presence of synthetic poly(cis-1,4-isoprene). These results suggest the involvement of the lcp gene in rubber degradation in NVL3. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.V., Vu, T. V.; J.C., Wells, John Craig
Title: Numerical simulations of solidification around two tandemly-arranged circular cylinders under forced convection
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ritsumeikan University Biwako-Kusatsu Campus, Kusatsu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Vu, T. V., School of Transportation Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Wells, John Craig, Department of Civil Engineering, Ritsumeikan University Biwako-Kusatsu Campus, Kusatsu, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents a parametric numerical investigation of solidification around two cooled cylinders placed in tandem under forced convection. The front-tracking/finite difference method is used together with an interpolation technique for solving the phase change process. Evolution of the solidifying interface is followed by the front-tracking, and the interpolation handles the presence of the solid phase and the no-slip and constant isothermal boundary conditions. The effects of various non-dimensional parameters on the evolution of the solid phase such as the Reynolds number Re, the Stefan number St, the dimensionless temperature of the inflowing liquid θ<inf>0</inf>, the ratios of the thermal properties k<inf>sl</inf> and C<inf>psl</inf>, and the distance between two cylinders L are studied. The computational results show that the solidified region expands with an increase in k<inf>sl</inf> or L, or with a decrease in any one of Re, Pr, θ<inf>0</inf>. However, St and C<inf>psl</inf> have a minor effect on the final form of the solid phase. The effect of density difference between the solid and liquid phases, and results in the case of side-by-side arrangement are also presented. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: B.L., Vong, Binh Long; Y., Nagasaki, Yukio
Author full names: Vong, Binh Long (55366287800); Nagasaki, Yukio (7006029895)
Title: Development of Redox Nanomedicine for Gastrointestinal Complications via Oral Administration Route
Affiliations: University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Vong, Binh Long, Department of Materials Science, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan, Department of Biochemistry, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nagasaki, Yukio, Department of Materials Science, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan, Master's School of Medical Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan, Satellite Laboratory, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: Oral drug administration is most widely used route and convenient for patients, although numerous challenges for this administration route are required to overcome. Nanoparticle-based drug delivery systems have been studied as novel therapeutics for treating numerous human diseases. These systems can improve drug bioavailability and specifically deliver therapeutic agents to diseased tissues, enhancing treating efficacy and minimizing unwanted adverse effects. In this chapter, we describe recent researches on treating oxidative stress-associated diseases including gastrointestinal disorders, using traditional medications and nanoparticle-based drug delivery systems via oral administration route. We also describe the development and recent research of our newly designed redox nanoparticle as a novel nanotherapeutics. The preparation of redox nanoparticle, the evaluation of its toxicity in vitro and in vivo, as well as the therapeutic application for inflammatory bowel disease and colon cancer will be also discussed in this chapter. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N., He, Ngovan; K., Mizutani, Keisuke; Y., Ikeda, Yoshiho
Author full names: He, Ngovan (55850920700); Mizutani, Keisuke (56911824200); Ikeda, Yoshiho (7404015384)
Title: Reducing air resistance acting on a ship by using interaction effects between the hull and accommodation
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Sanoyas Shipbuilding Corporation, Osaka, Japan; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: He, Ngovan, School of Transportation Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Mizutani, Keisuke, Sanoyas Shipbuilding Corporation, Osaka, Japan; Ikeda, Yoshiho, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: Nowaday, a study on saving energy as well as reducing resistance acting on a ship is important in maritime transportation. In this study, the authors present a study on reducing air resistance acting on a ship by using interaction effects between the hull and an accommodation. At first, air resistances acting on a hull and an accommodation of the ship are investigated by a commercial Computation Fluid Dynamic (CFD) code. Then, CFD results are compared with those of experimental results to validate the accuracy of the CFD. Secondly, air resistances acting on the ship with an accommodation on its deck are computed to obtain air resistances acting on the whole ships, on the hull and on accommodation. The results demonstrate that the interaction effects between the hull and its accommodation house be also shown how to reduce the total air resistance by using interaction effects between the hull and an accommodation house. The results can be applied in reducing the total resistances acting on a ship. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Accommodation House; Air Resistance; Cfd; Hull; Interaction Effects; Saving Energy

Authors: D.T., Sy, Do Tien; V., Likhitruangsilp, Veerasak; M., Onishi, Masamitsu; T.N., Phong, Thanh Nguyen
Author full names: Sy, Do Tien (57211342252); Likhitruangsilp, Veerasak (9043521100); Onishi, Masamitsu (7102474567); Phong, Thanh Nguyen (57211379007)
Title: Impacts of risk factors on the performance of public-private partnership transportation projects in Vietnam
Affiliations: Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Đại học Mở Thành phố Hồ Chí Minh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Sy, Do Tien, Department of Civil Engineering, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Likhitruangsilp, Veerasak, Department of Civil Engineering, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Onishi, Masamitsu, Department of Planning and Management Systems, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Phong, Thanh Nguyen, Department of Project Management, Đại học Mở Thành phố Hồ Chí Minh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: The rapidly increasing demand and the inefficacy of financing transportation infrastructure project investments have contributed to various challenges for Vietnam in recent decades. Since the country's budget is inadequate for investing in all necessary infrastructure projects, the Vietnam government has been inviting other economic sectors, especially the private sector, to participate in infrastructure development. The cooperation between the government agencies and the private entities, called Public-Private Partnership (PPP), must encounter various challenges leading to difficulties in attracting private investors. A main reason is that private investors must deal with critical risks concerning PPP investment environment. It is a challenging task for the government to optimally manage such risks to enhance the attractiveness of PPP projects for private investors. This paper examines the critical risk factors that influence the private sector's investment decisions on PPP transportation projects in Vietnam. Risk factors inherent in typical PPP projects were compiled by comprehensive literature review. To reflect unique characteristics of PPP projects in Vietnam, the compiled risk factors were reviewed by a group of PPP experts from both the public and private sectors in Vietnam through in-depth interviews and questionnaire surveys. In addition, ten PPP project case studies in Vietnam were analyzed to derive the risk profile of PPP transportation projects of the nation. These risk factors were quantitatively assessed based on their probabilities and impact levels. We found that the critical risk factors of PPP infrastructure projects in Vietnam are acquisition/compensation problems, approvals and permits, inadequate feasibility studies, finance market issues, subjective evaluation methods, and change in laws and regulations. By performing factor analysis, these critical risk factors were grouped into four categories: (1) bidding process, (2) finance issues, (3) laws and regulations, and (4) project evaluation issues. These critical risk factors represent the obstacles that repel private investors from PPP transportation projects in Vietnam. Thus, the Vietnam government agencies should meticulously address these issues to attract both domestic and foreign private investors in PPP projects. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.X., Bo, Tran Xuan; D.V., Long, Do Viet; H., Yanada, Hideki
Author full names: Bo, Tran Xuan (59160299500); Long, Do Viet (57211341163); Yanada, Hideki (6603756094)
Title: Dynamic friction behavior in pre-sliding regime of pneumatic actuators
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Toyohashi University of Technology, Toyohashi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Bo, Tran Xuan, Department of Fluid Power and Automation Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Long, Do Viet, Department of Fluid Power and Automation Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yanada, Hideki, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Toyohashi University of Technology, Toyohashi, Japan
Abstract: This paper focuses on investigating friction behavior in pre-sliding regime and developing a new mathematical model of friction for fluid power actuators. Using pneumatic cylinders with different sizes, an experimental setup is built to measure friction force-displacement characteristics in presliding regime under various conditions of pressures in the cylinder chambers. A new mathematical model of friction for the pneumatic cylinders is proposed by incorporating a hysteresis function into the new modified LuGre model. The experimental results show that when the pressures are varied, friction of the pneumatic cylinders in pre-sliding regime is represented by behavior of a nonlinear spring. In addition, hysteresis behavior with nonlocal memory is obtained in the friction force-displacement characteristics and that the size of the hysteresis loop is increased with increasing pressures in the cylinder chambers. The simulation results show that the new friction model can accurately simulate the friction behavior of the pneumatic cylinders in pre-sliding regime as well as sliding regime. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Fluid Power Actuator; Friction Behavior; Friction Model; Pneumatic Cylinder; Pre-sliding

Authors: D.T., Sy, Do Tien; V., Likhitruangsilp, Veerasak; M., Onishi, Masamitsu; T.N., Phong, Thanh Nguyen
Author full names: Sy, Do Tien (57211342252); Likhitruangsilp, Veerasak (9043521100); Onishi, Masamitsu (7102474567); Phong, Thanh Nguyen (57211379007)
Title: Different perceptions of concern factors for strategic investment of the private sector in public-private partnership transportation projects
Affiliations: Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Đại học Mở Thành phố Hồ Chí Minh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Sy, Do Tien, Department of Civil Engineering, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Likhitruangsilp, Veerasak, Department of Civil Engineering, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Onishi, Masamitsu, Department of Planning and Management Systems, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Phong, Thanh Nguyen, Department of Project Management, Đại học Mở Thành phố Hồ Chí Minh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: This paper identifies the concern factors of private investors associated with Public-Private Partnership (PPP) transportation projects in Vietnam. The concern factors are incorporated into four main groups: (1) company profile; (2) finance; (3) opportunities; and (4) risk perceptions. The paper examines the different perceptions by the public and private sectors about these concern factors adopted by experienced professionals related to PPP transportation projects. Based on a questionnaire survey in Vietnam, the most concern factors of private investors are their own capacity, demand issues, legal and political risks, long-term income, and financial sources issues of the PPP project. Moreover, five factors that represent the significant differences between the private and public sectors including political risks, enhancement of company's strength in its industry, construction risks, demand issues, and financial viability of the company are also discovered. Addressing the different perceptions is indispensable to ensure the public sector can establish necessary policies that appeal to both domestic and foreign private investors. The paper at the same time hopes to provide some of lessons for the private sector. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Concern Factors; Different Perceptions; Investment; Public-private Partnership; Transportation; Vietnam

Authors: T.H.L., Le, T. H.Lien; T., Shinohara, Tadashi; A., Tahara, Akira; A., Chianpairot, Amnuaysak; E., Viyanit, Ekkarut; L.H., Hoang, L. Hong; T.S., Pham, T. San
Author full names: Le, T. H.Lien (57203575455); Shinohara, Tadashi (57219026112); Tahara, Akira (7005041501); Chianpairot, Amnuaysak (36924559500); Viyanit, Ekkarut (6504668011); Hoang, L. Hong (57203567584); Pham, T. San (57213330069)
Title: Atmospheric corrosion behavior of steel in Asian areas
Affiliations: Institute of Materials, Hanoi, Viet Nam; National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan; Thailand National Metal and Materials Technology Center, Pathum Thani, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Le, T. H.Lien, Institute of Materials, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Shinohara, Tadashi, National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan; Tahara, Akira, National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan; Chianpairot, Amnuaysak, Thailand National Metal and Materials Technology Center, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Viyanit, Ekkarut, Thailand National Metal and Materials Technology Center, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Hoang, L. Hong, Institute of Materials, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Pham, T. San, Institute of Materials, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: The paper introduces the results of e-Asia Project implemented by Japan, Vietnam and Thailand. Carbon steel (CS) and weathering steel (WS) were exposed in out-door atmosphere of 38 test sites, the environmental parameters as temperature (T), air relative humidity (RH), total of rainfall, airborne salinity and SO<inf>2</inf> deposition rate, were collected in the same period of exposure. The corrosion rate of CS and WS after first year exposure were determined and classified according to ISO standard. The effects of environmental factors to corrosion rate of the steels were analyzed, which showed the increasing corrosion rate of the steels with air temperature when the temperature is lower than 19oC and the decreasing corrosion rate with air temperature when temperature is higher than 19oC. This phenomenon in Asia is different from temperate areas where corrosion rate gets peak at about 10oC. The comparison between the first-year corrosion rates of CS and WS are given in the paper. Especially, the corrosion rates of CS calculated by ISO dose-function and determined by exposure test were compared. The results showed that the actual measured values in almost test sites were higher than the estimated values. Therefore it is confirmed that an estimation formula suited to the Asian regions is needed. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.T., Nguyen, Tam Thanh; Y., Takahashi, Yuta; Y., Asakura, Yoshiyuki; K., Yasuda, Keiji
Author full names: Nguyen, Tam Thanh (57209166140); Takahashi, Yuta (57213130933); Asakura, Yoshiyuki (7103285701); Yasuda, Keiji (7403377802)
Title: Removal of silicic acid in geothermal water by a combination of ultrasonication and silica gel seed
Source title: Journal of Chemical Engineering of Japan
Affiliations: Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan; University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Honda Electronics Co., Ltd., Toyohashi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Tam Thanh, Department of Chemical Engineering, Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan, Faculty of Environment, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Takahashi, Yuta, Department of Chemical Engineering, Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan; Asakura, Yoshiyuki, Honda Electronics Co., Ltd., Toyohashi, Japan; Yasuda, Keiji, Department of Chemical Engineering, Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan
Abstract: A combination of ultrasonication and silica gel seed was studied as a silica scale prevention method in geothermal water. The effects of ultrasonic frequency, initial monosilicic acid concentration, pH, concentration, particle diameter and pore size of the silica gel on the removal ratio of silicic acid were examined. For comparison, stirring without and with silica gel, and ultrasonication with the addition of hydrogen peroxide or t-butanol were performed. Ultrasonication enhances the removal of silicic acid by silica gel seed. Ultrasonication at 500 kHz was more effective for the removal of silicic acid than ultrasonication at 28 kHz and stirring. The removal ratio of silicic acid increased with an increase in silica gel concentration. The small seed particle diameter of 60 μm and large seed pore size of 7 nm performed well in the removal of silicic acid. When the initial concentration of monosilicic acid was 1.1 g/L and the silica gel concentration was 1.5 g/L, the removal ratio of silicic acid was highest at pH 6 because the reaction between polymer and polymer is dominant. However, in the case of an initial monosilicic acid concentration of 0.5 g/L, the removal ratio was highest at pH 9 because reaction between polymer and monomer is dominant. The polymerization rate of monosilicic acid was increased by the addition of hydrogen peroxide due to a higher formation rate of hydroxide radicals. In contrast, the addition of t-butanol lowered the polymerization rate of monosilicic acid because the hydroxide radicals were scavenged. The frequency switching from 500 kHz to 28 kHz at 90 min for each ultrasonication enhanced the removal ratio of silicic acid. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
