Authors: N., Viet Long, Nguyen; Y., Yang, Yong; T., Teranishi, Toshiharu; C.M., Thi, Cao Minh; Y., Cao, Yanqin; M., Nogami, Massayuki
Author full names: Viet Long, Nguyen (35334870500); Yang, Yong (56406088300); Teranishi, Toshiharu (7101891244); Thi, Cao Minh (55315987000); Cao, Yanqin (55840210800); Nogami, Massayuki (57202849551)
Title: Biomedical applications of advanced multifunctional magnetic nanoparticles
Affiliations: Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai, China; Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Toyota Physical and Chemical Research Institute, Nagakute, Japan

Abstract: In this review, we have presented the latest results and highlights on biomedical applications of a class of noble metal nanoparticles, such as gold, silver and platinum, and a class of magnetic nanoparticles, such as cobalt, nickel and iron. Their most important related compounds are also discussed for biomedical applications for treating various diseases, typically as cancers. At present, both physical and chemical methods have been proved very successful to synthesize, shape, control, and produce metal- and oxide-based homogeneous particle systems, e.g., nanoparticles and microparticles. Therefore, we have mainly focused on functional magnetic nanoparticles for nanomedicine because of their high bioadaptability to the organs inside human body. Here, bioconjugation techniques are very crucial to link nanoparticles with conventional drugs, nanodrugs, biomolecules or polymers for biomedical applications. Biofunctionalization of engineered nanoparticles for biomedicine is shown respective to in vitro and in vivo analysis protocols that typically include drug delivery, hyperthermia therapy, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and recent outstanding progress in sweep imaging technique with Fourier transformation (SWIFT) MRI. The latter can be especially applied using magnetic nanoparticles, such as Co-, Fe-, Ni-based nanoparticles, α-Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>, and Fe<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf> oxide nanoparticles for analysis and treatment of malignancies. Therefore, this review focuses on recent results of scientists, and related research on diagnosis and treatment methods of common and dangerous diseases by biomedical engineered nanoparticles. Importantly, nanosysems (nanoparticles) or microsystems (microparticles) or hybrid micronano systems are shortly introduced into nanomedicine. Here, Fe oxide nanoparticles ultimately enable potential and applicable technologies for tumor-targeted imaging and therapy. Finally, we have shown the latest aspects of the most important Fe-based particle systems, such as Fe, α-Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>, Fe<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf>, Fe-FexOy oxide core-shell nanoparticles, and CoFe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>4</inf>-MnFe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>4</inf> core-shell nanoparticles for nanomedicine in the efficient treatment of large tumors at low cost in near future. © 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.V., Vu, T. V.; G., Tryggvason, Gretar; S., Homma, Shunji; J.C., Wells, John Craig
Author full names: Vu, T. V. (37125067100); Tryggvason, Gretar (7005126358); Homma, Shunji (56041843000); Wells, John Craig (55390003000)
Title: Numerical investigations of drop solidification on a cold plate in the presence of volume change
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; University of Notre Dame, Notre Dame, United States; Saitama University, Saitama, Japan; Ritsumeikan University Biwako-Kusatsu Campus, Kusatsu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Vu, T. V., School of Transportation Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tryggvason, Gretar, Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, University of Notre Dame, Notre Dame, United States; Homma, Shunji, Materials Science Division, Saitama University, Saitama, Japan; Wells, John Craig, Ritsumeikan University Biwako-Kusatsu Campus, Kusatsu, Japan
Abstract: We present a front-tracking/finite difference method for simulation of drop solidification on a cold plate. The problem includes temporal evolution of three interfaces, i.e. solid-liquid, solid-gas, and liquid-gas, that are explicitly tracked under the assumption of axisymmetry. Method validation is carried out by comparing computational results with exact solutions for a two-dimensional Stefan problem, and with related experiments. We then use the method to investigate a drop solidifying on a cold plate in which there exists volume change due to density difference between the solid and liquid phases. Numerical results show that the shape of the solidified drop is profoundly different from the initial liquid one due to the effects of volume change and the tri-junction in terms of growth angles ϕ<inf>gr</inf> on the solidification process. A decrease in the density ratio of solid to liquid ρ<inf>sl</inf> or an increase in the growth angle results in an increase in the height of the solidified drop. The solidification process is also affected by the Stefan number St, the Bond number Bo, the Prandtl number Pr, the Weber number We, the ratios of the thermal properties of the solid to liquid phases k<inf>sl</inf> and C<inf>psl</inf>. Increasing St, Bo, Pr, We, or k<inf>sl</inf> decreases the solidified drop height and the time to complete solidification. Moreover, the solidification growth rate is strongly affected by St, k<inf>sl</inf> and C<inf>psl</inf>. An increase in any of these parameters hastens the growth rate of the solidification interface. Contrarily, increasing ρ<inf>sl</inf> decreases the growth rate. However, other parameters such as ϕ<inf>gr</inf>, Bo, Pr and We have minor effects on the solidification growth rate. © 2015 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H.T., Nguyen, Hung Tien; T., Tran, Tien; Y., Fukunishi, Yoshifumi; J., Higo, Jun'ichi; H.K., Nakamura, Haruki K.; T., Le, Thithi
Author full names: Nguyen, Hung Tien (55909320400); Tran, Tien (56875118900); Fukunishi, Yoshifumi (56022607700); Higo, Jun'ichi (35597715900); Nakamura, Haruki K. (55477600500); Le, Thithi (56045128800)
Title: Computational Study of Drug Binding Affinity to Influenza A Neuraminidase Using Smooth Reaction Path Generation (SRPG) Method
Source title: Journal of Chemical Information and Modeling
Affiliations: Viện Khoa học và Công nghệ Tính toán, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Hung Tien, Viện Khoa học và Công nghệ Tính toán, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tran, Tien, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Fukunishi, Yoshifumi, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Higo, Jun'ichi, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Nakamura, Haruki K., The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Le, Thithi, Viện Khoa học và Công nghệ Tính toán, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, School of Biotechnology, International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: Assessment of accurate drug binding affinity to a protein remains a challenge for in silico drug development. In this research, we used the smooth reaction path generation (SRPG) method to calculate binding free energies and determine potential of mean forces (PMFs) along the smoothed dissociation paths of influenza A neuraminidase and its variants with oseltamivir (Tamiflu) and zanamivir (Relenza) inhibitors. With the gained results, we found that the binding free energies of neuraminidase A/H5N1 in WT and two mutants (including H274Y and N294S) with oseltamivir and zanamivir show good agreement with experimental results. Additionally, the thermodynamic origin of the drug resistance of the mutants was also discussed from the PMF profiles. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.D., Pham, Tien Duc; M., Kobayashi, Motoyoshi; Y., Adachi, Yasuhisa
Author full names: Pham, Tien Duc (55797010800); Kobayashi, Motoyoshi (8531601700); Adachi, Yasuhisa (7402465572)
Title: Adsorption characteristics of anionic azo dye onto large α-alumina beads
Affiliations: Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Pham, Tien Duc, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Graduate School of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Kobayashi, Motoyoshi, Graduate School of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Adachi, Yasuhisa, Graduate School of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: Adsorption of anionic azo dye, new coccine (NC), onto large α-alumina beads in aqueous media was systematically investigated as functions of pH and NaCl concentration. Adsorption amounts of NC decrease with increasing pH of solutions due to less positive charges of α-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> surface at high pH. At a fixed pH, the NC adsorption increases with decreasing NaCl concentration, indicating that NC molecules mainly adsorb onto α-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> by electrostatic attraction. Experimental results of NC adsorption isotherms onto α-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> at different pH, and ionic strength can be represented well by two-step adsorption model. The effects of NC on surface charge and surface modification of α-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> at the plateau adsorption are evaluated by streaming potential and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy with attenuated total reflection technique (FTIR-ATR), respectively. On the basis of adsorption isotherms, surface charge effect, and surface modification, we suggested that the formation of a bridged bidentate complex between aluminum ions of α-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> and two oxygen atoms of a sulfonic group induced the adsorption of NC onto α-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: C.T., Nguyen, Cuong T.; H.H., Bui, Ha H.; R., Fukagawa, Ryouichi
Author full names: Nguyen, Cuong T. (57220776877); Bui, Ha H. (58005436500); Fukagawa, Ryouichi (6701897384)
Title: Failure mechanism of true 2D granular flows
Source title: Journal of Chemical Engineering of Japan
Affiliations: Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Mechanics, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Monash University, Melbourne, Australia; Ritsumeikan University Biwako-Kusatsu Campus, Kusatsu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Cuong T., Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Mechanics, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Civil Engineering, Ritsumeikan University Biwako-Kusatsu Campus, Kusatsu, Japan; Bui, Ha H., Monash University, Melbourne, Australia; Fukagawa, Ryouichi, Department of Civil Engineering, Ritsumeikan University Biwako-Kusatsu Campus, Kusatsu, Japan
Abstract: Most previous experimental investigations of two-dimensional (2D) granular column collapses have been conducted using three-dimensional (3D) granular materials in narrow horizontal channels (i.e., quasi-2D condition). Our recent research on 2D granular column collapses by using 2D granular materials (i.e., aluminum rods) has revealed results that differ markedly from those reported in the literature. We assume a 2D column with an initial height of h<inf>0</inf> and initial width of d<inf>0</inf>, a defined as their ratio (a=h<inf>0</inf>/d<inf>0</inf>), a final height of h<inf>∞</inf>, and maximum run-out distance of d<inf>∞</inf>. The experimental data suggest that for the low a regime (a≤0.65) the ratio of the final height to initial height is 1. However, for the high a regime (a≥0.65), the ratio of a to (d<inf>∞</inf>−d<inf>0</inf>)/d<inf>0</inf>, h<inf>0</inf>/h<inf>∞</inf>, or d<inf>∞</inf>/d<inf>0</inf> is expressed by power-law relations. In particular, the following power-function ratios (h<inf>0</inf>/h<inf>∞</inf>≈1.42a2/3 and d<inf>∞</inf>/d<inf>0</inf>∼4.30a0.72) are proposed for every a≥0.65. In contrast, the ratio (d<inf>∞</inf>−d<inf>0</inf>)/d<inf>0</inf>≈3.25a0.96 only holds for 0.65≤a≤1.5, whereas the ratio (d<inf>∞</inf>−d<inf>0</inf>)/d<inf>0</inf>≈3.80a0.73 holds for a≥1.5. In addition, the influence of ground contact surfaces (hard or soft beds) on the final run-out distance and destruction zone of the granular column under true 2D conditions is investigated. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Abstract: How do we build research capacity throughout the world and capture the great human potential? To us, the answer is rather straightforward: the time-honored tradition of scientific mentoring must be practiced on a wider scale across borders. Herein, we detail the necessity for expanding mentorship to a global scale and provide several important principles to be considered when designing, planning, and implementing programs and centers of research around the world. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Yamamoto, Yoshimasa (55255881100); Shiobara, Keiichiro (56646309500); Nguyen, Thu Ha (57222878083); Nghia, Phan Trung (15763233700); Fukuhara, Lina (56398475300); Ishii, Hiroyuki (55226832100); Kawahara, Seiichi (7101824012)
Title: Hydrogenation of epoxidized natural rubber in latex stage
Affiliations: National Institute of Technology, Tokyo College, Hachioji, Japan; Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Yamamoto, Yoshimasa, Department of Chemical Science and Engineering, National Institute of Technology, Tokyo College, Hachioji, Japan; Shiobara, Keiichiro, Department of Materials Science and Technology, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Nguyen, Thu Ha, Department of Materials Science and Technology, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Nghia, Phan Trung, Department of Chemical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Fukuhara, Lina, Department of Chemical Science and Engineering, National Institute of Technology, Tokyo College, Hachioji, Japan; Ishii, Hiroyuki, Department of Chemical Science and Engineering, National Institute of Technology, Tokyo College, Hachioji, Japan; Kawahara, Seiichi, Department of Materials Science and Technology, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan
Abstract: Hydroxyl groups can be introduced in hydrogenated natural rubber by hydrogenation of epoxidized natural rubber (ENR). The ENR was prepared by cpoxidation of high ammonia natural rubber with peracetic acid followed by deprotcinization in the latex stage. Hydrogen gas in the presence of PdCl2 as a catalyst was used as the hydrogenation agent in the latex stage. The resulting product was characterized by nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. Under suitable reaction conditions, 90.7% of the double bonds could be converted. The content of residual double bond was 5.6% and the hydroxyl group content was 1.5%. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Affiliations: National Institute of Technology, Tokyo College, Hachioji, Japan; Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam

Abstract: Blends of poly(lactic acid)(PLA) and liquid cpoxidized natural rubber (LENR) or liquid cpoxidizcd deproteinized natural rubber (LEDPNR) were prepared by mixing and subsequent annealing at 200°C for 20 min. The conversion of LEDPNR and PLA was 23.4%, whereas that between ENR and PLA was just 5.8%. The stress at break of LEDPNR/PLA blend after annealing at 200°C was higher than that prepared without annealing. This may be attributed to chemical bonds between PLA and ENR, and a changes in morphology of the PLA/LEDPNR blend. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Duc, Daodao (55543152300); Yamada, Hidetaka (9732900100); Yogo, Katsunori (6701455797)
Title: Response surface optimization of impregnation of blended amines into mesoporous silica for high-performance Co2 capture
Affiliations: Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Research Institute of Innovative Technology for Earth Kizugawa, Kizugawa, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Duc, Daodao, Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Japan, Faculty of Chemistry, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yamada, Hidetaka, Research Institute of Innovative Technology for Earth Kizugawa, Kizugawa, Japan; Yogo, Katsunori, Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Japan, Research Institute of Innovative Technology for Earth Kizugawa, Kizugawa, Japan
Abstract: We used the response surface method (RSM) to optimize the conditions for the impregnation of blended amines into mesostructured cellular silica foam (MSU-F) to prepare effective solid sorbents for CO<inf>2</inf> capture. The effects of the amounts of tetraethylenepentamine (TEPA), diethanolamine (DEA), and methanol (MeOH) in the wet impregnation mixture on the amounts of CO<inf>2</inf> adsorbed were investigated. The influences of these three independent variables and their interactions were determined using the RSM; the optimum amounts of TEPA, DEA, and MeOH were 1.33 g (7.03 mmol), 0.85 g (8.08 mmol), and 58.2 g, for the preparation of 3 g of sorbent, respectively. Under the adsorption conditions of 40 °C and 100 kPa CO<inf>2</inf>, the optimum sorbent showed fast kinetics and an excellent CO<inf>2</inf> adsorption of 5.64 mmol/g; the value predicted by the RSM model was 5.67 mmol/g. Analysis of variance and the coefficient of determination (R2 = 0.9525) showed the utility of the approach used in this study to optimize the conditions for preparing high-performance solid sorbents. For the optimum sorbent, the heat of adsorption was determined to be 78.9 kJ/mol CO<inf>2</inf> at 40 °C and 100 kPa, using a Calvet calorimeter, indicating relatively strong chemisorption in the form of carbamate. We also found that the amounts of CO<inf>2</inf> adsorbed by the optimum sorbent substantially depended upon the adsorption temperature. The highest CO<inf>2</inf> adsorption, 6.86 mmol/g, was obtained at 50 °C and 100 kPa. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Q.D., Truong, Quang Duc; H.T., Hoa, Huu Thu; L.T., Son, Le Thanh
Author full names: Truong, Quang Duc (41361850100); Hoa, Huu Thu (55250552300); Son, Le Thanh (59157758300)
Title: Pt nanoparticles loaded titanium picolinate framework for photocatalytic hydrogen generation
Affiliations: Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Truong, Quang Duc, Institute of Multidisciplinary Research for Advanced Materials, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hoa, Huu Thu, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Son, Le Thanh, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Pt nanoparticles have been embedded into layers of a titanium picolinate framework by a photodeposition method. TEM images show the embedded and adsorbed Pt nanoparticles in the space between the layers with size of c.a 1 nm. The obtained Pt loaded titanium picolinate framework functions as an efficient photocatalyst for hydrogen evolution from methanol/water solution upon irradiation at wavelength longer than 300 nm (159.3 μmol h?1/0.1 g TiPF catalyst). © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Fujikawa, Yoko (7006120649); Sugahara, Masataka (7101986438); Honma, Tetsuo (7201857455); Hirayama, Sayaka (8784058900); Hung, Phan Do (57190814925); Sakurai, Shinji (35305923000); Yashima, Hiroshi (9840382100); Hashiguchi, Ayumi (57660818700); Taniguchi, Shogo (11939600700); Ozaki, Hiroaki (55786986100)
Title: Monitoring of arsenite sorption to biogenic iron oxide in a flow-through column by X-ray absorption spectroscopy
Source title: e-Journal of Surface Science and Nanotechnology
Affiliations: Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Osaka Sangyo University, Daito, Japan; Japan Synchrotron Radiation Research Institute, Sayo District, Japan; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Osaka Sangyo University, Daito, Japan; Modern Water plc, Guildford, United Kingdom; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Fujikawa, Yoko, Research Reactor Institute, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Sugahara, Masataka, Faculty of Human Environment, Osaka Sangyo University, Daito, Japan; Honma, Tetsuo, Japan Synchrotron Radiation Research Institute, Sayo District, Japan; Hirayama, Sayaka, Japan Synchrotron Radiation Research Institute, Sayo District, Japan; Hung, Phan Do, Institute of Environmental Technology, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Sakurai, Shinji, Research Reactor Institute, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan, Graduate School of Life and Environmental Sciences, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Yashima, Hiroshi, Research Reactor Institute, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Hashiguchi, Ayumi, Department of Civil Engineering, Osaka Sangyo University, Daito, Japan; Taniguchi, Shogo, Department of Civil Engineering, Osaka Sangyo University, Daito, Japan; Ozaki, Hiroaki, Department of Civil Engineering, Osaka Sangyo University, Daito, Japan
Abstract: We have conducted a pilot study of a biological filtration (BF) system for low-cost arsenic (As) removal from groundwater containing both ferrous iron (Fe(II)) and arsenic (As). Throughout the study, we have observed that arsenite (As(III)) as well as arsenate (As(V)) could be removed with this system. In conventional water treatment technologies, the preoxidation of As(III) to As(V) by oxidizing chemical is a mandatory step for As(III) removal However, such a preoxidation unit has not been used in our BF pilot unit, and hence the mechanisms of As(III) removal by BF have been of interest. Using a flow-through column reactor that simulates the actual BF pond for analysis by X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), we could observe the adsorption of As(III) in water onto iron hydroxides deposited on the biological filter. The time-resolved As K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra were obtained when the water containing As(III) and Fe(II) was continuously fed to the reactor. An increase in the absorption intensity of the X-ray with time was clearly observed in the time-resolved spectra, indicating that the spectra represented the concentration and chemical state of As adsorbed at the solid-liquid interface of the biological filter. The XAS results also show that while the original water fed to the reactor was supposed to contain only As(III) and Fe(II), a small portion of As(III) was oxidized to As(V) in the influent line when the As(III) solution met the Fe(II) solution before flowing into the reactor. Consequently, besides As(III), As(V) probably formed by the oxidation of As(III) in the influent, was detected on the filter by XAS. The results demonstrate that, in BF, mechanisms of As(III) removal are at least partially explained by the adsorption of As(III) in the raw water to the biological filter as it is. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M.E.L., Kalaw, Martin Ernesto L.; A.B., Culaba, Alvin B.; H.T., Nguyen, Hoc Thang; K., Nguyen, Khoi; H., Hinode, Hirofumi; W., Kurniawan, Winarto; S.M., Gallardo, Susan M.; M.B., Promentilla, M. B.
Author full names: Kalaw, Martin Ernesto L. (36623959600); Culaba, Alvin B. (6508063649); Nguyen, Hoc Thang (57312316600); Nguyen, Khoi (57212419149); Hinode, Hirofumi (6603680612); Kurniawan, Winarto (12752420700); Gallardo, Susan M. (7004678447); Promentilla, M. B. (15045622100)
Title: Mechanical and thermal properties of geopolymers from mixtures of coal ash and rice hull ash using water glass solution as activator
Affiliations: De La Salle University, Manila, Philippines; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; De La Salle University, Manila, Philippines
Authors with affiliations: Kalaw, Martin Ernesto L., Mechanical Engineering Department De, De La Salle University, Manila, Philippines; Culaba, Alvin B., Mechanical Engineering Department De, De La Salle University, Manila, Philippines; Nguyen, Hoc Thang, Faculty of Materials Technology, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Khoi, Faculty of Materials Technology, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Hinode, Hirofumi, Department of International Development Engineering, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Kurniawan, Winarto, Department of International Development Engineering, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Gallardo, Susan M., Chemical Engineering Department De, De La Salle University, Manila, Philippines; Promentilla, M. B., Chemical Engineering Department De, De La Salle University, Manila, Philippines
Abstract: Geopolymers, from industrial wastes such as blast furnace slag, red mud, and coal ash, among others, have emerged as technically viable, economically competitive, and environmentally attractive supplements and even alternatives to ordinary Portland cement (OPC). Furthermore, while the most impact shall be achieved with large-scale use in the general building and structural sector, as replacement or supplement to OPC, the properties of these geopolymers may be optimized for special niche applications. One of these applications is for light weight, low thermal conductivity, heat resistant, and moderate strength cement binder for low rise residential buildings. In this study, compressive strength, heat resistance, volumetric weight, mass loss, water absorption and thermal conductivity of geopolymers formed from mixtures of coal bottom ash and rice hull ash (CBA-RHA) and coal fly ash and rice hull ash (CFA-RHA) with sodium silicate solution (modulus 2.5) as activator were evaluated. Using mixture design and the JMP statistical software, the CBA-RHA combination at a mass ratio of 46% CBA, 32% RHA with 22% WGS gave properties at maximum desirability of 17.6 MPa compressive strength, 1640 kg/m3 volumetric weight, 273 kg/m3 water absorption, 28 MPa compressive strength after high temperature exposure (1000oC for 2 hours) with 4.4% mass loss, and 0.578 W/m-K thermal conductivity. On a performance basis, even as the geopolymers are formed as paste, these properties fall within the standards for lightweight OPC based-concrete with strength requirements for residential buildings. The low thermal conductivity and higher strength after high temperature exposure vis-à-vis OPC are additional advantages for consideration. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Bottom Ash; Fly Ash; Geopolymers; Rice Hull Ash; Waste Utilization; Water Glass Activation

Authors: H.T., Tran, Hang Thi; H., Ajiro, Hiroharu; M., Akashi, Mitsuru
Author full names: Tran, Hang Thi (14834555300); Ajiro, Hiroharu (6602489375); Akashi, Mitsuru (35463476100)
Title: Thermally stable polylactides by stereocomplex formation and conjugation of both terminals with bio-based cinnamic acid derivatives
Affiliations: Viet Tri University of Industry, Viet Tri, Phu Tho, Viet Nam; The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Japan Science and Technology Agency, Kawaguchi, Japan; Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Japan; Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Japan; The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tran, Hang Thi, Faculty of Chemical Technology, Viet Tri University of Industry, Viet Tri, Phu Tho, Viet Nam; Ajiro, Hiroharu, Department of Applied Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, Center for Advanced Medical Engineering and Informatics, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, Japan Science and Technology Agency, Kawaguchi, Japan, Graduate School of Materials Science, Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Japan, Institute for Research Initiatives, Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Japan; Akashi, Mitsuru, Department of Applied Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, Center for Advanced Medical Engineering and Informatics, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, Graduate School of Frontier Biosciences, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Abstract: Novel polylactides (PLAs) with conjugation of both terminals by cinnamic acid (CA) derivatives showed high thermal stability and photoreactivity. Their stereocomplex formation was influenced by the conjugation groups at both chain ends of the PLAs and showed photoreactivity and a dramatic improvement in their 10% weight thermal decomposition temperature (T<inf>10</inf>) from 250 to 320 or 345 °C for conjugated CA or 3,4-diacetoxycinnamic acid (DACA). Interestingly, CA or DACA-conjugated stereocomplexes showed above 98% weight remaining, although the original PLAs showed a 23 wt% pyrolysis, during isothermal degradation at 200 °C for 120 min. The thermal stability and photoreactivity of the PLAs or their stereocomplexes were controlled by the cinnamic acid derivatives. These PLAs and their stereocomplexes may be useful as functional bio-based materials for various application fields. © 2015 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N., Viet Long, Nguyen; Y., Yang, Yong; T., Teranishi, Toshiharu; C.M., Thi, Cao Minh; Y., Cao, Yanqin; M., Nogami, Massayuki
Author full names: Viet Long, Nguyen (35334870500); Yang, Yong (56406088300); Teranishi, Toshiharu (7101891244); Thi, Cao Minh (55315987000); Cao, Yanqin (55840210800); Nogami, Massayuki (57202849551)
Title: Related magnetic properties of CoFe2O4 cobalt ferrite particles synthesised by the polyol method with NaBH4 and heat treatment: new micro and nanoscale structures
Affiliations: Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai, China; Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Toyota Physical and Chemical Research Institute, Nagakute, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Viet Long, Nguyen, State Key Laboratory of High Performance Ceramics and Superfine Microstructure, Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai, China, Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Yang, Yong, State Key Laboratory of High Performance Ceramics and Superfine Microstructure, Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai, China; Teranishi, Toshiharu, Institute for Chemical Research, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Thi, Cao Minh, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Cao, Yanqin, State Key Laboratory of High Performance Ceramics and Superfine Microstructure, Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai, China; Nogami, Massayuki, Toyota Physical and Chemical Research Institute, Nagakute, Japan
Abstract: In this contribution, hierarchical CoFe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>4</inf> particles are successfully prepared via a modified polyol elaboration method with NaBH<inf>4</inf> and a proposed heat treatment process. Here, new as-prepared CoFe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>4</inf> particles with sizes in the range of 5 μm show highly uniform characteristics in their size, shape and cubic spinel crystal structure according to X-ray diffraction (XRD), whole pattern fitting and Rietveld refinement, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). We discovered that the CoFe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>4</inf> microparticles prepared in the certain size range of 5 μm show exciting configurations of grain and grain boundaries under particle heat treatment at the high temperature 900°C. Finally, CoFe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>4</inf> ferrite particles with various well-defined micro and nanoscale structures were produced after appropriate heat treatment processes under high temperature, and which have a high coercive field, H<inf>C</inf>, around 416-888 Oe, and the highest saturation magnetization, M<inf>S</inf>, of about 74-91 emu g-1 at room temperature (RT) for all of the as-prepared samples measured using a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM). Here, the magnetic behavior has shown persuasive evidence that the desirable ferrimagnetic properties of CoFe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>4</inf> oxides do not only depend on their size but also on the spinel structure of the CoFe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>4</inf> oxides as well. Finally, the as-prepared CoFe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>4</inf> particles with the formula CoO·Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> were regarded as the best inverse ferrimagnetic materials with magnetic parameters of H<inf>C</inf> at 896 Oe, M<inf>R</inf>/M<inf>S</inf> squareness around 0.420, and M<inf>S</inf> around 92 emu g-1 at 20 kOe for the downward part of the hysteresis loop. © 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: V.N.T., Sang, Vu Ngoc Thanh; N.D., Thang, Nguyen Duc; V., van Toi, Vo; N.D., Hoang, Nguyen Duc; T.Q.D., Khoa, Truong Quang Dang
Author full names: Sang, Vu Ngoc Thanh (56602818000); Thang, Nguyen Duc (35304327500); van Toi, Vo (36899371300); Hoang, Nguyen Duc (56602474200); Khoa, Truong Quang Dang (6602718689)
Title: Human activity recognition and monitoring using smartphones
Affiliations: International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology-HCM, Viet Nam; Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sang, Vu Ngoc Thanh, International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thang, Nguyen Duc, International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; van Toi, Vo, International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Hoang, Nguyen Duc, Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology-HCM, Viet Nam; Khoa, Truong Quang Dang, Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Japan
Abstract: The sedentary lifestyle is becoming popular especially for intellectual work. Although physical inactivity lifestyle may cause many unexpected illnesses, it is complicated to build up a positive lifestyle due to the lacks of reminder systems to manage and monitor physical activities of people. This research represents an effective way for daily activity monitoring using accelerator and gyroscope sensors embedded in a smartphone. Signals were recorded from accelerator and gyroscope sensors while a user wearing the smartphone performs different activities (going downstairs, going upstairs, sitting with the phone in a pocket, driving and putting the phone on the table). The classification algorithms with k-nearestneighbor (kNN) and artificial neural network (ANN) were applied to recognize user’s activities. The overall accuracy of recognizing five activities is 74% for kNN and 75.3% for ANN respectively. Based on the activities recognized during the day, users are able to manage their daily activities for a better life. © 2015 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: P.T., Kien, Pham Trung; K., Tsuru, Kanji; K., Ishikawa, Kunio
Author full names: Kien, Pham Trung (55984993300); Tsuru, Kanji (7005516232); Ishikawa, Kunio (7404554763)
Title: Development and characterization of porous calcium phosphate cement using α-tricalcium phosphate bead
Affiliations: Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kien, Pham Trung, Department of Ceramic Materials, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tsuru, Kanji, Department of Biomaterials, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Ishikawa, Kunio, Department of Biomaterials, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Abstract: Interconnected set porous-calcium phosphate cement (set porous-CPC), which has fully interconnected pores could be an ideal bone substitute. In this study, set porous- CPC consisting of α-tricalcium phosphate (α-TCP) beads and acidic calcium phosphate solution was developed and its basic setting reaction was studied. When α-TCP beads were exposed to the acidic calcium phosphate solution, brushite (CaHPO4 ·2H2O) was formed on the surface of the α-TCP beads. The formed brushite crystals interlocked with each other, resulting in a setting reaction of α-TCP microspheres within 10 min at 37°C. As a result of this setting reaction, a fullyinterconnected calcium phosphate macroporous structure was obtained. The set porous-CPC were immersed into simulated body fluid (SBF) at 37oC for different immersion time, The result clearly showed that brushite surface layer transformed to apatite layer after 3 days immersion into SBF solution by dissolution-precipitation reaction. Since apatite layer show excellent tissue response, the set porous-CPC would be a promising biomaterial used as artificial bone substitutes, and as the scaffold for tissue engineering. © 2015 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Giang, Tran Le (56602672100); Thang, Nguyen Duc (35304327500); van Toi, Vo (36899371300); Tâm, Nguyên Huynh Minh (36476818300); Dinh, Dong Luong (56015754900); Khoa, Truong Quang Dang (6602718689)
Title: Evaluation of hemodynamic responses to visual tasks using functional near infrared Spectroscopy
Affiliations: International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Canada; Kyung Hee University, Seoul, South Korea; Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Giang, Tran Le, Department of Biomedical Engineering, International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thang, Nguyen Duc, Department of Biomedical Engineering, International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; van Toi, Vo, Department of Biomedical Engineering, International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tâm, Nguyên Huynh Minh, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Canada; Dinh, Dong Luong, Department of Computer Engineering, Kyung Hee University, Seoul, South Korea; Khoa, Truong Quang Dang, Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Japan
Abstract: Functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) is becoming widely applied in many practical researches, especially in vivo researches on human. This study focuses on the hemodynamic responses of visual cortex when the human eye is excited by different conditions of flickering light stimulus. In our experiment, visual cortex is activated by flickering light at various spatial frequencies and modulation depths while the hemodynamic responses of the visual cortex are simultaneously monitored by fNIRS. Our experimental results suggest that flickering light can activate hemodynamic responses of the visual cortex but those changes are not significantly distinct among different stimulus conditions. © 2015 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Tan, Tranxuan; V., van Toi, Vo; T.Q.D., Khoa, Truong Quang Dang; H.D.H., Hanh, H. D.H.; T.T.K., Thu, T. T.K.; T.T.T., Lan, Thi Tuyet Tuyet
Author full names: Tan, Tranxuan (55536796000); van Toi, Vo (36899371300); Khoa, Truong Quang Dang (6602718689); Hanh, H. D.H. (56602742500); Thu, T. T.K. (56602603900); Lan, Thi Tuyet Tuyet (55570089700)
Title: Investigating chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) in vietnamese patients using impulse oscillometry (IOS)
Affiliations: International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Japan; University Medical Center, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Tan, Tranxuan, Department of Biomedical Engineering, International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; van Toi, Vo, Department of Biomedical Engineering, International University - Vietnam National University HCM City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Khoa, Truong Quang Dang, Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Japan; Hanh, H. D.H., University Medical Center, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thu, T. T.K., University Medical Center, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Lan, Thi Tuyet Tuyet, University Medical Center, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: Crucial measurement of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) relies extensively on the use of spirometry, “gold standard” for diagnosis of COPD. Impulse oscillometry system (IOS) is a non-volitional way to access the mechanical structure of the respiratory system. The goals of our study were to find out the sensitivity and specificity of the IOS in diagnosis of COPD patients, and investigate which IOS parameters are related to severity and airflow obstruction in Vietnamese COPD patients. The study contain twenty-two COPD patients (stage 3 and 4) and Thirty-four healthy people, whole of them are greater than 40 years, were recruited in Community Health Care Center, Ho Chi Minh city, Vietnam. IOS measurements (R5, R20, X5, X20, AX, Fres and Delta R5-R20), and Spirometry (FEV1, FEV1/FVC) were performed. Pearson or Spearman correlation determined the relationships between IOS and Spirometry. Firstly, R5, X5, X20, AX, Fres & Delta R5-R20 were all significantly associated (p < 0.05) with FEV1. However, R20 were not related to FEV1. The strongest associations were observed between FEV1 and X5 (r = 0.7737), AX (r = -0.7825) and Delta R5-R20 (r = -0.7823). Secondly, X5, AX & Delta R5-R20 were significantly associated with FEV1/FVC. The strongest correlation was observed between Delta R5-R20 and FEV1/FVC with r = - 0.6903. Reactance airway measurements (X5, X20, AX, Fres), peripheral airway resistance (Delta R5-R20) and total respiratory resistance (R5) are closely related to Vietnamese COPD diagnosis than central respiratory resistance (R20). The IOS measurements can be a significant value for COPD diagnosis in Vietnamese © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: L.H.M., Linh, Le Hoang My; T., Taniike, Toshiaki; N.B., Trung, Nguyen Ba
Author full names: Linh, Le Hoang My (55900724000); Taniike, Toshiaki (22136881100); Trung, Nguyen Ba (57224654135)
Title: Fabrication of silver nanoparticles-curcumin-agar nanocomposite film and its super antimicrobial activity
Affiliations: Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Linh, Le Hoang My, School of Materials Science, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Taniike, Toshiaki, School of Materials Science, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Trung, Nguyen Ba, Faculty of Chemistry, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Abstract: This work explores a novel method for in-situ fabrication of silver nanoparticles (NPs) using hydrolysed agar as a reducing agent and matrix for the dispersion of silver NPs. UV-vis spectroscopy, FT-IR, X-ray diffraction (XRD) and TEM were used to confirm the formation, crystallisation, and size of the synthesised silver NPs, respectively. The result showed that the size of synthesised silver NPs was in the range of 15 to 20 nm. Curcumin ((1E,6E)-1,7-Bis(4-hydroxy-3-methoxyphenyl)-1,6-heptadiene-3,5-dione) with anti-bacterial, anti-oxidant, and wound healing properties was mixed with the solution of the agar-based silver NPs in order to improve anti-bacterial properties of the resulting material. Anti-bacterial tests for the synthesised silver NPs-curcumin-agar material for Gram (-) and Gram (+) bacteria demonstrated significant effects against both Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus. Nanocomposite film of the silver NPs-curcumin-agar material may fnd use for a wide variety of biomedical applications, such as cosmetic masks, anti-bacterial polymers for wound dressing and burn-treatment medicines. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N., Viet Long, Nguyen; Y., Yang, Yong; C.M., Thi, Cao Minh; T.H., Bui, Thi Hang; Y., Cao, Yanqin; M., Nogami, Massayuki
Author full names: Viet Long, Nguyen (35334870500); Yang, Yong (56406088300); Thi, Cao Minh (55315987000); Bui, Thi Hang (57203943145); Cao, Yanqin (55840210800); Nogami, Massayuki (57202849551)
Title: Controlled synthesis and characterization of iron oxide micro-particles for Fe-air battery electrode material
Affiliations: Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai, China; Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; International Training Institute for Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Toyota Motor Corporation, Toyota, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Viet Long, Nguyen, State Key Laboratory of High Performance Ceramics and Superfine Microstructure, Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai, China, Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Laboratory for Nanotechnology, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Department of Molecular and Material Sciences, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Yang, Yong, State Key Laboratory of High Performance Ceramics and Superfine Microstructure, Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai, China; Thi, Cao Minh, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Bui, Thi Hang, International Training Institute for Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Cao, Yanqin, State Key Laboratory of High Performance Ceramics and Superfine Microstructure, Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai, China; Nogami, Massayuki, Toyota Motor Corporation, Toyota, Japan
Abstract: In this research, novel homogeneous iron (Fe) oxide particles with the pure α-Fe2O3 structure are successfully synthesized with controlling and shaping via a modified polyol method with NaBH4 as an efficient reducing agent according to drying and heat treatment processes. In the critical synthetic and experimental conditions, large α-Fe2O3 particles exhibited homogeneously large sizes in the certain ranges of 1-5 μm and 1-10 μm, which are regarded as a discovery of controlled and shaped synthesis. The electrochemical measurements indicated that oxide powders containing as-prepared pure α-Fe2O3 microparticles were successfully used in the electrodes. Accordingly, the cyclic voltammetry (CV) and galvanostatic cycling measurements indicated their potential applications for next-generation Fe-air battery technology in comparison with commercial oxide products of Fe2O3 particles. Finally, we suggest that the sharp polyhedral shape and morphology of the engineered micro-particles, such as metal, alloy, and oxide micro-particles, are of importance because they have very high stability and durability with respect to their applied properties. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: X., Cao, Xuanviet; H.H., Ismail, Hanafi H.; A.R., Azura, A. R.; T., Takeichi, Tsutomu; T., Vo-Huu, Thao
Author full names: Cao, Xuanviet (59099532000); Ismail, Hanafi H. (7102329732); Azura, A. R. (57211405393); Takeichi, Tsutomu (7005513741); Vo-Huu, Thao (46662053800)
Title: Effect of filler surface treatment on the properties of recycled high-density polyethylene/(natural rubber)/(kenaf powder) biocomposites
Source title: Journal of Vinyl and Additive Technology
Affiliations: School of Materials and Mineral Resources Engineering, Nibong Tebal, Malaysia; Toyohashi University of Technology, Toyohashi, Japan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Cao, Xuanviet, School of Materials and Mineral Resources Engineering, Nibong Tebal, Malaysia; Ismail, Hanafi H., School of Materials and Mineral Resources Engineering, Nibong Tebal, Malaysia; Azura, A. R., School of Materials and Mineral Resources Engineering, Nibong Tebal, Malaysia; Takeichi, Tsutomu, School of Materials Science, Toyohashi University of Technology, Toyohashi, Japan; Vo-Huu, Thao, Department of Polymer Materials, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: Biocomposites were prepared from a kenaf core powder and recycled high-density polyethylene/(natural rubber) blend by using an internal mixer at 165°C and 50 rpm. The effect of the filler content and the filler surface treatment was studied. Chemical modification of kenaf filler was performed with alkali pretreatment followed by treatment with silane. Scanning electron microscopy and infrared spectroscopy studies confirmed changes in the chemical compositions and structural characteristics induced through the modification. It was found that treated biocomposites offered higher tensile strength and tensile modulus, but lower elongation at break compared with untreated biocomposites. Lower water absorption and higher thermal stability of the resultant biocomposites were also obtained when treated fillers were used. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.H., Do, Thi Huyen; T.T., Nguyen, Thi Thao; T.N., Nguyen, Thanh Ngoc; Q.G., Le, Quynh Giang; C., Nguyen, Cuong; K., Kimura, Keitarou; N., Truong, Namhai
Author full names: Do, Thi Huyen (36882846600); Nguyen, Thi Thao (57212284047); Nguyen, Thanh Ngoc (55816131800); Le, Quynh Giang (59267031100); Nguyen, Cuong (57213860677); Kimura, Keitarou (7404820634); Truong, Namhai (55111296300)
Title: Mining biomass-degrading genes through Illumina-based de novo sequencing and metagenomic analysis of free-living bacteria in the gut of the lower termite Coptotermes gestroi harvested in Vietnam
Affiliations: Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vinh University, Vinh, Viet Nam; Food Research Institute, NARO, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Do, Thi Huyen, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Thi Thao, Vinh University, Vinh, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Thanh Ngoc, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le, Quynh Giang, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Cuong, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kimura, Keitarou, Food Research Institute, NARO, Tsukuba, Japan; Truong, Namhai, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: The 5.6Gb metagenome of free-living microbial flora in the gut of the lower termite Coptotermes gestroi, harvested in Vietnam, was sequenced using Illumina technology. Genes related to biomass degradation were mined for a better understanding of biomass digestion in the termite gut and to identify lignocellulolytic enzymes applicable to biofuel production. The sequencing generated 5.4Gb of useful reads, containing 125,431 ORFs spanning 78,271,365bp, 80% of which was derived from bacteria. The 12 most abundant bacterial orders were Spirochaetales, Lactobacillales, Bacteroidales, Clostridiales, Enterobacteriales, Pseudomonades, Synergistales, Desulfovibrionales, Xanthomonadales, Burkholderiales, Bacillales, and Actinomycetales, and 1460 species were estimated. Of more than 12,000 ORFs with predicted functions related to carbohydrate metabolism, 587 encoding hydrolytic enzymes for cellulose, hemicellulose, and pectin were identified. Among them, 316 ORFs were related to cellulose degradation, and included β-glucosidases, 6-phospho-β-glucosidases, licheninases, glucan endo-1,3-β-. d-glucosidases, endoglucanases, cellulose 1,4-β-cellobiosidases, glucan 1,3-β-glucosidases, and cellobiose phosphorylases. In addition, 259 ORFs were related to hemicellulose degradation, encoding endo-1,4-β-xylanases, α-galactosidases, α-. N-arabinofuranosidases, xylan 1,4-β-xylosidases, arabinan endo-1,5-α-. l-arabinosidases, endo-1,4-β-mannanases, and α-glucuronidases. Twelve ORFs encoding pectinesterases and pectate lyases were also obtained. To our knowledge, this is the first successful application of Illumina-based de novo sequencing for the analysis of a free-living bacterial community in the gut of a lower termite C.gestroi and for mining genes related to lignocellulose degradation from the gut bacteria. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: P.D., Luu, Phuongduc Duc; H.T., Truong, Hoa Thi; L., van Boi, Luu; P.N., Lan, Pham Ngoc; K., Imamura, Kiyoshi; N., Takenaka, Norimichi; Y., Maeda, Yasuaki
Author full names: Luu, Phuongduc Duc (56385435700); Truong, Hoa Thi (56385221700); van Boi, Luu (6507028401); Lan, Pham Ngoc (56385210900); Imamura, Kiyoshi (57202410922); Takenaka, Norimichi (7007012272); Maeda, Yasuaki (55797766600)
Title: Production of biodiesel from Vietnamese Jatropha curcas oil by a co-solvent method
Affiliations: Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Luu, Phuongduc Duc, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Truong, Hoa Thi, Danang Environmental Technology Center, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; van Boi, Luu, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Lan, Pham Ngoc, Faculty of Chemistry, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Imamura, Kiyoshi, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Takenaka, Norimichi, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Maeda, Yasuaki, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: Biodiesel fuels (BDFs) was successfully produced from Vietnamese Jatropha curcas oil with high content of free fatty acids (FFAs) in two stages. In the first stage, the esterification process was carried out with the optimal conditions as follows; a methanol-to-FFAs molar ratio of 6:1, 1wt% H<inf>2</inf>SO<inf>4</inf>, at a temperature of 65°C, and using 30% (wt/wt) acetonitrile as co-solvent. This step reduced the concentration of FFAs in the reaction mixture from 15.93 to 2wt% in 60min. In the second stage, the transesterification process generated fatty acid methyl esters (FAMEs) with 99% efficiency was performed in 30min with the optimal conditions as follows; a methanol-to-oil molar ratio of 6:1, 1wt% KOH, at a temperature of 40°C, and 20% (wt/wt) acetone as co-solvent. The produced biodiesel quality meets the standards JIS K2390 and EN 14214 regarding FAME yield, FFAs and water contents. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N., Viet Long, Nguyen; Y., Yang, Yong; C., Minh Thi, Cao; Y., Cao, Yanqin; M., Nogami, Massayuki
Author full names: Viet Long, Nguyen (35334870500); Yang, Yong (56406088300); Minh Thi, Cao (55636532000); Cao, Yanqin (55840210800); Nogami, Massayuki (57202849551)
Title: Ultra-high stability and durability of iron oxide micro- and nano-structures with discovery of new three-dimensional structural formation of grain and boundary
Source title: Colloids and Surfaces A: Physicochemical and Engineering Aspects
Affiliations: Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai, China; Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Toyota Physical and Chemical Research Institute, Nagakute, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Viet Long, Nguyen, State Key Laboratory of High Performance Ceramics and Superfine Microstructure, Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai, China, Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Laboratory for Nanotechnology, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Yang, Yong, State Key Laboratory of High Performance Ceramics and Superfine Microstructure, Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai, China; Minh Thi, Cao, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Cao, Yanqin, State Key Laboratory of High Performance Ceramics and Superfine Microstructure, Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai, China; Nogami, Massayuki, Toyota Physical and Chemical Research Institute, Nagakute, Japan
Abstract: In this research, we have applied a facile polyol method with the addition of NaBH<inf>4</inf> to synthesize polyhedral α-Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> oxide microparticles with the large size of 1-10μm at 200-230°C for about 25-30min. The sharp polyhedral shapes and morphologies have been formed in the good assistance of NaBH<inf>4</inf> as versatile strong reducing agent. The sharp polyhedral and large Fe oxide microparticles exhibited a uniform characterization of size, shape and morphology with the pure α-Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> structure. To study durability and stability of the microparticles under temperature, we have rationally carried out isothermal heat treatment of the prepared α-Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> oxide microparticles at high annealing temperature about 500°C and 900-910°C for 1h. A new structure was found in the pure α-Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> particles with micro- and nano-structure co-existed with the very good formation of a three-dimensional (3D) structure with the oxide grains and the boundaries. The interesting phenomena of the deformation of surface, size, shape, and structure are discovered in α-Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> oxide microparticles by isothermal heat treatment. Apart from surface deformation, the new micro- and nano-structure of large α-Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> microparticles cannot be destroyed but they can be retained in their specific characteristics of size, shape, and morphology because of both plastic and elastic deformation co-existed. The interesting surface deformation by heat treatment is observed in comparison with the case without heat treatment. The typical magnetic properties of α-Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> microparticles were investigated in the appearance of grain and boundary. Finally, our proposal of the new technologies with particle heat treatment is very crucial to make novel micro- and nano-structures of ultra-high durability and stability with the grains and the boundaries that can be utilized in catalysis, energy and environment for future. © 2014 Elsevier B.V. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Suzuki, Hiroyuki; T., Kido, Teruhiko; R., Okamoto, Rie; D.D., Nhu, Dang Duc; M., Nishijo, Muneko; H., Nakagawa, Hideaki; K., Tawara, Kenji; H., Horikawa, Hiroaki; Y., Sato, Yuko; P.T., Dung, Phung Tri

Title: The relationship between dioxin congeners in the breast milk of vietnamese women and sister chromatid exchange
Affiliations: Toyota West Hospital, Toyota, Japan; Kanazawa University, Kanazawa, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kanazawa Medical University, Kahoku, Japan; Hyogo Environmental Advancement Association, Kobe, Japan; National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; Griffith University, Brisbane, Australia; Hanoi Medical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Suzuki, Hiroyuki, Department of Nursing, Toyota West Hospital, Toyota, Japan, Institute of Medical, Pharmaceutical and Health Sciences, Kanazawa University, Kanazawa, Japan; Kido, Teruhiko, Institute of Medical, Pharmaceutical and Health Sciences, Kanazawa University, Kanazawa, Japan; Okamoto, Rie, Institute of Medical, Pharmaceutical and Health Sciences, Kanazawa University, Kanazawa, Japan; Nhu, Dang Duc, School of Medicine and Pharmacy, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nishijo, Muneko, Department of Epidemiology and Public Health, Kanazawa Medical University, Kahoku, Japan; Nakagawa, Hideaki, Department of Epidemiology and Public Health, Kanazawa Medical University, Kahoku, Japan; Tawara, Kenji, Hyogo Environmental Advancement Association, Kobe, Japan; Horikawa, Hiroaki, Department of Pathology, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; Sato, Yuko, Department of Pathology, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; Dung, Phung Tri, Griffith School of Environment, Griffith University, Brisbane, Australia
Abstract: The aim of this study was to clarify the relationship between dioxin concentrations in breast milk and the sister chromatid exchange (SCE) frequency in women from herbicide-sprayed and non sprayed areas. Blood samples were taken from 21 women with high TCDD (tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin) levels from sprayed areas, 23 women with moderate TCDD levels from sprayed areas, and 19 women from non sprayed areas to determine their SCE frequency. The SCE frequencies for the high and moderate TCDD groups from the sprayed area and for the non sprayed area group were 2.40, 2.19, and 1.48 per cell, respectively. Multiple regression analysis showed that the standardized β values for 1,2,3,6,7,8-hexaCDD (β = 0.60), 1,2,3,4,6,7,8-heptaCDD (β = 0.64), and octaCDD (β = 0.65) were higher than those for TCDD (β = 0.34) and 1,2,3,7,8-pentaCDD (β = 0.42). The adjusted R2 value for polyCDDs (R2 = 0.38) was higher than that for polyCDD toxic equivalents (TEQ (toxic equivalents); R2 = 0.23). This study therefore shows that levels of hexa-, hepta-, and octaCDD, which were previously regarded as being less toxic than TCDD, are closely related to SCE frequency and that the level of dioxin (pg/g lipid) is potentially more useful as an indicator than TEQ value for explaining SCE frequency. © 2014 by the authors; licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland. © 2015 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N., Viet Long, Nguyen; Y., Yang, Yong; M., Yuasa, Masayoshi; C.M., Thi, Cao Minh; Y., Cao, Yanqin; T., Nann, Thomas; M., Nogami, Massayuki
Author full names: Viet Long, Nguyen (35334870500); Yang, Yong (56406088300); Yuasa, Masayoshi (16508383800); Thi, Cao Minh (55315987000); Cao, Yanqin (55840210800); Nann, Thomas (55925608200); Nogami, Massayuki (57202849551)
Title: Gas-sensing properties of p-type α-Fe2O3 polyhedral particles synthesized via a modified polyol method
Affiliations: Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai, China; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Nagoya Institute of Technology, Nagoya, Japan; Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; University of South Australia, Adelaide, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Viet Long, Nguyen, State Key Laboratory of High Performance Ceramics and Superfine Microstructure, Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai, China, Department of Materials Science, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan, Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Laboratory for Nanotechnology, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Yang, Yong, Department of Materials Science, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Yuasa, Masayoshi, Department of Materials Science, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Thi, Cao Minh, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Cao, Yanqin, Department of Materials Science, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Nann, Thomas, University of South Australia, Adelaide, Australia; Nogami, Massayuki, Department of Materials Science, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Nagoya Institute of Technology, Nagoya, Japan
Abstract: The gas sensing properties of polyhedral α-Fe<inf>2</inf>O <inf>3</inf> particles were investigated. The polyhedral α-Fe <inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> particles were synthesized via a modified polyol method with the addition of an extra amount of NaBH<inf>4</inf> in ethylene glycol, and fabricated to a thick gas sensing film after calcination at 500°C and 900°C. The polyhedral α-Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> particles exhibited a p-type nature, which is a new result opposite to other results of recent reports of semiconductor gas sensors using α-Fe <inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>. In particular, we suggest that the difference between structure and morphology of α-Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> particles can lead to p-type and n-type characterization. In addition, we suggested that Na ions from NaBH<inf>4</inf> were incorporated into α-Fe<inf>2</inf>O <inf>3</inf> oxide. They are the cause of the generation of holes in α-Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> oxide that led to the p-type nature of α-Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> oxide. The measurement of the sensor response to hydrogen, carbon monoxide, toluene, propane and ethanol revealed that the sensor device synthesized using polyhedral α-Fe<inf>2</inf>O <inf>3</inf> particles is sensitive to hydrocarbons and ethanol. Importantly, the sensor device using polyhedral α-Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> particles calcined at 900°C was strongly sensitive to ethanol due to the porous structure of the α-Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> particles. © 2014 The Royal Society of Chemistry. © 2014 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Development and Characterization of Laccol Lacquer Blended with Urushiol Lacquer
Source title: International Journal of Polymer Analysis and Characterization
Affiliations: Meiji University, Tokyo, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Anzai, Kenichiro, Department of Applied Chemistry, Meiji University, Tokyo, Japan; Lu, Rong, Department of Applied Chemistry, Meiji University, Tokyo, Japan; Phuc, Bach Trong, Research Center for Polymer Materials, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Miyakoshi, Tetsuo, Department of Applied Chemistry, Meiji University, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: A lacquer blending urushiol and laccol was investigated. The blended lacquer with 30wt.% urushiol and 100wt.% laccol has a good drying property and film hardness. 2-D-NMR and FD-MS measurements of the lacquer dimer showed that a transfer of radicals between urushiol and laccol occurred during the enzymatic polymerization, and 4-4′ biphenyl, 4-6′ (4′-6), and 6-6 (6-6′) dibenzofuran structures were obtained. © 2014 Copyright Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. © 2014 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Controlled synthesis and characterization of iron oxide nanostructures with potential applications for gas sensors and the environment
Affiliations: Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai, China; Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; University of South Australia, Adelaide, Australia; Nagoya Institute of Technology, Nagoya, Japan

Abstract: In the present research, large iron oxide microparticles with large sizes in the range of 1-5 μm have been facilely synthesized by a modified polyol method with NaBH<inf>4</inf> as a versatile strong reducing agent. We found that the highly homogeneous iron oxide microparticles' novel structure is the best pure crystal phase of α-Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> in terms of polyhedral morphology and shape in existence. There are no diffraction peaks of other crystal phases from impurities in α-Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> microparticle products in the crystal growth. Interestingly, a new method of heat treatment or atomic surface deformation allowed for the discovery of a new large α-Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> structure with controlled specific α-Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> oxide grains in the crystal structure. The severe surface deformation of sharp, polyhedral, large α-Fe <inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> microparticles under a sintering treatment was found to give un-sharp, polyhedral large α-Fe<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> microparticles with specific grains and boundaries. © 2014 The Royal Society of Chemistry. © 2014 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.A., Nguyen, Tuan Anh; S., Yoshikawa, Shiro; S.A., Ookawara, Shinichi A.
Author full names: Nguyen, Tuan Anh (59723969400); Yoshikawa, Shiro (56924544100); Ookawara, Shinichi A. (7005004002)
Title: Steady State Permeate Flux Estimation in Cross-Flow Ultrafiltration of Protein Solution
Affiliations: Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Egypt-Japan University of Science and Technology, New Borg El Arab, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Tuan Anh, Department of Chemical Engineering, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Yoshikawa, Shiro, Department of Chemical Engineering, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Ookawara, Shinichi A., Department of Chemical Engineering, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan, Department of Energy Resources and Environmental Engineering, Egypt-Japan University of Science and Technology, New Borg El Arab, Egypt
Abstract: In the membrane separation process, the cross-flow configuration in which the fluid flows parallel to the membrane is widely utilized. Due to the shear stress exerted by the tangential feed flow, the accumulation of the retained species in the membrane is reduced, and the nearly steady state operation can be attained. The determination of steady state permeate flux is significant in the design and optimization problem. Several mechanisms of transport phenomena have been proposed to estimate the steady state permeate flux such as concentration polarization and Brownian diffusion, shear-induced diffusion, inertial lift, and surface transport. Another approach is using dimensional analysis to give the correlation equation with the operating condition instead of a deep focus on mechanism. In this study, we apply the model proposed in our previous study to predict the steady state permeate flux from the experimental data. After that, a new method using dimensional analysis is also developed to predict the steady state permeate flux from the operating conditions such as the trans-membrane pressure, the feed flow rate, and the feed volume fraction in a wide range. The correlation equation provides a good estimation of the experimental results. © Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. © 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: L., Khuong, Leduy; R., Kondo, Ryuichiro; R.D., Leon, Rizalinda De; K.A., To, Kim Anh; S., Meguro, Sadatoshi; K., Shimizu, Kuniyoshi; I., Kamei, Ichiro
Author full names: Khuong, Leduy (59845964000); Kondo, Ryuichiro (7102405123); Leon, Rizalinda De (56223731300); To, Kim Anh (57206415596); Meguro, Sadatoshi (7004958749); Shimizu, Kuniyoshi (7404960600); Kamei, Ichiro (55083269100)
Title: Effect of chemical factors on integrated fungal fermentation of sugarcane bagasse for ethanol production by a white-rot fungus, Phlebia sp. MG-60
Affiliations: University of the Philippines Diliman, Quezon City, Philippines; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; University of Miyazaki, Miyazaki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Khuong, Leduy, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of the Philippines Diliman, Quezon City, Philippines, Center for Research and Development in Biotechnology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kondo, Ryuichiro, Department of Agro-environmental Sciences, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Leon, Rizalinda De, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of the Philippines Diliman, Quezon City, Philippines; To, Kim Anh, Center for Research and Development in Biotechnology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Meguro, Sadatoshi, Department of Forest and Environmental Sciences, University of Miyazaki, Miyazaki, Japan; Shimizu, Kuniyoshi, Department of Agro-environmental Sciences, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Kamei, Ichiro, Department of Forest and Environmental Sciences, University of Miyazaki, Miyazaki, Japan
Abstract: Bioethanol production through integrated fungal fermentation (IFF), involving a unified process for biological delignification with consolidated biological processing by the white-rot fungus Phlebia sp. MG-60, was applied to sugarcane bagasse. Initial moisture content of the bagasse was found to affect biological delignification by MG-60, and 75% moisture content was suitable for selective lignin degradation and subsequent ethanol production. Additives, such as basal media, organic compounds, or minerals, also affected biological delignification of bagasse by MG-60. Basal medium addition improved both delignification and ethanol production. Some inorganic chemical factors, such as Fe2+, Mn2+, or Cu2+, reduced bagasse carbohydrate degradation by MG-60 during delignifying incubations and resulted in increased ethanol production. The present results indicated that suitable culture conditions could significantly improve IFF efficiency. © 2014 Elsevier Ltd. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: P.T.N., Nguyen, Phuong T.N.; C., Salim, Chris; W., Kurniawan, Winarto; H., Hinode, Hirofumi
Author full names: Nguyen, Phuong T.N. (57198903928); Salim, Chris (23569596300); Kurniawan, Winarto (12752420700); Hinode, Hirofumi (6603680612)
Title: A non-hydrolytic sol-gel synthesis of reduced graphene oxide/TiO 2 microsphere photocatalysts
Affiliations: Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Phuong T.N., Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan, Inorganic Chemical Engineering Department, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Salim, Chris, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Kurniawan, Winarto, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Hinode, Hirofumi, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Reduced graphene oxide/TiO<inf>2</inf> microspheres were produced by a non-hydrolytic sol-gel reaction of tetrabutyl orthotitanate and acetone followed by hydrothermal treatment. In the hydrothermal treatment, ammonia was used as a medium solution, and reaction temperature was varied from 120 to 180 °C to investigate the effect on crystal phase and morphology of the prepared samples. Prior to the hydrothermal treatment, graphene oxide was introduced into the medium solution as an impurity material. Graphene oxide was characterized using AFM to confirm the formation of single-layer graphene sheet and its image. Prepared catalysts were characterized by XRD, SEM, N<inf>2</inf> adsorption (BET), Raman spectroscopy, FTIR and UV-visible diffuse reflectance spectra. Ammonia as a medium in hydrothermal reaction promoted the formation of nanoflakes and nanorods on the microspheres. Hydrothermal reaction temperature was found to have a significant effect on the morphology and crystal phase of the catalyst. Lower hydrothermal treatment temperature produced amorphous samples with higher surface area that increased methylene blue adsorption capacity significantly. Higher hydrothermal treatment temperature, on the other hand, produced anatase crystal phase TiO<inf>2</inf> with lower surface area. Prepared samples at higher treatment temperature showed comparable photocatalytic activity to commercial P25 TiO<inf>2</inf> on the photocatalytic degradation of methylene blue under UV-visible light irradiation. The photocatalytic activity of prepared RGO/TiO<inf>2</inf> microspheres photocatalysts were further tested using orange II. The preparation method proposed in this study could produce reduced graphene oxide/TiO<inf>2</inf> photocatalyst that is promising for use in organic pollutants treatment in water in terms of high photocatalytic activity and easy recovery owing to microsized photocatalyst. © 2013 Elsevier B.V. © 2014 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H.T., Thi Thu, Hien Tran; T., Shirai, Takashi; M., Fuji, Masayoshi
Author full names: Thi Thu, Hien Tran (55976261800); Shirai, Takashi (7401554436); Fuji, Masayoshi (56231681000)
Title: An advanced fabrication route for alkali silicate glass by non-firing process
Affiliations: Nagoya Institute of Technology, Nagoya, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Thi Thu, Hien Tran, Ceramics Research Laboratory, Nagoya Institute of Technology, Nagoya, Japan, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Shirai, Takashi, Ceramics Research Laboratory, Nagoya Institute of Technology, Nagoya, Japan; Fuji, Masayoshi, Ceramics Research Laboratory, Nagoya Institute of Technology, Nagoya, Japan
Abstract: An amorphous silica powder surface was treated separately and combining mechanical and chemical treatment processes. The raw silica powder was mechanically modified using a planetary type mill at a rotation speed of 200 rpm for 15 min using a 5 mm size ball. The raw and the mechanically modified silica powders were hydrothermally treated for 5, 15 and 24 h lengths of time. Silanol surface groups successfully produced by the treatments were measured by diffuse reflectance infrared fourier transform (DRIFT) spectroscopy. The results show that the combination of mechanical and chemical, so call mechanochemical treatment, is the most efficient in enhancing the quantity of surface silanol groups. The mechanochemically treated powder was used for the fabrication of glass. Silica glasses were successfully fabricated without firing by mixing the treated powders with KOH 5 M solutions. Morphology and transparency of the obtained glasses were analyzed using SEM and UV-VIS-NIR techniques. Possible mechanism reactions of powder surface activation occurring during the mechanochemical and condensation processes are also discussed. © 2013 The Society of Powder Technology Japan.
