Authors: L., Thanh, Letu; K., Okitsu, Kenji; Y., Sadanaga, Yasuhiro; N., Takenaka, Norimichi; Y., Maeda, Yasuaki; H., Bandow, Hiroshi
Author full names: Thanh, Letu (7004530789); Okitsu, Kenji (56894735200); Sadanaga, Yasuhiro (6603718076); Takenaka, Norimichi (7007012272); Maeda, Yasuaki (55797766600); Bandow, Hiroshi (7004563774)
Title: A two-step continuous ultrasound assisted production of biodiesel fuel from waste cooking oils: A practical and economical approach to produce high quality biodiesel fuel
Affiliations: Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Thanh, Letu, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan, Faculty of Environmental Science, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Okitsu, Kenji, Department of Materials Science, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Sadanaga, Yasuhiro, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Takenaka, Norimichi, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Maeda, Yasuaki, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Bandow, Hiroshi, Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: A transesterification reaction of waste cooking oils (WCO) with methanol in the presence of a potassium hydroxide catalyst was performed in a continuous ultrasonic reactor of low-frequency 20 kHz with input capacity of 1 kW, in a two-step process. For the first step, the transesterification was carried out with the molar ratio of methanol to WCO of 2.5:1, and the amount of catalyst 0.7 wt.%. The yield of fatty acid methyl esters (FAME) was about 81%. A yield of FAME of around 99% was attained in the second step with the molar ratio of methanol to initial WCO of 1.5:1, and the amount of catalyst 0.3 wt.%. The FAME yield was extremely high even at the short residence time of the reactants in the ultrasonic reactor (less than 1 min for the two steps) at ambient temperature, and the total amount of time required to produce biodiesel was 15 h. The quality of the final biodiesel product meets the standards JIS K2390 and EN 14214 for biodiesel fuel. © 2010 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.; MEDLINE® is the source for the MeSH terms of this document.

Authors: T.D., Bui, Thuan Duc; A., Kimura, Akira; S., Ikeda, Shigeru; M., Matsumura, Michio
Author full names: Bui, Thuan Duc (56536030500); Kimura, Akira (55167304000); Ikeda, Shigeru (7404042302); Matsumura, Michio (7402157910)
Title: Determination of oxygen sources for oxidation of benzene on TiO2 photocatalysts in aqueous solutions containing molecular oxygen
Source title: Journal of the American Chemical Society
Affiliations: The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Bui, Thuan Duc, Research Center for Solar Energy Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, Institute of Materials Science, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kimura, Akira, Research Center for Solar Energy Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Ikeda, Shigeru, Research Center for Solar Energy Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Matsumura, Michio, Research Center for Solar Energy Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Abstract: Photocatalytic oxidation of benzene to CO<inf>2</inf> was studied in aqueous solutions using different kinds of TiO<inf>2</inf> powders, and isotopic oxygen tracers (H<inf>2</inf>18O and 18O<inf>2</inf>) were used to investigate the oxidation process. Phenol was produced as a main intermediate in solution. When anatase powders, which showed high activity for oxidation of benzene, were used, 70-90% of oxygen introduced into phenol was from water. On the other hand, when rutile powders were used, only 20-40% of the oxygen was from water. The rest was from molecular oxygen in both cases. The rate of phenol production by using molecular oxygen was nearly the same between anatase and rutile powders. Hence, the high activity of anatase powders for oxidation of benzene to CO<inf>2</inf> is attributed to their high activity for oxidation of benzene to phenol, which is considered to be the rate-determining step, using water as the oxygen source. The processes using water and molecular oxygen as the oxygen sources are ascribed, respectively, to oxygen transfer and hole transfer processes in the initial step of benzene oxidation. © 2010 American Chemical Society. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: L.Q., Nguyen, Long Q.; C., Salim, Chris; H., Hinode, Hirofumi
Author full names: Nguyen, Long Q. (59875877900); Salim, Chris (23569596300); Hinode, Hirofumi (6603680612)
Title: Roles of nano-sized Au in the reduction of NOx by propene over Au/TiO2: An in situ DRIFTS study
Affiliations: Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Long Q., Department of International Development Engineering, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan, Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Salim, Chris, Department of International Development Engineering, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Hinode, Hirofumi, Department of International Development Engineering, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: A mechanistic study of the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO<inf>x</inf> by C<inf>3</inf>H<inf>6</inf> has been investigated over nano-sized Au/TiO<inf>2</inf> catalyst using in situ diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS). The formation and consumption of adsorbed species on the catalyst surface have been intensively studied during co-adsorption of reactants and reaction condition. The presence of nano-sized Au particles played an important role in the formation of oxygenated hydrocarbons, especially acetate species. Importantly, Au active sites were crucial to the formation of isocyanate intermediate compounds and contributed to the conversion of these intermediates to N<inf>2</inf>. The reaction mechanism of SCR over Au/TiO<inf>2</inf> has been discussed on the basis of DRIFTS results. © 2010 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: V.H., Thang, Vu Hong; K., Kanda, Kohzo; G., Kobayashi, Genta
Author full names: Thang, Vu Hong (6507681166); Kanda, Kohzo (7202792998); Kobayashi, Genta (58100647500)
Title: Production of Acetone-Butanol-Ethanol (ABE) in direct fermentation of cassava by Clostridium saccharoperbutylacetonicum N1-4
Affiliations: Faculty of Agriculture, Saga, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Thang, Vu Hong, Department of Applied Biological Sciences, Faculty of Agriculture, Saga, Japan, Department of Fermentation Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kanda, Kohzo, Department of Applied Biological Sciences, Faculty of Agriculture, Saga, Japan; Kobayashi, Genta, Department of Applied Biological Sciences, Faculty of Agriculture, Saga, Japan
Abstract: In this work, acetone-butanol-ethanol (ABE) fermentation characteristics of cassava starch and cassava chips when using Clostridium saccharoperbutylacetonicum N1- 4 was presented. The obtained results in batch mode using a 1-L fermenter showed that C. saccharoperbutylacetonicum N1-4 was a hyperamylolytic strain and capable of producing solvents efficiently from cassava starch and cassava chips, which was comparable to when glucose was used. Batch fermentation of cassava starch and cassava chips resulted in 21.0 and 19.4 g/L of total solvent as compared with 24.2 g/L of total solvent when using glucose. Solvent productivity in fermentation of cassava starch was from 42% to 63% higher than that obtained in fermentation using corn and sago starches in the same condition. In fermentation of cassava starch and cassava chips, maximum butanol concentration was 16.9 and 15.5 g/L, respectively. Solvent yield and butanol yield (based on potential glucose) was 0.33 and 0.41, respectively, for fermentation of cassava starch and 0.30 and 0.38, respectively for fermentation using cassava chips. © Humana Press 2009. © 2012 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N., Viet Long, Nguyen; N., Chien, Nguyenduc; T., Hayakawa, Tomokatsu; H., Hirata, Hirohito; G., Lakshminarayana, Gandham; M., Nogami, Massayuki
Author full names: Viet Long, Nguyen (35334870500); Chien, Nguyenduc (12790723100); Hayakawa, Tomokatsu (7402974710); Hirata, Hirohito (8894536400); Lakshminarayana, Gandham (57194637883); Nogami, Massayuki (57202849551)
Title: The synthesis and characterization of platinum nanoparticles: A method of controlling the size and morphology
Affiliations: Nagoya Institute of Technology, Nagoya, Japan; Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Toyota Motor Corporation, Toyota, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Viet Long, Nguyen, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Nagoya Institute of Technology, Nagoya, Japan, Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Chien, Nguyenduc, Institute of Engineering Physics, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hayakawa, Tomokatsu, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Nagoya Institute of Technology, Nagoya, Japan; Hirata, Hirohito, Advanced Material Engineering Division, Toyota Motor Corporation, Toyota, Japan; Lakshminarayana, Gandham, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Nagoya Institute of Technology, Nagoya, Japan; Nogami, Massayuki, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Nagoya Institute of Technology, Nagoya, Japan
Abstract: In this paper, Pt nanoparticles with good shapes of nanocubes and nano-octahedra and well-controlled sizes in the range 5-7 and 8-12nm, respectively, have been successfully synthesized. The modified polyol method by adding silver nitrate and varying the molar ratio of the solutions of silver nitrate and H<inf>2</inf>PtCl<inf>6</inf> has been used to produce Pt nanoparticles of the size and shape to be controlled. The size and morphology of Pt nanoparticles have been studied by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high resolution TEM (HRTEM). The results have shown that their very sharp and good shapes exist in the main forms of cubic, cuboctahedral, octahedral and tetrahedral shapes directly related to the crystal nucleation along various directions of the {100} cubic, {111} octahedral and {111} tetrahedral facets during synthesis. In particular, various irregular and new shapes of Pt nanoparticles have been found. Here, it is concluded that the role of silver ions has to be considered as an important factor for promoting and controlling the development of Pt nanoparticles of {100} cubic, {111} octahedral and {111} tetrahedral facets, and also directly orienting the growth and formation of Pt nanoparticles. © IOP Publishing Ltd. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.D., Bui, Thuan Duc; A., Kimura, Akira; S., Ikeda, Shigeru; M., Matsumura, Michio
Author full names: Bui, Thuan Duc (56536030500); Kimura, Akira (55167304000); Ikeda, Shigeru (7404042302); Matsumura, Michio (7402157910)
Title: Lowering of photocatalytic activity of TiO2 particles during oxidative decomposition of benzene in aerated liquid
Affiliations: The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Bui, Thuan Duc, Research Center for Solar Energy Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, Institute of Materials Science, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kimura, Akira, Research Center for Solar Energy Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Ikeda, Shigeru, Research Center for Solar Energy Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Matsumura, Michio, Research Center for Solar Energy Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Abstract: TiO<inf>2</inf>-photocatalyzed reaction was conducted in pure benzene in which TiO<inf>2</inf> particles were suspended. Benzene was oxidatively decomposed into CO<inf>2</inf>, as most of organic compounds. However, the rate of CO<inf>2</inf> evolution from benzene was gradually lowered as the reaction continued, which was in contrast to the cases of other non-aromatic organic compounds, such as alcohols or acids. To clarify the reason for the decrease in activity of TiO<inf>2</inf>, intermediates produced in the solution phase and on the surface of TiO<inf>2</inf> were analyzed using chemical and physical techniques. Several kinds of intermediates were identified: phenolic compounds, aldehydes, carboxylic acids, and polymeric substance. Of these products, catechol and polymeric substance, which were observed only on the surface of TiO<inf>2</inf> powder, were found to be responsible for the lowering of the photocatalytic activity of TiO<inf>2</inf>. © 2009 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N.T.T., Kieu, Nguyen Thi Thanh; K., Ohdaira, Keisuke; T., Shimoda, Tatsuya; H., Hideki Matsumura, Hideki
Author full names: Kieu, Nguyen Thi Thanh (36514739200); Ohdaira, Keisuke (22958001800); Shimoda, Tatsuya (7102175250); Hideki Matsumura, Hideki (55218346400)
Title: Novel technique for formation of metal lines by functional liquid containing metal nanoparticles and reduction of their resistivity by hydrogen treatment
Source title: Journal of Vacuum Science and Technology B
Affiliations: Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kieu, Nguyen Thi Thanh, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan, ; Ohdaira, Keisuke, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Shimoda, Tatsuya, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Hideki Matsumura, Hideki, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan
Abstract: A novel technique for formation of metal lines for electronic devices, and for reduction of resistivity in such metal lines, is proposed. In the technique, the metal lines are formed in trenches by using functional liquids containing metal nanoparticles. The trenches are constructed on a plastic substrate by imprint of a patterned mold. When the whole surface of the plastic substrate is covered with a hydrophobic film, the hydrophobic property disappears only in the trenches due to the pressing process of the imprint, and thus the functional liquid automatically accumulates into the trenches. When the metallic functional liquid is modified with tween-20 (polyoxyethylene-20), metal lines with a width of 10 μm are formed by capillary effect. The resistivity of such metal lines can be lowered to the order of 10-6 ω cm by exposing them to hydrogen atoms generated in vacuum by catalytic cracking of hydrogen molecules with heated tungsten wires. © 2010 American Vacuum Society. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Vu, Hoang Anh (11838825900); Beppu, Yuuichi (24469774500); Chi, Hoangthanh (59786227300); Sasaki, Kousuke (36476642500); Yamamoto, Hideaki (55725333800); Xinh, Phan Thi (6507847078); Tanii, Takashi (7006919839); Hara, Yukihiko (7401853769); Watanabe, Toshiki (55586731900); Sato, Yuko (55509679200)
Title: Green tea epigalocatechin gallate exhibits anticancer effect in human pancreatic carcinoma cells via inhibition of both FAK and IGF-1R
Affiliations: Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan; National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; University of Medicine and Pharmacy at HCMC, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan; The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Hara Office Inc., Fujieda, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Vu, Hoang Anh, Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan, Department of Pathology, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan, University of Medicine and Pharmacy at HCMC, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Beppu, Yuuichi, Faculty of Science and Engineering, Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan; Chi, Hoangthanh, Department of Pathology, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan, Department of Medical Genome Sciences, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Sasaki, Kousuke, Faculty of Science and Engineering, Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan; Yamamoto, Hideaki, Faculty of Science and Engineering, Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan; Xinh, Phan Thi, Department of Pathology, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan, University of Medicine and Pharmacy at HCMC, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tanii, Takashi, Faculty of Science and Engineering, Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan; Hara, Yukihiko, Tea Solutions, Hara Office Inc., Fujieda, Japan; Watanabe, Toshiki, Department of Medical Genome Sciences, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Sato, Yuko, Department of Pathology, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Objectives: Green tea epigalocatechin galate (EGCG) has been shown to exhibit a growth-suppressive effect on human pancreatic cancer cells; however, the exact molecular mechanism by which EGCG suppresses cell proliferation is unclear. We hypothesize that interference with cell adhesion might be one mechanism. Methods: The effect of EGCG on cell adhesion and proliferation was examined using pancreatic cancer cells. Results: EGCG-treated pancreatic cancer cells AsPC-1 and BxPC-3 decrease cell adhesion ability on micro-pattern dots, accompanied by dephosphorylations of both focal adhesion kinase (FAK) and insulin-like growth factor 1 receptor (IGF-1R), whereas retained the activations of mitogen-activated protein kinase and mammalian target of rapamycin. The growth of AsPC-1 and BxPC-3 cells, when cultured at low density, can be significantly suppressed by EGCG treatment alone in a dose-dependent manner. At a dose of 100 μM that completely abolishes activations of FAK and IGF-1R, EGCG suppresses more than 50% of cell proliferation without evidence of apoptosis analyzed by PARP cleavage. Finally, the MEK1/2 inhibitor U0126 enhances growth-suppressive effect of EGCG. Conclusions: Blocking FAK and IGF-1R by EGCG could prove valuable for targeted therapy, which can use in combination with other therapies, for pancreatic cancer. © Springer-Verlag 2010. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Kashiwagi, Takehiro; N.T., Lan Phi, Nguyen Thi; M., Sawamura, Masayoshi
Author full names: Kashiwagi, Takehiro (7201759369); Lan Phi, Nguyen Thi (12792942400); Sawamura, Masayoshi (55888549400)
Title: Compositional changes in yuzu (Citrus junos) steam-distilled oil and effects of antioxidants on oil quality during storage
Affiliations: Japan Science and Technology Agency, Kawaguchi, Japan; Kochi University, Kochi, Japan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kochi University, Kochi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kashiwagi, Takehiro, Japan Science and Technology Agency, Kawaguchi, Japan, Faculty of Agriculture, Kochi University, Kochi, Japan; Lan Phi, Nguyen Thi, Japan Science and Technology Agency, Kawaguchi, Japan, Faculty of Agriculture, Kochi University, Kochi, Japan, Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Sawamura, Masayoshi, Faculty of Agriculture, Kochi University, Kochi, Japan, Tosa Food Business Creator Project Team, Kochi University, Kochi, Japan
Abstract: Changes in 44 compounds of yuzu (Citrus junos Sieb. ex Tanaka) steam-distilled peel oil (SDO) and possible artifacts that accrue during storage at 25°C were investigated after 1, 2, 3, 4, 8 and 12 weeks. Changes in SDO composition during storage took place more rapidly than in cold-pressed oil. Total monoterpene hydrocarbons decreased markedly, with major losses of limonene and γ-terpinene and notable increases in p-cymene, as well as alcohols. Bicyclogermacrene, the main sesquiterpene hydrocarbon of the fresh oil, practically disappeared. (-)-Spathulenol, the main artifact, was converted from bicyclogermacrene. Antioxidants such as α-tocopherol, β-carotene and 2,6-di-tert-butyl-4-hydroxytoluene (BHT) slowed the formation of oxidation products, such as p-cymene, (-)-spathulenol by inhibiting the formation of oxidative products. This suggests that the antioxidants can be used to maintain yuzu oil quality. © 2011 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Tuyen, Nguyen Viet (59662865800); Long, Nguyen Ngoc (11839801700); Hoa, Tran Thai (55005557700); Nghĩa, Nguyen Trọng (6603097887); Hieu Chi, Dam (7102227851); Higashimine, Koichi (6505844357); Mitani, Tadaoki (7101733388); Canh, Ta Dinh (35180944900)
Title: Indium-doped zinc oxide nanometre thick disks synthesised by a vapour-phase transport process
Affiliations: HUS, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hanoi University of Civil Engineering, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tuyen, Nguyen Viet, Faculty of Physics, HUS, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Long, Nguyen Ngoc, Faculty of Physics, HUS, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hoa, Tran Thai, Hanoi University of Civil Engineering, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nghĩa, Nguyen Trọng, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hieu Chi, Dam, Faculty of Physics, HUS, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Higashimine, Koichi, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Mitani, Tadaoki, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Canh, Ta Dinh, Faculty of Physics, HUS, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Indium-doped ZnO nanometre thick disks were successfully fabricated by thermal evaporation of a powder mixture of ZnO, In<inf>2</inf> O<inf>3</inf>, and graphite without catalyst. Incorporation of indium metal in the nanodisks during the synthesis was not successful due to the formation of In<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> phase. SEM images show that some ZnO disks have perfect hexagonal shape. These disks are about 1-5 μm in size and 40-100 nm in thickness. X-ray diffraction, Raman, transmission electron microscopy, and energy dispersive spectroscopy observations show that the disks are single crystalline ZnO with wurtzite structure. Effect of indium doping on the structure, morphology, optical absorption, and photoluminescence of the nanodisks are studied. © 2009 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: V.Q., Thang, Vu Quoc; T., Taniike, Toshiaki; M., Umemori, Masaki; M., Ikeya, Mitsuhiro; Y., Hiraoka, Yuichi; D.N., Nguyen, Duc Nghia; M., Terano, Minoru
Author full names: Thang, Vu Quoc (36454256500); Taniike, Toshiaki (22136881100); Umemori, Masaki (36454258400); Ikeya, Mitsuhiro (36453847800); Hiraoka, Yuichi (24484523100); Nguyen, Duc Nghia (57198994811); Terano, Minoru (7007051695)
Title: New quenching procedure for preservation of initial polymer/catalyst particle morphology in Ziegler-Natta olefin polymerization
Affiliations: Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Chemistry, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Thang, Vu Quoc, School of Materials Science, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Taniike, Toshiaki, School of Materials Science, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Umemori, Masaki, School of Materials Science, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Ikeya, Mitsuhiro, School of Materials Science, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Hiraoka, Yuichi, School of Materials Science, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Nguyen, Duc Nghia, Institute of Chemistry, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Chemistry, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Terano, Minoru, School of Materials Science, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan
Abstract: Preservation of initial polymer/catalyst particle morphology under air, was examined using stopped-flow Ziegler-Natta polymerization with various quenching conditions and postchemical treatments. The exposure of the initial particles to air caused the fast formation of cracks on the surface, finally leading to significant reformation of the particle shape, when polymerizing particles were washed with heptane at -65 oC under N<inf>2</inf> or under CO<inf>2</inf>. On the other hand, when the particles were washed with heptane containing an appropriate amount of tetrahydrofuran under CO<inf>2</inf>, the particle morphology under air was almost completely maintained even after 1 h exposure. The present results are useful for various ex situ characterizations of unstable initial polymer/catalyst particles. © 2009 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: V.T., Huong, Vu Thi; T., Shimanouchi, Toshinori; D.P., Quan, Do Phuc; H., Umakoshi, Hiroshi; P.H., Viet, Pham Hung; R., Kuboi, Ryoichi
Author full names: Huong, Vu Thi (59795767100); Shimanouchi, Toshinori (6701691675); Quan, Do Phuc (35307931100); Umakoshi, Hiroshi (6701925853); Viet, Pham Hung (6603329033); Kuboi, Ryoichi (35581341700)
Title: Polymethylthiophene/Nafion-modified glassy carbon electrode for selective detection of dopamine in the presence of ascorbic acid
Affiliations: The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Huong, Vu Thi, Department of Chemical Science and Engineering, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Shimanouchi, Toshinori, Department of Chemical Science and Engineering, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Quan, Do Phuc, Centre for Environmental Technology and Sustainable Development (CETASD), Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Umakoshi, Hiroshi, Department of Chemical Science and Engineering, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Viet, Pham Hung, Centre for Environmental Technology and Sustainable Development (CETASD), Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kuboi, Ryoichi, Department of Chemical Science and Engineering, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Abstract: The possible use of an electrode modified with electroactive conductive poly(3-methylthiophene) (PMeT)/Nafion as a chemical sensor was investigated for the voltammetric analysis of Dopamine (DA). The electrochemical behavior of dopamine was examined by cyclic voltammetry (CV) and differential pulse voltammetry (DPV) techniques. By using a PMeT-modified glassy carbon (GC/PMeT) electrode, DA and Ascorbic Acid (AA) signals could be separated but the AA at high concentrations still caused significant interference by overlapping the DA peak. In comparison to the GC/PMeT electrode, the glassy carbon (GC/Nafion/PMeT) electrode modified with hybrid film Nafion/PMeT was found to permit a superior separation by shifting the oxidation of AA peak toward the less positive potential. The DPV curves for a mixture of DA and AA at an GC/Nafion/PMeT electrode in a 0.1 M H<inf>2</inf>SO<inf>4</inf> solution showed peaks of DA and AA, at 0.45 and 0.21 V, respectively, indicating that the difference in the oxidation potential was 240 mV. In the 0.1 M H<inf>2</inf>SO<inf>4</inf> solution, the oxidation peak current on the differential pulse voltammograms for the GC/PMeT electrode increased linearly with the concentration of DA in the range 1 × 10-6 to 1 × 10-3 M, and the oxidation peak current on the differential pulse voltammograms for the GC/Nafion/PMeT electrode in the range 5 × 10-7 to 2 × 10-4 M. The DA detection sensitivity of the GC/Nafion/PMeT electrode (26.7 μA μM-1 cm-2) was 22 times higher than that of the GC/PMeT electrode (1.21 μA μM-1 cm-2). © 2009 Springer Science+Business Media B.V. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N.N., Sang, Nguyen Nhu; S.O., Soda, Satoshi O.; D., Inoue, Daisuke; K., Sei, Kazunari; M., Ike, Michihiko
Author full names: Sang, Nguyen Nhu (25226181400); Soda, Satoshi O. (7003462459); Inoue, Daisuke (55723196300); Sei, Kazunari (6701370623); Ike, Michihiko (55551254800)
Title: Effects of intermittent and continuous aeration on accelerative stabilization and microbial population dynamics in landfill bioreactors
Affiliations: The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Sang, Nguyen Nhu, Graduate School of Engineering, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, Institute for Environment and Resources, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Soda, Satoshi O., Graduate School of Engineering, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Inoue, Daisuke, Graduate School of Engineering, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Sei, Kazunari, Graduate School of Engineering, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Ike, Michihiko, Graduate School of Engineering, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Abstract: Performance and microbial population dynamics in landfill bioreactors were investigated in laboratory experiments. Three reactors were operated without aeration (control reactor, CR), with cyclic 6-h aeration and 6-h non-aeration (intermittently aerated reactor, IAR), and with continuous aeration (continuously aerated reactor, CAR). Each reactor was loaded with high-organic solid waste. The performance of IAR was highest among the reactors up to day 90. The respective solid weight, organic matter content, and waste volume on day 90 in the CR, IAR, and CAR were 50.9, 39.1, and 47.5%; 46.5, 29.3 and 35.0%; and 69, 38, and 53% of the initial values. Organic carbon and nitrogen compounds in leachate in the IAR and the CAR showed significant decreases in comparison to those in the CR. The most probable number (MPN) values of fungal 18S rDNA in the CAR and the IAR were higher than those in the CR. Terminal restriction fragment length polymorphism analysis showed that unique and diverse eubacterial and archaeal communities were formed in the IAR. The intermittent aeration strategy was favorable for initiation of solubilization of organic matter by the aerobic fungal populations and the reduction of the acid formation phase. Then the anaerobic H<inf>2</inf>-producing bacteria Clostridium became dominant in the IAR. Sulfate-reducing bacteria, which cannot use acetate/sulfate but which instead use various organics/sulfate as the electron donor/acceptor were also dominant in the IAR. Consequently, Methanosarcinales, which are acetate-utilizing methanogens, became the dominant archaea in the IAR, where high methane production was observed. © 2009 The Society for Biotechnology, Japan. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.; MEDLINE® is the source for the MeSH terms of this document.

Authors: T., Thi, Tranhang; M., Matsusaki, Michiya; M., Akashi, Mitsuru
Author full names: Thi, Tranhang (15119329300); Matsusaki, Michiya (6701561701); Akashi, Mitsuru (35463476100)
Title: Development of photoreactive degradable branched polyesters with high thermal and mechanical properties
Affiliations: The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Ministry of Industry and Trade, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Thi, Tranhang, Department of Applied Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, Faculty of Technology of Organic Chemistry, Ministry of Industry and Trade, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Matsusaki, Michiya, Department of Applied Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Akashi, Mitsuru, Department of Applied Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Abstract: Branched polyesters composed of poly(L-lactide)s (PLLAs) and 3, 4-dihydroxycinnamic acid (DHCA) were obtained by the thermal melt-polycondensation of 3, 4-diacetoxycinnamic acid (DACA)-terminally conjugated PLLAs (DACA-PLLAs). The chemical structures of the DHCA/PLLA polyesters were confirmed by FT-IR and 1H NMR measurements. All of the polyesters showed high photoreactivities independent of LLA content. Furthermore, the polyesters had high solubility even after UV irradiation. Interestingly, the thermal stability and mechanical properties of PLLA were improved depending on the incorporation ratio of the DHCA moiety into the backbone. The hydrolysis speed of the DHCA/PLLA polyesters decreased upon increasing the composition of LLA, but the pure PLLA presented the highest hydrolysis speed. Furthermore, all of the polyesters showed faster hydrolysis after UV irradiation as compared to the uncross-linked samples. These novel branched DHCA/PLLA polyesters with high thermal stabilities, mechanical properties and photocontrollable degradability may be useful as functional degradable polyester for the environmental and biomedical fields. © 2009 American Chemical Society. © 2015 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.Q., Nguyen, Tuan Quoc; K., Goto, Kiyokazu
Author full names: Nguyen, Tuan Quoc (56293919800); Goto, Kiyokazu (7403195435)
Title: Effects of heat shock treatment on rice quality during storage (part 1) ? Changes in starch components and fat acidity
Source title: Engineering in Agriculture, Environment and Food
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Gifu University, Gifu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Tuan Quoc, Department of Food and Post-harvest Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Faculty of Applied Biological Sciences, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Goto, Kiyokazu, Faculty of Applied Biological Sciences, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan
Abstract: Harvested rice (cv. Koshihikari) was microwave-radiated up to 60, 70 and 80°C and kept heat-treated for 0, 1 and 3 min, dried and then stored at 40°C for 6 months. A pronounced change in chemical properties of control rice during storage was observed such as increase in fat acidity, soluble sugars, total amylose and insoluble amylose content, while a decrease was founded in total starch content, and soluble amylose content. The above changes also occurred in heat shock treated rice, but with certain extent of delay. The heat shock treatment (HST) delayed the increasing rate of fat acidity. The HSTs at 60 and 70°C were effective in keeping the values of total amylose and insoluble amylose content low. The results showed that HST would benefit rice quality maintenance during storage. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.Q., Nguyen, Tuan Quoc; K., Goto, Kiyokazu
Author full names: Nguyen, Tuan Quoc (56293919800); Goto, Kiyokazu (7403195435)
Title: Effects of heat shock treatment on rice quality during storage (Part 2) ? Nutritional and pasting properties changes
Source title: Engineering in Agriculture, Environment and Food
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Gifu University, Gifu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Tuan Quoc, Department of Food and Post-harvest Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Faculty of Applied Biological Sciences, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Goto, Kiyokazu, Faculty of Applied Biological Sciences, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan
Abstract: Heat shock treatments (HSTs) using microwave radiation were performed on harvested rice (cv. Koshihikari) up to 60, 70 and 80°C, and kept additionally for 0, 1 and 3 min, following drying and storage at 40°C for 6 months. For control rice, during storage there was a decrease in protein and starch digestibility, increase in setback viscosity (SV), final viscosity (FV) and pasting temperature (PT), while peak viscosity (PV) increased rapidly for the first 2 months then decreased. The HSTs at 70 and 80°C were effective in maintaining a high value of starch digestibility and low value of PV during storage, while the HSTs at 60°C retarded changes of PV and FV values. The results showed that HST would benefit quality maintenance of stored rice. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Heat Shock Treatment; Nutritional Properties; Paddy Rice; Pasting Properties; Rice Quality; Storage; Energy Storage; Starch; Viscosity; Heat Shock Treatment; Nutritional Properties; Paddy Rice; Pasting Property; Rice Qualities; Food Storage
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Starch; Viscosity; Heat shock treatment; Nutritional properties; Paddy rice; Pasting property; Rice qualities; Food storage
Funding Texts: The effects of HSTs, both in the present research and in previous research (Nguyen and Goto, 2009) have been summarized briefly in Table 2. Consequently, the influences of HST on quality of stored rice were complicated. HSTs were effective in retarding an increasing rate of fat acidity, reduced total amylose and insoluble amylose, improved starch digestibility, PV and FV properties of stored rice while they decreased protein digestibility and induced high soluble sugar content. Although HSTs could not improve all of the mentioned quality properties, the obtained benefits could contribute to rice quality maintenance during storage. Depending on maintenance purposes, the applied HST temperature and exposure time could be regulated. IV Conclusions In the present study, a range of nutritional and pasting properties of rice has been examined. For the control rice, the decrease of nutritional values was clarified during storage. In addition, the pronounced changes of pasting properties were also determined. The above changes affected rice quality significantly, requiring quality maintenance measures. In the present study, HST influenced the nutritional and pasting properties differently. HSTs at 70 and 80°C were effective in keeping high value of starch digestibility and low value of PV during storage, while HSTs at 60°C retarded changes in both PV and FV values. Low FV values were also found in 70 and 80°C HST rice after 6 months storage. The results in both the present research and previous research (Nguyen and Goto, 2009) show that HST could improve rice quality during storage. Consequently, the HST could be an alternative technique for quality management of rice during storage. Authors: C.X., Viet, Cao Xuan; H.H., Ismail, Hanafi H.; A.R., Azura, A. R.; T., Takeichi, Tsutomu; V.H., Thao, V. H.
Author full names: Viet, Cao Xuan (25823523100); Ismail, Hanafi H. (7102329732); Azura, A. R. (57211405393); Takeichi, Tsutomu (7005513741); Thao, V. H. (8338099800)
Title: Organoclay filled natural rubber nanocomposites: The effects of filler loading
Affiliations: School of Materials and Mineral Resources Engineering, Nibong Tebal, Malaysia; Toyohashi University of Technology, Toyohashi, Japan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Viet, Cao Xuan, School of Materials and Mineral Resources Engineering, Nibong Tebal, Malaysia; Ismail, Hanafi H., School of Materials and Mineral Resources Engineering, Nibong Tebal, Malaysia; Azura, A. R., School of Materials and Mineral Resources Engineering, Nibong Tebal, Malaysia; Takeichi, Tsutomu, School of Materials Science, Toyohashi University of Technology, Toyohashi, Japan; Thao, V. H., Department of Polymer Materials, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: Organoclay filled natural rubber (NR) nanocomposites were prepared using a laboratory two-roll mill. The effect of organoclay loading up to 10 phr was studied. The vulcanized nanocomposites were subjected to mechanical, thermal, and swelling tests. The results indicated that the tensile strength and elongation at break reached optimum at 4 phr of organoclay loading, and the incorporation of organoclay increased the tensile modulus and hardness of NR nanocomposites. The thermal degradation was shifted to a higher temperature and the weight loss decreased with incorporation of organoclay. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and X-ray diffraction (XRD) were employed to characterize the microstructure of NR nanocomposites. Results from TEM and XRD show the formation of intercalated and exfoliated individual silicate layers of organoclay filled NR nanocomposites particularly at low filler loading (<4 phr). © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: P.T., Nghia, Phan Trung; H., Onoe, Hirufumi; Y., Yamamoto, Yoshimasa; S., Kawahara, Seiichi
Author full names: Nghia, Phan Trung (15763233700); Onoe, Hirufumi (24281386300); Yamamoto, Yoshimasa (55255881100); Kawahara, Seiichi (7101824012)
Title: Hydrogenation of natural rubber having epoxy group
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nghia, Phan Trung, Faculty of Chemical Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Materials Science and Technology, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Onoe, Hirufumi, Department of Materials Science and Technology, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Yamamoto, Yoshimasa, Department of Materials Science and Technology, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Kawahara, Seiichi, Department of Materials Science and Technology, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan
Abstract: Hydrogenation of epoxidized natural rubber (ENR) was performed to introduce hydroxyl group to hydrogenated natural rubber. The ENR was prepared by epoxidation of deproteinized natural rubber (DPNR) with peracetic acid in latex stage. Hydrogenation of epoxidized DPNR (EDPNR) was performed with p-toluenesulfonylhydrazide in p-xylene. The resulting product, hydrogenated EDPNR (HEDPNR), was characterized by nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy with various pulse sequences, i.e., two-dimensional correlation spectroscopy, two-dimensional heteronuclear correlation measurements. Carbons linking up to hydroxyl group were assigned to be quaternary and tertiary groups. The HEDPNR was proved to be a polyolefine elastomer through differential scanning calorimetry. © Springer-Verlag 2008. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Thi, Tranhang; M., Matsusaki, Michiya; D., Shi, Dongjian; T.I., Kaneko, Tatsuo I.; M., Akashi, Mitsuru
Author full names: Thi, Tranhang (15119329300); Matsusaki, Michiya (6701561701); Shi, Dongjian (14834485400); Kaneko, Tatsuo I. (8540292100); Akashi, Mitsuru (35463476100)
Title: Synthesis and properties of coumaric acid derivative homo-polymers
Source title: Journal of Biomaterials Science, Polymer Edition
Affiliations: Ministry of Industry, Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Thi, Tranhang, Faculty of Technology of Organic Chemistry, Ministry of Industry, Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Applied Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Matsusaki, Michiya, Department of Applied Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Shi, Dongjian, Department of Applied Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Kaneko, Tatsuo I., Department of Applied Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, School of Materials Science, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Akashi, Mitsuru, Department of Applied Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Abstract: Poly(4-hydroxycinnamic acid) (P4HCA), poly(3-hydroxycinnamic acid) (P3HCA), poly(3-methoxy-4-hydroxycinnamic acid) (PMHCA) and poly(3,4-dihydroxycinnamic acid) (PDHCA) were synthesized by the thermal poly-condensation of the corresponding monomers, which are lignin precursors, coumaric acid derivatives consisting of cinnamoyl groups and different position and number of OH groups. The solubility of the homo-polymers in organic solvents decreased in the order of P3HCA > PDHCA > P4HCA > PMHCA. The wide angle X-ray diffraction (WAXD) results indicated that P4HCA or PMHCA with p-OH group had higher crystallinity, in contrast to P3HCA or PDHCA with m-OH group which had lower crystallinity. Crossed-polarizing microscopy suggested that P4HCA had the nematic liquid crystal properties at 220°C and PDHCA showed birefringence properties at 200°C. In cell-adhesion tests, PDHCA showed the highest cell adhesion (ca. 70%), whereas P3HCA, P4HCA and PMHCA had 50, 18 and 10% cell adhesion, respectively. The coumaric acid derivative homo-polymers can be useful as cell adhesion controllable thermotropic polymers for biomedical and environmental fields. © 2008 VSP. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: P., Tuan, Phandinh; K., Mochidzuki, Kazuhiro; N., Sato, Nobuaki; A., Sakoda, Akiyoshi
Author full names: Tuan, Phandinh (57224819676); Mochidzuki, Kazuhiro (6602538808); Sato, Nobuaki (56323088100); Sakoda, Akiyoshi (7005966283)
Title: Analysis of rice refinery system in Mekong River Delta
Affiliations: Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Institute of Industrial Science, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tuan, Phandinh, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Mochidzuki, Kazuhiro, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Sato, Nobuaki, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Sakoda, Akiyoshi, Institute of Industrial Science, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The design and analysis of the biomass utilization system based on rice cropping is presented to promote sustainable biomass utilization in South-east Asia. The use of corn to produce biofuel, i.e., ethanol, and biochemicals, i.e., lactic acid, is developed in the North America. The total utilization system for rice crops including grain, husk and straw, are proposed to meet the concept of biomass refinery. This biomass refinery system for rice-based biomass is called as "Rice Refinery." To demonstrate the regional circulation, a plan of "Biomass Town" is drawn to meet the situation in the South-East Asia. The basic concept of Biomass Town is to utilize the biomass resources obtained in the region efficiently and economically, minimizing the waste energy and materials. As a research field for Rice Refinery-oriented Biomass Town, the study focuses on South Vietnam, including Hochiminh City and Mekong River Delta, which is one of the world's largest production centers of rice. The potential of biomass resource originated from rice cropping was examined, using both the statistical data and the results obtained in a series of field studies in an existing paddy field. Based on the analyses of the material and energy balance/flow in the region, including the available quantity of biomass, its collection and transportation, biomass conversion technologies and the local market of the biomass-based products, a comprehensive evaluation of the Rice Refinery system in the Mekong River Delta area was conducted. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 2007 AIChE Annual Meeting (Salt Lake City, UT 11/4-9/2007). © 2009 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Conference name: 2007 AIChE Annual Meeting

Abstract: The biomass utilization system based on rice cropping was studied to promote sustainable biomass utilization in South-east Asia. The total utilization system for rice crops including grain, husk and straw, to meet the concept of biomass refinery is proposed. This biomass refinery system for rice-based biomass is called as "Rice Refinery". To demonstrate the regional circulation, a "Biomass Town" is considered to meet the situation in the South-East Asia. The basic concept of Biomass Town is to utilize the biomass resources obtained in the region efficiently and economically, minimizing the waste energy and materials. The potential of biomass resource originated from rice cropping was examined, using both the statistical data and the results obtained in a series of field studies in an existing paddy field. Based on the analyses of the material and energy balance/flow in the region, including the available quantity of biomass, its collection and transportation, biomass conversion technologies and the local market of the biomass-based products, a comprehensive evaluation of the Rice Refinery system in the Mekong River Delta area is carried out. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the AIChE Annual Meeting (Salt Lake City, UT 11/4-9/2007). © 2009 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.H., Pham, Tho Hoan; D.H., Tran, Dang Hung; T., Ho, Tubao; K., Satou, Kenji
Author full names: Pham, Tho Hoan (57198492399); Tran, Dang Hung (14523528500); Ho, Tubao (24472876700); Satou, Kenji (7004982766)
Title: Prediction of histone modifications in DNA sequences
Affiliations: Trường Đại học Sư phạm Hà Nội, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Pham, Tho Hoan, Trường Đại học Sư phạm Hà Nội, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tran, Dang Hung, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Ho, Tubao, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Satou, Kenji, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan
Abstract: DNA molecules are wrapped around histone octamers to form nucleosome structures whose occupancy and histone modification states profoundly influence the gene expression. Depending on the DNA segment that a nuleosome incorporated, its histone proteins exihibit paticular modifications by added some functional chemical groups to specific amino acids. The key approach up to now to determining the DNA locations of histone occupancy as well as histone modifications is an experimental technique called ChiP-Chip, or Chromatin Immunoprecipitation on Microarray Chip. This experimental technique has some disadvantages such as it is tedious, wastes time and money, produces noise, and cannot provide results at an arbitrarily high resolution, especially with large genomes like human's. We have developed a computational method to determine qualitatively histone-occupied as well as acetylation and methylation locations in DNA sequences. The method is based on support vector machines (SVMs) to learn models from training data sets that discriminate between areas with high and low levels of histone occupancy, acetylation or methylation. Our computational method can give quickly the prediction at any position in a DNA sequence based on the content and context of the subsequence around that position. The prediction results on the yeast genome by three-fold cross-validation showed high accuracy and were consistent with the ones from experimental methods. Moreover, SVM-classification models in our method can present genetic preferences of DNA areas that have high modification levels. ©2007 IEEE. © 2009 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: V.D., Nguyen, Viet D.; R.R., Tan, Raymond R.; Y., Brondial, Yolanda; T., Fuchino, Tetsuo
Author full names: Nguyen, Viet D. (57199220002); Tan, Raymond R. (56962727300); Brondial, Yolanda (16243937900); Fuchino, Tetsuo (6701737703)
Title: Prediction of vapor-liquid equilibrium data for ternary systems using artificial neural networks
Affiliations: Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; De La Salle University, Manila, Philippines; Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Viet D., Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, De La Salle University, Manila, Philippines; Tan, Raymond R., De La Salle University, Manila, Philippines; Brondial, Yolanda, De La Salle University, Manila, Philippines; Fuchino, Tetsuo, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Most solvents used in the semiconductor industry are toxic and costly. Thus, the solvents should be recovered for re-use in these processes by distillation methods, and vapor-liquid equilibrium data are necessary for the design and operation of distillation columns. These data can be estimated using activity coefficient models. In this work, artificial neural networks were applied to predict and estimate vapor-liquid equilibrium data for ternary systems saturated with salt. The databases taken from literature were split into training, validating and testing data and the best architecture was an 8-6-7-4 network. The absolute mean errors for the whole database were 0.0166, 0.0177, 0.0151 for the vapor mole fraction of components (y<inf>1</inf>, y<inf>2</inf>, y<inf>3</inf>) and 0.74 °C for the bubble point temperature. The artificial neural network predictions showed better agreement with experimental data than the thermodynamic model predictions. © 2007 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: K., Mochidzuki, Kazuhiro; N., Sato, Nobuaki; A., Sakoda, Akiyoshi; P., Tuan, Phandinh
Author full names: Mochidzuki, Kazuhiro (6602538808); Sato, Nobuaki (56323088100); Sakoda, Akiyoshi (7005966283); Tuan, Phandinh (57224819676)
Title: Development of local biomass-based fuel systems in Mekong Delta area
Affiliations: The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Institute of Industrial Science, Tokyo, Japan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Mochidzuki, Kazuhiro, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Sato, Nobuaki, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Sakoda, Akiyoshi, Institute of Industrial Science, Tokyo, Japan; Tuan, Phandinh, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: The biomass-orientated regional material and energy circulations were developed to nurture the growth of the sustainable society. To demonstrate the regional circulation, a plan of "Biomass Town" were drawn to meet the situation in the South-East Asia. The basic concept of Biomass Town is to utilize the biomass resources obtained in the region efficiently and economically, minimizing the waste energy and materials. It is important to understand and respect the individuality of the region for successful energy and material circulations. The Mekong Delta area, Vietnam, was the focus as one of the promising region for Biomass Town. The concept and system design for the biomass refinery based on the rice cropping, development of ethanol production process from rice straw/husk, and total design of Biomass Town in Mekong area, based on the analyses of the material and energy flow in the region were presented. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the AIChE Annual Meeting (San Francisco, CA 11/12-17/2008). © 2009 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Conference name: 2006 AIChE Annual Meeting

Authors: Q.T., Le, Quy Thu; H., Takenouti, Hisasi; S., Touzain, Sébastien
Author full names: Le, Quy Thu (57218214000); Takenouti, Hisasi (7005813229); Touzain, Sébastien (6603312299)
Title: EIS characterization of thick flawed organic coatings aged under cathodic protection in seawater
Affiliations: Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Sorbonne Université, Paris, France; La Rochelle Université, La Rochelle, France
Authors with affiliations: Le, Quy Thu, Institute for Tropical Technology, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Takenouti, Hisasi, UPR 15, Sorbonne Université, Paris, France; Touzain, Sébastien, Laboratoire d'Etudes des Matériaux en Milieux Agressifs, La Rochelle Université, La Rochelle, France,
Abstract: Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was used to monitor, up to 20 months, the degradation kinetics of four thick organic coatings under cathodic protection in seawater. EIS experiments were realized onto a flawless zone, which surrounds an artificial hole of the coating using the Luo's cell or a removable cell. EIS spectra were analyzed first with classic equivalent circuits and then with an approach involving the dipolar relaxation of polymer layer. These two models were unable to explain the experimental data, especially for a long immersion experiments. Taking into account the presence of vacuoles, namely pre-existing air pockets that will be then filled by electrolyte, modified equivalent circuits were used and a good representation of experimental data was obtained. The parameters extracted allowed the coating degradation to be followed. It was found that a solvent-free coating exhibited the best compatibility with cathodic protection. © 2005 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. © 2013 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.T.N., Lan, Tran Thi Ngoc; T.P.T., Nguyen, Thi Phuong Thoa; R., Nishimura, Rokurou; Y., Tsujino, Yoshio; M., Yokoi, Masayuki; Y., Maeda, Y.
Author full names: Lan, Tran Thi Ngoc (36766007600); Nguyen, Thi Phuong Thoa (55887864700); Nishimura, Rokurou (35578887100); Tsujino, Yoshio (7004938285); Yokoi, Masayuki (36977648000); Maeda, Y. (7402845138)
Title: Atmospheric corrosion of carbon steel under field exposure in the southern part of Vietnam
Affiliations: Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Environmental Pollution Control Center, Osaka, Japan; Osaka Research Institute of Industrial Science and Technology, Izumi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Lan, Tran Thi Ngoc, Department of Physical Chemistry, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Thi Phuong Thoa, Department of Physical Chemistry, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nishimura, Rokurou, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Tsujino, Yoshio, Environmental Pollution Control Center, Osaka, Japan; Yokoi, Masayuki, Osaka Research Institute of Industrial Science and Technology, Izumi, Japan; Maeda, Y., Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: The corrosion behavior of carbon steel with and without shelter at four test sites (four cities) in the south of Vietnam was investigated in terms of the environmental factors such as average relative humidity, rainfall, sulphur dioxide and chloride depositions, and various exposure periods. The mass losses of the specimens with shelter at four test sites were related to SO<inf>2</inf> concentration at each site. Without shelter, the mass loss at HoChiMinh was lower than that with shelter, whereas those of the other sites were higher without shelter than with shelter. Although the corrosion behavior at HoChiMinh was difficult to explain based on the environmental factors, it was estimated from a protective corrosion products caused by a synergistic effect among SO<inf>2</inf> concentration, rain and sunlight. © 2005 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Suzuki, Tohru; L.H., Tran, Lien Ha; M., Yogo, Masanori; O., Idota, Osamu; N., Kitamoto, Noriyuki; K., Kawai, Keiichi; K., Takamizawa, Kazuhiro
Author full names: Suzuki, Tohru (55549701900); Tran, Lien Ha (23494014600); Yogo, Masanori (12142133700); Idota, Osamu (12141691500); Kitamoto, Noriyuki (7004247416); Kawai, Keiichi (58431934300); Takamizawa, Kazuhiro (7006212101)
Title: Cloning and expression of NAD+-dependent L-arabinitol 4-dehydrogenase gene (ladA) of Aspergillus oryzae
Affiliations: Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Aichi Industrial Technology Institute, Kariya, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Suzuki, Tohru, Life Science Research Center, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan, Faculty of Applied Biological Sciences, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Tran, Lien Ha, Institute of Biological and Food Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yogo, Masanori, Faculty of Applied Biological Sciences, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Idota, Osamu, Faculty of Applied Biological Sciences, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Kitamoto, Noriyuki, Food Research Center, Aichi Industrial Technology Institute, Kariya, Japan; Kawai, Keiichi, Faculty of Applied Biological Sciences, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Takamizawa, Kazuhiro, Faculty of Applied Biological Sciences, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan
Abstract: A gene of Aspergillus oryzae, ladA, which encodes L-arabinitol 4-dehydrogenase (EC 1.1.1.12), and its cDNA were cloned in Escherichia coli. The gene consisted of a 1209-bp coding region, interrupted by a 59-bp intron, which encoded a 382-amino-acid polypeptide (40,812 Da). The protein showed 67 identity to a well-studied L-arabinitol 4-dehydrogenase (Lad1) of Hypocrea jecorina. The cell-free extract of E. coli, which expressed ladA cDNA, showed L-arabinitol dehydrogenase activity with NAD+. It was also reactive for ribitol and xylitol. © 2005, The Society for Biotechnology. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.; MEDLINE® is the source for the MeSH terms of this document.

Authors: T.T.N., Lan, Tran Thi Ngoc; R., Nishimura, Rokurou; Y., Tsujino, Yoshio; Y., Satoh, Yukihiro; T.P.T., Nguyen, Thi Phuong Thoa; M., Yokoi, Masayuki; Y., Maeda, Yasuaki
Author full names: Lan, Tran Thi Ngoc (36766007600); Nishimura, Rokurou (35578887100); Tsujino, Yoshio (7004938285); Satoh, Yukihiro (15920126700); Nguyen, Thi Phuong Thoa (55887864700); Yokoi, Masayuki (36977648000); Maeda, Yasuaki (55797766600)
Title: The effects of air pollution and climatic factors on atmospheric corrosion of marble under field exposure
Affiliations: Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Osaka Prefectoral Environ. P.C.C., Osaka, Japan; Osaka Research Institute of Industrial Science and Technology, Izumi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Lan, Tran Thi Ngoc, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nishimura, Rokurou, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Tsujino, Yoshio, Osaka Prefectoral Environ. P.C.C., Osaka, Japan; Satoh, Yukihiro, Osaka Research Institute of Industrial Science and Technology, Izumi, Japan; Nguyen, Thi Phuong Thoa, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Yokoi, Masayuki, Osaka Research Institute of Industrial Science and Technology, Izumi, Japan; Maeda, Yasuaki, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: The atmospheric corrosion of marble was evaluated in terms of SO <inf>2</inf> concentration as air pollution and climatic factors such as rainfall, relative humidity, temperature and so on under the field exposure. Marble of calcite type (CaCO<inf>3</inf>) was exposed to outdoor atmospheric environment with and without a rain shelter at four test sites in the southern part of Vietnam for 3-month, 1- and 2-year periods from July 2001 to September 2003. The thickness loss of marble was investigated gravimetrically. X-ray diffraction and X-ray fluorescent methods were applied to study corrosion products on marble. The corrosion product of marble was only gypsum (CaSO <inf>4</inf>·2H<inf>2</inf>O) and was washed out by rain under the unsheltered exposure condition. It was found that the most substantial factors influencing the corrosion of marble were rainfall, SO<inf>2</inf> concentration in the air and relative humidity. Based on the results obtained, we estimated the dose-response functions for the atmospheric corrosion of marble in the southern part of Vietnam. © 2004 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: L., Luan, Lequang; V.T.T., Ha, Vo Thi Thu; N., Nagasawa, Naotsugu; T., Kume, Tamikazu; F., Yoshii, Fumio; T.M., Nakanishi, Tomoko M.
Author full names: Luan, Lequang (7004715908); Ha, Vo Thi Thu (36803760700); Nagasawa, Naotsugu (7007143686); Kume, Tamikazu (7101665690); Yoshii, Fumio (35447464900); Nakanishi, Tomoko M. (7402644246)
Title: Biological effect of irradiated chitosan on plants in vitro
Affiliations: Graduate School of Agricultural and Life Sciences The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kashiwa, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Luan, Lequang, Graduate School of Agricultural and Life Sciences, Graduate School of Agricultural and Life Sciences The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Ha, Vo Thi Thu, Dalat Nuclear Research Institute, Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nagasawa, Naotsugu, Department of Materials Development, Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kashiwa, Japan; Kume, Tamikazu, Department of Materials Development, Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kashiwa, Japan; Yoshii, Fumio, Department of Materials Development, Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kashiwa, Japan; Nakanishi, Tomoko M., Graduate School of Agricultural and Life Sciences, Graduate School of Agricultural and Life Sciences The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: For degradation of chitosan, chitosan with an 80% degree of deacetylation and a weight-average molecular mass (M̄<inf>w</inf>) of approx. 48 kDa was irradiated with γ-rays at doses up to 200 kGy in a 10% (w/v) solution. The M̄<inf>w</inf> of chitosan was reduced from 48 to 9.1 kDa by irradiation. The characteristics of irradiated chitosan were analysed by using Fourier-transform IR spectroscopy and an elemental analyser. The amino group was found to be stable, whereas the C-O-C group decreased with increase in the dose. The product of chitosan irradiated at 100 kGy with an M̄<inf>w</inf> of approx. 16 kDa showed the strongest growth promotion effect on plants in vitro. For shoot culture, supplementation with irradiated chitosan increased the fresh biomass of shoot clusters (7.2-17.0%) as well as the shoot multiplication rate (17.9-69.0%) for Chrysanthemum morifolium (florist's chrysanthemum), Limonium latifolium (limonium or sea-lavender), Eustoma grandiflorum (lisianthus, tulip gentian or Texas bluebell) and Fragaria ananassa (modern garden strawberry). The optimum concentrations of irradiated chitosan were found to be approx. 70-100 mg/l for chrysanthemum, 50-100 mg/l for lisianthus and 30-100 mg/l for limonium. For the plantlet culture, the optimum concentrations were found to be approx. 100 mg/l for chrysanthemum, 30 mg/l for lisianthus, 40 mg/l for limonium and 50 mg/l for strawberry. Supplementation with optimum concentrations of irradiated chitosan resulted in a significant increase in the fresh biomass (68.1 % for chrysanthemum, 48.5% for lisianthus, 53.6% for limonium and 26.4% for strawberry), shoot height (19.4 % for chrysanthemum, 16.5 % for lisianthus, 33.9 % for limonium and 25.9% for strawberry) and root length (40.6 % for chrysanthemum, 66.9 % for lisianthus, 23.4% for limonium and 22.6% for strawberry). In addition, treatment with irradiated chitosan enhanced the activity of chitosanase in treated plants and also improved the survival ratio and growth of the transferred plantlets acclimatized for 10-30 days under greenhouse conditions. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.; MEDLINE® is the source for the MeSH terms of this document.

Authors: L.H., Tran, Lien Ha; M., Yogo, Masanori; H., Ojima, Hiroshi; O., Idota, Osamu; K., Kawai, Keiichi; T., Suzuki, Tohru; K., Takamizawa, Kazuhiro
Author full names: Tran, Lien Ha (23494014600); Yogo, Masanori (12142133700); Ojima, Hiroshi (25636293800); Idota, Osamu (12141691500); Kawai, Keiichi (58431934300); Suzuki, Tohru (55549701900); Takamizawa, Kazuhiro (7006212101)
Title: The production of xylitol by enzymatic hydrolysis of agricultural wastes
Affiliations: United Graduate School of Agricultural Science, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Tran, Lien Ha, United Graduate School of Agricultural Science, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan, Institute of Biological and Food Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yogo, Masanori, United Graduate School of Agricultural Science, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Ojima, Hiroshi, United Graduate School of Agricultural Science, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Idota, Osamu, United Graduate School of Agricultural Science, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Kawai, Keiichi, Faculty of Applied Biological Sciences, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Suzuki, Tohru, Life Science Research Center, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Takamizawa, Kazuhiro, Faculty of Applied Biological Sciences, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan
Abstract: Agricultural waste products, beech wood and walnut shells, were hydrolyzed at 40°C using mixed crude enzymes produced by Penicillium sp. AHT-1 and Rhizomucor pusillus HHT-1. D-xylose, 4.1 g and 15.1 g was produced from the hydrolysis of 100 g of beech wood and walnut shells, respectively. For xylitol production, Candida tropicalis IFO0618 and the waste product hydrolyzed solutions were used. The effects on xylitol production, of adding glucose as a NADPH source, D-xylose and yeast extract, were examined. Finally, a 50% yield of xylitol was obtained by using the beech wood hydrolyzed solution with the addition of 1% yeast extract and 1% glucose at an initial concentration. ©KSBB. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Cloning and expression of a NAD+-dependent xylitol dehydrogenase gene (xdhA) of Aspergillus oryzae
Affiliations: Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Aichi Industrial Technology Institute, Kariya, Japan; Faculty of Applied Biological Sciences, Gifu, Japan; Gifu University, Gifu, Japan

Abstract: XdhA, which encodes a xylitol dehydrogenase gene, was cloned from Aspergillus oryzae genomic DNA. It consists of 1214 bp structural region, which is interrupted by two introns, and encodes 358-amino-acid protein (38,197 Da). It is similar to the known NAD+-dependent xylitol deliydrogenase (EC 1.1.1.9). The gene was expressed in Escherichia coli BL21-AI using a T7 promoter. The cell-free extract of the transformant showed a 36.5 kDa band upon SDS-PAGE and NAD+-depeadent xylitol dehydrogenase activity. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: L., Luan, Lequang; N.Q., Hien, Nguyen Quoc; N., Nagasawa, Naotsugu; T., Kume, Tamikazu; F., Yoshii, Fumio; T.M., Nakanishi, Tomoko M.
Author full names: Luan, Lequang (7004715908); Hien, Nguyen Quoc (8619670600); Nagasawa, Naotsugu (7007143686); Kume, Tamikazu (7101665690); Yoshii, Fumio (35447464900); Nakanishi, Tomoko M. (7402644246)
Title: Biological effect of radiation-degraded alginate on flower plants in tissue culture
Affiliations: Graduate School of Agricultural and Life Sciences The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Takasaki Advanced Radiation Research Institute, Takasaki, Japan; Takasaki Advanced Radiation Research Institute, Takasaki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Luan, Lequang, Graduate School of Agricultural and Life Sciences The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Hien, Nguyen Quoc, Dalat Nuclear Research Institute, Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nagasawa, Naotsugu, Takasaki Advanced Radiation Research Institute, Takasaki, Japan; Kume, Tamikazu, Takasaki Advanced Radiation Research Institute, Takasaki, Japan; Yoshii, Fumio, Takasaki Advanced Radiation Research Institute, Takasaki, Japan, Department of Material Development, Takasaki Advanced Radiation Research Institute, Takasaki, Japan; Nakanishi, Tomoko M., Graduate School of Agricultural and Life Sciences The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Alginate with a weight-average molecular mass (M<inf>w</inf>) of approx. 9.04 x 105 Da was irradiated at 10-200 kGy in 4% (w/v) aqueous solution. The degraded alginate product was used to study its effectiveness as a growth promoter for plants in tissue culture. Alginate irradiated at 75 kGy with an M<inf>w</inf> of approx. 1.43 x 104 Da had the highest positive effect in the growth of flower plants, namely limonium, lisianthus and chrysanthemum. Treatment of plants with irradiated alginate at concentrations of 30-200 mg/l increased the shoot multiplication rate from 17.5 to 40.5% compared with control. In plantlet culture, 100 mg/l irradiated alginate supplementation enhanced shoot height (9.7-23.2%), root length (9.7-39.4%) and fresh biomass (8.1-19.4%) of chrysanthemum, lisianthus and limonium compared with that of the untreated control. The survival ratios of the transferred flower plantlets treated with irradiated alginate were almost the same as the control value under greenhouse conditions. However, better growth was attained for the treated plantlets. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.; MEDLINE® is the source for the MeSH terms of this document.

Authors: K., Masuda-Jindo, Kinichi; V., van Hung, Vu; P., Tam, Phamdinh
Author full names: Masuda-Jindo, Kinichi (35584942900); van Hung, Vu (6603224521); Tam, Phamdinh (59784721900)
Title: Application of statistical moment method to thermodynamic quantities of metals and alloys
Source title: Calphad: Computer Coupling of Phase Diagrams and Thermochemistry
Affiliations: Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Hanoi University of Education, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Masuda-Jindo, Kinichi, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; van Hung, Vu, Hanoi University of Education, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tam, Phamdinh, Hanoi University of Education, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: The thermodynamic quantities of metals and alloys are studied using the moment method in the quantum statistical mechanics, going beyond the harmonic approximation, and fully taking into account the anharmonicity of lattice vibrations. Including the power moments of the atomic displacements up to the fourth order, the free energy, specific heats C<inf>v</inf> and C<inf>p</inf> mean square relative displacements and thermal lattice expansion coefficients are given explicitly in terms of the second and fourth order vibrational coupling constants. The effects of anharmonicity of lattice vibration on the long range order (LRO) parameter and order-disorder transitions of the binary alloys are investigated in detail. The changes in the root mean square atomic displacements upon the order-disorder phase transition are evaluated and compared with the available experimental results. We also discuss the melting transitions of metals and alloys within the framework of the present statistical moment method, and estimate the melting temperatures through the limiting temperature of the crystalline stability. © 2002 Published by Elsevier Science Ltd. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Characterization of petroleum-degrading bacteria from oil-contaminated sites in Vietnam
Affiliations: Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Biotechnology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Huy, Nguyen Quang, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Biotechnology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Material and Life Science, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Jin, Sha, Department of Material and Life Science, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Amada, Kei, Department of Material and Life Science, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Haruki, Mitsuru, Department of Material and Life Science, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Huu, Nguyen Ba, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Biotechnology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hang, Dinhthuy, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Biotechnology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ha, Dang Thi Cam, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Biotechnology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Imanaka, Tadayuki, Dept. Synth. Chem. and Biol. Chem., Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Morikawa, Masaaki, Department of Material and Life Science, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Kanaya, Shigenori, Department of Material and Life Science, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Abstract: Four petroleum-degrading bacterial strains, 2TN-NB, 6TBX-CL, MVK2-5, and XCK, were isolated from various oil-contaminated sites in Vietnam. Determination of the nucleotide sequence of the gene encoding 16S rRNA allowed 2TN-NB to be identified as Acinetobacter sp. and the other three stains as Pseudomonas sp. Among the four isolates, 2TN-NB was most effective in degrading crude oil: in 1 d, it degraded 95% of the crude oil in the culture medium (5%, v/v). The isolated strains could also degrade a sulfur- containing aromatic hydrocarbon, dibenzothiophene (DBT), with low efficiency. Except for MVK2-5, which degraded crude oil least efficiently, the isolates produced biosurfactants in amounts sufficient for structural analysis. FT-IR measurement suggested that strains 6TBX-CL and XCK produced glycolipid-type biosurfactants while that produced by 2TN-NB was of the polysaccharide type. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Abstract: Ethylene, produced by steam cracking of hydrocarbons, contains acetylene, which is hydrogenated to purify the ethylene for polymerization. The process is low temperature, < 80°C, and catalysts are typically peripherally deposited 0.03% Pd/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>. Industrial experience, as well as experimentation at WPI, is that ethane yields are 100 to 150% of the acetylene in the feed at about 70% conversion. The reason for the problem is that catalyst pellet temperatures are far higher than gas stream temperatures, in order to transfer heat generated by reaction through the boundary layer to the gas stream. © 1992. © 2015 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
